column2: The opera "Attila" is based on a German romantic play about Attila the Hun's attacks on Western civilization. The premise may not be everyone's idea of a fun night out, but just trust us on this one. Tonight, Riccardo Muti, the former music director and conductor of the Teatro alla Scala in Milan, will make his long-awaited debut at the Metropolitan Opera, conducting the Verdi work. "I find 'Attila' a very mysterious but exquisitely defined score," Mr. Muti said in a recent interview. "In the prologue, as the Roman general Ezio plots with Attila to divide up the empire between them, Ezio sings, 'Avrai tu l'universo, resti l'Italia a me!' 'You can have the universe, leave Italy for me!' One can just imagine the effect that line must have had in 1846, delivered by the baritone over his full octave-and-a-half range. The first performance stopped dead and the audience went absolutely crazy." This will be the company's first production of the early opera, directed by Pierre Audi, and it's worth going just to see the sets and costumes, designed by Herzog & de Meuron and Miuccia Prada.

The National Counterterrorism Center is struggling with staffing flaws and internal cultural clashes, a study says.
Mr. Obama’s proposal, which would provide coverage to more than 30 million uninsured people, is a firm basis for both the Senate and House to move forward with comprehensive reform.

The office of lieutenant governor of New York is relatively powerless, but it has importance from a succession standpoint.

KRUMHOLZ--Mera, on February 21 in New York City. Beloved wife of the late Jack; mother of Allan and Walter; mother-in-law of Francine; grandmother of Matthew and wife Ana, and Andrea and husband Ilan; great-grandmother of Jacob, Clara, Natalie, Judah and Phoebe. Services on Tuesday, February 23, 12:30pm at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Forest Hills. Donations in her memory may be made to Friends of Akim USA.

NEWMARK--June, died February 21 after a valiant 13-year battle against ovarian cancer. A New York City girl her whole life, she was born February 14, 1932, and was a graduate of The Dalton School, Sarah Lawrence College, and Teachers College, Columbia University, where she obtained her Master's degree. June was passionate about many things. She was a champion tennis player, an accomplished artist with a painting hanging in the John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum in Boston, and an avid piano player with an encyclopedic knowledge of musicals and show tunes. In recent years, June turned to philanthropy, making major gifts to NYU Medical Center, where she served on the Board of the NYU Cancer Institute, and Weill Cornell Medical College, where she served on the Dean's Council Executive Committee. June was predeceased by her parents, Saul and Ella Newmark, for whom she named her charitable foundation. She is survived by her brother Allan Newmark and his wife Betty, her niece Amy Newmark and her husband Bill Rouhana, along with Amy's children Michael and Ella Damiano, her nephew Andrew Newmark and his wife Catherine, along with their children Peter and Carolyn, and her niece Abby Newmark. She is also survived by her cousin Stanley Sandberg. Donations may be made to NYU Cancer Institute c/o Ella and Saul Newmark Cancer Research Fund, 212-404-3652, or to Weill Cornell Medical College c/o Ella and Saul Newmark Scholarship, 646-962-8216. Funeral services: Wednesday, February 24, at 11:30am, at Frank E. Campbell Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

COPEN--Ilona. The board, staff and volunteers of the New York International Ballet Competition mourn the death of our inspirational founding Executive Director, Ilona Copen. Over the past 25 years, Ms. Copen profoundly changed the lives of young ballet dancers from all over the world. Her guiding principle was to develop each dancer's potential through education and coaching. Ms. Copen's approach to the advancement of dance as an art form combined with her generous nature made her a moving force in the creation and operation of the World Dance Alliance and the International Dance Committee of the International Theater Institute-UNESCO. Always reaching out with an open heart and a helping hand she built life-long relationships in and out of the dance world. We celebrate her immense talent and capacity to galvanize people into action. Her passion, leadership, and warmth will be deeply missed.

The greatest team in Knicks history left an indelible impression, but not enough DNA to provide a blueprint for future generations. Descendants have failed to replicate its success or its spirit, although a few occasionally came close. The surviving members of the Knicks' 1970 championship team gathered Monday night at Madison Square Garden. The team's spirit was embodied by Willis Reed, its flash by Walt Frazier and its intelligence by Bill Bradley.

Officials from bobsled's international governing body removed ice from some of the corners at the controversial Whistler Sliding Centre in hopes of reducing speeds and preventing crashes. The F.I.B.T. made the decision after meeting with coaches and representatives from several countries. Four-man bobsleds from Croatia and Latvia crashed during Monday's supplementary training. After the accidents, the F.I.B.T. prematurely ended the session.
MUFSON--Joanna. 8/16/69-2/23/83 "Might I but live to see thee in my touch, I'd say I had eyes again." Mom

NEWMARK--June. The Board of Trustees, faculty, and staff of NYU Langone Medical Center mourn the passing of June Newmark, esteemed member of the Board of Directors of the NYU Cancer Institute. Ms. Newmark was a generous supporter of NYU Medical Center, founding the Ella and Saul Newmark Cancer Research Fund for the study of women's cancers in1998 in honor of her parents. An accomplished artist and wise investor, Ms. Newmark graciously supported various institutions in New York City focusing on art, education, and medicine. As an artist, she specialized in creating collages and paintings. Her work has been exhibited at the Cornell Medical Library and a collage she once sent to President John F. Kennedy was later displayed in the Kennedy Library. Her remarkable giving and support have enabled us to make important strides in the diagnosis and treatment of cancer in women and her presence will be missed profoundly. To her wide circle of loving friends and family, we extend our deepest condolences. Martin Lipton, Esq. Chairman, Board of Trustees New York University Kenneth G. Langone Chairman, Board of Trustees NYU Langone Medical Center Robert I. Grossman, MD Dean and CEO NYU Langone Medical Center William Carroll, MD Director, NYU Cancer Institute

SHAPIRO--Raymond, M.D.,age 94, died peacefully at home on February 19, 2010 surrounded by loved ones. Ray moved to Santa Rosa, CA to be closer to his family in 1996 from Hewlett Harbor, NY. He was preceded in death by his wife, Beryl Petchesky Shapiro, son Donald and brother Edward. He is survived by his son Peter Shapiro, MD and wife Patricia of Santa Rosa; grandson Scott and fiancee Lisa Figlietti, granddaughter Allyson Shapiro, and nieces and nephews Elizabeth, Skipper and Michael. A graduate of NYU Medical School (1938) and NYU Dental School (1940), he interned at King's County Hospital (1940-1942). Ray served in the US Army during WWII landing in Normandy in 1944 with the 34th evacuation hospital (3rd army) and treated battlefield injuries across Europe and rose to the rank of Lt. Colonel. He completed his Plastic and Maxillofacial residency in 1948 and practiced for 40 years in Hempstead, NY with his brother Edward. Among his many achievements Ray was chief of plastic surgery at Long Island Jewish Hospital, governor of the American College of Surgeons (1963-1969) and chairman of the credentials committee. He held academic appointments as professor of surgery at SUNY Downstate Medical Center, Stonybrook University and Mt. Sinai University. Ray was mentor to hundreds of young surgeons and oversaw the treatment of many cleft palate patients during his tenure as Chief of Plastic Surgery. Ray enjoyed fishing, gardening and in his later years, became an avid writer. He published numerous short essays honoring his WWII experiences as well as his autobiography. Ray was a kind, generous and loving man who will be missed by all who knew him, especially his family and companion Ruth Hucklebridge. Funeral Services will be held on Friday, February 26, 2010 at 10am Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, Hewlett, NY. Interment, Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. A Celebration of Life in Santa Rosa will be held this spring. The family would like to extend their thanks to his devoted caregivers as well as his physician, Gary Johanson. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Raymond N. Shapiro Endowment of Autobiographic Writing through the SRJC Foundation, 1501 Mendocino Ave., Santa Rosa, CA 95401. Daniels Chapel of the Roses (707) 525-3730.

ABLON--Margery, passed away February 19, 2010. A loving wife, devoted mother of three, proud grandmother, and creative artist. Her signature red curls will forever be a reminder to us of her love for life and her ability to instill joy in others. She will live on in our memories through the valuable lessons she has taught us and her many artworks which serve as a spiritual extension of herself. In lieu of flowers or gifts, we kindly ask those who knew her to donate to the NYU Melanoma Research Dept.
DRABKIN--Steven Wayne. Oct 19, 1961- Feb 23, 1981. His memory is enshrined in our hearts forever.

SAUERHOFF--Irving, beloved husband of Harriet for 66 years. Devoted father of Mitchell (Ronna), Jeffrey (Naomi) and Claire. Loving grandfather of Gabriel, Alex and Zach and great-grandfather of Quinn. Former president of Venus Pen & Pencil, Executive vice-president of Lanvin-Charles of the Ritz, former president of the Jericho Jewish Center. Generous, loving and known for his genuine smile.

LUBARR--Shulamith, 95, on February 21, 2010. Survivors: Naomi and Norman Patz, Gila Reinstein, Stephen Steinlight, Andrew and Mary Hilowitz. Beloved mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, master teacher. Zikhronah lv'rakhah.

They had to wait four years, but the United States women's hockey team finally avenged a semifinal defeat against Sweden at the 2006 Turin Games by trouncing the Swedes, 9-1, in a semifinal Monday at Canada Hockey Place. The victorious Americans were thinking only of their next game, which will come Thursday when they play for the gold medal against Canada, a 5-0 winner against Finland in Monday's other semifinal.
NEWMARK--June. Our 54 year friendship was not long enough. You will be in my heart forever. Love, Edie

He moved to Manhattan as an infant and spent most of his life on the Upper East Side until moving to The Carlisle Palm Beach in 2001. Longtime friends, Douglas and Annick Werner

TUCKER--Ann Marie, of Chappaqua, NY, died February 20, 2010. She will be deeply missed by her beloved husband of 41 years Brian, daughter Allison and sons Brett and B.J. Mother-in-law to Heather Tucker, Crista Tucker and grandmother of Hadley, Owen and Mena. Loving sister to John Whooley and the late Timothy Whooley. Calling hours Wednesday 2-4 and 6-9pm at Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville, NY. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday 10am, The Church of St. John and Mary (upper church), Chappaqua, NY. Burial Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center; Attn: Dr. David Spriggs, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10075.

The prime minister of Iceland said on Monday that her country was seeking the help of the United States to ensure that Britain and the Netherlands did not use a dispute over aid to depositors of its collapsed banks to hold up international loans. The announcement came as Iceland's government and opposition officials met to discuss revised terms offered by Britain and the Netherlands on a $5.4 billion ''Icesave loan.''

O'NEILL--John P. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn with deep sadness the passing of John O'Neill, the Museum's Publisher and Editor in Chief. In a career spanning 31 years at the Metropolitan Museum through his retirement in December, he oversaw the publication of more than one thousand exhibition and collection catalogues as well as the quarterly Bulletin, annual Journal, and all the gallery labels accompanying works of art in the Museum. John's extraordinary commitment to quality raised the standards for museum publishing worldwide, and his passions for art, literature, and above all opera were inspirations to those around him. He was respected and loved by his Museum colleagues and will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest condolences to his entire family. Visiting hours will take place Thursday, February 25, 4-7pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, and a memorial service will be held on a date to be announced. James R. Houghton, Chairman Thomas P. Campbell, Director Emily K. Rafferty, President

While they often seem flawless to most viewers, the top competitors in the women's figure skating have all received deductions for underrotating their jumps and most have been penalized at some point for entering a lutz or flip jump on the wrong edge. These errors are often difficult to discern, even to the most avid fans, so the technical panel of judges can use video replay to determine if these violations have occurred. The deductions can be costly: For underrotation, it is at least two-thirds of the value of the jump attempted, or starting at 4.1 points on a triple lutz. For a wrongedge takeoff, it can be as much as 3 points. The women's event begins Tuesday with the short program in which the skaters will have 2 minutes 50 seconds to perform eight required elements. Below, a look at some of the top skaters.

KINGSBERY--Walton Waits, Jr.,81, a retired Senior Executive of Price Waterhouse, New York City, NY, died in Spring Lake, NJ at home. He and Helen Elizabeth Clayton were married in 1953 in Spring Lake, the sea side town to which they retired in 1987. He was a US Army Veteran during the Korean War from 1950-1953. He is survived by his wife, Betty, three sons and daughters-in law: Walton III and Tara, James C. and Mary Louise, Peter C. and Christine and thirteen grandchildren. A funeral service will be held on today 9:30am at St. Catharine's RC Church, Spring Lake under the direction of O'Brien Funeral Home, Wall, NJ. Committal will be at St. Catharine's Cemetery in Sea Girt. A family spokesman has requested that in lieu of flowers, contributions be made to the Spring Lake First Aid Squad in Spring Lake 07762. For further information or to send condolences please visit: obrienfuneralhome.com

8 P.M. (NBC) 2010 WINTER OLYMPIC GAMES Female figure skaters, including South Korea's Kim Yu-na, the reigning world champion and gold-medal favorite, take to the ice in the short program. The Canadian skater Joannie Rochette, the silver medalist in the 2009 world championships, is also expected to compete, two days after the death of her mother. Other prime-time coverage includes women's bobsled and women's ski cross. The day's events include men's curling, at 6 a.m. on Universal; men's hockey and women's curling, at noon on USA; men's 10,000-meter speed-skating gold-medal final and women's biathlon, at 3 p.m. on NBC; men's hockey and men's curling, at 5 on CNBC; women's curling, at 10 on MSNBC; women's figure skating and award ceremonies, at 12:35 a.m. on NBC; and women's curling (same-day tape) at 3 on MSNBC. 8 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL The top 12 female semifinalists perform and viewer voting begins.

It is a sad story. But what can I do? I can't kill myself because of this, so I have to learn to live with it. FABIENNE JEAN, 31, a Haitian dancer and earthquake survivor whose crushed and infected leg had to be amputated below the knee. [A1]

The head of a militant Sunni group accused by the Iranian government of a string of terrorist attacks has been captured in eastern Iran, according to a report on Tuesday by the official Islamic Republic News Agency. The rebel leader, Abdolmalek Rigi, has been sought by Iran for years, and the government has charged that his group, Jundallah, or Soldiers of God, is allied with Al Qaeda.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has never been shy about talking about how his staggering wealth, now estimated at somewhere in excess of $15 billion, has enabled him to lead a fortunate life. He swells with evident pride at how his charitable contributions, topping more than $200 million a year, have helped to boost the arts in New York, and finance antismoking and traffic safety endeavors in poor countries.

MISERANDINO--Catherine, of Dominican Village Amityville, formerly of Valley Stream on February 20, 2010. Active volunteer in Our Lady of Lourdes R.C. Church Malverine and the Amityville School District. Beloved wife of the late Dominick. Devoted mother of Anthony Miserandino Ph.D. and his wife Barbara Gentile, Gerald Miserandino and his wife Karen, Donald Miserandino and his wife Janet, Cathryn Miserandino Ph.D. and her husband Norman Sengelow and Marianne Miserandino Ph.D. and her husband Dimitrious Dimantaras. Family will receive friends today 2-4 and 7-9pm at the Moore Funeral Home, 54 West Jamaica Avenue, Valley Stream. Funeral Mass Wednesday, February 24th, 9:45am at Our Lady of Lourdes R.C. Church, Malverine. Interment Saint John's Cemetery, Middle Village. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Lupus Alliance of Long Island, 2255 Centre Avenue, Bellmore, NY 11710.

WHISTLER, British Columbia - Ski jumping could use more cowbell. But that might wake the children. As the Winter Olympics get bigger, faster, higher and slipperier, the original danger sport of ski jumping feels quaint and old-fashioned.

AXELROD--Gerald A, passed away on February 22, 2010 in Palm Beach, FL. Beloved husband of Arlene for 53 years. Loving father of Susan Lemkin of Washington, DC, Amy (Kenneth) Arlein of Florham Park, NJ, and Jill (Douglas) Robertson of Chatham, NJ, adoring grandfather of Dr. Mark (Laura) Lemkin, Dr. Daniel (Ellen) Lemkin, Michael (Lesley) Arlein Esq., Amanda (Jeremy) Isenberg, Kate and Jake Robertson. Devoted brother to Phyllis (Martin) Biener and Marvin (Zella) Axelrod. Mr. Axelrod was an Air force veteran of WWII and former head of Axelrod Fabrics. A graduate of Lowell Textile, leading designer and importer of madras and silks from India for the fashion industry. Services to be held at Gutterman Warheit Memorial Chapel Tuesday, at 1pm. A Committal service to be held at the Abraham & Sarah Mausoleum, Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ on Thursday, 11am. The family requests that donations be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County.

A strike at Total refineries in France entered a second week on Monday with no signs of abating, raising fears about possible fuel shortages in the country. Eighty percent of Total's refinery workers were on strike on Sunday, according to the union, which has called for the strike to spread beyond Total to sites operated by Exxon Mobil, Petroplus, LyondellBasell and Ineos. The union said that output would be fully halted at Total's largest refinery, Gonfreville, by late Tuesday.
KOURIDES--Peter T. Your sincerity, kindness and loyalty represent my fondest remembrances. May your beautiful soul rest in eternal peace. Chris Demetriades

NEWMARK--June. The Officers and Members of Old Oaks Country Club mourn the passing of dear friend and fellow member, June Newmark. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to her entire family. Richard Fleder President
GREIF--Charles. 2/23/80 Dear Dad, 30 years. We miss you. Love, Steve and Don

CHARLES--Alfred W. Died February 20, 2010, at the age of 78. "Fred", an attorney in practice in New York for 52 years, will be long-remembered and cherished by his wife of 47 years, Judith Korey Charles, his son Frederic, sister Marilyn Bart, daughter-in-law Anne Mary, granddaughter Madison. He will be long held in the memory of his many friends within the legal profession, the men he served with in the United States Army, and by the citizens of the Upper West Side where he participated tirelessly and creatively in many aspects of community life. He served two terms as President and long-time treasurer of the North West Central Park Multi-Block Association. He also served two terms on the New York City's Community School Board District #

PORTUGAL--Sylvia B.,died February 19, 2010 in Louisville, KY. She was a native of Bronx, NY. The daughter of Rose and Nathan Goldberger. One of the three sisters, Bernice, Doris and Sylvia. She worked for the War Department during WWII and then was an administrator for the New Yorker until retirement. A long time resident of Louisville, she will be fondly remembered. She is survived by her son David. She will be buried in Wellwood Cemetery in New York City. Services by Herman Meyer & Son in Louisville, KY.

BREEN--Marion I.,died on February 2, 2010 in New York City. She was 96. Marion was born in Chicago on November 14, 1913 to Cornelius and Kathryn (Vander Starr) Breen. Marion graduated from Northwestern University with honors in 1935. Following graduation she was employed by Bell and Zoller Coal Company working her way up to Advertising Manager. She moved to New York in 1947 to be the personal secretary of CV Starr who was the founder of American Underwriters Insurance a forerunner of AIG. After Mr. Starr's death in 1968 she was an officer of The Starr Foundation and an honorary director until the time of her death. She had a tremendous love of the arts and music frequenting the Metropolitan Opera and the New York Philharmonic as a patron. Marion was a long-time and faithful member of Marble Collegiate Church. Through her generosity and kind spirit she touched the lives of many people and organizations. She was predeceased by her brother, Cornelius who died at birth, and sister, Janet and Janet's husband, Lester and their older son, The Rev. Brian Helge. She is survived by her nephew, The Rev. Mark P. Helge and his wife, Kathleen and their sons, Andrew and Joel. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, February 25 at 2pm at Marble Collegiate Church on Fifth Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Marble Collegiate Church or the Recording for the Blind and Dyslexic.

Tata Uy and a dozen members of his militia were milling around their base, a bullet-pocked mosque on a hill overlooking forests and farmland here in the southern Philippines. Mr. Uy pointed to a spot a couple of miles away where gunmen loyal to his uncle were holed up. As one of his men patrolled the area on a water buffalo, a rifle slung over his shoulder, Mr. Uy (pronounced OO-ey) explained that he and his uncle had a falling out four years ago. But skirmishes escalated to full-blown fighting last year after he made it clear that he intended to run against his uncle, a local mayor, in an election this year.

HAMMOND--Maury, 90, on February 21, 2010 of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Manhattan. He was a commercial photographer and a veteran of WWII. Survived by daughter Idelle Hammond-Sass (Dale) of Ann Arbor, MI and the love of his life Sherry Plevy Arenstein. Funeral February 24th, 11:30am at Cedar Park Cemetery in Paramus. Memorial gathering in Boca Raton this Friday.
KAYE--Robbie. 1/16/76-2/23/96. Still missed, still loved, never forgotten. Mom, Dad and Andy

HEINEMAN--William M.,of Westport, CT at age 84, died on February 21 due to brain surgery and ensuing complications. He is survived by his wife Harriet and their three children, Kay (and Bob Calabretta) Annemarie (and Neil Doherty) and Tom and by granddaughter Kalieska Doherty and by nieces and nephews and by his brother Andrew. Bill graduated from The Horace Mann School and Williams College and served in WWII in the Army Air Corps. He was a partner for 55 years in the textile brokerage firm Heineman & Co. The family will be receiving at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home at 81st St. and Madison Ave. on Thursday, February 25, 5pm - 8pm. Contributions to: Williams College for The RRR and Mary Brooks Scholarship Fund which Bill and Andy established. (Development Office, 75 Park St, Williamstown, MA 01267) or to the charity of your choice will be greatly appreciated.

CASTLEMAN--Randal L. With profound sorrow, the HM Community mourns the death of Randal L. Castleman, beloved friend, respected colleague, visionary educator and esteemed teacher of countless Horace Mann students and alumni. A dedicated and professional educator, Randal's graciousness, integrity, high educational and moral standards were inherent in every conversation, memo and daily encounter. In his years of service to Horace Mann, Randal has headed HM's Summer School, served as Head of the Upper Division in 1992, was Chair of the Upper Division English Department and held the position of Dean of Students, Grades nine thru twelve. At the time of his death Randal served as the Associate Dean of Student Life. In each position he served with great dedication, elegance and grace. He was a masterful English teacher of sublime intelligence, and his tenure as Head Librarian of the Theresa Loeb Library was an outstanding and distinguished one. He served with conviction and sound judgement on numerous committees. A small sampling includes: the Committee on Instruction (Chair), the Faculty Benefits and Compensation Committee and the Financial Aid Committee. His love and commitment to the students he advised and mentored are legendary. The Class of 2004 showed their deep appreciation for their grade dean when they dedicated their Mannikin in his honor. "To the Class of 2004 Mr. Castleman is a teacher, a dean, a parent and mentor. He is an active member of the community attending athletic matches, arts, performances, student organized dinners, and athletic events. We are honored to have been able to develop such a unique relationship with our grade dean." Randal's wit and sense of humor were keen and well honed. His ready smile and affability were all part of his wonderful persona. An accomplished athlete in his own right, Randal coached boys' and girls' varsity soccer for several years. His love of jazz, theatre, English prose and poetry, sports and his voracious appetite for reading and storing and sharing knowledge were inspirational. A dignified, reserved individual, he was, nevertheless, passionate in striving to help others. Randal was a man of strength and integrity who fought a courageous battle against the serious disease that afflicted him at the height of his career. Randal developed professional and personal relationships with HM parents and students, HM Trustees and administrators, HM Faculty and staff. HM alumni and with HM associates that span decades. At HM's 2004 commencement address to the graduating seniors, Randal said, "Think of all the things you've had a chance to do here - of the games and the concerts and the plays and the publications and the conferences...you will remember what you got to do here. Because Horace Mann is...creative and energetic people coming together to do exciting things." Dr. Thomas M. Kelly, Head of School commented, "Since his arrival at Horace Mann in January of 1978, Randal has contributed to the very essence of HM in so many purposeful ways. From our libraries to our course offerings to many of the policies and procedures that continue to govern how we teach and care for our students, his contributions and keen insight serve as a shining example of the tremendous effect one person can have on a community." Randal's love, warmth and depth of devotion to his wife, Cornelia Locher, to his children, Matthew HM 2004 and to Laura 2008 are acknowledged by all. We extend our thoughts and prayers to Cornelia, Matthew and Laura, and to Randal's beloved extended family and devoted friends. Horace Mann mourns the loss, honors the life, and celebrates the legacy of Randal L. Castleman. His remarkable presence will be remembered. The Castleman family has requested that donations in Randal Castleman's memory be made to: Horace Mann School - Financial Aid, 231 West 246th Street, Bronx, New York 10471. Thomas M. Kelly, Ph.D. Head of School Steven M. Friedman, HM 1972 Chair, Board of Trustees Justin Lerer, HM 1995 President, HM Alumni Council

The United States men's hockey team's 5-3 victory over Canada on Sunday night was the most watched sports program ever shown on Canadian TV. The average of 10.6 million who watched on six networks, including CTV, exceeded the 10.3 million for Canada's gold-medal-winning game over the Americans at the Salt Lake Games eight years ago. At its peak, the viewership of the game in Canada reached 13 million.

FARB--Ellen on February 21, 2010. Beloved wife of Julian. Devoted mother of Marcy Nathanson and Dr. Andrew Farb. Loving grandmother of Ariel, RaeAnn and Jacob Nathanson and Anna and Emily Farb. Cherished sister of Ruth Feigen. Funeral services were held Monday, February 22, at Gutterman's Inc., Rockville Centre, Long Island.

MULHOLLAND--Mary Kathryn. Chieftain Capital Management mourns the untimely passing of our long-time colleague. She was deeply devoted to the business and to her loving husband, Danny. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her family. John M. Shapiro Thomas D. Stern Joshua R. Slocum

The Plastiki, a boat built from recycled plastic, is expected to begin a 100-day crossing of the Pacific Ocean in March to test the seaworthiness of new materials and draw attention to ocean-borne plastic waste. The boat is now undergoing sea trials in San Francisco Bay.

Husband of Helen Sue Zeidman (Flatow), father of Mark Zeidman (Margaret), Laurel Glassman (Alan), grandfather of Jessica Zeidman, MD, Steven Glassman(Christin), Joseph Zeidman and Adam Glassman. Great-grandfather to Elizabeth Glassman. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Jewish Community Center of Harrison, 130 Union Avenue, Harrison, New York 10528. The premiere of a documentary about Bill Cunningham, a photographer for The New York Times, will open New Directors/New Films, the annual series presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art, the society and the museum announced. The documentary, called "Bill Cunningham New York," follows Mr. Cunningham on his assignments for the Styles sections of The Times and chronicles his life and work over eight decades. It is directed by Richard Press and produced by Philip Gefter, a former staff member of The Times, and will be presented on March 24 at MoMA.

Trust the folks from Project No. 8, one of the city's more thoughtfully hip boutiques, to curate an out-of-the ordinary hotel shopping experience for travelers. Elizabeth Beer and Brian Janusiak conceived No. 8a - in Manhattan's hopping Ace Hotel - as a place to find useful objects and unusual souvenirs. Forget bad books, phone chargers and tacky swimsuits. Instead, you'll find underpinnings from Falke, Schiesser and VPL, the cult skin-care line In Fiore, accessories from the likes of Maison Martin Margiela, Christian Wijnants, Bless and Natalia Brilli, and a continuing project called "Mementos," an amusing collection of New York ephemera (think Chinatown Soccer Club mugs, Statue of Liberty night lights and Krink graffiti markers) gathered by the designers Josee Lepage and Tobias Wong. There's also a mini-outpost of Kiosk, a downtown shop that regularly mounts themed "exhibitions" of objects.

Charter schools in New York City get slightly less government funding per pupil than traditional public schools when the charter school is located in a public school building, and 18 percent less per student when the charter rents private space, according to a study released Wednesday by the city's Independent Budget Office.

Three to six inches of wet snow are forecast for Thursday, 50-mile-an-hour winds are coming Friday, and the sun may not shine till Sunday, but there's always the orchid show at the New York Botanical Garden. Entitled Cuba in Flower, it opens Saturday and promises, among its thousands of brilliantly colored flowers, "an oasis of beauty, fragrance and the intrigue of the tropical island nation." The exhibit's designers, the garden's Web site says, have "recreated the charm of the city of Havana, infused with Caribbean rhythm and romance." Plus, it's indoors.

The demonstrator's fist in Slide 1, which has just dealt a surprisingly effective blow to a riot police officer in Athens, is just the first of a remarkable gallery of hands in Wednesday's show. Yes, hands; in all their expressive power. You can read the unleashed fury in the first picture. In Slide 4, a victim's clenched hand speaks of the awful desperation of death under a landslide. Hands comfort in Slide 5 and they heal in Slide 7. They are said to be playing in Slide 10, but there is an undeniably haunting quality to that hand in the center of the frame.

The theater producers Hal Luftig and Scott Sanders are aiming to mount the first Broadway revival of the musical "Evita" in the next year or two, with the Argentine actress Elena Roger in the title role, which she played to acclaim in London in 2006, an executive involved with the production said on Wednesday.
The Millburn Township Committee voted last night to increase the budget -- and the fees -- for the Downtown Millburn Development Alliance so the alliance can do more to help boost business.

Firing his latest zinger at the White House ahead of Thursday's big forum on health care policy, the House Republican leader, Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, urged President Obama to invite Representative Bart Stupak, a Michigan Democrat who authored tight restrictions on insurance coverage for abortions that were added to the House health care bill before it was adopted in November.

The Munich Philharmonic Orchestra is wooing Lorin Maazel as chief conductor, according to German news reports. Mr. Maazel, 79, who ended a term as music director of the New York Philharmonic last season, declined to comment on the reports, a spokesman said Wednesday. The Web site of the Sueddeutsche Zeitung said Munich's mayor, Christian Ude, confirmed that negotiations were under way. Mr. Maazel is well known in Munich, having led the Bavarian Radio Symphony there from 1993 to 2002. In an interview last June Mr. Maazel said he was done with permanent posts. ''After the New York Philharmonic, one doesn't take positions,'' he said.

We have had decades of fusion food. Now, at last, we have fashion fusion. For "gender bending" - a vestige of feminism and gay pride - substitute "gender blending," as designers unite drape and straight and meld a womanly softness with masculine confidence. The concept of women dressing like men to shatter the glass ceiling hung around throughout the 1980s. But that attitude has been replaced by a new aesthetic: take any elements from either sex and piece them together.

Barely discernible makeup may be the beauty trend du jour, but those mavens of maquillage Cyndi Lauper and Lady Gaga never got the memo. "I have a huge suitcase full of the stuff," said Lauper, who is composing the music for the coming Broadway adaptation of the movie "Kinky Boots." "I am just sorry I only have one face to put it all on." It's an addiction shared by her stylistic heiress. "I am a glamour girl through and through," Lady Gaga said. "See," she added, pointing to welts on her left arm, "I burned myself with a curling iron. Glamour, girl!" Little wonder, then, that M.A.C. has tapped them to be the latest mouthpieces for its VIVA Glam campaign. In addition to appearing in the company's new advertisements, they have each created a lipstick. (Lauper's is a light coral red, and Gaga's is a bubble-gum pink; $14.) All proceeds go to the M.A.C. AIDS fund. Who said glamour was only for the shallow?

Carnegie Hall's $200 million renovation is entering a new phase that will cause the displacement of most of its administrative staff. Some 175 employees will vacate the building in May and take up residence at 1633 Broadway, at 50th Street, through at least the end of 2012, said Clive Gillinson, Carnegie's executive and artistic director. Stagehands and a few other employees will remain at the hall, where performances and box office operations will be unaffected, he said. E-mail and postal addresses will stay the same, along with phone numbers. The work, which began in the summer and is expected to last four or five years, will create room for education programs and offices, as well as renovate the backstage area and other spaces. The plan will expand Carnegie's footprint into the studios in two towers once rented by artists, residents and others.

"Snow Canvas With the Leica" may not be the most exciting of book titles, but the author Stefan Kruckenhauser knew how to capture the drama and beauty of skiing in the Austrian Alps in the 1930s. He was known as the "pope of skiing," and he trained many instructors on the finer points of the sport. While you might not understand or care for all the terminology, the images he took are glorious - something right out of an Arnold Franck mountain film. "Skikamerad Toni/Winterfahrten in Garmisch-Partenkirchen" by Dr. Paul Wolf is another bland title (loose translation: My Ski Comrade Tony/Winter Sports in Garmisch-Partenkirchen) but offers gorgeous moments of the sport as well as the après-ski scene in Austrian's fanciest resorts.

Among the biggest challenges for hybrid and battery cars are the size, weight and cost of their battery packs. A new joint project involving Volvo and the Imperial College London is attempting to address all three simultaneously by supplementing the battery with ultracapacitors that can quickly store and discharge energy. That part isn't new - a number of companies are working on ultracaps for battery vehicles - but this portion of the $4.5 million research program, funded by the European Union, is unique in that its energy storage doubles as part of the car.

Agyness Deyn is the latest model trying to make the transition to acting, but she's doing it via the art gallery rather than Hollywood. In "Mean to Me," a visually sumptuous 12-minute film noir written and directed by David McDermott and Peter McGough, Deyn trades her gamine look for raven-hued finger waves and crimson lips - all the better to deliver a blow to the head of her lover (the "Law & Order" star Linus Roache), wrestle him into the bathtub, tie him up and extort a sizable check. Set in the Great Depression and named for a popular song of the era, the artist duo's first scripted film chronicles the disastrous end of an affair. McDermott and McGough began collaborating 30 years ago, and capturing the essence of a time past has always been part of their work, so recreating the 1930s proved no challenge. Period-perfect down to its wallpaper, telephone and radio, McGough's Art Deco Manhattan apartment provided the set. Deyn's costumes, by Zac Posen, might as well be of that vintage. The Shalimar perfume and pearls, around which crucial plot points turn, were courtesy of Guerlain and Mikimoto, which underwrote the project. Deyn got the gig at the suggestion of McGough's pal Louie Chaban, director of Women Management. "Peter asked for a girl who wanted to act," Chaban says. And can she? McGough proclaims: "A star is born."

I spent some time in London last week, talking to British political observers about their upcoming election, which is "scheduled" (to the extent that U.K. elections ever are) for the first week in May. " 'Clybourne Park,' " writes Ben Brantley, "concerns, to borrow from Raymond Carver, what we talk about when we talk about race." The play by Bruce Norris, which opened Sunday night at Playwrights Horizons, "focuses on the evasions, euphemisms and tongue-tied paralysis that afflict such discussions and comes to the conclusion that talk — at least among the all-American solipsists he portrays — is worse than cheap: it's valueless." Half a century separates this "spiky and damningly insightful new comedy," which is set in 1959 and 2009. Clybourne Park was the all-white Chicago neighborhood "on which a hopeful African-American Southside family set its sights in 'A Raisin in the Sun,' Lorraine Hansberry's 1959 epochal drama. The house in the play is the dream house that Hansberry built, the place her upwardly mobile Younger family was planning to inhabit. In the first act the Youngers haven't arrived yet. In the second they're long gone, and Clybourne Park has become a very different, predominantly black neighborhood. And it is now a white family that wants to move into an area that shows every promise of being thoroughly regentrified." In both parts of this production, "Mr. Norris is examining his subjects through the same merciless telescope, with a historian's distance and an ethnographer's detachment."

If you missed the show at the Allen Room, don't despair: you can listen to a world premiere by the composer David Longstreth, the band's guitarist and lead singer, tonight. His piece is one of four world premieres that will be presented by Bang on a Can All-Stars at the 2010 People's Commissioning Fund Concert at Merkin Concert Hall. As part of the program, the chamber ensemble will also perform works by the Swiss ambient-funk-pianist-composer Nik Bärtsch, the British electro-acoustic composer Oscar Bettison and the Boston composer-inventor Christine Southworth. There will also be a recent work by Michael Nyman for a film by the photographer Paul Strand and a selection from the group's live arrangement of Brian Eno's "Music for Airports."

Ligaya Mishan asks: "Is there room in this town for another pork bun?" The answer is yes if the bun is from Baohaus, which opened on the Lower East Side in December. Their specialty is gua bao, or Taiwanese hamburgers. "For $4, you get a lily-white bun — the bao — brimming with Niman Ranch pork belly, glossy with fat and topped with the classic Taiwanese condiments: peanuts pulverized to a powder and tossed with red sugar; suan cai (pickled mustard greens), and a fistful of cilantro." The buns, which have eccentric names — Chairman Bao is named after Mao Zedong, who is said to have loved red-cooked pork belly, and Uncle Jesse is packed with tofu — are the creation of Eddie Huang, the 27-year-old son of Taiwanese immigrants who is also a street-wear designer and a former lawyer. "Mr. Huang cooks everything himself and is prone to whipping up new dishes on the spot. For Chinese New Year, he devised an eight-course menu. But he says he wants to focus on his gua bao. After all, less is more."

ABLON--Jeanne (nee Barken), beloved wife, mother and grandmother, passed away peacefully in her home on February 19 with her daughters Barbara and Susan and her faithful friend of 50 years, Lula Mae Favors by her side. There was not a sweeter more loving person in this world. Jeanne devoted her life to her husband, the late Carl S. Ablon and her daughters. She is also survived by her sons-in-law, Richard I. Solomon and Craig H. Lubin, M.D.; cherished grandchildren Jordan and Caroline. Jeanne was beautiful on the outside and the inside and was kind to absolutely everyone she met. She grew up in Miami Beach, FL and graduated from the University of Miami. Shortly after WWII, she married a dashing Lt. Colonel from the U.S. Army. She and Carl were married for 52 years. An avid bridge player, Fashionista, wife, mother, grandmother and friend. She brought happiness into the lives of everyone she met. She was dearly treasured and will be greatly missed. The Solomon family will receive friends at their Manhattan residence on Thursday, February 25, 5-9pm.

President Obama called Tuesday for repealing the health insurance industry's exemption from federal antitrust laws, escalating his attack on insurers as he tries to revive the stalled effort to overhaul the nation's health care system. The White House sent to Congress a statement in support of a House bill to overturn parts of the McCarran-Ferguson Act of 1945, which granted insurance companies broad protection from federal monopoly oversight and left regulation of the industry largely to state governments.

After 25 laps around the Richmond Olympic Oval, the Dutch speedskater Sven Kramer crossed the finish line Tuesday and raised his arms in triumph, having secured -- or so he thought -- his second Olympic record and gold medal of the Vancouver Games. Within seconds, Kramer's celebration turned icy cold. When his coach, Gerard Kemkers, caught up to him during his warm-down lap, he palmed his head and delivered the bad news: Kramer was disqualified for incorrectly changing lanes with eight laps remaining in the 10,000-meter race.

After a week of playing political hard-to-get that put this country on edge and caused Kenya's stock market and currency to slide, Kenya's feuding president and prime minister finally met Tuesday. The two sat down and talked for more than an hour in President Mwai Kibaki's office in downtown Nairobi, the capital, according to Kenyan lawmakers. ''It was a good meeting,'' said Jakoyo Midiwo, a political ally of the prime minister, Raila Odinga. ''They agreed to address the issues that divide us.''

Luring the team behind No. 7, a highly regarded restaurant in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, to open a sub shop at the Ace Hotel in Manhattan took time. ''They started talking to us over a year ago,'' said Matt Suchomski, a partner. Why a sub shop? At No. 7, the chef and partner, Tyler Kord, right, has played with sandwiches on his bar menu: fried tofu sliders, General Tso's catfish sandwich. At the new black, white and marble shop, set to open March 1, the sandwiches will be assembled on sub rolls that the restaurant will bake in Brooklyn. Ceviche with fried hominy and avocado, roast kohlrabi with fresh mozzarella, braised lamb with yogurt, a ''Sunday ham'' sandwich with pineapple and garish maraschino cherries, and a turkey Cubano with pickled daikon are some of Mr. Kord's inventions. There are a few tall tables but no chairs.

President Obama says he is eager for substantive negotiations Thursday when he convenes Democrats and Republicans at Blair House for a bipartisan meeting on health care. But before the negotiations, there are the negotiations -- talks about who sits where, who gets to talk, and what the agenda will be. The White House has a broad sketch for the six-hour session, based on consultations with House and Senate leaders in both parties. An official, speaking on condition of anonymity, discussed the administration's vision for how the meeting will play out.

9:30 P.M. (BBC America) THE INBETWEENERS Hypothermia, anyone? Season 2 of this British Comedy Award-winning series from Damon Beesley and Iain Morris about the humiliations of teenage life finds Will (Simon Bird, above, second from left) cozying up to Lauren (Jayne Wisener), the newest transfer to his London school, on a boating excursion as part of a geography and sociology field trip. But a wet blanket is thrown on the outing when Simon (Joe Thomas, above, far left), Neil (Blake Harrison, above, second from right) and Jay (James Buckley, above, far right) show up looking for love as well. ''If you buy the old rumors that Disney animators sometimes slipped pornographic images into their artwork, then you can probably also readily imagine that writers of Disney teenage comedies like 'Jonas' and 'Wizards of Waverly Place' sit around after hours, knock back a few and concoct raunchy versions of their standard scripts,'' Neil Genzlinger wrote in The New York Times. ''If that were true, 'The Inbetweeners' is what they might come up with: filthy, hilarious and much truer to actual teenage life than anything they produce on company time.'' 8 P.M. (NBC) 2010 OLYMPIC WINTER GAMES Freestyle skiers take to the air in the women's aerials competition. Prime-time coverage includes bobsled and short-track speed skating. The day's events begin with men's hockey and women's curling at 6 a.m. on Universal; men's hockey quarterfinals, at 3 p.m. on NBC and at 7 on CNBC; curling tiebreakers, at 5 p.m. and 3 a.m. on MSNBC; and women's speed skating and award ceremonies, at 12:05 a.m. on NBC.

The Australian bobsled team withdrew from the four-man competition as two of its athletes continued to recover from injuries sustained during crashes in the two-man competition. Duncan Harvey, a brakeman for Christopher Spring, is recuperating from back pain caused by a training run crash at the Whistler Sliding Centre on Feb. 17. Duncan Pugh, a brakeman for Jeremy Rolleston, sustained a concussion from a crash in the opening run of the two-man competition on Saturday.

The military junta that seized power last week named a new prime minister Tuesday while continuing to delay announcing a transition to civilian rule or a date for elections. The prime minister, Mahamadou Danda, is a former minister of youth, sport and communication in a previous junta government a decade ago. Maj. Salou Djibo, the head of the junta, and other officers overthrew the country's longtime autocratic leader, Mamadou Tandja, on Thursday.

New Yorkers may not think so. Other Americans certainly don't think so. But just about everyone else in the world thinks that New York is the most American of cities. After all, as the writer Alfred Kazin observed, ''No other country in the world could have created New York.'' Granted, New York is not exactly the kind of place that wears the stars and stripes on its sleeve. But its Americanism is always there. Sometimes, in fact - as in this sidewalk plaque on lower Broadway - it's right underfoot.

"Fred", an attorney in practice in New York for 52 years, will be long-remembered and cherished by his wife of 47 years, Judith Korey Charles, his son Frederic, sister Marilyn Bart, daughter-in-law Anne Mary, granddaughter Madison. SHAPIRO--Raymond, M.D.,age 94, died peacefully at home on February 19, 2010 surrounded by loved ones. Ray moved to Santa Rosa, CA to be closer to his family in 1996 from Hewlett Harbor, NY. He was preceded in death by his wife, Beryl Petchesky Shapiro, son Donald and brother Edward. He is survived by his son Peter Shapiro, MD and wife Patricia of Santa Rosa; grandson Scott and fiancee Lisa Figlietti, granddaughter Allyson Shapiro, and nieces and nephews Elizabeth, Skipper and Michael. A graduate of NYU Medical School (1938) and NYU Dental School (1940), he interned at King's County Hospital (1940-1942). Ray served in the US Army during WWII landing in Normandy in 1944 with the 34th evacuation hospital (3rd army) and treated battlefield injuries across Europe and rose to the rank of Lt. Colonel. He completed his Plastic and Maxillofacial residency in 1948 and practiced for 40 years in Hempstead, NY with his brother Edward. Among his many achievements Ray was chief of plastic surgery at Long Island Jewish Hospital, governor of the American College of Surgeons (1963-1969) and chairman of the credentials committee. He held academic appointments as professor of surgery at SUNY Downstate Medical Center, Stonybrook University and Mt. Sinai University. Ray was mentor to hundreds of young surgeons and oversaw the treatment of many cleft palate patients during his tenure as Chief of Plastic Surgery. Ray enjoyed fishing, gardening and in his later years, became an avid writer. He published numerous short essays honoring his WWII experiences as well as his autobiography. Ray was a kind, generous and loving man who will be missed by all who knew him, especially his family and companion Ruth Hucklebridge. Funeral Services will be held on Friday, February 26, 2010 at 10am Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, Hewlett, NY. Interment, Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. A Celebration of Life in Santa Rosa will be held this spring. The family would like to extend their thanks to his devoted caregivers as well as his physician, Gary Johanson. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Raymond N. Shapiro Endowment of Autobiographic Writing through the SRJC Foundation, 1501 Mendocino Ave., Santa Rosa, CA 95401. Daniels Chapel of the Roses (707) 525-3730.

Nine months after effectively banning most fund-raising food sales in New York City schools, a city board will vote Wednesday on an amended regulation that would allow student groups to sell items like Pop-Tarts and Doritos during the school day, but not brownies, zucchini bread or anything else homemade. The new regulation is meant as a compromise between the city's concerns about childhood obesity-- which they cite as the reason for the restrictions -- and the fund-raising needs of student and parent groups, some of which are struggling amid difficult economic times, especially after losing one of their most lucrative sources of revenue.

MARJA, Afghanistan -- The black, red and green flag of Afghanistan was hoisted over the center of this onetime militant stronghold on Thursday, as Afghan officials symbolically claimed control after a major military offensive by Afghan and international troops to drive out Taliban fighters. With Afghan soldiers, tribal elders and residents of Marja looking on, the governor of Helmand Province, which includes Marja, and a leading Afghan army general promised at the ceremonial flag-raising to restore security and stability to the city, and to transform it from a bastion of the Taliban into a ''symbol of peace.''

Nine months after effectively banning most fund-raising food sales in city schools, a city panel will vote Wednesday on an amended regulation that will allow student groups to sell items like Pop-Tarts and Doritos during the school day, but not brownies, zucchini bread or anything else homemade. The new regulation is meant as a compromise between the city's concerns about childhood obesity- which they cite as the reason for the restrictions - and the fund-raising needs of student and parent groups, some of which are struggling amid difficult economic times, especially after losing one of their most lucrative sources of revenue.Under the new rules, students may sell fresh fruits and vegetables, or one of 27 specific packaged items that have been approved for sales in city vending machines, between the start of school and 6 p.m. on weekdays. The same goes for parent groups, except for an exception carved out for one no-brownies-barred Parent Teacher Association bake sale during the school day per month.

For his latest restaurant, which opened on Feb. 23 in the Mark Hotel, Jean-Georges Vongerichten has tapped the chef who has been with him almost from his first days in New York, Pierre Schutz. In the 1980s at Lafayette, Mr. Vongerichten's first high-profile restaurant in the city, Mr. Schutz worked on finely wrought dishes like a marbled carpaccio of black bass and tuna. But the Mark Restaurant by Jean-Georges will be quite a departure from Lafayette, or from what Mr. Schutz was doing at Vong until it closed in November.

CONNOR--Lisa Forrestal, 59, died February 16, in her home in Emeryville, California. She was born June 12, 1950, in Summit, New Jersey, where she attended Oak Knoll School and Kent Place School before moving to Washington, DC, where she graduated Holton Arms School. She was the daughter of John T. Connor, then President of Merck & Co., who went to Washington to serve in the Cabinet of Pres. Lyndon B. Johnson as Secretary of Commerce, and Mary O'Boyle Connor. Lisa then graduated from Smith College and Harvard Business School and enjoyed a successful career in cable television in the San Francisco Bay area where she made her home during her working days and thereafter. She suffered from bi-polar disorder and multiple sclerosis. A world traveler with her then husband, Fredric Postle, a business school classmate, to whom she was married for twenty-two years, she collected art and artifacts from Africa and Asia. Lisa was active in mental health issues and organizations in California and maintained a wide circle of friends and associates. Known for her great humanity, she kept birds, cats and a dog and managed to visit parks and Bay Area sites on a regular basis. She is survived by her mother Mary, her two brothers, John and Geoffrey, and their wives Susan and Holly, her Aunts Mary Waters and Betty Ann Waldheim, her uncle Stan Waldheim and numerous nieces, nephews and Connor, O'Boyle, Waters, Kendrick, Waldheim and English cousins. Contributions are welcome to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society.

WYNPERLE--Sara "Nan", born in Groningen, Holland, passed away Monday, February 22, at the age of one hundred and eight. She was the daughter of Lea and Gosschalk Sinaasappel, and the sister of Johan, all of whom died in Bergen Belsen. She was the widow of Charles Israel Wynperle of Amsterdam, with whom she had a loving marriage of close to half a century. Sara will be missed and is survived by her son Bernard Wynperle and Ann, her daughter Lea Michael, her grandson Lawrence Michaels and his daughter Serena, her granddaughter Leslie Tabet and her husband Christian, and their children Sarah and Max. In addition, Lea's late husband Sidney Michael was a most devoted and loving son-in-law. In her later years, Sara had the wonderful care and love of her devoted friend, Maggie Lopez. In addition, the family wishes to extend its thanks to Dr. Michael Jacobson for his excellent care and devotion. Sara Wynperle faced life with tenacity, courage, and humor, and greatly impacted the lives of those around her. She will be greatly missed and always remembered.

First, the hair. The curls that stick out from under his ski helmet and fall to his shoulders are natural. So is the color, tinged with gold. Sun and salt, he said. He uses conditioner once a week. Women like it. Second, the place. It is San Marino, a dot of a republic with about 30,000 people on a rocky mountain surrounded by Italy, not far from the Adriatic Sea. There is no skiing there. Its formal name is Most Serene Republic of San Marino, which makes it sound like a place where Borat might live.

FILIZ--Dr. Gencer, beloved husband of Tamara, father of Kamer Ninyo and Alain Filiz, grandfather of Jak (Liz) Ninyo, great-grandfather of Adam and Jared Ninyo, and uncle. Master Cardiologist of the American Academy of Cardiology. Loved and respected by his patients and colleagues for his integrity and generosity. Passed on February 21, 2010 at age 97. Funeral services will be held on February 25, 2010, Thursday at 11:30am at I.J. Morris Funeral Home, 1895 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn, 718-377-8610.

ELSAS--Greta, 92, passed away at home February 22, 2010. Loving wife of the late Richard, beloved mother of Dennis and wife Nancy, adoring grandmother of Peter and Samantha, their spouses Hilary and Spencer and great-grandchildren Spencer, Audrey, Skylar and Ryan. A driving force at Bloomingdales, she enriched the lives of everyone she met with compassion, grace, wise counsel, humor and style. Services Thursday, February 25th 11:30 at Schwartz Brothers Chapels in Forest Hills.

Gary Bettman could be finding himself boxed into a corner, his position that N.H.L. participation in future Olympics may not be worth the sacrifice rendered untenable by the big television audience last Sunday for the game between Canada and the United States. Bettman, the N.H.L. commissioner, has suggested that shutting down for 15 days may be more costly to the league than the benefits it derives from having its stars showcased internationally. The league gets no revenue from Olympic telecasts, but the high viewership numbers suggest that the N.H.L. is getting more exposure from the Olympics than Bettman or anyone else expected.

James G. Wieghart, a former editor of The Daily News in New York who toggled between reporting on public servants and being one, writing political analysis on one side of the divide and, on the other, contributing to the final report of the independent counsel on the Iran-contra affair, died Sunday in Clare, in central Michigan. He was 76 and lived in nearby Lake City, Mich. The cause was complications of pneumonia, said his wife, Sharon.

ISAACS--Jack, age 99, of Boyton Beach, FL and formerly of Brooklyn, NY, died peacefully on February 22nd 2010. Devoted husband, father, grandfather, and great-grandfather. His kindness and love will always be with us. The Isaacs and Herz Families

NEWMARK--June. How can I describe the most brilliant, generous person I knew. Her courage and strength throughout her dreadful disease was an inspiration to all who knew her. June, I miss you already. Barbara and Paul Carter

In Ernest Hemingway's short story "Now I Lay Me," Nick Adams, the writer's alter ego, stays up at night listening to the silk worms feeding on mulberry leaves outside his army tent in Italy. During World War I, Hemingway had himself developed insomnia so severe that he was afraid to go to bed with the lights out. And he struggled with sleeplessness the whole rest of his life, although this issue was often hard to separate from his other ailments - including severe depression, chronic alcoholism and diabetes. "I myself did not want to sleep," he writes, "because I had been living for a long time with the knowledge that if I ever shut my eyes in the dark and let myself go, my soul would go out of my body."

Wal-Mart has announced an initiative that aims to achieve major reductions in greenhouse-gas emissions from its supply chain. As Stephanie Rosenbloom reports for The New York Times, the company said it would cut 20 million metric tons of emissions by the end of 2015 by focusing on popular product categories with the highest embedded carbon - milk, bread, meat, clothing. It said it would lean on its suppliers to rethink the sources, manufacturing processes, packaging and transportation of their goods.

What's big, bad and draped in a black Prada overcoat? Think less the Matrix and more the early Middle Ages. Attila, aka Attila the Hun, one of the most fearsome rulers in history, is the central character in a new production at the Metropolitan Opera. True to the fate of a grand Italian operatic divo, Attila is depicted not so much as a brute barbarian as a man with a soft spot for women and dashing attire. Whether or not you're a stickler for period costumes and a strict interpretation of history, this devil looks great in Prada.

A sleepless night of research, phone calls, and meetings with lawyers has failed to yield results: Turns out there is no way to wipe the "American Idol" semifinalist slate clean and start over with a new group of 24. Given that, it's worth considering that this is at least an implicit part of the show's plan: some contestants are just there to fill space while the favorites gain strength and confidence. He spent six years on his own creek and, in-between, struggled through some varsity blues and obeyed a few rules of attraction. Edward Meadham and Benjamin Kirchhoff just showed the fourth season of their Meadham Kirchhoff brand under the New Gen new talent initiative in London. They've got themselves a bit of reputation for being all moody and slouchy and gothic, but this season they did something more exciting than most of the other stuff being churned out in London: Riot Grrrls and gowns that were almost like couture and veils and tinsel tiaras made in collaboration with millinery wunderkind Nasir Mazhar. I just got back from the international framing show in Italy. Yes, there are trade shows for picture framing. Last month, I went to the national frame and art show in Las Vegas. Both shows have gotten smaller over the years, and several other shows have been discontinued. From what I have seen and heard, attendance has been declining at most trade shows in most industries. There are numerous reasons, including fewer small businesses, more reluctance to travel and more information on the Internet.

Balenciaga's Nicolas Ghesquière is currently one of the world's most influential designers, but when it comes to Spanish fashion, it's Cristobal Balenciaga who casts a long shadow. At the 51st edition of Cibeles Fashion Week, which wrapped up this week in Madrid, many of the city's most celebrated designers found inspiration in an ultrastructured, old-school couture ideal -- a point of reference that was about as relevant to 2010 as it sounds. Luckily, there were plenty of other distractions including a buzzing scene at the Feria de Madrid site and an array of eccentric bold-face names who could have walked out of an Almodovar film.Much of the excitement on the runways came courtesy of the top-tier models who skipped London, where few designers can afford to pay fees, in favor of Madrid. Iris Strubegger, Marina Peres, Eniko Mihalik, Egle Tvirbutaite, Denisa Dvorakova, Michaela Kocianova Diana Farkhullina, Daiane Conterato and Charlotte di Calypso added some "super" appeal to the calendar.

Riccardo Muti will open his term as music director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra with a concert in Millennium Park on Sept. 19, the orchestra said on Thursday in announcing its 2010-11 season. In other highlights, his opening subscription concerts will feature Berlioz's "Symphonie Fantastique" and "Lélio," with the actor Gérard Depardieu as narrator, and Mr. Muti will lead concert performances of Verdi's "Otello" in Chicago and at Carnegie Hall in April 2011. The violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter will play the Beethoven violin concerto for the first time in nearly two decades with the orchestra at the orchestra's gala, the "Symphony Ball," on Oct. 2. Mr. Muti will spend 10 weeks with the orchestra.

With just a few days to go before Oscar ballots are due, all the scuttlebutt is coming out. Last Friday, Nicolas Chartier, the producer who put up the financing for "The Hurt Locker," sent out an e-mail message asking people to vote for his indie film over a certain multimillion-dollar behemoth. "If everyone tells one or two of their friends, we will win and not a $500M film," he wrote in the e-mail message, which Pete Hammond reprinted in a Los Angeles Times blog. Though Mr. Chartier didn't mention "Avatar" by name, the reference seemed pretty clear, and a violation of the Academy's rules. Mr. Hammond thought a fitting punishment would be to revoke an Oscar seat or two.

Apple announced on Thursday that Louie Sulcer of Woodstock, Ga., clicked the "Buy" button at an opportune time, downloading the 10 billionth song from the company's iTunes Store since the site went active in April 2003. The fortuitous purchase makes Mr. Sulcer the winner of the iTunes Countdown to 10 Billion Songs, and he'll receive a $10,000 iTunes gift card.

The sartorial forecast this spring calls for ruffles with a chance of flowers and prints. But what's in store for your romantic get-up when the seasonal rains roll in? Instead of ruining it with a frumpy discount umbrella, raise it to new heights with couture coverage from Parasolerie Heurtault. Obsessed with umbrellas since childhood, the French artisan Michel Heurtault opened this Parisian atelier-boutique in 2008 after 20 years of working as a costume designer and corset maker for film, theater and fashion. Through the windows of the vaulted shop, clients can watch him construct made-to-measure umbrellas and parasols using waterproofed and UV-protected silk, taffeta, linen and cotton, then hand-finish them with button fixtures instead of snaps. "Umbrellas have been vulgarized as disposable objects," says Heurtault, who's committed to creating silhouettes as sturdy as they are stylish. "When beautifully designed, they can give instant allure and attitude to a chic ensemble while providing ultimate protection and comfort." Go to parasolerieheurtault.com.

My wife, Jackie, and I tend to keep our refrigerator a bit colder than the manufacturer recommends - better safe than sorry - and we got back from a recent trip to find a semi-frozen bunch of parsley in the vegetable bin. Normally, I would have just thrown it away, but I tasted a leaf and found it pretty flavorful. But frosty: rinsed, dried and chopped, it would probably have had an unpleasant consistency. So, looking ahead to the evening's spaghetti-with-leeks dinner, I tossed the whole bunch into a pot of boiling salted water, just for 30 seconds, then drained it and pureed it in a blender, along with a couple of tablespoons of the cooking water - just enough to give the blender a chance to do its work.

For anyone interested in reading more about the state of British conservatism, I highly recommend this big Financial Times piece on the influence of evangelical Christians - and particularly Tim Montgomerie, the founder of the prominent ConservativeHome website - in David Cameron's Tory Party. It's thick with heavy breathing about the perils of religious influence on politics, but mostly that comes from old-guard Conservative apparatchiks quoted sniping at Montgomerie, rather than from the author's own editorializing. Overall, the story strikes me as a fair-minded look at the attempt to forge a distinctively Christian approach to right-of-center politics - and to do so in a country where religious believers are a distinct minority, and evangelicals are particularly marginal. There are echoes of the religious right and Bush-esque "compassionate conservatism" in what Montgomerie and Co. are up to, but also striking differences as well. And as with Cameronism writ large, I think that there are ways in which American conservatives - and social conservatives, obviously, in particular - might profit from their example.

A Suit Against Oakland Goes Forward | A federal judge in San Francisco said in a ruling this week that a wrongful-death lawsuit against the city of Oakland could go forward.  The suit arose from the death of Jerry Amaro, who was arrested in 2000 in East Oakland and died a month afterward after claiming he had been beaten by the police. Judge William Alsup of Federal District Court wrote that "misleading statements and conduct" by the police made soon after Mr. Amaro's death discouraged his mother, Geraldine Montoya, from filing a wrongful death lawsuit. The family filed a lawsuit in 2009, but the city had argued that the statute of limitations had passed.  The Federal Bureau of Investigation is conducting a separate inquiry into whether or not the police covered up the circumstances surrounding Mr. Amaro's death. [The Oakland Tribune]

Barb Jungr, Stephen Holden writes, is a revelatory British interpreter and jolly iconoclast, who dramatically reinvents every song she touches. Songwriters featured in her new show, "River," include Bruce Springsteen, Hank Williams, Bob Dylan, Kern and Hammerstein, Leonard Cohen and many others. Simon Wallace accompanies on piano. There are apparently 90 minutes of unseen footage on the just-released DVD of "The September Issue." A few extra clips from the documentary by R. J. Cutler about Vogue's biggest issue have been posted on New York Magazine's Web site, including additional appearances by the movie's breakout star, Grace Coddington, and they leave us wanting more. Tonight, thankfully, Ms. Coddington, the magazine's creative director, will oblige. She and another fashion favorite, Vogue editor-at-large Andre Leon Talley, will be at Barnes & Noble to discuss the film. Go in your best fashion-week-inspired outfit and ask about "Catwalk Cats," the rumored animated feature in the works about Ms. Coddington's famous feline family.

" 'Socrates,' Alastair Macaulay writes, "though not simple, is simply beautiful: the most sensuously attractive new choreography that I have seen by Mark Morris in more than 10 years." The new work is one of three pieces being performed by the Mark Morris Dance Group at BAM through Saturday. The other two are "Behemoth" and "Looky," which is having its New York premiere, but the new piece is generating the most excitement. "The work is set to Erik Satie's cantata 'Socrate.' Its movement idiom is one of deliberate neo-Classicism — in the first of the three sections, the dancers keep crossing the stage right to left, largely in flattened profile, like a Grecian bas-relief passing before our eyes — that seems to melt in later sections into its own, less obviously antique but more three-dimensional Classicism." Prior to the performance, Mr. Morris will be in conversation with the celebrity chef Mario Batali, a fellow foodie and Washington State native. FOR a sport that seemingly focuses on the bottom half of the body, snowboarding requires a lot from gloves. Beginners and intermediates spend a lot of time picking themselves up after a tumble, so waterproofing is important. And experienced riders grab the board to do tricks (as viewers of the Olympic Games have witnessed this month), so a firm grip is essential. Snowboarders tend to be male and in their teens and 20s, and many favor fashion -- or ''steez,'' in their parlance -- over function, said Marc Loebe, who owns the Boardroom, a snow and skate shop in Jackson, Wyo. Steez (a mash-up of style and ease) often translates to colorful gloves with maximum grip but minimum warmth. ''The next move will be a cross between the two,'' Mr. Loebe said.

As the snowbanks begin to recede, it is possible to look with hope for signs of spring. A harbinger in the Middle Atlantic region would be the return of the purple martins, which like retirees, head south before winter. To follow the birds' progress as it returns north, I turn to BirdsEye, an iPhone app that takes a different approach to bird watching than most ornithological applications. Rather than just giving you a field guide and a log in which to record sightings, BirdsEye shows you where birds have been spotted, which means it can serve as a migration tracker.

Plasma and LCD television sets capable of 3-D have yet to hit the market, but the accessories one needs to complete the experience are starting to trickle out. The latest add-on is Sony's first 3-D-ready audio receiver. The STR-DN1010, available this June for about $500, adds HDMI 1.4 capability to its feature set, allowing a full HD 3-D signal to be passed from a 3-D Blu-ray player, through the receiver and into a 3-D-capable HDTV. Only the new version of HDMI, version 1.4, is capable of passing a full HD 3-D signal from a video source to a display.

David Talbot, the author of ''Brothers: The Hidden History of the Kennedy Years,'' has become the latest historian to add his voice to a chorus of pre-emptive criticism of ''The Kennedys,'' a planned mini-series that the producer Joel Surnow (''24'') is preparing for the History channel. Mr. Talbot's book was among the works cited by the ''Kennedys'' screenwriter, Stephen Kronish, as source material for the project in a recent article in The New York Times. On Thursday Mr. Talbot said that after the article appeared he was contacted by Robert Greenwald, the liberal filmmaker who has recorded other historians' critiques of the project and posted them at a Web site, stopkennedysmears.com, and who provided him with preliminary scripts for four episodes of ''The Kennedys.'' Having read the scripts, Mr. Talbot said they presented President John F. Kennedy as dithering and indecisive on the issue of civil rights and his brother Robert as being soft on organized crime, among other errors. ''You can't just make things up that 100 percent violate the truth,'' Mr. Talbot said. In a statement the History channel said: ''The mini-series will be historically accurate and based on the work of multiple noted scholars. Anyone claiming otherwise is basing their claim on inaccurate information that has not been vetted by the History channel.''

The premiere of a documentary about Bill Cunningham, below, a photographer for The New York Times, will open New Directors/New Films, the annual series presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art, the society and the museum announced. The documentary, called ''Bill Cunningham New York'' and directed by Richard Press, follows Mr. Cunningham on his assignments for the Styles sections of The Times and chronicles his life and work over eight decades. It will be presented on March 24 at MoMA. The festival's closing-night film, on April 4, will be ''I Killed My Mother'' (''J'ai Tué Ma Mère'') by the Canadian writer and director Xavier Dolan. Mr. Dolan also stars in the film, with Anne Dorval, as a man who is consistently at odds with his mother as he discovers his homosexuality. New Directors/New Films will present 38 films, including 27 features and 11 shorts, representing filmmakers from 20 countries.

NEW DELHI -- The resumption of diplomatic talks between India and Pakistan set for Thursday comes at a critical moment, with the United States hoping that even a modest improvement in relations between the nuclear-armed neighbors could help the broader American military effort in Pakistan and Afghanistan. Yet achieving that is likely to prove a challenge, analysts say. Even as the foreign secretaries of India and Pakistan were preparing to meet in New Delhi, the countries have squabbled over what would be discussed. India wants the agenda to focus on terrorism, while Pakistan wants to resume broader talks that broke off after the November 2008 attacks in Mumbai, India, by militants trained in Pakistan.

Samsung just announced its new TL500 camera, a high-performance compact model that has a very bright f/1.8 lens and a comparatively large image sensor. These two features should make it much easier to get good shots in low-light conditions. The TL500's f/1.8 maximum aperture is the widest I've seen on a compact camera, so I'm eager to see how the camera does in hands-on reviews. It should enable users to capture better low-light images as well as provide some depth-of-field effects like a blurred background. The sensor offers a maximum ISO speed of 3,200, which should also help it perform capably in low lighting.

EPC CIGAR COMPANY manufactures and distributes cigars that are hand-rolled in the Dominican Republic from Ecuadorean, Nicaraguan and Dominican tobacco. It has been in business since April, although the family that owns it previously ran a successful cigar company that was sold to Swedish Match in 1999. THE CHALLENGE To develop a cost-effective and efficient marketing strategy to promote the company and its new brand, E. P. Carrillo, while building on the family's legacy.
