Teaching bridge has its interesting aspects. I give many lessons throughout the year, but most fall during the first three months. My classes usually begin with a discussion of the topic du jour, then the students play six prepared deals that highlight the material. When my talk is about card play, the students are well prepared for the deals. But when the subject is bidding, they have no clue what to expect in the play. This is more realistic, of course, but means a lower success rate.

BEHIND the scenes at the fall 2010 fashion shows last week, hair and makeup were polished but mostly free of cloying retro references. Backstage at the Marc Jacobs show, François Nars set the tone, creating an unvarnished face (bottom right) sparingly accented with coral lips and lightly outlined eyes. Mr. Nars's approach -- a startling departure from last season's stridently colorful '80s-inspired paint -- was complemented by Guido Palau's honey-tone hair for a look as subtle as it was uncontrived. Elsewhere the palette was similarly muted, though enlivened here and there with frank theatricality. The models at Gary Graham (center, far right) showed off up-dos that were sculptured and teased for a wind tunnel effect; winged brows the color of anthracite underscored that streamlined look. At Vena Cava (right) and Costello Tagliapietra (below) scarlet lips peeking out from brimmed hats, or contrasting shrilly with ghostly pale skin, provided a touch of dramatic relief.

SABELLA--Marcello, on February 23, 2010. Beloved husband of Therese. Loving father of Marcello, Christopher and Marissa. Adored brother of Dominic and Gaspare. Fond son of Ignazio and Maria. Reposing at Colonial Funeral Home (Staten Island). Visiting Thursday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass Friday, 10:15am at St. Charles Church. Interment Moravian Cemetery.

The nonprofit Sundance Institute, which supports independent filmmakers, said Keri Putnam, below, had been appointed as its new executive director. Ms. Putnam succeeds Ken Brecher, who resigned in April after a 14-year tenure. Ms. Putnam was the president for production of the Walt Disney Company's Miramax Films unit until Disney scaled it down and cut its executive staff last year. At Miramax she was associated with a number of widely acclaimed films, including ''No Country for Old Men,'' ''There Will Be Blood,'' ''Doubt'' and ''The Diving Bell and the Butterfly.'' In announcing her appointment, Robert Redford, the institute's president and founder, said he expected Ms. Putnam to help ''expand our international presence, connect to new audiences and experiment with emerging areas of artist support.'' Sundance is known for its filmmaker labs, which help artists to develop their movies, and for the annual Sundance Film Festival in Park City, Utah.

STOCKMAN--Dora Goldstone, 97 on February 10, 2010. Born NYC December 19, 1912. Married to late Abram H. Stockman (died 1977). Residing in Larchmont New York until her death. 1935 graduate of Pembroke College at Brown University. Mrs. Stockman was active in the Larchmont Garden Club and the Westchester Ethical Culture Society. An avid reader, gardener, opera lover, and creative artist. Survived by her sister, Betty White; her children Peter, James (Cornelia), Edward, and Abigail; seven grandchildren and three great-granddaughters. Donations can be made in her memory to the Larchmont Public Library, 121 Larchmont Avenue, Larchmont, NY 10538. There will be a Memorial Service in the spring.

FRUHAUF--Henry. The National Association for Temple Administration mourns the passing of one of the great giants of our field. Henry not only served his own congregation with distinction but was also a model NATA leader and past president, a visionary for what our organization could be, and a tower of strength and mentor to individual administrators. He has made us all better able to serve our congregations and Reform Judaism. May his memory be a blessing. Edward Alpert NATA President

RICE--Anne Corbin Armstrong (Nancy), died February 24, 2010 in Highland, NY. Born September 27, 1915 at Danskammer Farm in Newburgh, NY. Shipley School '33, Vassar '37. She was a good woman, and strong. She loved animals and supported many causes. Survived by her son Peter Stuyvesant Brooks and daughter-in-law Frances Ann of Tarrytown, NY and by her brother Noel Armstrong of Lexington, VA. A memorial service will be arranged at a later date.
TRIEBWASSER--Charles. Feb 25, 1930 - Mar 24, 1987. Chuck, we love and miss you. Your adoring family and friends

KADAR--Naomi Carol Prawer, Ph.D.,60, a remarkable educator and scholar of Yiddish children's literature passed away in her home on February 23. Naomi spearheaded BrainPOP ESL, a web-based English as a Second Language program for children. Recently she taught at Tel Aviv University's Goldreich Family Institute and at The Jewish Theological Seminary. Naomi's legacy lives on in her support of new educational initiatives in Israel as well as the inspiration she gave to her students. We mourn this strong, brave and profoundly humble woman. Her love, passion and warmth will always be with us. She is survived by her husband Avraham, and her children Maya, Nadav and Einat, her mother Lola, her sister Renee, her son-in-law Gil, her granddaughter Eden and many nieces and nephews. Service Thursday 11:45am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.
SPECTOR--Robert Donald. 9/21/22-2/25/2009 Bob Dear, forever and one day. We love you so much. Eleanor, Stephen, Hedda, Eric, Roger, Jesse and Caroline

MOSS--Stephen Charles, of New York CIty on February 22, 2010. Devoted son of Jeanette and the late Harry. Loving brother of Robert and brother-in-law of Hedwig (De). Beloved uncle of Steven and Nicole. Loyal friend of Linda Burns and her three children Krista, Bryan and Thomas. Cherished by his many cousins and friends. Graveside services Thursday, February 25th, 11am at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. Stephen was very dedicated to the needs of children. Donations in his memory may be made to Big Brothers Big Sisters of Erie County, 85 River Rock Drive, Suite 107, Buffalo, NY 14207.

WHISTLER, British Columbia -- The vast majority of slalom skiers attach a chin guard to their helmet to protect their face during races and training. Modern slalom technique requires racers to ski directly at the flexible slalom gates, slamming them backward with the racer's shins and with hand guards affixed to ski poles.

Most programs for reducing peak electricity demand involve air-conditioners or (in farm states) irrigation. In Idaho, for example, the main power company pays homeowners to allow their air-conditioners to be cycled on and off in 15-minute intervals during some summer afternoons, and farmers are paid to turn off their water pumps during those times.

There's a hot new ride parked beside the Maybachs at the tony Les Airelles ski resort in the French Alps: a horse-drawn carriage by Hermès. The Moment was curious and tracked down the carriage's fur-hatted, liveried coachman, Fred Molinas, who grew up on a farm near Avignon. Fred was lovely, if not exactly loquacious, but he did tell us (through a translator) that he has worked as a carriage driver at some of the most beautiful resorts in France, and Les Airelles - nestled in the spectacular Tarentaise Valley - is his absolute favorite. But wouldn't anything look beautiful from such a prestigious perch? With wheels like these - his coachman's seat is done up in Hermès ebony bull-calf leather, and his passengers keep warm inside the brick-leather interior with a pair of luxurious Hermès blankets - Fred's smart to toe the company line. Au trot!

What happens when you cross the scion of a storied jewelry company with a chic nomad? In the case of Mario Buccellati and Carla Forte, it's a unique jewelry line called Prediletto, which means favorite in Italian. Their first collection - all of it handmade in Italy - is full of references to Forte's far-flung travels. There are necklaces inspired by the views from a window at Versailles or from an open portico in a Palladian villa outside Venice, and earrings that recall the chandeliers in an ornate dining room from her childhood. Other pieces, like this $6,500 gold, sapphire and diamond gate pendant, are simply tiny sculptures of architectural elements the designer finds beautiful. Call (914) 218-8207 for information.

The market for nose tackles became officially barren this week after the Packers and the Patriots applied franchise tags to Ryan Pickett and Vince Wilfork. The two could still receive long-term deals with their clubs, but at the very least, they'll play under a lucrative one-year contract in 2010. Veteran NT Casey Hampton was also kept off the market; the Steelers agreed to a three-year deal with their nine-year star. The move guaranteed Hampton $11 million and allowed Pittsburgh to use its franchise tag on kicker Jeff Reed.Also franchised was Raiders defensive lineman Richard Seymour.

Members of the financially ailing Philadelphia Orchestra have made key concessions in pay and pensions, the orchestra said Friday. Overview | Who are "the new poor," and why do some labor experts believe that many unemployed Americans will spend years waiting for new jobs? In this lesson, students consider the scope and personal impact of the unemployment crisis, as well as some ideas for fighting joblessness. They then interview people in the community about the local effects of unemployment and produce written, audiotaped or videotaped interviews to share with the larger community.

"Uncharted Waters, Fragile Hopes" (09:00)"Cancer is a nasty disease, and it fights back," said Chris Nelson, who suffered from advanced melanoma, a disease that commonly kills within a year. Mr. Nelson was involved in the first phase of human testing of a new drug, PLX4032, which showed tremendous initial promise in several subjects. Mr. Nelson himself seemed to be on the road to recovery, but, as we learn from this powerful and informative video, a magic elixir to fight cancer remains elusive. This video, produced by Kassie Bracken of The Times, is the third in a series about the complexities and controversies of cancer drug trials. The videos complement an three-part print series by Amy Harmon. The videos take us into the homes of cancer patients and their families, as they struggle with heart-wrenching decisions and heart-rending diagnoses. (E.O.)

That's because it reads more like a marketing piece or an advertisement instead of the dry legalese that most of us have come to expect from cumbersome Securities and Exchange Commission filings.

David Brooks: Dick, thanks a million for filling in for Gail while she takes a vacation. As you know, over the past few months, Gail has published a book and done a book tour all while writing a witty and wise column twice a week, so she deserves a few weeks off so she can attend conferences on how to save the public option.

Milan fashion week has only just begun, but it was interesting to see how some key themes in the men's-wear shows, which took place here in January, have carried into the women's. At D&G, Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana reprised last month's ski motif, complete with the season's ubiquitous alpine knits. What a shame that the Vancouver Olympics are nearly over! Wouldn't it be fun if Lindsey Vonn had worn glittery D&G goggles? Or if the medalists had sashayed onto the podium wearing massive furry leg warmers?

Sarah Palin isn't the only one who has taken issue with "Family Guy" lately. According to a report from the media research firm SNL Kagan, that Fox animated series is responsible for more that 190,000 indecency complaints that have been filed and and are still pending at the Federal Communications Commission, with Fox shows accounting for half of the Top 50 complaints.

Musical theater fans unable to make it to Avery Fisher Hall for "Sondheim: The Birthday Concert" on March 15 and 16 can breathe a sigh of relief. "Great Performances" will broadcast the New York Philharmonic show, Playbill.com has reported. The exact dates for the telecast have not yet been determined, but representatives for that PBS program told Playbill that it would most likely be shown in the fall. The star-studded, sold-out show, directed by Lonny Price and hosted by David Hyde Pierce, is scheduled to include performances by Patti LuPone, Bernadette Peters, Audra McDonald, Laura Benanti, Matt Cavenaugh, Michael Cerveris, Victoria Clark, Jenn Colella, Jason Danieley, Joanna Gleason, Nathan Gunn, George Hearn, Marin Mazzie, ,John McMartin, Donna Murphy, Gillian Murphy, Laura Osnes, Mandy Patinkin, , Ethan Stiefel, Elaine Stritch, Jim Walton and Chip Zien. Mr. Sondheim celebrates his 80th birthday on March 22.

The international high-speed rail operators Eurostar and Thalys said Friday that full service into and out of Brussels would be restored on Monday, two weeks after a fatal collision of two commuter trains forced the closure of a section of track outside the Belgian capital.

Although it was overshadowed by the Toyota drama taking place in the House of Representatives, the Senate Appropriations Subcommittee for Energy and Water Development held a hearing on "Electric Vehicles in the Light Duty Auto Sector" this week, and the Senators heard a fairly unified message from players in the electric vehicle community. There could be a significant early gap between E.V. demand and E.V. supply, they said, and we need help getting these green cars off the ground.

Q.Dear Alisa and Gina,One afternoon last week I ran into a woman at the supermarket who I know because our older children are in the same school. When I asked how her children were, she told me that they were home alone while she was running errands. Her kids are only seven and four! She must have seen the look of surprise on my face, because she said the seven year old is very responsible and she was only gone for half an hour or so. The only thing I said was, "Well, I'm sure you'll want to hurry home to make sure they're OK." Should I have said something else? Or reported her? --Horrified

It wasn't the best way to start the day. "When I was leaving the house this morning, my husband saw what I was wearing and said, 'What do you think you're doing, you complete freak?' " recalls Phoebe Philo with a laugh. "He said that skinny jeans, a sweatshirt, a Crombie coat and loafers are the uniform of the British National Party. And he has a point."

If, after listening to all 18 tracks and 67 minutes of the Rolling Stones' "Exile on Main Street" you've ever thought to yourself, "Boy, I could really do with a few more scuzzy, skeevy, down-and-dirty Stones tracks from those same recording sessions," your ship has just come in. For a character who makes only a passing appearance in the original "Star Wars" trilogy, things are going swimmingly for Admiral Ackbar, a bit player from "Return of the Jedi." Ackbar, the squidlike leader of the Rebel Alliance's assault on the Death Star who vocally declares that his forces have stumbled into a trap, has lately been ensnared by the popular culture: he's received shout-outs on television programs from "Robot Chicken" to "The Daily Show" to "The Colbert Report." And if things go his way, he could even end up the new mascot of the University of Mississippi.The Atlanta Journal-Constitution reported that the students of Ole Miss voted on Tuesday to seek a new mascot to replace the school's Colonel Reb, who was deemed too evocative of the Old South and potentially offensive. Among the leading candidates to replace the Colonel? The Admiral, who's been getting a boost from student Web sites like notatrap.org, which declares: "He led the Galactic Rebellion, and he knew he needed to be with the Ole Miss Rebels."

Facebook Granted Patent on the News FeedAs we noted Thursday, Facebook has been granted a patent for the its central feature, the news feed. ReadWriteWeb spotlights the discussion in the blogosphere on the topic, with many questioning if Facebook actually invented the algorithm-driven newsfeed. Bloggers also ask if the company will enforce its patent against other services, including Google Reader and Google Buzz, or if the move is just defensive.

The second volume of "All-Star Superman" lands at No. 3 on our paperback list this week. The All-Star line from DC Comics was conceived as a way for creators to tell stories about Superman and Batman that were free of the years of continuity that come with the characters, and "All-Star Superman," written by Grant Morrison and illustrated by Frank Quitely, was embraced as one of the best Superman titles in years. In this volume Superman faces his backward foe Bizarro; meets two survivors from his home planet, Krypton; and deals with his own mortality.

The Times offers some interesting perspectives on Thursday's health care confab between Republicans and Democrats. Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Robert Pear suggest that the "all-day televised session might have driven the parties even farther apart." David M. Herszenhorn reports that the summit meeting left President Obama "with little choice but to try to rally Democrats to act on their own," as Republicans seemed unpersuaded. Take a look, and share your thoughts in the comments section.

CKE Restaurants, the owner of fast-food chains like Hardee's and Carl's Jr., agreed on Friday to sell itself to the private equity firm THL Partners for $619 million in cash as the leveraged buyout industry continues to revive.

Telecasting Prop. 8's Closing Arguments May be Back on the Table | Federal judges in the Bay Area are again proposing to allow cameras in the courtroom, which may mean the closing arguments of the lawsuit challenging California's ban on same-sex marriage will be broadcast beyond the courthouse. As the trial began in January, the United States Supreme Court ruled that the proceedings could not be shown on YouTube. The justices noted that witnesses testifying for same-sex marriage opponents expressed fear of intimidation. The United States District Court in San Francisco has now posted the same proposal to its Web site, allowing judges to take part of a pilot program that would allow telecasting of a nonjury trial's proceedings. The closing arguments would not involve any witness appearances. They will be set after the final round of briefs in the case is delivered on Friday. [The San Francisco Chronicle]

One hundred years after a major flood swept through Paris, temporarily transforming the city and causing widespread damage, two exhibitions take a look back at the extraordinary event. After months of unusually wet weather in 1909, January 1910 brought even heavier rainfall that, combined with faulty engineering, swelled the waters of the Seine. The river eventually rose to 26 feet above normal levels, flooding the streets and squares of central Paris. For a time, Paris looked more like Venice: famous boulevards turned into canals, and boats replaced the flooded Métro tunnels as the preferred mode of transportation. This novel and strangely beautiful urban landscape drew the attention of artists and photographers from around the world.

One Tough Fight Deserves Another | The results of the sharp-edged election within Local 1021 of the Service Employees International Union will be announced on Saturday. But the backdrop of this fight is less the personality-driven politics of that local union than the impact that that rough contest will have on an even rougher one:  the negotiations over San Francisco's budget for the next fiscal year. Gerry Shih's article in Friday's Bay Area Report explores the links between the two bitter and intractable fights, explaining how each exacerbates the other. The trend lines laid out by city economists describe a government with a shrinking capacity to deliver vital services or to underwrite new initiatives, particularly if pension obligations keep expanding. And then there is the $522 million deficit for the coming fiscal year."This is the toughest year that anyone has seen in recent history," said David Chiu, the president of the Board of Supervisors, "in large part because last year we cut to the bone, and this year, we're cutting bone."

The ubiquitous posters and trailers for Tim Burton's "Alice in Wonderland" make us want to smear on a lot of white face paint, dark lipstick and take on the Red Queen. Seattle's Abney Park will perform and there will also be swing dancing and lessons. Costumes are encouraged.

It's always a challenge to sift through all the art at the Whitney Biennial, and this year is especially difficult because of a no-frills selection. Thankfully, we have Holland Cotter to point out what to skip and what to see. "The show has dead spots," Mr. Cotter writes, "mainly where it reflects the retrenched art-about-art spirit of the day. But it also has strong work (particularly in video) that speaks of life beyond the art factory." Head to a group of snap-shot-style family photographs by Nina Berman, part of a series Ms. Berman made of American soldiers who returned home wounded from Iraq. "You have to get up close to the pictures to see what's going on. And the shock they generate, due in part to the exploitive vibes they give off, ripples through everything around them." Another set of photographs, by the photojournalist Stephanie Sinclair of women in Afghanistan who immolated themselves to escape punishing marriages, is also a highlight. "Like much painting at present (and if you don't believe there's a ton of it around, just spend an afternoon in Chelsea), the work is clean, cool, classy, retro-modernist, labor-intensive."

"The Tibetans are like the Na'vi," Robert A. F. Thurman, a professor of Indo-Tibetan studies at Columbia University who helped found Tibet House, said recently in an interview. "They're hanging in there. Maybe not fighting with bows and arrows, but they are staying connected to nature, and we think they will prevail." For the past two decades, Mr. Thurman and his organization have hosted concerts, held at Carnegie Hall since 1994, to draw attention to the Tibetans' cause. These celebrity-filled events, Ben Sisario writes, "have developed into an institution of their own, shining a light each year on the urgency of preserving Tibetan culture and offering music fans starry, varied lineups." This year is no different. Tonight, the Tibet House Benefit Concert, which is curated by Philip Glass, will feature performances by Iggy Pop, Patti Smith, Gogol Bordello, Regina Spektor and many more.

KAHN--Gilbert S. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the passing of Gilbert S. Kahn, a member of our board from 1997 to 2009 and of our Council for Artistic Excellence at the time of his death. The Met was honored to be among the many artistic and cultural organizations he generously supported. At the Met, he underwrote Robert Wilson's production of Wag- ner's Lohengrin in 1998 and helped to fund seven other productions on our stage, as well as the 2008 PBS telecast of Tristan und Isolde. Gilbert enjoyed attending performances here in New York and, in recent years, at home in Florida through The Met: Live in HD movie-theater transmissions. On behalf of the company, we send sincere condolences to John J. Noffo Kahn, and to John and Gilbert's family and friends. He will be missed. Christine F. Hunter, Chairman of the Board William C. Morris, President & CEO Peter Gelb, General Manager

When his daughter won a gold medal last week, Karl Ricker was on a different mountain, being a Weasel. It is a term of affection. Ricker is an original member of the Whistler Weasel Workers, a volunteer group dating to the 1970s that prepares courses for international ski races here. No project has been bigger than the day-and-night preparation for the Winter Olympics.

The New York International Children's Film Festival opens Friday night and runs through March 21 at six Manhattan locations. A full, updated schedule is at (212) 349-0330 and gkids.com. Tickets are $10 to $30; most are $12. (The ''Film and Food'' benefit is $150 for adults, $100 for those 17 and under.) ''Shorts for Tots'' (ages 3 to 6), ''Short Films One'' (ages 5 to 10) and ''Short Films Two'' (ages 8 to 14) play at least once every weekend, though some screenings are sold out. Selected additional highlights still available as of press time: SATURDAY AND SUNDAY Saturday at the Cantor Film Center, 36 East Eighth Street, East Village: 10:30 a.m., ''Oblivion Island'' (ages 7 and older); 2 p.m., ''Amuse-Bouche: French Short Animation'' (ages 8 and older); 3 p.m., ''Heebie Jeebies'' (ages 10 and older); 5 p.m., ''Girls' POV.'' Sunday at Scholastic Theater, 557 Broadway, at Spring Street, SoHo: Noon, ''Get a Grip'' (ages 6 and older), a behind-the-scenes workshop about filmmaking.

A United States Olympic bobsledder was ''detained and released'' by the Canadian authorities late Wednesday, according to the United States Bobsled and Skeleton Federation's chief executive, Darrin Steele. The bobsledder, Bill Schuffenhauer, who pushes for USA-3 and was a silver medalist at the 2002 Salt Lake Games, was expected to compete in the four-man competition, which begins Friday, Steele said.
CHARLES W. HUTSON 'A Survey'

The women's long program in figure skating is one of the premier events of these Olympics, with photographers from all over the world wanting to have an ice-level position to capture every jump and spin. But the first-come, first-served nature of securing one of these positions left photographers who arrived eight hours before the event out of contention for a spot. Photographers started waiting to secure a shooting position the night before the event was scheduled. At previous Olympics, tickets were distributed to photographers the day before the event by their country's organizing committee. JADE-SNOW MOY

WARWICK--Jane Hawke, long-time resident of Greenwich Village, died peacefully at home on Tuesday, February 23rd. Raised in Smethport, PA, she graduated from Goucher College, moved directly to the Village and never left. She began her career at Mademoiselle Magazine in the fiction department where she became editor and continued to work in publishing throughout her life. She lived above the Cherry Lane Theater on Commerce Street with her husband where they raised their three children. She is survived by her husband Arnold Warwick, her children Liadain, Matthew and Samantha and her seven grandchildren.

Despite poor weather, Bill Demong and Johnny Spillane gave the United States first- and second-place finishes Thursday in the men's long hill/10-kilometer Nordic combined event. The United States team partly secured its victory through tactical skiing. While not common in cross-country skiing, they followed the methods of professional cyclists and worked to ensure that the break containing Demong, who finished first, and Spillane was not chased down.

The Chinese police have detained 18 people they say assaulted a group of artists in an effort to evict them from their homes and studios on the edge of the capital, the Xinhua news agency reported Thursday. Xinhua did not identify those detained, but the artists said that the attackers were hired by developers who are seeking to demolish a cluster of artist communities and replace them with shops and upscale housing. As many as 1,000 artists in Beijing are facing displacement in the midst of a redevelopment boom.
MATTIA BONETTI Paul Kasmin

The government issued guidelines on Thursday setting out when it was most likely to prosecute people in cases of assisted suicide. The guidelines, which replace interim rules issued last fall, place particular emphasis on the motivation of the person helping the suicide -- whether the person acted ''wholly compassionately'' and in accordance with the victim's wishes, for example, or whether he or she stood to gain from the death. But Keir Starmer, director of the public prosecutions, said the guidelines did not change the law -- assisted suicide is still illegal, and carries a jail sentence of up to 14 years -- and had no bearing on cases of so-called mercy killing.

FRUHAUF--Henry. The National Association for Temple Administration mourns the passing of one of the great giants of our field. Henry not only served his own congregation with distinction but was also a model NATA leader and past president, a visionary for what our organization could be, and a tower of strength and mentor to individual administrators. He has made us all better able to serve our congregations and Reform Judaism. May his memory be a blessing. Edward Alpert NATA President

A House panel has found that Rep. Charles B. Rangel of New York broke Congressional rules by failing to properly disclose financial details of a trip to the Caribbean, a House official said. Mr. Rangel, who heads the House Ways and Means committee and who has served his Harlem district for nearly four decades, has been under investigation by two house subcommittees.

RAVINA--Oscar. The New York Philharmonic mourns the passing, on February 25, 2010, of Oscar Ravina, 79, a violinist with the Orchestra from 1963 to 2004 and a beloved teacher. Our deepest condolences to his wife Ruth, sons Mark and Bernard, and family.

MORRIS--Richard A.,78, died at his home in Sarasota, FL, February 17th. He was a graduate of Bronx Science and Adelphi College. After retiring from the insurance business and moving to Sarasota, he began an (unpaid) career as co-founder, with his wife Sue, of the nonprofit, member-supported Sarasota Film Society. As booker, screener and distributor of classic, independent and international films, Dick was a highly visible promoter of the arts, including film, as opportunities for enlightenment as well as entertainment. Famously outspoken in his remarks on both culture and politics, Dick was admired by many as a "contrarian with a cause." He is survived by his wife of 50 years, Susan (nee Kroll) Morris, daughter Leslie (Robert) Godwin, son-in-law Steve Sam- uels, two grandchildren, many relatives and countless friends. He was predeceased in 2002 by his daughter Kathryn (KT) Samuels.

Survived by her sister, Betty White; her children Peter, James (Cornelia), Edward, and Abigail; seven grandchildren and three great-granddaughters. Donations can be made in her memory to the Larchmont Public Library, 121 Larchmont Avenue, Larchmont, NY 10538. There will be a Memorial Service in the spring.

KAUFMAN--Rosalind Melamed, 90, on February 25, 2010. Born Binghamton, New York, June 24, 1919. A matriarch of exceptional dignity loving, devoted and caring wife to Bernard (deceased); mother to Alexandra Raine (William) and Marjorie Benjamin (Ross); sister to Myron, Evelyn, Lenore (deceased) and Estelle; grandmother to Spencer (Renee), Evan, Amalie (Ken) and Hallie; great-grandmother to Noah and friend to countless. Funeral: Sunday, February 28th at 1pm, Zion Memorial Chapel, 785 East Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck, NY 10543. Donations: The Rosalind and Bernard Kaufman Scholarship Award, c/o HIAS Heritage Society, 333 Seventh Avenue, New York, NY 10001. Shiva: Sunday and Monday, 617 Sylvan Avenue, Mamaroneck. Tuesday and Wednesday in Great Neck and Newton, 7-9pm.

CONNOR--Lisa Forrestal, 59, died February 16, in her home in Emeryville, California. She was born June 12, 1950, in Summit, New Jersey, where she attended Oak Knoll School and Kent Place School before moving to Washington, DC, where she graduated Holton Arms School. She was the daughter of John T. Connor, then President of Merck & Co., who went to Washington to serve in the Cabinet of Pres. Lyndon B. Johnson as Secretary of Commerce, and Mary O'Boyle Connor. Lisa then graduated from Smith College and Harvard Business School and enjoyed a successful career in cable television in the San Francisco Bay area where she made her home during her working days and thereafter. She suffered from bi-polar disorder and multiple sclerosis. A world traveler with her then husband, Fredric Postle, a business school classmate, to whom she was married for twenty-two years, she collected art and artifacts from Africa and Asia. Lisa was active in mental health issues and organizations in California and maintained a wide circle of friends and associates. Known for her great humanity, she kept birds, cats and a dog and managed to visit parks and Bay Area sites on a regular basis. She is survived by her mother Mary, her two brothers, John and Geoffrey, and their wives Susan and Holly, her Aunts Mary Waters and Betty Ann Waldheim, her uncle Stan Waldheim and numerous nieces, nephews and Connor, O'Boyle, Waters, Kendrick, Waldheim and English cousins. Contributions are welcome to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society.

Major League Soccer and its players union appeared unlikely to reach a labor agreement before the current deal expired at midnight Thursday, raising the possibility of a strike. The two sides vowed to keep talking, and the league said it would not lock out the players if a collective bargaining agreement was not reached before the season opened March 25. The union said it would continue negotiating but considers the current deal dead. ''There simply hasn't been enough progress made in the negotiations to date to warrant an extension of the agreement,'' said Bob Foose, the union's executive director. The agreement was extended twice after its Jan. 31 expiration date.

BOKEN--Dr. Julia B.,died January 7, 2010. The retired college professor and author taught English Literature at SUNY Oneonta, received her Doctorate from Columbia University in 1970, and specialized in Lord Byron and Hawaiian history and culture. She lived in New York City and is survived by nephew Paul Boken of Cape Cod, MA. Memorial contributions may be made to Columbia University Graduate Program.

LEVINE--Roslyn, wife of the late Morton Levine Esq. Daughter of Ida and Abraham Aronowitz. Survived by her beloved daughters Marsha Levine and Stephanie Levine and granddaughter Alexandra Petre. Service Monday 12:15pm at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

Viktor F. Yanukovich was sworn in as president of Ukraine on Thursday, and he vowed to make the country stable and prosperous, as well as a bridge between Russia and Europe. Mr. Yanukovich, left, who narrowly prevailed in the election this month, warned that Ukraine ''was in a very difficult situation'' because of a weak economy, corruption and poverty. But he said he was confident that the country could overcome these challenges. While he called for unity, his election opponent, Prime Minister Yulia V. Tymoshenko, and her political allies boycotted the inauguration. Ms. Tymoshenko has contended that Mr. Yanukovich won only because of fraud, though European monitors called the election fair.

SNOWBER--John R.,on February 25, 2010. Beloved husband of Jacqueline (nee Longo) of 46 years. Loving brother of the late Frank (late Grace), the late Robert (Joan), Mary Gruning (late Carl), twin sister Eleanor Sluys (late William) and the late Eileen Hatton (late Tim). Also survived by numerous nieces and nephews. Reposing at Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, 61-40 Woodhaven Blvd, Rego Park, on Sunday, 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass, Monday, 10:30am, Our Lady of Hope Church, Middle Village. Entombment to follow at St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, NY.

In New York's cold-case crime files, few have as firm a grip on the collective psyche of city law enforcement officers as the so-called zip-gun bomber. ''Here is a case that has so many turns, and it's still unsolved,'' said one law enforcement official who is familiar with it. ''Some of the people involved are still here, some are deceased. It is a really old case. Every time something happened on this, it opened another door.''
BRYAN--Diana, died February 22, 2010. Respected illustrator, teacher at Parsons for over 20 years. Loving life partner to Bob Pearl. We are heartbroken to lose Diana.

The owner of Testwell Laboratories, once the leading concrete testing company in New York, tried to kill himself last week, two days after he was convicted of falsifying concrete mix reports, according to court documents. V. Reddy Kancharla, the owner, slit his wrists and took sleeping pills, his lawyer, Paul Shechtman, told Justice Edward J. McLaughlin of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, according to a transcript of a closed-door meeting the judge had with the lawyers in the case.

I'm bracing myself for comments about my Sunday column about religion. There's a tendency for liberals to devote lots of ink to decrying conservative Christians, because of their positions on social issues. I disagree strongly with typical evangelical positions on gay marriage, abortion, abstinence only education -- but I also think that liberals don't appreciate the impact of the arrival of evangelicals into humanitarian space or give sufficient credit for that change. The United States is doing far more for Africa today than a decade ago largely because evangelicals became a strong constituency for the Pepfar AIDS program and the PMI malaria program. Liberals were always in favor of such ventures, and what changed was that conservatives pushed for them as well -- and of course the Bush White House listened to them in a way it did not listen to liberals. And don't minimize those programs: Pepfar and PMI are saving millions of African lives.

Hisanori Takahashi threw another impressive bullpen session Saturday and drew raves from Rod Barajas, who was laughing trying to track his breaking ball. Takahashi is scheduled to pitch the first spring training game March 2, but may not be able to if his work visa doesn't come through by then. If it does, he could start that game. As of Saturday the Mets still did not consider themselves close to attaining the left-handed reliever Joe Beimel. But Beimel told The Denver Post that he was weighing the offer. INDIANAPOLIS - Texas quarterback Colt McCoy, who suffered a nerve injury that drove him from the national championship game, said he wasn't able to throw for about three weeks after the injury, but now he feels great. McCoy, who lost feeling in his arm during the game, said the feeling returned a few days later, but while he rested his arm, he worked on his footwork. He said there is nothing structurally wrong with his shoulder.

Because the Bears and the Jaguars finished 7-9, had identical strengths of schedule and did not play head-to-head, their draft position was determined by a coin flip at the combine Friday. Last September I posted about the increasingly widespread belief in the global development  community that one way to help high school girls in poor countries stay in school is to help them manage menstruation. There's anecdotal evidence that girls stay home during their periods (because of a lack of hygiene products and underwear, as well as embarrassment, cramps and taboos). Then they get further and further behind and eventually drop out. If that's true, then interventions to address this would be a cost-effective way of keeping girls in school.

SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE - I made a discovery while solving this puzzle that's going to sound ridiculous - using a pencil. I do almost everything in pen these days, from solving puzzles to sketching to writing, even writing puzzles. But for me, an acrostic takes a bit more guessing than a crossword, and it finally occurred to me that a pencil might be a better choice given the limited space in the Times layout. It was.

KAUFMAN--Rosalind Melamed, 90, on February 25, 2010. Born Binghamton, New York, June 24, 1919. A matriarch of exceptional dignity loving, devoted and caring wife to Bernard (deceased); mother to Alexandra Raine (William) and Marjorie Benjamin (Ross); sister to Myron, Evelyn, Lenore (deceased) and Estelle; grandmother to Spencer (Renee), Evan, Amalie (Ken) and Hallie; great-grandmother to Noah and friend to countless. CONRAD--Robert, 90, died in Ann Arbor, MI on February 18. He was born in New York City, received undergraduate and law degrees from New York University, and was a proud veteran of World War II, serving in the deception unit known as the "Ghost Army." He practiced law in New York City for nearly 60 years, served as president of the City Club of New York, and was active in Democratic Party politics at the local, state and national levels. He is survived by Esther, his beloved wife of 60 years, sons Dan of San Francisco and Fred of Ann Arbor, their wives Sarah Wilcox and Betsy Brooks, grandchildren Paul, Ted, Allison, and Jeffrey, and eight nieces and nephews. Bob loved the theater, ballet, and music; he was an enthusiastic and generous host, and loved a party. He and Esther were world travelers, always looking forward to their next trip. He was loved and respected by the many friends he made throughout his life. His friends and family will miss him always. Memorial contributions may be sent to Peoples' Symphony Concerts; Suite 703; 121 W. 27th Street; New York, NY 10001.
BAUMAN--Lionel R. Beloved partner, friend and colleague, died on February 27, 1987. Sorely missed by all. Eugene M. Grant & Co., LLC

Dressed in azure, accompanied by Gershwin, Kim Yu-na of South Korea seemingly floated to the clouds with her soaring jumps and airy elegance Thursday night, winning an Olympic gold medal and her rightful place as one of the greatest women's figure skaters of any era. Demonstrating technical superiority and ethereal grace at 19, Kim delivered a world-record performance of 228.56 total points. Math alone cannot fully describe the resourcefulness, complexity and artistry of her skating, except in this context: Kim would have finished ninth in the men's competition, nearly 10 points ahead of the American national champion, Jeremy Abbott.

RAVINA--Oscar, NY Philharmonic violinist, professor of music at Montclair State College, beloved teacher, husband, father, and grandfather, died at home on February 25th after a long illness, comforted by hospice care. Born in Warsaw in 1930, Ravina studied at the Leningrad Conservatory, and continued his studies after World War II at the Bruckner Conservatory and the Academy of Music in Vienna. Encouraged to emigrate to the US by Isaac Stern, he arrived in New York in 1950 and worked at the Radio City Music Hall before joining the New York Philharmonic in 1963. As a Philharmonic musician he worked with the greatest conductors of his generation and performed on five continents. Active in chamber music he co-founded and led the Philharmonia Virtuosi of New York and the Ravina String Quartet and performed with the New York Philharmonic Chamber Ensembles. A devoted, passionate, and beloved teacher, he was named professor emeritus after his retirement from Montclair State University, where he taught for over twenty-five years. He is survived by his wife, Ruth Ravina, his sister (Rochelle Rubin of Montclair), two sons (Mark Ravina of Atlanta and Bernard Ravina of Rochester), and seven grandchildren. A funeral service will be held on Sunday February 28th, at 1pm at the Jewish Memorial Chapel, 841 Allwood Road, Clifton, NJ 07012, (973-779-3048). In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to the Oscar Ravina Talent Grant in Music, Keith Wiggs, Montclair State University, Upper Montclair, NJ 07043 (973-655-3443).

DOHERTY--Henry Joseph, passed into eternal life on February 23, 2010. Beloved husband of Patricia. Dear brother of Kay and sister Jane Doherty, O.P. Loving stepfather of Mary Ellen Larkin, Siobhan Duffy, Allison Gallagher and Patricia McCormack. Dear uncle of Michele Wyllie, George and Michael. Loving step-grandfather of nine and great-uncle of nine. Reposing at the Lloyd Funeral Home, 214-43 39th Ave., Bayside, NY, Saturday and Sunday 2-5 and 7-9pm. Mass of the Resurrection Monday 10:45am at St. Kevin Church. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations should be directed to the American Cancer Society.

SOYER--David. The musicians, staff and trustees of Marlboro Music share the loss of a beloved member of its community with his wife Janet and his family. From his first summer in 1961 to the founding of the Guarneri Quartet at Marlboro in 1964 to his return as dynamic mentor for the last thirty years, David gave most generously of his music and himself. He was an inspiration to us all. The entire Marlboro Family will miss him dearly.
LEVY--Arthur. Happy Birthday Darling. You are loved and remembered today and everyday. Your Family

CARR--John D.,Jr., died on February 14th. Retired radio and television personality on WNYC. Member of AFTRA and SAG. Survivors include his widow Winnifred, son John Donald Carr III, and sister Donna Truby.

GITTELL--Marilyn Jacobs, Ph.D.,78, died February 26, 2010 at her home in the East Village. Lifelong resident of New York City and Sag Harbor. Professor of Political Science at The Graduate School CUNY and Director of The Howard Samuels Center. Renowned scholar and respected social activist. Loving wife of the late Irwin Gittell; devoted mother of daughter Amy and her husband Tom, son Ross and his wife Jody; beloved grandmother to Brett, Molly, Rose and Grace. Service: Sunday, February 28, 11:45am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to: M. and I. Gittell Endowed Fellowship Fund at CUNY, 365 Fifth Ave., Suite 8204, New York, NY 10016.

WASHINGTON -- The House ethics committee cleared seven members of Congress on Friday of official charges of wrongdoing in a lobbying scandal despite a separate, independent investigation that cast a harsh spotlight on the pay-to-play culture in Washington. In a harshly worded report that closed out its inquiry into the charges, the Office of Congressional Ethics -- created in 2008 as an independent, professionally staffed monitor of internal ethics questions -- found that private contractors who received millions in defense industry earmarks from the seven lawmakers generally believed that their political contributions to the members facilitated the financing their companies received.

ROSENBLATT--Daniel, Ph.D. In loving memory of Daniel Rosenblatt who died on February 24, 2009. A resident of Manhattan, Southold, NY and Fort Lauderdale, FL. Better health does not seem to explain why so many young people forgo health insurance. Rather, income does, according to new survey data released by Gallup. One of the explanations for rising health care costs is that relatively healthy people are taking their chances and going without insurance.

KAHN--Gilbert Stanley, born March 11, 1928 in New York City, devoted son of the late Janet Annenberg Hooker and the late L. Stanley Kahn, died suddenly on Monday, February 22, 2010 at his Palm Beach home. Mr. Kahn was a nephew of the late Ambassador Walter H. Annenberg. He was active in numerous philanthropic organizations in Miami, Palm Beach, New York City and Newport, RI. He was deeply committed to the world of purebred dogs (judging, showing, and breeding), Chairman of The AKC Museum of the Dog, former director of The Metropolitan Opera, and a member of the board of overseers for the University of Pennsylvania School of Veterinary Medicine. Gilbert will be greatly missed by his family and friends. He will be lovingly remembered and his kindness will always be with us. He is survived by his son John Noffo Kahn, his brother Donald Paul Kahn, his nieces Alexandra Kahn Graubert and Julie Kahn Brown, his nephews Donald Paul Kahn, Jr., Douglas Thompson Kahn, and Stephen David Kahn, and by four grand nieces and three grand nephews. A private service and interment will be held in New York.

For most young American soccer players, the road to the pros -- whether in Major League Soccer or abroad -- usually begins as a precocious sprout, jersey reaching past his knees in the beehives of youth soccer. From there, it is on to club soccer, soccer in high school and either a pit stop in college or, for the elite, perhaps a tryout with a European, M.L.S. or Mexican club.

INDIANAPOLIS -- Quarterbacks work out at the scouting combine Sunday. If, in fact, any of them were planning to do anything. Most of the big-name quarterbacks do not plan to throw here, preferring to wait for their college's pro days, when they can throw to familiar receivers. That's understandable for quarterbacks like Sam Bradford, Jimmy Clausen and Colt McCoy, all of whom are recovering from injuries. But the decision by others hasn't pleased many coaches and general managers, who wanted to see quarterbacks -- the healthy ones, at least -- throw on neutral ground. (Central Michigan's Dan LeFevour irked them in particular, because he is healthy and, unlike Tim Tebow, is not revamping his throwing motion.)

INDIANAPOLIS -- Chris Johnson's combine 40-yard dash record of 4.24, set in 2006, appears to be safe this year, but not by much. On Sunday morning, Clemson receiver Jacoby Ford, who is listed at 5-foot-9 and 186 pounds, was unofficially clocked running the 40 in 4.28 and 4.27 seconds. That's blazing fast, but the official times are usually a few ticks slower.
Readers are sharing their photographs from the Chile earthquake.
After an 8.8-magnitude earthquake, residents of Santiago are seeking refuge where they can. Park benches have become beds, and cars have become bedrooms.

As my colleagues Alexei Barrionuevo and Marc Lacey report, more than 2 million have been displaced by Saturday's 8.8 magnitude earthquake off the coast of Chile. The country's president said the death toll now stands at 708 and is expected to rise. My colleague Martin Fackler reports from Japan that there was widespread relief around the Pacific that the earthquake did not cause a deadly tsunami, as a larger earthquake off Chile did in 1960.

GRAHAMSTOWN, South Africa -- Most South African towns have a kind of parallel city close by; the township, where thousands of people live in tiny, close-packed houses or self-made shacks, often several families to the one room that constitutes the house. Yesterday, as part of their U.S. State Department tour, the Evidence Dance Company spent the day in the township of Joza, a short drive away from the wide, tree-lined streets and Victorian houses of Grahamstown, where they are based for several days.

He was the workout warrior who wowed the 1995 scouting combine, running and lifting so well that he went from a third-round prospect to a top-10 pick, only to turn into a cautionary tale about putting too much stock in performance at combine drills. The Eagles traded up to take Mamula seventh over all, passing up Warren Sapp, the defensive tackle who anchored Tampa Bay's defense and is almost certainly on his way to the Hall of Fame.

GRAHAMSTOWN, South Africa -- Saturday was the first working day in South Africa for members of the Evidence Dance Company, one of three troupes (Urban Bush Women and ODC/Dance are the others) chosen for a series of monthlong tours to different continents, all funded by the State Department. DanceMotion USA, as it's called, is the first time in decades that dance has played a major role as an official instrument of cultural exchange; the State Department is dedicating $1 million to this program, and plan for it to continue, according to Maura Pally, the acting assistant secretary at the Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs. "This administration is very keen on people-to-people diplomacy," Ms. Pally said by telephone. "The scope of audiences we can reach with this kind of programming is unparalleled, but it's a personal connection too."

Being the key player on a team that finished with more than 50 victories in each of the last two seasons was apparently not enough for center Dwight Howard of the Orlando Magic. Nor were his four trips to the All-Star Game, his slam-dunk contest title in 2008 or his Defensive Player of the Year award in 2009. On Wednesday, he did something that had not been done since the 1968-69 season, scoring 30 points, grabbing 16 rebounds and not missing a field goal. The player whose accomplishment he matched: Wilt Chamberlain.

Along with vibrant cultural and night-life scenes, another thing New York and Istanbul share in common is the talent of the saxophonist and impresario Ilhan Ersahin. Born in Stockholm, Mr. Ersahin now lives in New York, where in 2002 he opened Nublu, a small downtown club known for its eclectic programming and general good times (he also runs a small record label with the same name). He has recorded extensively in New York and Istanbul.

Most online travel guides focus on the obvious -- the Eiffel Tower, say, or the Pyramids of Giza. Not Atlas Obscura. The Web site (atlasobscura.com) has the opposite goal: highlighting the oddest places the world has to offer, ''places that are evocative of wonder, that provoke one's sense of curiosity and that might be underappreciated or undercelebrated,'' said Joshua Foer, a co-founder of the site. The site is organizing Obscura Day on March 20, with guides and ticketing for some 50 events (and counting), many of which were suggested by its readers.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ending Saturday, February 13th 2010, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Among those categories not actively tracked are: perennial sellers; required classroom reading; text, reference and test preparation guides; journals and workbooks; calorie counters; shopping guides; comics and crossword puzzles. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

In-store/Browns She may be a fashion-world legend, but Joan Burstein, whose groundbreaking London emporium turns 40 this year, isn't one to rest on her laurels. She presides over six locations, including a free-standing shoe salon and a men's shop, where she continues to introduce customers to the latest and greatest designers. ''I like to think I have a good instinct, but I'm still learning every day,'' she says. ''These are much more challenging times, but they are also a lot more interesting.'' Go to brownsfashion.com. Sandra Ballentine 1. In a season bursting with pretty blossoms, Burstein's favorite floral is this strapless number by Alexander McQueen (about $4,300). ''It's summery, fresh, and the shape is super-flattering because it shows off your décolletage,'' she says. She would accessorize it with a pair of Loree Rodkin diamond earrings and a simple VBH silk clutch in ivory or nude.

The sartorial forecast this spring calls for ruffles with a chance of flowers and prints. But what's in store for your romantic get-up when the seasonal rains roll in? Instead of ruining it with a frumpy discount umbrella, raise it to new heights with couture coverage from Parasolerie Heurtault. Obsessed with umbrellas since childhood, the French artisan Michel Heurtault opened this Parisian atelier-boutique in 2008 after 20 years of working as a costume designer and corset maker for film, theater and fashion. Through the windows of the vaulted shop, clients can watch him construct made-to-measure umbrellas and parasols using waterproofed and UV-protected silk, taffeta, linen and cotton, then hand-finish them with button fixtures instead of snaps. ''Umbrellas have been vulgarized as disposable objects,'' says Heurtault, who's committed to creating silhouettes as sturdy as they are stylish. ''When beautifully designed, they can give instant allure and attitude to a chic ensemble while providing ultimate protection and comfort.'' Go to parasolerieheurtault.com. Zeva Bellel

FAINBLATT--Martin of NYC and Hillsdale, NY. Beloved Husband of Charlotte. Cherished and devoted father of Lynn Wertheim (James) and Lori Fodale (Patrick). Loving and adored grandfather of Jacqueline Vanderburgh (David), Robert Wertheim, Alexander Wertheim and Hannah Fodale. Brother of the late Robert Fainblatt. Loving brother-in-law of Susan and Dr. Jeffrey Rudnick and Dr. Philip and Muriel Altus. Affectionate uncle to nieces and nephews. His was a wonderful personality with a loving heart. Her Right Brain -Diane Keaton, who grew up in Southern California and whose favorite thing to do in life is ''cutting out pictures and dreaming,'' fell in love with magazines and imagery as a young girl. Her mother, whom Keaton describes as having had ''one of the great faces,'' set the standard for Diane and her three younger siblings by collaging everything in sight, including wastebaskets; she also kept numerous collage-journals, and Keaton has followed suit, although she no longer painstakingly pastes the images in. ''I put them in plastic and double up on the sides. More bang for the buck.'' Absolutely anything and everything can catch her vigilant, foraging eye, from the photo of a dog -- ''That is the most beautiful dog. I was very drawn to that dog. I'm nothing but a sap'' -- to a piece of fabric or a particular font. ''I like patterns -- plaids and stripes and polka dots -- as well as shapes, numbers and words.'' She considers a 1950s photo of her family standing in front of their car (below left) ''heartbreakingly ordinary and perfect. It's Everypicture, like Everyman.'' House Proud - Keaton, who is besotted with architecture and is doing her second book for Rizzoli on architectural style, inherited her love of houses from her father, who was a civil engineer. ''He used to take me when I was little to model homes. I thought they were dream homes.'' She has taken this interest to heart, using her keen visual sense and admiration for certain vernacular styles -- ''For the past 15 years, I've been extremely excited about Spanish colonial homes'' -- to energetically renovate several houses of her own, and three of them landed Architectural Digest covers. She has a preference for wood, is particularly drawn to kitchens and if she had her way would buy an old factory building and move it. ''Old material has a patina, a sense of emotion.'' Lately Keaton has been excited about barn structures -- ''It's a basic American look that's very appealing to me'' -- and feels a kinship with inventive regional architects like Tom Kundig, Howard Backen and Roy McMakin. ''I'm very interested in how one lives one's life within one's home. It's a safe confine within the crazy world we live in.''

LONG TIME Ekpe Udoh, left, had 20 points and blocked 7 shots while playing in his home state as No. 24 Baylor won at Oklahoma, 70-63, for its first victory in Norman since 1977. LONGER TIME California (20-9, 12-5 Pacific-10) clinched at least a share of its first conference title since 1960 (when the league was known as the Pac-8) by beating visiting Arizona State, 62-46.

MERCY--Sue B.,68, of New York City, born in Brooklyn, NY to the late Irving and Muriel Bernstein, passed away on February 26, 2010 after a determined and courageous battle against cancer. She was at home surrounded by family. Sue is survived by her adoring husband Gene, her partner for 46 years in all of the joys and sorrows of life, her beloved children, Tod, Andy, and daughter-in-law Molly, her wildly adored grandchildren, Baxter, Jasper, and Emily, and her brother Jay Bernstein. Sue attended Great Neck High School, and graduated in 1963 from Connecticut College. For those who knew her, Sue's vital presence felt like a force of nature. Apart from her devotion to her family, Sue's life was filled with friends and her love for music, art (especially modern art), the great outdoors and sport. Sue brought people together; she had a joyous sense of fun and the capacity to make everyday life feel like a celebration. From the beginning of her adult life, Sue was passionate and unstinting in her charitable work. Among other efforts, for thirty years she supported the New York Philharmonic, serving on its Board of Directors; she was on the Board of Directors of Humanity in Action International, and of Young Audiences; and she was a Trustee Emeritus of Connecticut College. She leaves a hole in the hearts of all those who loved her. A funeral service will be held on Tuesday, March 2 at 11am at Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue and 55th Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Sue's favorite organizations: Humanity in Action, The New York Philharmonic, and Young Audiences.

JEFF KOONS, at 55, is one of the world's most famous living artists. And every night before drifting off to sleep in his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, he is able to survey the salmon-pink walls of his bedroom and commune with a small pantheon of the most famous artists of centuries past. In one corner hangs an early-16th-century painted bust of a hollow-cheeked, very tender-looking Jesus by Quentin Massys, the first important painter of the Antwerp school. Across the way, perhaps reflecting Mr. Koons's love of mingling the sacred and the profane, a risqué Fragonard stares back, showing a young woman cradling a pair of puppies at her bared breasts. But for the most part this extremely private collection, piled up salon style on the walls, seems far more classicist than Koonsian, like an eccentric little gallery transplanted from the Met: Manet, Courbet, Poussin and scholars' delights like Nikolaus Knüpfer and Cornelis van Haarlem.

You flew all the way down here from New York just to come to this place?'' says the guy behind the counter at the Marni outlet in Orlando, Fla., incredulous that two women of seemingly reasonable intelligence -- this would be me and my friend Laura -- would travel a thousand miles to chase a bargain on a saggy sack dress or a cashmere sweater with elbow patches. But hey, did anyone question Jack Kerouac and Neal Cassady when they crossed the country in search of hot chicks and enlightenment? They may have trekked in service of the dharma, but Laura and I -- and thousands of other women just like us -- are members of another powerful cult, one that worships the oddly charming Italian clothes, sort of a cross between Raggedy Ann on a bender and Sophia Loren in ''Two Women,'' that bear the Marni label.

BARELY discernible makeup may be the beauty trend du jour, but those mavens of maquillage Cyndi Lauper and Lady Gaga never got the memo. ''I have a huge suitcase full of the stuff,'' said Ms. Lauper, who is composing the music for the Broadway adaptation of the movie ''Kinky Boots.'' ''I am just sorry I only have one face to put it all on.''

''I am cursed to be in this Mother Hubbard body,'' Alice Neel once remarked of her grandmotherly image. The artist's sensitivity to nuances of style and gesture informs the portraits in ''Alice Neel: Painted Truths,'' a retrospective opening next month at the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston. Since her portrait work was largely uncommissioned and did not require that she flatter the sitter, ''you get a sense of how people really looked,'' says Barry Walker, who, with Jeremy Lewison, curated the show. That's as true for the cheerful Fuller Brush man and Dachau survivor who showed up on her doorstep in 1965 as it is for the art-world elites who (eventually) posed for her -- including the Factory's Ritta Redd and Jackie Curtis (right) and Andy Warhol himself, seminude and scarred. (Neel was notorious for sweet-talking her subjects out of their clothes.) When faced with truly stylish subjects, like the art-world players John Gruen and Jane Wilson and their daughter, Neel focused on the psychological -- the self-assured couple and the young girl, hunched like a figure out of Munch -- but she didn't neglect the clothes. The painting's pet name: ''Six Patent Leather Shoes.'' LESLIE CAMHI

While he tried to slash a canvas in the National Gallery, he did not succeed in doing so. The error was repeated on Feb. 7, Feb. 14 and last Sunday.

SCHACK--Samuel D. "Don", professor and former chair of the Department of Mathematics at the State University of New York at Buffalo, died on February 9, 2010 after a battle with cancer. He was 57. Schack graduated from the University of Pennsylvania in 1974 where he went on to earn a doctoral degree in mathematics before joining the UB faculty in 1981. An expert in the areas of algebra, homology, deformation theory and quantum groups, Schack was active in UB faculty governance, serving on the Faculty Senate and the senate's Executive Committee. "He was a thoughtful commentator, critic and-once a proposal was refined and improved-effective supporter of many actions by the senate and its executive committee during his service," noted William H. Baumer, professor of philosophy and longtime member of the Faculty Senate. Professor Schack is survived by his sister Elizabeth Silver-Schack, his brother-in-law Larry A. Silver of Philadelphia, his nephew Zachary James Silver and niece Laura Ruth Silver. A memorial service on the UB campus is planned in the fall. Donations in Schack's name may be made to the Martin House Restoration Corporation, 617 Main St., Buffalo, NY 14203.

CRANDALL--Therese. Terry DeGrace Crandall died February 19, 2010 at age 85 in Briarcliff Manor, NY. She died at home after a long illness. Born in Athol, MA to Alfred and Alice DeGrace. An alumna of Wellesley College ('45). Married Robert Wilson Crandall (deceased) of Rochester, NY in 1949. A long-time resident of Briarcliff, and owner of Yellowplush Antiques. She is survived by her loving family: Five children and their spouses, 10 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Services will be held March 6 at 2pm at Ossining Children's Center, 92 South Highland Ave., Ossining, NY. Donations in her honor may be made to Ossining Children's Center and Ossining Open Door Family Health Center.

NEWTON--John Crawford, of Redding, CT, died peacefully in his sleep February 21st at age 95. Born to Howard and Anna Newton, September 22, 1914, in Philadelphia, PA. He was predeceased by his brother Howard, sister Dorothy Stephens and eldest daughter Jo-Ann Vercoe (Will) Moody (Stan). He is survived by his beloved wife of 70 years, Angelita (Alonso), daughters Nancy duBusc (Richard), Pamela Newkirk (Ben), eight grand and eight great-grandchildren who span the globe. Starting in the mailroom in 1933 he worked his way up to President and Director of the Near East Development Corp. at Mobil Oil in its New York and London offices. He later ran Mobil's Marine and Trading Companies in Bermuda where he lived for 36 years. Retiring from Mobil in 1978 he worked for several Bermuda companies until age 92 when he and his wife moved to Redding. There, at 93, he wrote the "Story of the Iraq Petroleum Company". He was a member of the Royal Bermuda Yacht and Mid-Ocean Clubs. He loved his piano, his banjo, golf and swimming. He was a clear thinker and a great adviser with a keen sense of humor. He will be dearly missed by his family and all who knew him. Donations may be made to the National MS Society.
SOYER--David. David will be missed by his many admirers and friends. He was a man of the biggest heart and kindness. Our thoughts are with Janet. Midori, violinist

SATYAPAL--Dr. K.N. (Pal), 79, who retired in 1990 from the United Nations Development Program (UNDP), passed away in Maryland on January 26, 2010. Pal came to the United States from India by cargo ship in the 1950's, while only in his 20's. Despite huge obstacles and losing his father, he worked hard and received a Ph.D. from Michigan State University (MSU) in agriculture and soil sciences. He chose a path of service, working for the Food and Agriculture Organization in Kabul and Tanzania, and moved to New York in 1965, recruited by UNDP. In 1962, he married Thunga, a physics professor, and had three daughters. Pal received the Distinguished Alumni Award from MSU and was honored by the Consultative Group on International Agricultural Research in The Hague for his "untiring, devoted, and outstanding services in support of their efforts to help alleviate hunger and poverty through scientific research." Pal's kindness, humor and pure child-like spirit touched the hearts of many. He opened his Kew Gardens' home of 25 years to many people until they were settled. Fluent in several languages, he had an outstanding memory and remembered hundreds of birthdays. He was known for his love of animals, music (his whistling and mimicry) and gardening, including growing banana trees and many plantings at the Maryland temple. Pal is survived by his beloved wife, three daughters (Sunita, currently chief engineer of the United States Department of Energy's Fuel Cell Program; Shobita, an astrophysicist and professor in the Department of Physics and Astronomy at George Mason University; and Shanti, a research analyst at the Institute for Defense Analyses), four grandchildren, and many devoted friends and relatives. Donations in his memory may be made to UNICEF or Sankara Nethralaya: A Mission for Vision (http://omlog.org/). See: pumphreyfuneralhome.com

THE NEWS The Vermont Senate voted 26 to 4 to deny renewal of the operating license for the state's only nuclear power plant; the license expires in 2012. BEHIND THE NEWS After decades in the political wilderness, the nuclear industry had been gaining favor, with President Obama recently announcing $8.3 billion in loan guarantees to build a new plant in Georgia. But a history of radioactive leaks at the aging Vermont Yankee plant and misstatements in testimony by plant officials challenged claims by nuclear advocates that nuclear plants were clean, well run and worth building.

In 1829, a year before Belgium gained independence from Holland, Charles Delvaux founded what would become the world's oldest luxury leather-goods company. Now pushing 200, Delvaux continues to make bags in small runs signed by master craftsmen. Which doesn't mean the label isn't looking toward the future. It has forged bag collaborations with the designer Bruno Pieters, the model Hannelore Knuts and the Belgian avant-gardist Natalia Brilli, who wraps watches and objects in taut lambskin. But Delvaux's biggest score to date was hiring Veronique Branquinho as artistic director. ''It's a legendary brand with a great history,'' says Branquinho, who in addition to reworking existing classics is introducing several new bag styles for spring -- most notably a deep-blue duffel and a buttery beige envelope (right). ''Many years ago, I received my first Delvaux from friends who purchased it at a vintage store,'' she says. ''It's still contemporary and beautiful after all these years.''

''Do you need change?'' Funny you should ask, because I just gave you a $10 bill, and my latte and raspberry scone came to $5.75. As much as I think you're pleasing to look at, and you do magical things with frothy milk, I just don't see your services commanding a 70-plus percent premium over the market rate for my breakfast.

If fashion is all about performance, then Chantal Thomass is a master player. Anyone familiar with the French designer instantly associates her with blunt-cut jet fringed hair, crimsonlips and a strict black and white wardrobe with an enticing bit of lingerie coyly on display. There may or may not be a corset in the mix, and a satin whip or feathered tickler might be tucked away somewhere in a tufted boudoir. The look is equal parts dominatrix and ''I can have it all'' workingwoman. This season, designers swung from one end of the style spectrum to the other: Gaultier and Dior had sultry sexpots flashing underwear as outerwear, while Chanel and Jil Sander, among others, went back to nature with bucolic peasant garb and frocks with frayed edges. But for Thomass, this dichotomy is old hat. In fact, before the lingerie-baring shows she held from the 1970s until the mid-'90s, she was a bit of a flower child.

CIMMET--Eve Hlavaty Cimmet, died on February 25 from cancer. Eve: wife, mother, grandmother, teacher, writer, artist, actress, photographer, hostess, puzzler and a huge fan of the New York Yankees. On March 14, between 10 and 3, family and friends will gather at 16 Gunstock Rd, Scarborough, ME.

Agyness Deyn is the latest model trying to make the transition to acting, but she's doing it via the art gallery rather than Hollywood. In ''Mean to Me,'' a visually sumptuous 12-minute film noir written and directed by David McDermott and Peter McGough, Deyn trades her gamine look for raven-hued finger waves and crimson lips -- all the better to deliver a blow to the head of her lover (the ''Law & Order'' star Linus Roache), wrestle him into the bathtub, tie him up and extort a sizable check. Set in the Great Depression and named for a popular song of the era, the artist duo's first scripted film chronicles the disastrous end of an affair. McDermott and McGough began collaborating 30 years ago, and capturing the essence of a time past has always been part of their work, so recreating the 1930s proved no challenge. Period-perfect down to its wallpaper, telephone and radio, McGough's Art Deco Manhattan apartment provided the set. Deyn's costumes, by Zac Posen, might as well be of that vintage. The Shalimar perfume and pearls, around which crucial plot points turn, were courtesy of Guerlain and Mikimoto, which underwrote the project. Deyn got the gig at the suggestion of McGough's pal Louie Chaban, director of Women Management. ''Peter asked for a girl who wanted to act,'' Chaban says. And can she? McGough proclaims: ''A star is born.'' Jean Nathan

Do you find walking tours too passive, like sitting through a boring lecture? Wish they were more like ''The Amazing Race,'' the popular CBS reality show? Then you might try Whaiwhai, a high-tech Italian touring game that is part ''Amazing Race'' and part treasure hunt, with a bit of DaVinci Code-style storytelling mixed in.

UTE MAHLER'S work is testament to the subversive role that fashion can play in an authoritarian state. Ms. Mahler, who studied graphics and hoped to become a photojournalist, took a job in 1977 at Sybille, one of three fashion magazines in East Germany. She focused not on extreme fantasy but on a heightened sense of reality. She presented women as strong individuals, concerned more with style than with the latest fashions (which weren't available anyway).

AUSTERER--Walter. We note with sorrow the passing of our member Walter Austerer and extend our sincerest condolences to his bereaved family. Rabbi Peter Rubinstein and President Kenneth Heitner, Central Synagogue of New York City

What is that scary loud sound like crunching, screeching metal? It's the Hummer being consigned to the scrapheap of history. Off to the two-car garage in the sky. General Motors said on Wednesday that it was retiring the limping hulk after plans to sell the brand to China's Sichuan Tengzhong Heavy Industrial Machinery (for the un-Hummer-like sum of $150 million) fell through, and it didn't look like anyone else was lined up to bid. Hummer lumbered out of its battlefield beginnings and onto the American suburban scene in the early 1990s. Arnold Schwarzenegger had suggested the production of a civilian-ready model and proceeded to acquire a fleet of them. Hummer sales dropped 67 percent last year. Only 9,046 were sold.

Federal authorities investigating a Canadian doctor have uncovered information tying several N.F.L. players to the use of performance-enhancing drugs, according to several people who have been briefed on the investigation. The identities of the football players were not known.

LEDER--Michael R. Son of the late Shirley and Leon, devoted husband to Carol, father to Lee, brother to Neil. Touched everyone he knew. "You left your footprints in the sand." You're simply the best and will be sorely missed.

WEXLER--Jean Sigsbee Small, author (as Jean Arnold) and member of a prominent Washington family for four generations, died in her sleep at The Pines of Sarasota in Sarasota, FL on February 20. Ms. Wexler was educated at the Universities of Miami, Pittsburgh, and Rome. As a young woman, she worked as a reporter and editor in New York and Europe, serving as the first American woman correspondent in Germany (Stars & Stripes) after the 1945 liberation of Berlin. Ms. Wexler went on to teach English literature at the University of Pittsburgh and Bard College. Ms. Wexler was the author of three novels, including Prettybelle, which was adapted for Broadway, Fausto's Keyhole, and The Scissor Man under her nom de plume Jean Arnold. Ms. Wexler was born in Washington, DC in 1921 to Robert T. Small, one-time head of the Associate Press' southern division and Ethel Sigsbee Small, daughter of Rear Adm. Charles D. Sigsbee who commanded the Battleship Maine when it was blown up in Havana harbor. Ms. Wexler's great-grandfather, Commodore Henry H. Lockwood was a founder of the Naval Academy. She moved to the artist's colony Woodstock, NY in 1946, and was married to internationally renowned violist and author Frank Mele until 1960. In 1962 she married artist Fletcher Martin. The couple moved to Mexico in 1967, where they lived until his death in 1979. In 1985 she wed Jerry Wexler, record producer and part owner of Atlantic Records. The couple divided their time between New York and Florida until 2005. Mr. Wexler died in 2008. She is survived by her son, Andre Mele and his wife Lisa Rainwater; step-children Donovan Martin, Paul Wexler and Lisa Wexler; her granddaughters Paloma Mele and Tina Freligh; grandson Justin Lopez-Mena, and four great-grandchildren. A family service will be held in Sarasota, FL on February 23. A public service will be held at the Woodstock Artists' Cemetery in Woodstock, NY in June.

KINGSLEY--Walter. Television executive and community leader, died of heart failure in Portland, Oregon, February 6th, at age 86. A New York native and graduate of Amherst College, he was involved in many humanitarian causes. Walter was the proud co-founder of Big-Brothers/Big-Sisters of Greater Los Angeles, board member BB/BS of America, and a big brother to two wonderful little brothers. Among other professional accomplishments, he was the founding President of TV firm ITC, where he brought the first British program to CBS with Patrick McGoohan as Danger Man. Walter is survived by his children Janis Scott of Los Angeles; Sam of New York; Tom of Portland; six grandchildren; and his beloved companion of five years, Donna Benson, of Portland. He was predeceased by his son Jim, and brothers Jerry and Len, both of San Francisco. Contributions appreciated at Big Brothers Big Sisters of America, 230 N 13th St., Philadelphia, PA 19107.
