BERSON--Emanuel Dover, D.D.S.,on February 19, 2010 of Coconut Creek, FL. A decorated and heroic veteran of the Normandy Campaign and extremely dedicated dentist for over 50 years. He derived tremendous satisfaction from his work and relationships with patients and colleagues. Passionate about classical music, avid follower of politics and lover of golf, his generous spirit, sense of humor and exuberant personality endeared him to all. He is survived by his wife Vera, loving daughter Ellice, granddaughter Jessica, niece Andrea, and nephews Jeffrey and Gary. A memorial service will be scheduled in Manhattan.
Theater Charles Isherwood

BAJGER--Theresa G. (Terry). 1949-2009. With shocking suddenness on December 28, 2009, Terry died from a coronary attack. A quick end for her but for me and her family-Rose, Anna, Maryann, Betty, John and Joseph the loss of this beautiful woman haunts us. Terry was special. When she entered a room, it was brightened by her smile, quick charm and beauty, making everyone present happier. For ten years, Terry and I shared wonderful experiences daily and on our frequent travels. Those memories will live with me forever. I thank God for the wonderful gift he gave me-Terry Bajger. She is gone too soon. Joe

MAIER--Arthur I. With deep sorrow The Summer Camp community mourns the passing of Arthur I. Maier, father of our founder, Nancy Maier. Arthur and his wife Sue's dedication and steadfast support over the past 25 years has had immeasurable impact on our campers and our program. Our heartfelt condolences to the entire Maier family.

TRELSTAD--Robert, M.D.,a physician who focused his research on cell biology and innovations in medical education, died at home in Princeton, NJ on February 15 of Frontotemporal Dementia; he was 69. Born in Redding CA, and raised in Salem, OR, he graduated from Columbia University in 1961 and Harvard Medical School in 1966, where he worked with the pioneers of cell biology. He was a resident at the Massachusetts General Hospital and, in 1972, became an assistant professor at Harvard Medical School. From 1975 to 1981, he was Chief of Pathology at the Shriners Burns Institute in Boston. In 1981, he became Chair of Pathology at Robert Wood Johnson Medical School, in Piscataway, NJ, and in 1998 founded the Child Health Institute of New Jersey. He founded Keyboard Publishing, which developed computer-based learning products, and chaired the Health Professions Advising Committee at Princeton University. He is survived by his wife of 48 years, Barbara; two brothers, John and Donald; four sons, Derek, Graham, Brian, and Jeremy, and five granddaughters.
BRYAN--Diana, died February 22, 2010. Respected illustrator, teacher at Parsons for over 20 years. Loving life partner to Bob Pearl. We are heartbroken to lose Diana.

MILLIMET--James Andrew, 52, died in peace at the Barlow Respiratory Hospital, affiliate of the University of Southern California on February 25th in the loving presence of his father and brother. Jamie was born in Hastings-on-Hudson, New York, the younger son of Renee and Erwin Millimet and grandson of Henrietta and Maurice Millimet of New York City. Renee predeceased Jamie in 1988. Jamie was a graduate of Hackley School in Tarrytown, New York and attended the University Of North Dakota in Veterinary Medicine. He attended the Theatrical School of the University of California in Long Beach, following his mother and maternal grandmother, on stage with humor. He was a loving and gentle man who made people feel good and laugh. He was a well known stand-up comic in New York City, Los Angeles and Las Vegas under the name A.J. Millett. He was also a championship swimmer and spent much of his time helping young children with special needs through water activities under the name, Swimmingly Yours. He has been seen as an actor on nationally viewed television commercials. He was active in organizations concerning kindness to all animals, the preservation of the natural beauty of the land, and led a vegan lifestyle. He is survived by his father, his brother Robert of Los Angeles and his sisters, Rachel and Sarah of Longmeadow, MA, of whom he was so proud, and their mother Mary Millimet. A gathering to Celebrate Jamie's Life will be held on Tuesday, March 2nd from 7:00 9:00pm, with a service commencing at 7:30pm, at Forastiere Smith Funeral Home in East Longmeadow. Donations to celebrate Jamie's life may be made to any organization of personal choice, in loving help for children with special needs, to local animal shelters and to Hackley School.

ROSENBLATT--Daniel, Ph.D. In loving memory of Daniel Rosenblatt who died on February 24, 2009. A resident of Manhattan, Southold, NY and Fort Lauderdale, FL. His interest in the visual arts, theatre and the art of therapy will live on through the Rosenblatt Foundation, established by him in 1998. We miss him but he is with us still. James A. Pritchard

He was a collaborator with some of the great musical artists of the twentieth century. His charming wit, his profound humanity, and his extraordinary artistry will be deeply missed by us all. Backstage after their spring show, the designers Viktor & Rolf explained that because of the credit crunch, they had decided to ''crunch their couture'' -- literally, burrowing tunnels and cutting away slices in their extravagant tulle dresses. In the spirit of fashion's new D.I.Y. ethos, they offered this simple guide to reproducing their results. Have fun. 1. Purchase 149 yards of fine tulle for the skirt, 44 yards of stiffer tulle for the underskirt and 2.3 miles of very thin yarn, which you will use to sew the garment by hand.

Who needs the podium when you have the penthouse? A few days after Canada's Own the Podium program became an international joke because of the country's lackluster performance at the Vancouver Games, Canada has abruptly taken command of the medal table -- at least the column for the biggest prizes, gold medals.

CONRAD--Robert, 90, died in Ann Arbor, MI on February 18. He was born in New York City, received undergraduate and law degrees from New York University, and was a proud veteran of World War II, serving in the deception unit known as the "Ghost Army." He practiced law in New York City for nearly 60 years, served as president of the City Club of New York, and was active in Democratic Party politics at the local, state and national levels. He is survived by Esther, his beloved wife of 60 years, sons Dan of San Francisco and Fred of Ann Arbor, their wives Sarah Wilcox and Betsy Brooks, grandchildren Paul, Ted, Allison, and Jeffrey, and eight nieces and nephews. Bob loved the theater, ballet, and music; he was an enthusiastic and generous host, and loved a party. He and Esther were world travelers, always looking forward to their next trip. He was loved and respected by the many friends he made throughout his life. His friends and family will miss him always. Memorial contributions may be sent to Peoples' Symphony Concerts; Suite 703; 121 W. 27th Street; New York, NY 10001.

MERCY--Sue B. Sue, your passing leaves an incredible void in our life. Irrepressible and irreplaceable, you were a dear friend. Your light and joy graced our lives and will live on in our memory. Our hearts go out to Gene, Tod, Andy and Molly and your grandchildren. Murray and Susan

A clutch is one of those things that will be around for a while. They're just so classic, really -- I've got clutches from the '30s, in that envelope style that's really simple and not too overdone. This one is part of the collection that I just designed for Longchamp, and you can actually stuff a load of things in it and bash it around. The leather is textured to look like shagreen, which I love. Most bags are too heavy to carry things in, and so many of them are stiff, and you know it's going to take years to mess them up. I like things that are already worn in, something tactile that's going to be comfortable on your skin. When I was working on the collection, I showed it to my daughter, but she's a bit -- you know. She just said, ''Yeah, it's all right.'' She prefers bling and Hello Kitty. She says she doesn't like Hello Kitty anymore, but I know she really does. I mean, I love it, too. I just nabbed her Hello Kitty makeup bag, in fact. What can I say? I like a mismatch. Kate Moss, as told to Alexandra Marshall

KT AULETA In Paris, circa 2003, KT Auleta dropped off her photo portfolio at the offices of the avant-garde fashion magazine Self Service. Six months later, she got the call -- and a 20-page assignment. Not bad for a self-taught photographer. (If a friend hadn't given her a Yashica, she might still be performing in a noise band today.) These days she shoots routinely for V, Dazed & Confused, AnOther Man and Russian Vogue. In this issue's ''Strip'' section (Page TK), she shows that beige can be beautiful, and bold. ''I like the disposability of fashion,'' she says. ''You don't get attached.'' Auleta just completed ''Runaround,'' a short film ''about a slutty American girl growing up in a small town,'' which she's now sending to film festivals.

MAIER--Arthur I.,August 26th 1922 - February 27, 2010. Arthur died peacefully at home surrounded by his family after a long, heroic battle with pancreatic cancer. Arthur's passion for all the people he loved and the ideals he lived by each day will be missed by his family and friends. Arthur was a WWII Veteran, a lifelong New Yorker, a tireless leader of the fashion, accessories industry, an athlete and an accomplished bridge player. He fiercely supported his children (Bruce, Richard, Debi and Nancy) and Grandchildren (Julie, Jenni, Ilana, Andrew, Austin and Rebecca) in all of their endeavors. He treasured his time with his sister and brother-in-law, Judy and George. He loved Susie everyday for the past 57 years. The family will have a private burial. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to The Summer Camp 8 Church Street Bridgton, Maine 04022.

ALL-NIGHTERS To combat our ''culture of exhaustion,'' Americans spend nearly $24 billion a year on sleep-related goods and services, buying $5,000 mattresses, 600-thread count sheets and high-end sound machines that simulate the surf or chirping birds. By 2012, the market for insomnia drugs is expected to grow 78 percent, to nearly $3.9 billion. But with sleeping pills what are we really getting? They provide only an additional 11.4 minutes of sleep over placebo pills, and they interfere with memory formation, with the result that people sometimes forget how badly they actually slept. Some sleep doctors say if people perceive their sleep is better, they'll feel better. But that strikes me as ''Alice in Wonderland'' logic: ''I wonder if I've been changed in the night? Let me think. Was I the same when I got up this morning? I almost think I can remember feeling a little different. But if I'm not the same, the next question is, 'Who in the world am I?' '' -- Patricia Morrisroe, excerpt from

If the new barter economy means that you can trade a Dries Van Noten winter coat for last summer's Marni sandals, things can't be that bad. ReFashioner, a new invitation-only Web site, lets you swap your unwanted designer and vintage clothes for other couture castoffs. Kate Sekules, a New York writer, editor and Comme des Garçons addict, said the site was created for women who love ''good designers and good design -- and who like turnover.'' No money is exchanged, though a $5 fee is charged per trade. And while you wait to receive an invite from Anna Wintour, you can window-shop at refashioner.com. CHRISTINE MUHLKE

Vampires are so last decade -- these days, it's all about monsters. At the center of this scary trend is Lady Gaga, whose stage performances feature ''Thriller'' -style choreography and ghoulish costume changes. (Even Filipino prisoners helped push the trend with their famous YouTube video.) Alexander McQueen, who has cited Lady Gaga as an influence, recently showed an otherworldly collection accented with prosthetic makeup and podlike 10-inch reptilian platforms. Gareth Pugh also unleashed a legion of threatening, heavily powdered models in a broodingly romantic zombie romp, and Lanvin's disturbing new ad campaign stars the photographers Vinoodh Matadin and Inez van Lamsweerde -- the latter in full-body makeup that makes her look as if she's been skinned alive. Perhaps the house should consider a partnership with the jewelry designer Emily Miranda, whose chunky pieces feature flesh-ripping animal claws. The film world is also right on trend. Spike Jonze got things going with ''Where the Wild Things Are,'' which was followed by remakes of ''The Wolfman'' and, in theaters soon, ''A Nightmare on Elm Street.'' Natalie Portman has signed on for ''Pride and Prejudice and Zombies,'' and Tim Burton's dark directorial oeuvre is being celebrated in a career retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art through April 26. From a pop-psych perspective, this macabre obsession reads as a projection of the collective anxiety we're dealing with, given a glossy sheen to make it less scary. Wouldn't it be nice if instead of financial crises and terrorist attacks, all we had to worry about were things that go bump in the night?

D.I.Y./ (d w) /adj. / An acronym for ''do it yourself''; an apropos modifier at a time when resourceful designers are festooning the runways with enough embroidery, frayed seams and patchwork appliqués to rival a suburban crafternoon, e.g., 'I know a hundred nuns went blind making this homespun top, but as Rachel Zoe would say, I die for D.I.Y.'

1. Gaia Repossi tapped her friend Eugénie Niarchos to be co-designer of Nérée, a collection for her family's eponymous jewelry house. The Asian-inspired pieces include a ring that looks like a carving of Chinese jade and earrings that resemble Japanese floral prints. 2. Linn Lomo may hail from the Norwegian woods, but her first jewelry line is strikingly urban. After stints at street-centric houses like Elise Overland, Lomo wanted to create pieces that are beautiful but not too pristine. Her clusters of spheres and spikes swing toward the polished side of punk.

Nicolas Ghesquière is one of the fashion flock's great innovators, but his collections almost always carry a whiff of nostalgia. Fittingly, his first fragrance for Balenciaga also demonstrates his particular knack for keeping a respectful eye on the pastwhile forging a path to the future. With inspirations that range from the traditional (violet chypre, patchouli, cedar and carnations) to the more unusual (floor wax and gasoline), the resulting scent is ultimately modern enough for the likes of Charlotte Gainsbourg (above right, with Ghesquière), his muse and the face of the ad campaign. ''It has a sexy presence that's not at all about romanticism,'' he says. ''It's more urban -- a little sharp, even a little tough.'' Sandra Ballentine

HOVEY--Graham. After a long career of covering world affairs in the United States and abroad for newspapers, wire services and public radio, Graham Hovey joined The New York Times in 1965, serving on its editorial board for more than 12 years, then working in its Washington Bureau as a foreign-policy reporter until September of 1980. Mr. Hovey passed away Saturday, February 20, 2010 in the Luther Crest community in Allentown, PA. He retired from The Times in 1980 to become professor of communications at the University of Michigan and director of Michigan Journalism Fellows, a program that provides an academic year of study and research for journalists at or near mid-career. After his official retirement at 70 in 1986, Hovey remained at Michigan as a professor emeritus to teach a first-year seminar on "The Making of U.S. Foreign Policy." He and his wife, Mary Jean, moved in 1998 to the Luther Crest retirement community in Allentown, PA to be nearer their son, Thomas D. Hovey. Hovey attended what is now the University of Northern Iowa in Cedar Falls, but transferred to the University of Minnesota, where he became assistant city editor of the Minnesota Daily and took his BA in journalism and economics in 1939. After two years as a reporter on the Waterloo Daily Courier in Iowa, he joined the International News Service (INS) bureau in Detroit in 1940 and covered the beginnings of the conversion of Detroit-area industries for war production. Hovey became a full-time sports writer for INS in Chicago in October, 1941. He was covering an intra-city football game in Comiskey Park between the Bears and the Cardinals when he learned of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, December 7, 1941. This effectively ended Hovey's sports-writing career for he moved to the INS cable desk in New York in March, 1942, and sailed for Africa in May as an INS war correspondent. Hovey left INS late in 1944 to become a foreign-affairs reporter for the Associated Press in Washington. Two years later he joined the New Republic as an assistant editor. But in 1947 he changed course to pursue an MA in political science and history and teach journalism at the University of Minnesota. He moved in 1949 to the University of Wisconsin, where he rose to the rank of associate professor. He also broadcast a weekly program called "The Background of the News" over the university radio station WHA and nine affiliated stations of the Wisconsin State Broadcasting Service. In 1953, Hovey took leave from Wisconsin to accept a two-year Fulbright grant to Italy, where he was accredited to Radiotelevisione Italiana and broadcast a weekly "Letter from Italy" for member stations of the National Association of Educational Broadcasters, a forerunner of National Public Radio. He returned to Wisconsin for the 1955-56 academic year, then joined the editorial page staff of the Minneapolis Star and Tribune, since merged as the Star Tribune. But he also covered international crises at the United Nations, winning the Overseas Press Club of America award for "Best American Press Interpretation of Foreign Affairs" and sharing a National Headliners Club award for his U.N. coverage in 1958. He was then sent to London in January, 1959, as the Minneapolis Tribune's first European Correspondent. After nearly seven years of covering NATO, the evolution of the European Common Market and Community and recurring crises with the Soviet Union over Berlin, Hovey accepted an invitation from John B. Oakes to join the editorial board of The New York Times in 1965. He wrote editorial and occasional signed columns on U.S. policies in Europe, Africa and the Americas, and often visited those areas. Hovey was married June 20, 1941, in Waterloo, Iowa, to Mary Jean Landgraf, a graduate of Columbia University's School of Library Science, who worked in libraries in Iowa, New Jersey, Minnesota, Wisconsin and Washington, DC, in addition to serving as her husband's researcher for writing and lectures. She survives along with their son, Thomas D. Hovey, his wife, Barbara A. of Forty Fort, PA; three grandchildren, Attorney Matthew T. Hovey of Pottstown, PA, Carolyn B. Hovey of Forty Fort, David L. Hovey of Forty Fort. Also surviving are two nieces, Marjorie Eger of Indiana and Lois Schmoe of Florida. Services: Private at the convenience of the family. Services by Stephens Funeral Home, Inc. Please share on-line condolences at: www.stephensfuneral.com Contributions: In lieu of flowers, to Landgraf-Hovey Scholarship, University of Northern Iowa Foundation, 205 Commons, Cedar Falls, Iowa 50614 or the Salvation Army, 144 N. 8th St., Allentown, PA 18101.
Stuff that's spot on.

Back before fashion became a global corporate enterprise, it was a haven for deviants from the norm. Fey boys, gawky girls, misfits in their own homes and their own hometowns, they left their backgrounds behind and emigrated to the land of Style, where they were welcomed into the business of making and marketing illusion. In time, they landed jobs as designers, photographers, display directors, makeup artists, hairdressers, stylists, editors, arbiters. Brilliant but not atypical was Ara Gallant, né Ira Gallantz. He fled the family's Bronx beauty parlor and worked as a hairstylist on photo shoots before becoming a photographer himself. ''Ara Gallant'' (Damiani) brings together images by Richard Avedon and others, for which Gallant styled the hair; his own photos, including Interview covers; memories of Gallant by his friends, colleagues and celebrity subjects; and quotes from Gallant himself. (''I went into hair. . . . I hated it. But I was good at it. . . . I had always thought to be talented at something, you had to like it.'')

She is survived by her husband Paul, three sons Paul, Peter and Phillip and a granddaughter Rebecca. Her ashes will rest at Fort Rosecrans National Cemetery. All services will be private.

Each week on the City Room blog, editors select a New Yorker to answer reader questions. Here are excerpts from last week with Chuck Scarborough, an Emmy Award-winning anchor and correspondent at WNBC-TV. Coming this week: Lee Quinones, graffiti artist. Q. What defines a great local news story to you? What are you most excited to report on with regard to the New York metro area? cml A. I don't judge a story's greatness based on the topic, but on the execution. We'd like to avoid the crowds of Positano and find a town with a small hotel that is friendly and charming.

The Samurai Shopper, though possessed of boundless wisdom, is afflicted with a waggish skepticism -- chalk it up to experience. I had to abandon the passionate energies and utter stupidity of youth. There wasn't a choice; birthdays happened. I do miss my younger self, especially the part where I awoke each morning looking radiantly fresh, like a shiny penny in a mud puddle. Now it takes many, many shiny pennies to find illumination, which mainly comes from skin-care counters. Like the Doge's Palace in Venice, my exterior has borne the insults of time and seeks restoration to the alabaster glory that once was me. Besides, bright people don't deserve dull skin.

I HAD a sort of, maybe, what should have been a grand idea. On Monday night, I enlisted Aidan, my 17-year-old son, to take in a game between the New York Knickerbockers and the Milwaukee Bucks at Madison Square Garden. For aficionados of bad parental decision-making, this is akin to admitting that I enlisted Aidan to journey with me to a particularly banal version of purgatory.

WHAT happens when you cross the scion of a storied jewelry company with a chic nomad? In the case of Mario Buccellati and Carla Forte, it's a jewelry line called Prediletto, which means ''favorite'' in Italian. Their first collection, all handmade in Italy, nods to Ms. Forte's far-flung travels: necklaces inspired by the views from Versailles and from a Palladian villa outside Venice, and earrings that recall the chandeliers from her childhood home. Other pieces, like this $6,500 gold, sapphire and diamond gate pendant, are simply tiny sculptures of architectural elements the designer finds beautiful: (914) 218-8207. SANDRA BALLENTINE

The Wizarding World of Harry Potter, to open this spring at the Islands of Adventure theme park at Universal Orlando Resort, announced its first vacation packages for travel starting May 28. The four-night package starts at $285 for adults, $130 for children 3 to 9. The package includes moderately priced accommodations at a Universal Partner Hotel, like the Quality Inn International; early admission to the Harry Potter theme park; a three-day park ticket that allows entry to one Universal theme park each day; and breakfast at the Three Broomsticks, named for the fictional pub where Harry and his friends indulge in glasses of butterbeer. More upscale hotels, like the Hard Rock Hotel, are available for a higher price.

FORGET the bad books, phone chargers and tacky swimsuits in most hotel shops. The folks from Project No. 8, one of New York's more thoughtfully hip boutiques, have curated an out-of-the-ordinary hotel shopping experience. Elizabeth Beer and Brian Janusiak designed the store, No. 8a, in the trendy Ace Hotel in Manhattan, as a place to find useful objects and unusual souvenirs. You'll find underpinnings from Falke, Schiesser and VPL; the cult skin-care line In Fiore; accessories from Maison Martin Margiela, Christian Wijnants, Bless and Natalia Brilli; and ''Mementos,'' an amusing collection of curios -- Chinatown Soccer Club mugs, Statue of Liberty night lights and Krink graffiti markers -- gathered by the designers Josee Lepage and Tobias Wong. There's also a mini-outpost of Kiosk, a downtown shop that mounts exhibitions of household objects. 22 West 29th Street; (212) 725-0008. SANDRA BALLENTINE

The plan was for Sandra Laoura to return to Canada, the country where she lost the use of her legs. She would make her peace with the place and, at the same time, with the Olympics. But peace has been unexpectedly difficult to come by for Laoura, who won a bronze in moguls skiing at the 2006 Winter Games, in Turin, Italy, and is working here as a reporter for French television.

Before he was the creative director and founder of Acne, Jonny Johansson knocked around as a musician. So it's no surprise that the Swedish fashion label's first furniture collection takes its cues from the place where music and fashion meet: the remix. Take the Nya Berlin, a 1920s sofa designed for that city's Swedish embassy by the modernist Carl Malmsten. Johansson stretched and contorted the sofa's no-nonsense curves to arrive at five new variations, built in the south of Sweden and upholstered in cupcake shades of denim. Johansson says of his latest release: ''I have all these architect and designer friends who are inspired by fashion. I thought, Why not look at it the other way around?'' Jill Singer

KAHN--Gilbert Stanley, born March 11, 1928 in New York City, devoted son of the late Janet Annenberg Hooker and the late L. Stanley Kahn, died suddenly on Monday, February 22, 2010 at his Palm Beach home. Mr. Kahn was a nephew of the late Ambassador Walter H. Annenberg. He was active in numerous philanthropic organizations in Miami, Palm Beach, New York City and Newport, RI. He was deeply committed to the world of purebred dogs (judging, showing, and breeding), Chairman of The AKC Museum of the Dog, former director of The Metropolitan Opera, and a member of the board of overseers for the University of Pennsylvania School of Veterinary Medicine. Gilbert will be greatly missed by his family and friends. He will be lovingly remembered and his kindness will always be with us. He is survived by his son John Noffo Kahn, his brother Donald Paul Kahn, his nieces Alexandra Kahn Graubert and Julie Kahn Brown, his nephews Donald Paul Kahn, Jr., Douglas Thompson Kahn, and Stephen David Kahn, and by four grand nieces and three grand nephews. A private service and interment will be held in New York.

Fur and all its imitations were worn by many guests attending the recent New York Fashion Week, no doubt prompted at least in part by the bitter cold and snow. But fur also was paraded on the designer runways. Conspicuous by their absence were anti-fur protesters, who usually demonstrate at the site of the shows. Underscoring fashion's capricious nature, some women at the showings wore snow-white summer skirts.

With two wars on and a recent surge, military flourishes were all but axiomatic on the spring runways, leaving unenlisted designers looking less like conscientious objectors than ostriches in a state of denial. Balmain's Christophe Decarnin led the charge with camouflage patchwork smothered in gold sequins; Haider Ackermann had cargo pants and epaulet-tipped jackets in washed leather. Of course, this is all just a little bit of history repeating itself. In 19th-century Europe, women's wardrobes took on a military flavor thanks to the Napoleonic wars. Cavalry regiments loved passementerie -- and soon so did the ladies, who heaped braids, tassels and knots on hats, bodices and spencers. When World War II came around, Mainbocher created a uniform for the Waves (Women Accepted for Voluntary Emergency Service) that erased the line between service wear and civilian wear: stripped of their embellishments, the four-button jacket and six-gore skirt were intended as a day suit for peacetime.

In the rolling Piedmont hills of North Carolina, potters were turning out fine work before the American Revolution. But by the 20th century, the tradition had faltered. Two passionate women, a half-century apart, saved it. Nancy Sweezy, who died on Feb 6. at 88 in Cambridge, Mass., was the second.

MERRILL--Harvie M. IV, Age 88, of Winter Park, FL, died February 19, 2010 of natural causes. He was the loving and devoted husband of Mardelle Merrill for 66 years and the caring father of Susan Merrill Rosoff of Winter Park and Merrill Ashley of New York City. Born in Detroit MI, he graduated at the top his class at Purdue University with a degree in chemical engineering. He was a member of the Sigma Phi Epsilon fraternity, Scabbard & Blade, and Tau Beta Pi Engineering Honor Society. He did graduate work at Yale University and served in World War II as a captain in the US Army Air Corps. He had a long career at Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Co. Later, he became Vice-President of Stauffer Chemical Co. before becoming President of Hexcel Corp. in San Francisco. As Chairman and CEO there, he initiated international divisions of the company in Paris, London and Brussels and brought the company to listing on the New York Stock Exchange. He and his wife were 35-year residents of Nob Hill in San Francisco. While there, he was a member of The Pacific Union Club, The Bohemian Club, and Burlingame Country Club. He also served on the boards of the French American School, the California Pacific Medical Center, and was active at Grace Cathedral. He is survived by his wife, daughters, grandson Christopher Merrill Rosoff, and great-granddaughter Hannah Merrill Rosoff. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Grace Cathedral Music Dept. would be appreciated. www.gracecathedral.org/ welcome/overview

Not long ago at some ungodly hour of the morning I saw an early Charles Bronson movie ("Showdown at Boot Hill") in which the tough-guy actor played a bounty hunter driven by the fact that he was very short. Bronson (Luke Welch) spends some time explaining to his love interest that his entire life, including his decision to strap on a gun, has been a response to the humiliations visited on him because of his diminutive stature. Synopses of the movie on the Internet either do not mention this prominent aspect of the plot or touch on it only in passing, perhaps because it seems so much at odds with the figure Bronson cut (often semi-naked) in a series of famous movies - "The Magnificent Seven," "The Great Escape," "Hard Times," "Chato's Land," "Mr. Majestyk" and, of course, in what sometimes seemed to be a series of innumerable and increasingly violent "Death Wish" movies.Bronson is by no means the only action star whose larger than life screen persona was or is at odds with his "real-life" statistics. (Just what those statistics are is often debated on Web sites where there may be a three-inch variation in the height assigned to a particular actor.) The pattern was set in the 1930s and '40s by Edward G. Robinson ("Little Caesar"), James Cagney, George Raft, Humphrey Bogart and Paul Muni - all small men who usually played tough and cruel. Sometimes camera angles obscured the physical facts -

A new museum on the life of Frédéric Chopin has opened on the composer's 200th birthday in his native country, Poland. GRAHAMSTOWN, South Africa -- Members of the Evidence Dance Company are serving as cultural ambassadors on their State Department-sponsored tour of Africa, but the flip side is that the Americans are being exposed to other cultures, too. "It's very much about learning from, as well as sharing with," said Nathan Holt, public affairs officer at the U.S. consulate in Cape Town, who was in Grahamstown Monday to watch the company perform for an audience of schoolchildren from surrounding areas. On their one day off in Senegal, a week ago, the troupe visited what had been a slave house on Gorée Island, just over a mile away from Dakar's harbor. "You read about this in history in school," said Arcell Cabaug, the associate artistic director of Evidence. "But it's very different standing there in the cell. You call feel the pain, imagine the screams. They don't teach you that."

With the proliferation of 24-hour news channels, the bar for what gets covered live on television these days has been lowered quite a bit since, say, the moon landing. Last year, for instance, people around the planet watched an unboyed balloon float above Colorado for hours. Last Saturday, hours after the catastrophic earthquake in Chile, Chilean television was broadcasting live images of Hawaii's coastline to its viewers, just in case a deadly tsunami appeared.

The plot of "Logan's Run": An idyllic sci-fi future has one major drawback: life must end at 30.In the N.F.L., it seems that life as a running back must end at 30. So by that measure, the Jets' Thomas Jones, who will be released by the Jets on Friday, has cheated fate. He has rushed for over 1,000 yards in each of the last five seasons, and he's 31. With one of the most imposing physiques in the N.F.L., he's not done. He just had an excellent season: a career-high 1,402 yards with 14 rushing touchdowns despite battling injuries and despite surrendering much of the work load to Shonn Greene.

Sometimes you can tell as much about the state of fashion by the way collections are presented as by the clothes themselves. It can't be a coincidence, for example, that both Dolce & Gabbana and Ferragamo kicked off their runway shows with nostalgic black-and-white films of cheerful, tireless atelier seamstresses producing "Made in Italy" garments. (The clips were enough to make even the most seasoned national populist propagandist green with envy.) Why the sudden obsession with heritage? It's not exactly that designers are scaling back to basics - there was enough fur in Milan to outfit a Yeti convention - but fashion houses are undoubtedly playing to their core audiences. And it wasn't just Dolce & Gabbana, with its emphasis on sensuality and Sicilian tailoring, or Ferragamo, with its quietly elegant town-and-country staples.

Duke Energy and PPL Energy are reportedly engaged in competing bids for the German power giant E.On's American operations, according to SparkSpread, an energy industry news Web site. The Kentucky-based utilities companies owned by E.On could fetch up to $6 billion, making it one of the largest power deals seen in the utility industry for quite some time.

The Insider is a recurring profile of tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. Here, the downtown D.J. Mike Nouveau declares his hardcore love for fashion, Diet Coke and friendship. Nouveau, who can be seen around fashion week wearing Comme des Garçons skirts, had recent gigs such as the 10-year anniversary party for Seven New York; the soft opening of night-life godfathers' Paul Sevigny and Nur Khan's Kenmare lounge; and Marc Jacobs's aftershow at the Standard Hotel's 18th floor.
Peter J. Henning follows issues related to white-collar crime for DealBook's White Collar Watch.

A. O. Scott gets ready for his close-up by looking back at the director Billy Wilder's meditation on fame and celebrity, "Sunset Boulevard" (1950). Following the life of Norma Desmond (Gloria Swanson), a star of the silent era whose fame has dissipated, the film looks at the glamor and the tragedy of life in the spotlight. "Sunset Boulevard" was nominated for eleven Academy Awards and won three. Please share your thoughts on the film.

Representative Nathan Deal, a Georgia Republican, will resign from the House next week, a move that likely gives the Democrats a little extra breathing room as they try to pass legislation overhauling the health care system. Mr. Deal's departure will leave 431 members in the House, meaning Democrats would, for the time being at least, presumably need 216 votes to pass their health care bill. Read the full story at The Caucus.

The Korean fried chicken chain Kyochon, which has more than 1,000 restaurants, including two in Queens, will open its American flagship on Wednesday in a sleek two-story red and white space that cost $2 million.

Bank of America's chief executive, Brian T. Moynihan, says he plans to vote for Representative Barney Frank of Massachusetts in November, praising Mr. Frank for balancing lender and consumer concerns as chairman of the House Financial Services Committee, Bloomberg News reports.
Interesting items from around the Web chosen by New York Times technology journalists:
The basic formula for gaining and losing weight is well known: a pound of fat equals 3,500 calories.

On its Web site, The Chronicle of Higher Education examines the concept of honors colleges, in which big public research universities set aside dedicated classroom and housing space within their walls for programs on the scale of small liberal arts colleges. The publication tallies more than 70 such programs and focuses on one in particular, at the University of South Carolina. It describes the South Carolina Honors College as marketing itself to students as "a place where they could take classes with just 8 or 10 other students, and then join a crowd of 80,000 in the football stadium.''

BTIG, a New York-based broker-dealer, said Monday that it was expanding its reach into equity research and  hiring two senior analysts, Richard Greenfield and Walter Piecyk, who previously worked at the now-closed Pali Capital, to lead the effort. The firm will focus on the media and telecommunications sectors and plans to eventually expand into other sectors.
A. O. Scott looks back at Billy Wilder's classic meditation on celebrity and Hollywood.
The online photo editing service Picnik announced Monday that it had been acquired by Google.

I visited my college-freshman son last week, and over pizza we talked about drinking. Part of pledging a fraternity means being the sober designated driver, I learned, and I was relieved that the the idea had become ingrained in college culture. Kids get it that driving while drinking is dangerous, right? Not exactly, he corrected. What they get is that a single D.U.I. means expulsion, and that's a concept students respect.

The heavy snowstorm in the New York City area last week, combined with the end of the traditional February school vacation period, made for a sluggish week at the Broadway box offices, with ticket sales dropping for most plays and musicals compared to the previous week.

During the Super Bowl, the 1-year-old son of New Orleans Saints quarterback Drew Brees was seen sporting ear muffs. As a story in today's Science Times explains, they were far more than a winter fashion statement.

In today's Cases column, Dr. Marc E. Agronin explores how often we make the wrong assumptions about old age. He tells the story of an elderly woman in a nursing home. He expected her to be grieving for her late husband, but instead found she had thrown herself into new activities and relationships.

Book a flight, save a life. That's the goal of MASSIVEGOOD, a new fund-raising initiative that allows travelers to make "micro-contributions" to global health causes when booking a plane, hotel or car.

James Levine has canceled appearances Wednesday, Friday and Saturday with the Berlin Staatskapelle, in Berlin, because of his doctors' recommendation that he not travel while they adjust his medication, said his representative, Ronald A. Wilford, the chairman of Columbia Artists Management. The medication is part of Mr. Levine's treatment following back surgery in October. "Nothing serious, thank God," Mr. Wilford said. Daniel Barenboim will step in for Mr. Levine on Wednesday and Saturday; the Friday concert, which was to be a benefit, will be rescheduled.
State and local government workers are much more likely to get hurt on the job than private sector workers, according to a new report from the Labor Department.

If you felt your heartstrings tugged just a bit too insistently during the Vancouver Olympics, you were not alone. Broadcasters and advertisers use the Games as an excuse to unload their stockpile of sentimentality, the kind of emotional words and images that don't go over so well during, say, the Super Bowl.

A businesswoman in Jackson Heights, Queens, who falsely promised to secure legal immigration status for dozens of illegal immigrants has been ordered to pay $3 million in restitution and penalties by the State Supreme Court, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Monday.

The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Milan Fashion Week. Here, the model Alla Kostromichova from Women before (top, bottom) and after makeup by Gordon Espinet and hair by Sam McKnight. (Drag the orange bar up to reveal the full transformation.)

The big international design fairs are a smorgasbord of ideas for editors and store buyers -- and occasionally even for designers themselves. The Dutch designer Ineke Hans, known for things like her chunky "Ordinairy" recycled plastic tables and benches and her charmingly sturdy carved wood Neo Country collection for Cappellini, is fresh from Ambiente, the enormous Frankfurt design fair, where she checked out the range of exhibitions on offer and cherry-picked her favorite treats.

The work of Tomás Munita Philippi, a freelance photographer based in Santiago, Chile, has become instantly familiar to a worldwide audience in the last few days. But for those who watch credit lines, Mr. Munita's name is already widely known and well respected. And this is not the first earthquake he has covered.

In February 2009, Christoph Niemann, the illustrator and children's book author, published an installment of "Abstract City", his monthly blog on The New York Times Web site. "I Lego N.Y." depicted various Big Apple institutions, from the Statue of Liberty to the Metrocard, using that ubiquitous modular building system with hilarious, haiku-like economy of means. Those images, plus 13 new ones, are now available in book form. "I Lego N.Y." (Abrams Image) radiates the affection that this onetime New Yorker (who now lives in Berlin) feels for his former home. My two painfully funny favorites are shown here.

Michael Douglas says that when he's offered a lifetime achievement prize these days, he does an act of due diligence first. "I normally check how many cardiologists are on the review panel for the award, just to see if they know something that I don't," he said Monday in a telephone interview.

My column today includes a quote from its subject, Mitch Daniels, warning Republicans about the perils of overconfidence. To drive the point home, here's a passage from a decades-old David Broder column, which Ezra Klein just exhumed from The Washington Post's archives, assessing Ronald Reagan's presidency in the wake of the 1982 midterms:
Neither have you. Stereotyping people by their favorite New York Times writer.
Heritage, precision and cachet are among the characteristics that fine watches and fine cars share. Generally, though, one can find a pretty good watch for less than the price of a pretty good car.
Via Mark Thoma, the trillion-dollar gap:

ORLANDO - When Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. spoke to the nation's labor leaders on Monday, he seemed to be speaking not so much to them but to millions of disaffected Americans. And he pushed a straightforward message: We get it. We hear your pain, and we're trying to do something about it.
Oprah Winfrey, an executive producer of "Precious: Based on the Novel 'Push' by Sapphire," has lined up a television home for the Oscar-nominated film: OWN, her forthcoming cable channel.

We're smack dab in the middle of tax season, and I am done. I spent a couple of Saturdays gathering all of my bank statements and other documents, making post-closing general journal entries, and printing out financial statements to deliver to my C.P.A. for both our corporate and personal income tax returns. As my Canadian father would say, my books are now tickety-boo (translation: in perfect working order).

Alec Baldwin's character Jack Donaghy on "30 Rock" may have complicated animal issues - the neutering of his childhood dog Pop, on his mother's orders, created all sorts of trauma - but he has nothing on the next alpha male Mr. Baldwin is to play. He will star as the psychiatrist Martin Dysart in a production of Peter Shaffer's play "Equus" this summer at Guild Hall in East Hampton, N.Y.

The annual CeBIT technology trade show begins on Tuesday at the Congress Centre in Hanover, Germany. This year's event, titled "Connected Worlds," has more than 4,150 exhibitors from 68 countries and is expected to draw more than 300,000 attendees from the fields of information technology, green energy and education.
Michelle Leder, who runs the Web site footnoted.org, is keeping an eye on corporate perks disclosed in regulatory filings this proxy season for DealBook's Perks Watch.

Human rights violations often seem the preserve of distant lands with despotic leaders and destitute peoples. But on Friday, federal officials preparing a report for the United Nations heard directly from New York residents and advocates about the abuse of rights in the city.
Correcting Behavior with Hand Signals
Has this one got you stuck? There's one more week left to take a look at Phil Chen's most recent cartoon and then conjure up a caption.
The new boss for CNN en Español, Cynthia Hudson, has a notable title.

A justice in State Supreme Court paved the way Monday for the transfer of private land to the developer Bruce C. Ratner for his long-delayed $4.9 billion Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn, after rejecting a challenge by local property owners to the state's use of eminent domain.
Mixing Joy and Structure

Like other automakers, Ford Motor Company is betting heavily on electric vehicles as the economy recovers. That decision has been powering the prospects of Azure Dynamics, a company in Oak Park, Mich., that makes electric drive trains and other components for hybrid commercial fleet vehicles like courier vans.

It's no secret that it's been a tough year for Goldman Sachs, perhaps not in terms of their financials -- the company reported very strong earnings for 2009 back in January -- but clearly in the court of public opinion. Goldman has been pummeled over excessive compensation and its role in the global economic crisis, including the current crisis in Greece, and the firm has had to issue clarifications on statements made by its chief executive, Lloyd C. Blankfein, and to even hire a public relations firm headed by former President George W. Bush's director of communications.

The South Orange Maplewood school district's eighteenth annual Music Marathon is back this Saturday, March 6, from 11 a.m. to 6 p.m., in the South Orange Middle School Auditorium. 3:54 p.m. | Updated The event is district wide and includes students from elementary through high school.
What more could NBC ask for? The most medals an American team had ever won in a Winter Olympics and then a finale straight out of Hollywood (well, almost).

The Tony Award winner Donna Murphy has been cast in the coming New York City Center Encores! revival of "Anyone Can Whistle," the Stephen Sondheim-Arthur Laurents musical that closed on Broadway after only nine performances in 1964.

So much is going to be happening at the Geneva auto show, which opens to the news media on Tuesday, that automakers are having a hard time keeping it all under wraps. Displays are going up all over town, in train stations, the airport, in malls and hotel lobbies. Billboards are everywhere. Last year, you may remember, workers placing advertising banners for a new Volkswagen messed up and unfurled them a day early. This year the auto show opened the doors to the exhibition halls to early media arrivals, while some new concept cars were yet to be wrapped, automakers were rehearsing their elaborate press conferences and setting up.
Spring has almost sprung. How will it smell?
Because of some major moves, the Seattle Mariners have been pegged by some as the biggest winner of this past off-season.
Celebrity Cruises will have a one-day sale tomorrow, with discounted fares to the Caribbean starting at about $77 a night.

After the heavy metal physics arguments about the papaya battery which are still ongoing, I thought we should relax with some lighter number music. Today's problem requires nothing more than simple arithmetic and in one case, finding the square root. Today's puzzle blog is based on problems devised by Dr. Aziz Inan, whom we met previously in Backdating.
Food Network Magazine is getting bigger.

In the opening scene of "Reservoir Dogs," Mr. Brown, et al., are having breakfast at a diner. After Joe Cabot pays for the meal, he asks everyone to leave a tip for the waitresses and everyone does, except for Mr. Pink. After Joe calls him out, he reluctantly hands over $1. As a rule, Mr. Pink does not tip.

The magnitude-8.8 earthquake in Chile, one of the strongest in recorded history, has left more than 700 dead and displaced 1.5 million people. But because of stricter building codes and the quake's greater distance from population centers, the damage was far less than that caused by the 7.0 quake in Haiti.
Calling on Students

March is Women's History Month, and this year's theme, according to the National Women's History Project and the Library of Congress, is "Writing Women Back Into History." (Note, too, that International Women's Day is March 8.)
Reading Aloud
The Township of Millburn Zoning Board of Adjustment has canceled tonight's meeting.
Setting High Expectations
Another day closer to the final Oscar ballot, another series of divisive - and divided - articles about the authenticity of "The Hurt Locker."
From Julia Werdigier, a DealBook colleague:

Europe's forests have been expanding for the last 60 years. But the rate at which forests are growing in Europe is slowing, and forested areas face even more acute challenges in the future because of climate change, Janez Potocnik, the E.U. commissioner for the environment, warned today.

Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.

Three months into working on "The Golden Archipelago," the new album by Shearwater, the group's vocalist, guitarist and songwriter, Jonathan Meiburg, listened to a recording of the Bikini Atoll national anthem on the Internet. The natives were singing on the islet of Kili, where they'd been displaced since 1948 to make way for U.S. atomic tests.

I was talking to a woman in Rhode Island the other day whose father is in a nursing home with advanced dementia. Her weary mother had voiced a fairly common sentiment: "When I reach that point, just leave a bottle of pills by the bed."

David Soyer, the founding cellist of the Guarneri String Quartet, died on Thursday at 87 (his obituary can be read here). The Guarneri was long-lived and world-renowned, and Mr. Soyer was known as a teacher and mentor as well as an accomplished musician.

There is something Zen about the snow. The city slows and quiets down as it falls, and the white blanket requires you to adapt your movements -- smaller steps, more sliding -- so as to work with the slippery surfaces and not against them.
Everyone knows about flat Italian frittatas and Spanish tortillas. But what about the savory versions from Tunisia, Greece and Iran?

Representative Nathan Deal, a Georgia Republican, will resign from the House next week, a move that likely gives the Democrats a little extra breathing room as they try to pass legislation overhauling the health care system.

My school district is closed today. Not because of the 30 inches of snow we received on Friday. And not because of the power, which came back to the high school by last night. No, it is closed, the predawn message from the superintendent said, because of what "could be perceived as a vague threat against student and staff safety."

Many people watch the unemployment rate to get a sense of how much pain there is in the job market. But as we and others have pointed out, it includes only people out of work who are actively looking for work. It doesn't take into account people who have given up looking for jobs, and it doesn't include people who are stuck in part-time positions but really want to be working full time.
So often we base our sense of risk on our own experience. The mistake, of course, is failing to realize that our experience is often so limited as to be of almost no value.

Readers questions on advertising.

Late Friday night, both sides in Perry v. Schwarzenegger filed briefs with Judge Vaughn Walker outlining their arguments over whether or not the 2008 state ban on same-sex marriage, Proposition 8, is constitutional. At the nonjury trial in January in San Francisco Federal District Court, lawyers presented their cases with testimony from two gay couples, who are the plaintiffs, political leaders and academic experts.

Laurent Tourondel, the chef who gave his name to the BLT empire, and his partner, Jimmy Haber, have parted company just two days short of the sixth anniversary of their association. They have divvied up their holdings in what both describe as an amicable divorce.

Some of the most interesting items at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum in Cleveland, like Buddy Holly's high school diploma and Jim Morrison's death certificate, are usually hidden in storage as part of the library and archive. But by the end of the year those items will have a new home in a high-tech $35 million building the museum will share with Cuyahoga Community College, about two miles from the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame's lakefront headquarters, The Plain Dealer reported. "We want this to be the world's pre-eminent research center for rock 'n' roll," Andy Leach, director of the hall's archives, told the paper.

Writing about makeup can be frustrating. You can never quite show the texture, the pigment and the sparkle that makes one eye shadow or foundation superior to the next. We here at T may have found a solution. In an interactive feature produced by the photographer Eric Maillet and the beauty editor of Numéro magazine, Laurence Hovart, you can now click on a moonscape of color and texture. And voilà! A hue with at view.
Freescale Semiconductor, the chip maker, is introducing a new microprocessor on Monday that it says will improve the performance and lower the cost of black-and-white e-reading devices.
Looting is taking place in severely struck Concepcion and other cities, including Santiago, France 24 correspondent Cyril Vanier reports.
The State Department is urging people to avoid "non-essential" travel to Chile, in the aftermath of a powerful earthquake that struck 73 miles north of Concepción.

Roasting a batch of fennel a couple of weeks ago, it occurred to me that its relatively long cooking time begged for it to serve as the base for a slightly more complicated dish. The idea here was that the fennel would lend its flavor to the chicken, the chicken would lend its juices to the fennel and the creation would need little else.

1:21 p.m. | Updated In an opinion released on Monday, a federal bankruptcy judge in Manhattan approved the controversial method that a court-appointed trustee was using to calculate the victims' losses in Bernard L. Madoff's enormous Ponzi scheme, The New York Times's Diana B. Henriques reports.

The widely praised Jacques Audiard film "A Prophet" ("Un Prophète"), already a grand prize winner at the 2009 Cannes Film Festival, added to its trophy collection on Saturday night when it was named best picture at the César awards, France's equivalent of the Oscars, Reuters reported. The film, about a young man of Arabic descent and his journey through the French prison system, took home nine César awards in all, including those for best director, original screenplay and cinematography, as well as acting awards for Tahar Rahim, who plays the central character, and Niels Arestrup, who plays an aging mob boss whose influence he comes under. Read more on ArtsBeat...

The fifth and final episode of our new original series stars Edoardo Ballerini, who played Christopher's heroin-addicted lackey on "The Sopranos." Click here to watch previous episodes of "The Park," directed by Poppy de Villenueve and featuring performances by Macaulay Culkin, Q'orianka Kilcher, Tammy Blanchard and Mary-Beth Peil.

For almost 40 years, the Society for American Baseball Research has painstakingly unearthed and saluted the accomplishments of long-forgotten contributors to the game. Now it will honor the stars of its own: by creating, in effect, the Baseball Historian Hall of Fame.

Spider-Man may be able to spin a web of any size, but how far can his secret identity, Peter Parker, stretch a dollar? The wall-crawling Marvel Comics hero will have to depend on his thrifty sense as much as his Spidey-sense in the months to come as a new story sees him become the latest addition to the nation's ranks of unemployed. On Monday, Marvel said that in a plot line that begins in issue No. 623 of Amazing Spider-Man, Peter Parker -- who has lately given up his gig at The Daily Bugle to become the official photographer of the mayor of New York -- will lose that job and, potentially, his career as he becomes blacklisted throughout the city.
"Ask an Expert" is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.
Several years ago, I watched Vint Cerf, who helped draft the architecture of the Internet and is now chief Internet evangelist at Google, give a talk about the future of the Internet.
Efforts to eliminate at least one year of high school for some students have been gaining momentum in recent weeks.

It has been a tough year for the Working Families Party, the labor-backed political powerhouse that played a pivotal role in the 2009 New York City elections but now faces a barrage of accusations that it violated campaign finance laws to aid its favored candidates.
Media Source, the owner of The Horn Book, a review publication for children's titles, has bought Library Journal and School Library Journal from Reed Business Information.
President Obama pledged today to tackle the dropout rate of American high school students, calling it an economic imperative if the United States intends to remain competitive in the global society.

And after all that, the N.H.L. season resumes tonight with the Red Wings in Colorado, the only game on the schedule. For Mike Babcock, the first coach to lead teams to both the Stanley Cup and the Olympic gold medal, it's back to his day job with the Red Wings.
Public health workers are another casualty of recent budget cuts in cities and counties across the country.
Young Unwitting Costly Kids - a dubious acronym for adult children who rely on financial support from their parents.
Excellent wine at half price? Good steaks? No problem getting a reservation? We'll get to that soon enough.

The widely praised Jacques Audiard film "A Prophet" ("Un Prophète"), already a grand prize winner at the 2009 Cannes Film Festival, added to its trophy collection on Saturday night when it was named best picture at the César awards, France's equivalent of the Oscars, Reuters reported. The film, about a young man of Arabic descent and his journey through the French prison system, took home nine Césars in all, including those for best director, original screenplay and cinematography, as well as acting awards for Tahar Rahim, who plays the central character, and Niels Arestrup, who plays an aging mob boss whose influence he falls under.
MSCI joined in on Monday's merger flurry with its $1.55 billion acquisition of the analysis and proxy advisory firm RiskMetrics, but it isn't done looking at deals yet.

Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

Chrystia Freeland, the United States managing editor of The Financial Times, has jumped to Reuters with the new title global editor at large, Reuters announced Monday. The Financial Times named Gillian Tett, an assistant editor, as Ms. Freeland's replacement.
3/2/10 | Update Sony announced that it had fixed the problem and restored service. More details are here.

Rose Gray, who founded the River Cafe in London with Ruth Rogers, bringing many in England their first taste of the simple pleasures of straightforward Italian cooking, has died. She was 71. Among the chefs who worked at her restaurant were Jamie Oliver and Hugh Fearnley-Whittingstall. Adam Gopnik, the New Yorker writer, once called the River Cafe "the best Italian restaurant in Europe."

For most musical acts, it is traditional to first go out on tour and then get bogged down in personal squabbles and inconvenient pregnancies. The cast of Fox's "Glee," however, is doing things slightly backward: after the characters have endured their first season of trials, tribulations and trimesters, the actors who portray them will hit the road for a series of live performances, the Fox television studio and the show's co-creator Ryan Murphy said on Monday.

Hallelujah! What appear to be the last remaining guild awards before the Oscars have been handed out, but - drat! - in terms of keeping you ahead of your colleagues/friends/family members in the pool, there's only so much to celebrate. The Costume Guild recognized Sandy Powell for "The Young Victoria" and Monique Prudhomme for "The Imaginarium of Doctor Parnassus." Both are nominated for the best costume Oscar. The academy tends to favor period films (Ms. Powell) over fantasy (Ms. Prudhomme), though, so perhaps Lil Vicki has the edge.

Two items in the Associated Press daybook, that sometimes arbitary arbiter of What's News Today, fall under the ever-broader category of Sexual Politics. At 11 a.m., Kristin Davis, the politically connected brothel-keeper and author of a new book (note absence of link), is announcing her candidacy for governor in Midtown. Then, at 12:45 p.m., Hiram Monserrate, the expelled state senator, convicted girlfriend assaulter and defender of the exclusivity of male-female marriage, will be endorsed by a group of ministers who are upset that a pro-gay-marriage group is campaigning against his effort to regain his seat. Now you know.

A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

In Brooklyn today, the discussion turned to food, not art, as the best barometer of gentrification. Brownstoner.com is collecting a list of restaurants that signified change in certain neighborhoods, like the Farm on Adderly in Ditmas Park and Roberta's in Bushwick.

But another tantalizing take on the show can be seen on the blog of the animator Michael Sporn, which  recounts how a feature-length cartoon version was quashed in 1955 before a single frame was shot.

In a recent post, I mentioned the many things I learned about my company and even about myself during my extended time away on my honeymoon. I have now been back a few weeks, and it is time to address our short-term and long-term goals --- and the action plan we will create to achieve them.

Gov. David A. Paterson said on Monday that he would not bow to pressure to resign and insisted that his authority had not been compromised by a domestic violence scandal involving a top aide that forced him to abandon the governor's race.

Donald L. Kohn, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, who helped coordinate the central bank's response to the fiscal crisis in 2008, told the White House on Monday that he would retire when his four-year term expires on June 23, The New York Times's Sewell Chan reports.

As my colleague Marc Lacey reports, aftershocks struck Chile Monday morning, complicating efforts to rescue survivors of the 8.8 magnitude earthquake that devastated much of the country on Saturday. The death toll now stands at 711, but is expected to rise. The Lede is tracking the response to the earthquake online. Readers who are in Chile are encouraged to submit first-hand accounts in the form of text, video or photographs by posting comments or links in the thread below.

Once again, Pentax demonstrates a new focus on design with an update to its line of rugged cameras. The new $330 Optio W90 looks like it belongs on a mountainside (thanks to its included carabiner) and feels more solidly built than its predecessor, the Optio W80.

This week, Lee Quiñones, an artist who emerged from the subway art movement of the 1970s, responded to readers' questions about his life, work and the evolution of graffiti as art in New York City.

The Winter Olympics ended in Vancouver on Sunday night with an all-star Canadian tribute to Canada, which, amid the playful French-Canadian clowns, William Shatner's jokes about writing one's name in the snow, Michael Bublé's stripping off a Mountie uniform and the giant inflatable beavers, featured a performance from Toronto's own Neil Young.
Happy Monday morning, Bits readers. Here's your daily news round-up:
Attention, South Orange gardeners: the village has established a community garden!

Employees wept and audience members grew silent at SeaWorld as the theme park's popular killer whale show resumed over the weekend with a photo montage memorial for a trainer who had been killed days earlier by an orca in front of horrified spectators.

A week ago, Jimmie Johnson took advantage of a yellow flag with 26 laps to go (and a little bit of luck) to win. Last Sunday at Las Vegas Motor Speedway, there was another late-race yellow. But this time, strategy more than luck contributed to Johnson winning his second straight.

Depictions of Jesus Christ's wounds and suffering on the cross are on rare display at the National Gallery of Art, as the museum presents its first comparison of painting and sculpture from the Roman Catholic Church.

Even in a city saturated with success stories, Adam C. Hochfelder achieved more by his early 30s than most people do in a lifetime. Through partnerships with prominent real estate families, he rose to manage or have ownership interest in $2.7 billion in Manhattan skyscrapers. He moved into Harry B. Helmsley's former Park Avenue office and was lauded for his heady deals and charitable work.

Last week in Deauville, France, two generations of great and rising chefs converged at the Omnivore Food Festival to share their techniques. It was the fifth such event dedicated to celebrating the new wave of cuisine - as opposed to nouvelle cuisine - that the young food and wine organization has hosted.

Jeffrey Skilling, the former Enron chief executive who was found guilty of fraud for his role at the collapsed energy giant, has one last shot at overturning that conviction on Monday by appearing before the Supreme Court of the United States.

This weekend, co-vocabularists have shared the face-saving phrases they reach for at awkward social moments.

Before the Bernard L. Madoff scandal erupted, Harry Markopolos was toiling away as a little-known investigator who repeatedly pestered the Securities and Exchange Commission to take a look at the funny numbers of Mr. Madoff.

Exhibitionism | Tell us what's going on in the picture above (use the comment link below). It's the latest of the uncaptioned images we're posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. The latest funniest captions are at right.

Halfway into the Jil Sander show, as ponytailed models zipped around the company's white showroom, nearly all of them in the same flat black boot with Velcro tabs, I thought: why can't young designers do clothes like this? At 42, Sander's designer, Raf Simons, is hardly old. But the clothes he designed for fall 2010 seemed to embody a sense of speed and energy that is certainly felt today, in the hyperactivity of texting and tweeting, in the connectedness of social media, in the economy and self-control you get from being able to shop or bank - or read a book or have sex - online.

Emily Post Will Be Commuting With You | The Golden Gate Transit agency has begun a campaign to improve the behavior of bus and ferry riders. They are being asked to refrain from talking for too long on their cellphones, occupying a nearby seat with a laptop and personal grooming like clipping fingernails and toe nails. Bus drivers and ferry workers will be able to refer to the code of conduct, which will be posted on every vehicle, to enforce the rules. "It used to be smoking was a big issue, and now it is how people use the cellphone," said Mary Currie, spokeswoman for the transit agency. "The problems change. But cellphone use is the No. 1 issue right now. We ask people to put phones on vibrate and not talk for long periods. In some cases, someone will get on in Santa Rosa and yack on their cellphone on business all the way into the city while the passenger next to them wants to get some sleep." [The Marin Independent Journal]
Astellas Pharma, a Japanese drug maker, unveiled on Monday a $3.5 billion offer for OSI Pharmaceuticals, in what is its second unsolicited bid for a biotech company in as many years.

Read All About It | As many cities struggle to support one newspaper, Palo Alto has three: The Daily Post; The Daily News, which began publishing in 1995; and The Palo Alto Weekly, which has a daily online edition and has been around since 1979. And in a city where laptops, iPhones and Kindles are standard issue, many residents still walk a block or two to pick up one of the city's newspapers -- all of which are free.

About three years ago, Berlin's Brunnenstrasse -- a raw and rough street leading from Berlin-Mitte to Prenzlauer Berg and Wedding -- was an emerging destination for the arty set. Back then, several pioneering galleries had settled in to long-empty storefronts and derelict courtyard spaces; the first upscale retail space and hipster bar had just opened. And that was all on one block.

BAGHDAD - I long ago learned not to discuss war movies with soldiers. They tend to be detail-oriented and obsessed with authenticity. They frequently dismiss well-made, thought-provoking films because of some minor detail - the scope on a rifle is wrong, or the markings on a vehicle incorrect.

Billions of dollars promised to private equity firms to finance an epic acquisition spree were threatened, and banks wanted dealmakers to share the pain. Renegotiate the loans, the banks said. The private equity firms disagreed: a deal, they argued, is a deal.

Is Chatroulette another Internet fad that will disappear in the next six months? Probably, but that doesn't mean you shouldn't make the most of the live-video-chat Web site while the trend lasts. "Entering Chatroulette is akin to speed-dating tens of thousands of perfect strangers — some clothed, some not," writes Nick Bilton. The site connects visitors through Webcams to a random, fathomless succession of strangers from across the globe. The experience is "very strange, and not just because you are parachuting into someone else's life (and they yours), a kind of invited crasher. It is also the eerie thrill of true randomness — who, or what, will show up next?" Tonight, Union Hall in Brooklyn is inviting New Yorkers to a Chatroulette night beginning at 7:30.

A bus "tricked out with a dance floor, moody lighting, a D.J. and free alcohol," with "Judas Priest blasting and cigarette smoke billowing." This is the scene on the Rusty Knot party ride from Williamsburg, Brooklyn, to the Rusty Knot, a campy nautical-theme bar in the West Village. Begun last month by the owners of the bar, Taavo Somer and Ken Friedman, the shuttle "was at first nothing more than a way to fill their bar on Monday nights in the dead of winter," writes Alex Williams. But "with its minimal supervision (you must be 21 or older), the ride is a reminder of the days when New York nightlife seemed to have no rules." The free trip takes about 60 minutes and includes free Budweisers, and not surprisingly it results in a "cocoon of debauchery." "But even with music that can be punk-club loud, on the sidewalk nothing is heard but a muffled rumble. It is of New York, but separate from New York." Pick-up locations and times can be found on the bar's Web site and by following the Rusty Knot on twitter @therustyknot.

MAIER--Arthur I. With deep sorrow The Summer Camp community mourns the passing of Arthur I. Maier, father of our founder, Nancy Maier. Arthur and his wife Sue's dedication and steadfast support over the past 25 years has had immeasurable impact on our campers and our program. Our heartfelt condolences to the entire Maier family.

ROGUE WAVE ''Permalight'' (Brushfire) Rogue Wave reacts to trauma with pop. The songs on ''Permalight,'' its fourth album, have briskly strummed guitars, melodies hinting at the Beatles and Big Star and often -- in a shift from the band's past handmade indie-pop -- perky synthesizers and snappy programmed drumbeats. But the lyrics, as cryptic and telegraphic as they are singable, hint at bitter disagreements, sieges, death and disasters. ''Can't you feel the fear itself?'' Zach Rogue sings in a dulcet high tenor, savoring the tune while insisting on the anxiety.
AUSTERER--Walter. Our special friend who meant so much to us. We will miss you. Maxine and Stan Landau

SACKSMAN--Stanley Walter, passed away February 24, 2010. He was predeceased by his Gretchie, Gretel Mina, his wife of 50 years. He was a Bronx boy born and bred. He loved New York and spent his career working for the City. Unassuming, undemanding and generous, he spent many hours as a volunteer teaching children, reading to the elderly or befriending patients. Stanley's love of words was his focus. He quoted prose and poetry and had a remarkable vocabulary. He was an astute inquisitor and an acute listener. He never drove a car and walked thousands of miles keenly observing his neighborhood. He is survived by his caring nephew Paul Sacksman and his wife Lisa, his loving niece Sandi Garfield and her husband Jeffrey and his great niece Melinda Garfield. A special thank you to Maria Colasuonno who was Stan's companion, conscience and caregiver these last few years.

MERCY--Sue B. Humanity in Action deeply mourns the death of Sue B. Mercy: visionary co-founder of HIA, constant supporter, Board member, uniquely inspiring mentor to HIA Fellows. In its 10th anniversary, Senior Fellows honored her with the annual designation of Sue Mercy Fellows to follow her example of distinguished philanthropy. Our deepest sympathies to her loving family. Hans Binnendijk, Chair, Judith Goldstein, Executive Director and the HIA Fellows

DANNY GOKEY ''My Best Days'' (19/RCA Nashville) Last year Danny Gokey placed third on ''American Idol,'' his transcendent moment coming early in the competition, when he covered Carrie Underwood's ''Jesus, Take the Wheel'' in a roaring, pained, audacious performance that almost shattered the original.

SOYER--David. Manhattan School of Music is saddened by the passing of David Soyer, a longtime and beloved member of MSM's college and precollege cello and chamber music faculties. Mr. Soyer was an inspiration to concertgoers worldwide through his extraordinary performances as cellist of the Guarneri String Quartet and as a mentor to generations of cellists and chamber musicians. His support, encouragement and incomparable musical knowledge will be sorely missed. With heartfelt sympathy, we extend our condolences to his wife Janet, and sons Daniel and Jeffrey. Peter Robbins, Chairman, Board of Trustees Robert Sirota, President

AUSTERER--Walter, died February 27th of prostate cancer. Born in Vienna, he was a Holocaust survivor who came to England on the Kinderstransport and eventually to America. He served in the U.S. army during World War II. He was a gifted artist and sculptor and a collector of Eskimo Art on which he lectured periodically. He was a man with an open mind and generous heart. He embraced life, loved music and sought out adventure. He was deeply loved by all who knew him. He is survived by his loving wife of 25 years Sylvia, his sons Steven and Warren, his stepsons Jordan and Scott Smoller, his daughters-in- law Camille, Alexis, Becky, and Jan, and his granddaughters Taylor, Ava, Ajanta and Jaeda. His loss to all of us is beyond words. The funeral services will be held on Monday March 1 at the Central Synagogue Main Sanctuary, 123 East 55th Street, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Cancer Society or the Rangeley Library in Maine which he loved at: Rangeleylibrary.com.

MILLIMET--James Andrew, 52, died in peace at the Barlow Respiratory Hospital, affiliate of the University of Southern California on February 25th in the loving presence of his father and brother. Jamie was born in Hastings-on-Hudson, New York, the younger son of Renee and Erwin Millimet and grandson of Henrietta and Maurice Millimet of New York City. Renee predeceased Jamie in 1988. Jamie was a graduate of Hackley School in Tarrytown, New York and attended the University Of North Dakota in Veterinary Medicine. He attended the Theatrical School of the University of California in Long Beach, following his mother and maternal grandmother, on stage with humor. He was a loving and gentle man who made people feel good and laugh. He was a well known stand-up comic in New York City, Los Angeles and Las Vegas under the name A.J. Millett. He was also a championship swimmer and spent much of his time helping young children with special needs through water activities under the name, Swimmingly Yours. He has been seen as an actor on nationally viewed television commercials. He was active in organizations concerning kindness to all animals, the preservation of the natural beauty of the land, and led a vegan lifestyle. He is survived by his father, his brother Robert of Los Angeles and his sisters, Rachel and Sarah of Longmeadow, MA, of whom he was so proud, and their mother Mary Millimet. A gathering to Celebrate Jamie's Life will be held on Tuesday, March 2nd from 7:00 9:00pm, with a service commencing at 7:30pm, at Forastiere Smith Funeral Home in East Longmeadow. Donations to celebrate Jamie's life may be made to any organization of personal choice, in loving help for children with special needs, to local animal shelters and to Hackley School.

Advertising spending was $117 billion in 2009, a drop of 9 percent from 2008. Cable television and Spanish language cable in particular had increases as advertisers tried to reach ever narrower audiences. National ad buys, like those for network TV, above, decreased. Spending in the top 10 product categories decreased 9.5 percent in 2009 from 2008. The auto industry, for example, spent $8.04 billion, a drop of 23 percent. Three categories showed minor increases: department stores (2.8 percent), pharmaceuticals (1.8 percent) and quick-service restaurants (1.3 percent). SHELLY FREIERMAN
