About this time last year, Intel and TSMC announced a groundbreaking deal. Intel, which loves to make its own chips, tapped TSMC, which loves to make chips for other companies, to make variants of its Atom processor. The deal was seen as a response by Intel to the growing popularity of customized chips from ARM Holdings. It hasn't worked out all that well for Intel or TSMC, based in Taiwan.

SHOOTER JENNINGS & HIEROPHANT ''Black Ribbons'' (Black Country Rock/Rocket Science) Shooter Jennings's new album takes the form of a play within a play, whose story begins in the not-too-distant-future. The authorities are bearing down on America's last defender of freedom, an outlaw radio host called Will o' the Wisp. It's Will's last ride: at midnight, he explains, America's airwaves will be ''commandeered for government-approved and regulated transmission.''

MERCY--Sue B.,68, of New York City, born in Brooklyn, NY to the late Irving and Muriel Bernstein, passed away on February 26, 2010 after a determined and courageous battle against cancer. She was at home surrounded by family. Sue is survived by her adoring husband Gene, her partner for 46 years in all of the joys and sorrows of life, her beloved children, Tod, Andy, and daughter-in-law Molly, her wildly adored grandchildren, Baxter, Jasper, and Emily, and her brother Jay Bernstein. Sue attended Great Neck High School, and graduated in 1963 from Connecticut College. For those who knew her, Sue's vital presence felt like a force of nature. Apart from her devotion to her family, Sue's life was filled with friends and her love for music, art (especially modern art), the great outdoors and sport. Sue brought people together; she had a joyous sense of fun and the capacity to make everyday life feel like a celebration. From the beginning of her adult life, Sue was passionate and unstinting in her charitable work. Among other efforts, for thirty years she supported the New York Philharmonic, serving on its Board of Directors; she was on the Board of Directors of Humanity in Action International, and of Young Audiences; and she was a Trustee Emeritus of Connecticut College. She leaves a hole in the hearts of all those who loved her. A funeral service will be held on Tuesday, March 2 at 11am at Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue and 55th Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Sue's favorite organizations: Humanity in Action, The New York Philharmonic, and Young Audiences.
MERCY--Sue. A force of nature with a heart of gold. You will be missed. Love, Laurie and Petey

NEWTON--John Crawford, of Redding, CT, died peacefully in his sleep February 21st at age 95. Born to Howard and Anna Newton, September 22, 1914, in Philadelphia, PA. He was predeceased by his brother Howard, sister Dorothy Stephens and eldest daughter Jo-Ann Vercoe (Will) Moody (Stan). He is survived by his beloved wife of 70 years, Angelita (Alonso), daughters Nancy duBusc (Richard), Pamela Newkirk (Ben), eight grand and eight great-grandchildren who span the globe. Starting in the mailroom in 1933 he worked his way up to President and Director of the Near East Development Corp. at Mobil Oil in its New York and London offices. He later ran Mobil's Marine and Trading Companies in Bermuda where he lived for 36 years. Retiring from Mobil in 1978 he worked for several Bermuda companies until age 92 when he and his wife moved to Redding. There, at 93, he wrote the "Story of the Iraq Petroleum Company". He was a member of the Royal Bermuda Yacht and Mid-Ocean Clubs. He loved his piano, his banjo, golf and swimming. He was a clear thinker and a great adviser with a keen sense of humor. He will be dearly missed by his family and all who knew him. Donations may be made to the National MS Society.

9 P.M. (13, 49) DOLLEY MADISON Hostess with the mostest. The beauty of President James Madison's wife, Dolley, may have attracted attention, but she used her position for serious purposes: to legitimize the country's new capital through weekly parties and bipartisan political gatherings, helping to forge a national identity. She also paved the way for first ladies to adopt social causes, choosing as her own the advocacy of children left orphaned by the War of 1812. ''American Experience'' portrays the Madisons' life and times through dramatic re-creations starring Eve Best, above, and Jefferson Mays. There are also interviews with the NPR news analyst Cokie Roberts and the historians Catherine Allgor and Richard Norton Smith. ''Morristown: Where America Survived,'' at 10:30, revisits the winter of 1779-80, when Gen. George Washington built a log-hut city in New Jersey for his troops and effectively saved the American revolution. 10 A.M. (Fox Business Network) FRONTIER MARKETS: INVESTING IN THE MIDDLE EAST Cheryl Casone reports from Syria, the Palestinian territories and Israel during this weeklong series on the pursuit of international market opportunities by the New York investors David Grayson, managing director of Auerbach Grayson & Company, and Jim Awad, managing director of Zephyr Management.

FOX--Howard, a manager of high-end portfolios at Wall Street investment firms for more than 30 years, died February 27. After serving in the U.S. Air Force from 1951 to 1955, he worked for Goldman Sachs in Philadelphia. In 1960, he became a partner at P. F. Fox and Co. in New York, joining the firm his father, P. Fred Fox, had founded. In 1975, he went to work for Carret and Co. He retired in 1993. He is survived by his wife, Geraldine (Ziegenfuss) Fox; two sisters, Dr. Renee C. Fox of Philadelphia and Rosa Gellert of New York City; two daughters, Mindy L. Fox of New York City and Susan Fox Hallenbeck of Madison, CT; a son-in-law, Brian Hallenbeck; and a granddaughter, Erin Hallenbeck. You can remember these things, sure, but they seem abstract - faded dreams from another life.

The Supreme Court heard oral arguments on a major gun control case on Tuesday. The issue in the case, McDonald v. City of Chicago, is whether the Second Amendment protects the individual right to keep and bear arms against state and city gun laws. The case is considered a sequel to a Supreme Court decision in 2008, District of Columbia v. Heller, which limited what the federal government can do in restricting gun rights.

Pfizer is reportedly gearing up this week to bid 3 billion euro ($4.08 billion) for Ratiopharm, a generic drug maker based in Germany, according to Bloomberg News, which cited two unidentified people with knowledge of the talks. The move would pit Pfizer, the world's largest drug maker, against Teva Pharmaceuticals Industries of Israel, the world's largest generic drug maker, and Actvis of Iceland, another big generic drug maker, both of which are said to be interested in Ratiopharm, according to Bloomberg.

You've probably never heard of Janet Patterson, the costume designer who received her fourth Oscar nomination for "Bright Star," a quiet meditation on the unconsummated love affair between Fanny Brawne and the poet John Keats. With a résumé that includes "The Piano" (1993), Patterson is revered by industry peers, few of whom have met her. Far from prolific, she retreats between movies for years at a time. In 1965, the lights went out from Ontario to the Eastern Seaboard. Prisoners rioted. Riders trapped in elevators and subway cars took to singing in the blackness. Streetlamps flickered out, trains slowed to a stop, and a quiet filled the air as the people of Gotham gathered at their windows to reflect upon their still and moonlit city. The birth rate, nine months later, spiked.

It seems that Mickey Kaus, one of the deans of the blogosphere, is going to challenge Barbara Boxer in California's Democratic primary. I fearlessly predict that he will lose, but I hope he acquits himself well enough (or at least entertainingly enough) to encourage more pundits and policy wonks to throw their hats into the political ring. We've reached a point in American life where the line between celebrities, television personalities and politicians is tissue-thin. But when non-politicians who actually know something about policy - be they political journalists, think-tankers or public intellectuals - get involved in government, it's almost always as spokespeople, speechwriters and policy advisers, rather than as actual candidates for office. National Review's Rich Lowry flirted with a bid for New York mayor in 2001, and there was a brief "Lawrence Lessig for Congress" boomlet in 2008, but both Lowry and Lessig ultimately decided against running. And there's certainly no current American equivalent of Britain's Boris Johnson, the magazine-editor-turned-Tory M.P.-turned-Mayor-of-London - or Michael Ignatieff, the historian, essayist and academic who's now the leader of Canada's Liberal Party.

Steven Alan has a thing for basics. Or, as the New York-based designer puts it, "the perfect 'blank.' " The perfect flannel shirt. The perfect five-pocket jeans. And now the perfect bag. Alan's latest design is a waxed cotton and leather carry-on valise he created for V Australia, an offshoot of Virgin Airlines. You can hear all about the trip the airline sent Alan on for inspiration - Sydney, the Great Barrier Reef, the Daintree River - but for a designer obsessed with essentials, the real force behind the bag was simple: Where do you put your laptop and your laundry? "The curious specialty of the choreographer Alexei Ratmansky is to envision a 20th-century Soviet Union that might have been, the land that composers once dreamed of optimistically," Alastair Macaulay wrote last year about the work of Mr. Ratmansky, the Russian artist. Mr. Ratmansky will have the chance to present that vision again, in 2011. American Ballet Theater has announced that it will present the company premiere of Mr. Ratmansky's production of "The Bright Stream" on Jan. 21, 2011, at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington. The comic two-act narrative ballet about members of a Russian farm collective in the 1930s, set to music by Shostakovich, was first staged by Mr. Ratmansky for the Bolshoi in 2003. The original production was choreographed by Fyodor Lopukhov and first performed in 1935 in Leningrad. The ballet will also be performed during the company's spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House, which will run from May 16 through July 9, 2011. Mr. Ratmansky joined American Ballet Theater as Artist in Residence in January 2009.

Avant-garde fashion finds inspiration in many quarters, but few designers have been willing to tackle, um, dentistry. Enter the retainer necklace by Jules Kim of Bijules NYC, with its single protruding gold tooth - it would never be "accidentally" thrown away with a lunch tray in the junior high cafeteria. Kim created it especially for her roommate, the fashion photographer Brooke Nipar, who had lost a tooth in a bar fight; she cast it in gold and hung it from a detachable chain so that Nipar could pop it in her mouth or wear it around her neck with pride. Meanwhile, the London artist William Hunt has created a limited-edition set of silver cuff links made from casts of the wisdom teeth he had removed as a "performance" in art school. The three Six Six Six girls, whose macabre design line is named Triskaidekaphobia after the fear of the number 13, offer spiky silver bangles and slinky pendants sculptured from metal baby teeth; the San Francisco gothic brand Loved to Death offers actual human baby teeth set in gold, Victorian-inspired settings. And Dominic Jones's yellow gold shark fangs interspersed with gold rose thorns are just begging for someone to take a nibble.

Those of us who have written something freakishly mean -- we are legion in an age of snark -- and then come to gnaw the bone of regret can identify with Will Leitch. Writing at Deadspin, Mr. Leitch walks back the cat on a  missile he launched long ago at Roger Ebert that was entitled, more or less, "I Am Sick of Roger Ebert's Fat (something even more nasty and less descriptive) Face." Mr. Ebert, perhaps the most famous film critic of our age, has lost his voice and part of his face to thyroid cancer and was recently profiled in Esquire to very remarkable effect. Now that Mr. Ebert's face is no longer fat, Mr. Letich has had time to contemplate his choice of targets -- Mr. Ebert had shown him significant professional courtesies over the years -- and writes about what it was like to use his keyboard to do something really dumb.

Fortunately, when my Internet went dead I had just set up the new Palm Pre Plus from Verizon. Fortunately, I say, because the Plus can act as a wireless hot spot. I used it to temporarily replace my Wi-Fi network and was able to connect my desktop and laptop to the Internet through the phone.

The Senate has passed a $15 billion package that is aimed at helping small businesses. There are two key parts. One is the extension of section 179 of the tax code, which allows up to $250,000 of capital expenditures to be expensed immediately instead of being depreciated over time. This will motivate some companies to make capital expenditures that will reduce their tax bills, which is good for the economy. The other part is the suspension of FICA payments for the rest of the year for new hires.

The Samurai Shopper, though possessed of boundless wisdom, is afflicted with a waggish skepticism - chalk it up to experience. I had to abandon the passionate energies and utter stupidity of youth. There wasn't a choice; birthdays happened. I do miss my younger self, especially the part where I awoke each morning looking radiantly fresh, like a shiny penny in a mud puddle. Now it takes many, many shiny pennies to find illumination, which mainly comes from skin-care counters. Like the Doge's Palace in Venice, my exterior has borne the insults of time and seeks restoration to the alabaster glory that once was me. Besides, bright people don't deserve dull skin.

She may not be, in the words of the head of her record label, "the best technical singer," but Taylor Swift will have another opportunity next month to appear astounded by her awards-show largess: she's been nominated for five Academy of Country Music Awards, including entertainer of the year. The nominations, which were announced on Tuesday morning, were most generous to the Nashville group Lady Antebellum, which picked up seven nominations including album of the year (for its self-titled 2008 release) and top vocal group, as well as single record of the year, song of the year and video of the year for "Need You Now." Miranda Lambert is nominated for six awards, as is Carrie Underwood, the academy's reigning entertainer of the year, who is once again nominated in that category. Kenny Chesney picked up four nominations, as did Brad Paisley and the Zac Brown Band. The winners will be announced at a ceremony in Las Vegas on April 18.

For a cultural institution interested in promotional items, the tote bag is king. They are to museums and public radio stations what T-shirts are to rock bands, what bumper stickers are to middle school honor rolls. This limited-edition tote ($98) by Tommy Hilfiger celebrates the just-opened 2010 Whitney Biennial and highlights the work of one of its artists, Ari Marcopoulos. A New York photographer of Dutch extraction and a former assistant to Andy Warhol, Marcopoulos is known for the great lengths he'll go to to get a picture, whether it's shadowing the Beastie Boys or chasing snowboarders down the Alps. The image on this tote bag comes from "Detroit," Marcopoulos's video piece in the Biennial, about two boys who make electronic music in a small Detroit bedroom using little more than foot effect pedals. Marcopoulos was given an advance copy of the bag, which went on sale Thursday, and he approved of it. "I thought it was going to be a really cheap tote bag," he said. "But it's functional. And when I wore it, people on the subway were checking me out."

Barry Hannah, the quintessentially Southern author of "Geronimo Rex" and "High Lonesome," has died, The Associated Press reported. He was 67 and died on Monday at his home in Oxford, Miss. The coroner said the death was not under investigation.

Highlights from media coverage in today's New York Times:

Jerry Brown Expected to Announce Candidacy | Jerry Brown, the state's attorney general, is expected to announce on Tuesday that he is running for governor. If he wins, he will be the oldest governor in California history. Mr. Brown, who turns 72 in April, is a former mayor of Oakland and former governor of California. "It's not much of a career-builder; it's more of a career-ender," he said. "But I feel I could bear that better than the other candidates." [The New York Times]

The closure of a main runway at John F. Kennedy International Airport was expected to make travel to New York difficult. High winds on Monday made the experience miserable, as delays for arriving flights were averaging nearly two hours on the first day that the main runway was shut down for a four-month, $376 million project to widen and improve the largest of its four runways. At one point, the airport was down to just one runway, due to the wind.

QAIM, Iraq--In the once lawless and still unruly wilds of Anbar Province, Col. Mark R. Stammer had the equivalent of an election-week skip in his step. A South Dakota native, his booming voice was more West Texas than Black Hills, with the twang of a steel guitar, and he had a message to deliver in the town of Qaim: get out to vote.

The vice chairman of the Federal Reserve announced on Monday that he would retire in June, giving President Obama an expanded opportunity to put his stamp on the central bank as it faces a difficult balance between heading off inflation and addressing high levels of unemployment, The New York Times's Sewell Chan writes.

"A Town Called Panic" is a Belgian stop-motion animated film starring three enterprising toys: a cowboy, an Indian and a horse. Tonight the movie will be screened as part of the French Institute Alliance Française's ode to Belgian cinema. The series, which runs Tuesdays throughout March, also includes a screening of "When the Sea Rises" which earned director Yolande Moreau two Césars (that's the French equivalent of the Oscar). We recommend a dinner of waffles and Stella Artois beforehand.

Lil Wayne once claimed he didn't need to read because of his innate intelligence. But maybe he's not the best role model. The first installment of the Hip Hop Book Club at Goodbye Blue Monday in Bushwick tonight will feature rappers who read. Co-hosted by Kid Lucky and Susan Hwang, the event invites aspiring songwriters to read a book and then compose and perform an original song about it. Go hear hip-hoppers riff on "Frank Miller's Batman: The Dark Knight Returns." Those slated to appear include Breez Evahflowin, Timothy Dark, Core Rhythm, Dan Costello, Susannah Pryce and We Stole the Show. The event is free; Batman-themed snacks and drinks will be provided.

"More than any other living choreographer just now," Paul Taylor seems to be in love with his dancers, writes Alastair Macaulay. Tonight, see the results of that love at City Center, where Mr. Taylor is celebrating his 80th birthday with a program of rich repertory, two premieres and a little extra attention for the women. "The variety Mr. Taylor finds in his women is astonishing," adds Mr. Macaulay. "Amy Young is a different woman in every dance — mature, immature, anguished, serene — and yet I'm not aware of her acting. Her solo in 'Cascade' is a marvel of both legato and stillness; nothing in 'Esplanade' stays in my head more amazingly than her quick series of backward falls." Catch her, Annmaria Mazzini in "Changes" — "the single most sensational performance of the season so far" — and Laura Halzack, "the company's most utterly beautiful woman." In "Sunset," Mr. Macaulay writes, "she has only to raise an eye to make us think differently of how these women are amid these men."

MERCY--Sue. All of us at Publicolor are deeply saddened by the passing of Sue Mercy, beloved wife of our lifetime trustee, Gene Mercy. Our board, staff, and students send their deepest condolences to their family. Ruth L. Shuman, founder

MERCY--Sue B.,68, of New York City, born in Brooklyn, NY to the late Irving and Muriel Bernstein, passed away on February 26, 2010 after a determined and courageous battle against cancer. She was at home surrounded by family. Sue is survived by her adoring husband Gene, her partner for 46 years in all of the joys and sorrows of life, her beloved children, Tod, Andy, and daughter-in-law Molly, her wildly adored grandchildren, Baxter, Jasper, and Emily, and her brother Jay Bernstein. Sue attended Great Neck High School, and graduated in 1963 from Connecticut College. For those who knew her, Sue's vital presence felt like a force of nature. Apart from her devotion to her family, Sue's life was filled with friends and her love for music, art (especially modern art), the great outdoors and sport. Sue brought people together; she had a joyous sense of fun and the capacity to make everyday life feel like a celebration. From the beginning of her adult life, Sue was passionate and unstinting in her charitable work. Among other efforts, for thirty years she supported the New York Philharmonic, serving on its Board of Directors; she was on the Board of Directors of Humanity in Action International, and of Young Audiences; and she was a Trustee Emeritus of Connecticut College. She leaves a hole in the hearts of all those who loved her. A funeral service will be held on Tuesday, March 2 at 11am at Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue and 55th Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Sue's favorite organizations: Humanity in Action, The New York Philharmonic, and Young Audiences.

MERCY--Sue B. We, and all of the many people whose lives were made better by your being part of it, will miss you. You lived life to the fullest and put up a valiant fight. Our love and sympathies to Gene, the children and grandchildren. Helaine and Fred.

MAIER--Arthur I. The Board of Governors and members of Sunningdale Country Club are deeply saddened by the death of our esteemed member, Arthur I. Maier. We extend our sincerest sympathy to his wife Susan, son Richard and the entire family.

For most young American soccer players, the road to the pros -- whether in Major League Soccer or abroad -- usually begins as a precocious sprout, jersey reaching past his knees in the beehives of youth soccer. From there, it is on to club soccer, soccer in high school and either a pit stop in college or, for the elite, perhaps a tryout with a European, M.L.S. or Mexican club. But for Danny Arthur Quimby Cruz, now a midfielder for the Houston Dynamo, soccer was nothing more than a way to stay in shape ... for football, American style.

CONRAD--Robert, 90, died in Ann Arbor, MI on February 18. He was born in New York City, received undergraduate and law degrees from New York University, and was a proud veteran of World War II, serving in the deception unit known as the "Ghost Army". He practiced law in New York City for nearly 60 years, served as president of the City Club of New York, and was active in Democratic Party politics at the local, state and national levels. He is survived by Esther, his beloved wife of 60 years, his sister-in-law Mildred Nollman of Foxborough, MA, sons Dan of San Francisco and Fred of Ann Arbor, their wives Sarah Wilcox and Betsy Brooks, grandchildren Paul, Ted, Allison, and Jeffrey, and eight nieces and nephews and their families. Bob loved music, ballet, and the theater; he was an enthusiastic and generous host, and loved a party. He and Esther were world travelers, always looking forward to their next trip. He was loved and respected by the many friends he made throughout his life. His friends and family will miss him always. Memorial contributions may be sent to Peoples' Symphony Concerts; Suite 703; 121 West 27th Street; New York, NY 10001.

The Jets announced Monday that they would release running back Thomas Jones when free agency begins Friday. The move seemed inevitable once it became clear that Jones, who will turn 32 before the start of the 2010 season, would not restructure his contract to save the Jets a $3 million roster bonus due next week. Jones rushed for a career-high 1,402 yards in 2009, carrying the burden for an offense trying to insulate the rookie quarterback Mark Sanchez during the Jets' unexpected run to the American Football Conference championship game.

JAFFE--Andrew, a noted foreign correspondent for Newsweek, editor of Adweek Magazine, head of the international advertising Clio Awards, and finally a consultant to the advertising and marketing industries, died today after a courageous ten year battle with multiple myeloma, a cancer of the bone marrow. He was 71. Fresh out of Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism, Jaffe began his career as a newsman for the Associated Press where he won notice for his coverage of the 1965 Watts Riot. He then joined Newsweek Magazine, first as a domestic correspondent in Atlanta covering race relations, and then in 1969 as a correspondent and later bureau chief for its Africa bureau in Nairobi, Kenya. While there, he covered the Biafran civil war, the end of Haile Selassie's rule as emperor of Ethiopia, and Idi Amin's rule in Uganda, as well as the end of Portuguese colonialism in Mozambique and Angola. In 1975 he accepted a post back in the U.S. as bureau chief in Miami. He left Newsweek in 1977 to become business editor for the Los Angeles Herald Examiner. In 1984, he set off for New York, where he worked as marketing director of the international travel firm, Special Expeditions. In 1986 he was hired by Adweek Magazine as editor of a regional edition based in Atlanta. And in 1988, he moved to New York to become editorial director of the magazine's six editions. Jaffe spent the next 15 years immersed in advertising. In 1992 he was made a vice president of Adweek responsible for starting Adweek Conferences and other brand extensions; and, in 1997, he managed its acquisition of the Clio Awards. He headed the Clios for the next six years, until he retired from the company in 2003 and set up his own consultancy in Norwalk, Connecticut. Before going to Columbia Journalism, Jaffe was a student at Phillips Exeter Academy and then Pomona College. From 1960-1962 he served on active duty in the U.S. Army in Korea and Alaska, with the rank of First Lieutenant. Opening his own consultancy, Compass Consulting, in 2003, he worked for various New York agencies and for the One Club, helping it introduce the first awards show for branded entertainment, One Show Entertainment. He also served on the board of the Brandcenter, a graduate program at Virginia Commonwealth University that offers a masters degree in the creative side of advertising. As a board member, he helped establish its executive education program for mid-career professionals. In 2003, he authored a book, "Casting for Big Ideas," published by John Wiley & Co. Jaffe was a member of the Cornell Club, the American Society of Magazine Editors and the Overseas Press Club. He was chairman of the Neal Awards program, sponsored by American Business Media to recognize excellence in business-to-business journalism. His hobbies included fly fishing, travel and experiments with fiery cooking recipes. Jaffe was married to communications executive Eileen Ast in 1994. Their home is in New Canaan, Connecticut. Jaffe is survived by his wife, his son, Christopher, a computer executive, Chris' wife Katie and a granddaughter, Stella, all of whom live in Burlingame, California; a stepson, Nicholas Ast, a student at Eckerd College; and two brothers, Steve, a crisis PR expert in Beverly Hills, and Bruce, a computer specialist and photographer in New York City. The family requests that in his memory people consider a charitable contribution to the Andrew Jaffe Scholarship Fund at the Brandcenter, Virginia Commonwealth University or to the Whittingham Cancer Center at Norwalk Hospital. Memorial services are pending.

FAIL--James M.,was a true southern gentleman who never met a challenge that did not excite him or an adventure that did not inspire him. He was a successful businessman and a generous philanthropist. Most recently, he served as the chairman of Stone Holdings, his Dallas-based financial holding company. A native of Mobile, Alabama, he attended Murphy High School and served three years in the U.S. Navy before graduating from the University of Alabama in 1949. His lifelong respect for education manifested itself in his numerous gifts to both educational facilities and individuals, including his establishing a scholarship at Birmingham Southern College for "any worthy and deserving student." This reiterated his belief that education was the greatest gift he could offer. In 2009, he was honored by the University of the South at Sewanee with a Doctorate of Civil Law honoris causa. James' love for music began at a young age with the violin, viola, and trombone. He played in the Murphy High School band and continued to enjoy performing with the Woody Herman Big Band and the Swingles in the 1940s. Later, he was a generous supporter of the Phoenix Symphony, serving as director, and the Mobile Symphony; making a sizable donation endowing its principal cello chair in memory of his wife. His great enthusiasm for sports lead him to repeatedly give to the Crimson Tide Foundation. His first donation enabled the University to build the department's media suite, named for his father- in-law, Naylor Stone, whom he greatly admired. In 2008, much to his delight and befitting his wonderful sense of humor, the University of Alabama found a way to thank him for his ongoing support by naming the visitor's room at Bryant-Denny Stadium "The Fail Room." He gained a great deal of joy from making the long journey to Pasadena this January to see the Crimson Tide win the National Championship. James' adventurous and always curious nature led him to make many great trips around the world. He took great joy in bringing his family and friends with him to share the experiences of faraway lands and new cultures; stories of these trips always entertained and inspired those around him. Mr. Fail was a member of Kappa Sigma fraternity, the Economic Club of New York and a founder of its Centennial Society, the Metropolitan Club of New York, Phoenix Country Club, the Summit Club, The Inverness Country Club, The Club of Birmingham, and The Noah Society. He attended St. Mary's-on-the-Highlands Episcopal Church. James was preceded in death by his wife, Emily Stone Fail; his son, James Naylor Fail; and his parents, Joe and Rosalie Fail. He is survived by his daughters Kathryn Luttrull and Marcia Boykin, both of Phoenix, Arizona; his grandchildren Lindsay, Hayley, Bobby, Marbury, Liza, Grey, Coulter, and Malcolm; his great-grandchildren Stone, Jonas, and Dahlia; brothers Alton and Charles Fail, and a large extended family. Throughout his successes, James Fail never lost his humility and maintained his generosity to a fault. With his beloved wife Emily, he was a shining example of how to live a rich and joyful life. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the University of Alabama general scholarship fund or St. Mary's-on-the-Highlands.Visitation will be held Wednesday, March 3, 2010 from 6pm until 8pm at Johns-Ridout's Southside. A funeral service will be held on Thursday, March 4, 2010 at 11am at St. Mary's-on-the-Highlands, with burial to follow at Elmwood Cemetery. A celebration of his life will follow at the Veranda Restaurant.

The Pakistani-American author Daniyal Mueenuddin was named the winner of the Story Prize on Wednesday night for his collection "In Other Rooms, Other Wonders," the award's organizers said in a news release. Mr. Mueenuddin's work, a series of eight interconnected stories about the power dynamics surrounding the estate of a landowner in Pakistan, was chosen from among 78 books entered by 53 publishers and imprints. Mr. Mueenuddin receives $20,000 with the prize; awards of $5,000 each went to the finalists Victoria Patterson, for her collection "Drift," and Wells Tower, for "Everything Ravaged, Everything Burned." The Story Prize, given annually to a collection of short fiction written in English, has previously been awarded to Edwidge Danticat, Jim Shepard and Tobias Wolff, among other authors.

I was inspired to write about Nujood's case when I read her book, but the backdrop is my growing concern about Yemen itself. As Al Qaeda finds itself under more pressure in Pakistan and Afghanistan, it may see Yemen as a nice refuge. Indeed, there are signs that that is already beginning to happen. And since the Yemeni government's authority weakens at the capital's city limits, and the president has other priorities (such as holding his country together), it's not a bad spot for extremists.

Speaking of blurring the line between bloggers and politicians, Ezra Klein and Congressman Paul Ryan just had an interesting online exchange about Ryan's remarks at last week's health care summit. The Wisconsin congressman, you may recall, accused partisans of the pending legislation of disguising the real cost of the bill, which may total $2.3 trillion over 10 years once all the subsidies are phased in. Klein responded that yes, "the bill might cost $2.3 trillion" in its second decade, but over that period "it either raises or saves $2.95 trillion, for a net deficit impact of negative $650 billion." Ryan, he suggested, was using "the classic 'This Is A Big Number' technique to imply that the bill is financially irresponsible, when putting the number in context would show just the opposite."

"I am cursed to be in this Mother Hubbard body," Alice Neel once remarked of her grandmotherly image. The artist's sensitivity to nuances of style and gesture informs the portraits in "Alice Neel: Painted Truths," a retrospective opening on March 21 at the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston. Since her portrait work was largely uncommissioned and did not require that she flatter the sitter, "you get a sense of how people really looked," says Barry Walker, who, with Jeremy Lewison, curated the show. That's as true for the cheerful Fuller Brush man and Dachau survivor who showed up on her doorstep in 1965 as it is for the art-world elites who (eventually) posed for her - including the Factory's Ritta Redd and Jackie Curtis and Andy Warhol himself, seminude and scarred. (Neel was notorious for sweet-talking her subjects out of their clothes.) When faced with truly stylish subjects, like the art-world players John Gruen and Jane Wilson and their daughter, Neel focused on the psychological - the self-assured couple and the young girl, hunched like a figure out of Munch - but she didn't neglect the clothes. The painting's pet name: "Six Patent Leather Shoes."
A look inside the artist Marina Abramovic’s SoHo loft and her home in upstate New York.
An increasing number of lawmakers are pushing to dock their own salaries by 5 percent in an effort to show that Congress is prepared to sacrifice as the economy stumbles.

In Baghdad, Michael Kamber interviewed Iraqis about their outlook on the upcoming election. On the streets, the mood is subdued but cautiously optimistic that the election would come off without major violence. Many appear somewhat cynical that the election will bring a quick change in their lives.

At a budget committee meeting on Wednesday, Deputy Controller Monique Zmuda presented to the Board of Supervisors her latest report on the city's overtime expenditures [PDF] - including pending payments to a firefighter who logged 1,053 hours of overtime in the first 193 days of this fiscal year.
After a long, cruel winter, Paris is awakening to spring. Check out these magical photo exhibitions and enchanted storefronts.

Karina Murga, 27, was born and raised in Constitución, Chile, where she lived with her mother, daughter and other family members until Saturday. Early that morning, when the 8.8 magnitude earthquake struck Chile and badly damaged Constitución, Karina's six-year-old Carla was staying with her godmother, Cristina Vergara, and her godmother's son, Jorge Zurita.

In the tradition of Jenna Wortham's posts on Internet etiquette, Nick Bilton over on the Bits blog dove into two thorny topics -- the dos and don'ts of sending text messages during dinner and the ethics of riffling through the e-mail and text messages of a spouse or significant other -- in a discussion with Diane Sawyer of ABC.

Two  reinsurance companies based in Bermuda -- the Max Capital Group and Harbor Point -- announced Wednesday afternoon that they had agreed to merge, forming a combined company that would be renamed Alterra Capital Holdings.
Carnival Cruise Lines has reversed a rule that sought to prevent travel agents from mentioning the company's name or its trademarks on social media sites like Facebook and Twitter.

DETROIT -- Following a 47-year career in the car business that earned him a reputation as an innovative but outspoken maverick, Bob Lutz will retire from General Motors on May 1. The announcement came after a major reorganization that G.M. announced on Tuesday.

Lovers of historic musical instruments are living on a roller coaster. Weeks after the Victoria & Albert Museum in London permanently shut down its renowned collection on the subject, the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York reopened its musical instrument gallery after eight months of refurbishing.

PEORIA, Ariz. - Tim Lincecum was 4 years old when Ken Griffey Jr. made his major league debut in 1989 for the Seattle Mariners, Lincecum's local team. Lincecum starred at Liberty High School in Renton, Wash., and then at the University of Washington, before winning the last two National League Cy Young Awards for the San Francisco Giants. Still, he had never met Griffey until Wednesday.

There's prestige, sure, and the conventional wisdom holds that small films get a much-needed box office bump from awards attention. But it turns out so do blockbusters.

At the turn of the century, magazine and catalog illustrations of the latest fashion collections were rather dry, using models who acted more like cutout dolls. It took the work of Baron Adolph de Meyer to loosen up fashion editorial with challenging portraits in the pages of Vogue, Vanity Fair and Harper's Bazaar. A rare showing of more than 100 of his society portraits, commercial fashion photography and still lifes recently opened at Robert Miller Gallery (through April 3; robertmillergallery.com).

A Funny Or Die video brings together almost every surviving "S.N.L." cast member who has ever played a U.S. president, including Fred Armisen, Will Ferrell, Darrell Hammond, Dana Carvey, Dan Aykroyd and Chevy Chase.

We were happy enough at the start of this Funny Or Die video to see the "Saturday Night Live" alumna Maya Rudolph playing Michelle Obama -- just to see Ms. Rudolph playing anyone, really. But beyond those first few crucial seconds, there's a skit reuniting almost every surviving "S.N.L." cast member who has ever played a United States president: Fred Armisen as Barack Obama; Will Ferrell as George W. Bush; Darrell Hammond as Bill Clinton; Dana Carvey as George H. W. Bush; Dan Aykroyd as Jimmy Carter; and even Chevy Chase as Gerald Ford.

People who suffer from fibromyalgia experience problems beyond the pain caused by their illness. Their condition is little understood and hard to explain, and often they are disbelieved by doctors. Even friends and loved ones may express skepticism toward the fibromyalgia sufferer, who, burdened with inexplicable pain, may cancel social plans, miss work and recoil from physical affection because it hurts too much.
Sometimes it's the kids who need help navigating the social shoals of elementary school. Sometimes it's the parents.

Natalie Dessay has withdrawn as Ophélie from the Metropolitan Opera's production of "Hamlet," by Ambroise Thomas, because of illness, the Met said on Wednesday. Marlis Petersen, who was to have sung one performance, on April 9, will take her place for the first six shows - on March 16, 20, 24, 27, 30 and April 2. Another soprano, as yet to be announced, will sing the last two performances, on April 5 and 9. Simon Keenlyside sings the title role. The Met has not staged the work since 1897.

After Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, sent a letter to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Wednesday morning requesting a "leave of absence" from his post as chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, the presiding officer of the House announced that "the resignation is accepted."

A court decision chastising the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission for its failure to take action on certain landmark designation requests and calling for new expedited procedures has been reversed on appeal.

Chase used to offer a Cash Plus card that offered 5 percent cash back for purchases made in everyday categories like gas stations, grocery stores and drugstores and 1 percent back on all other spending. But it stopped marketing the card in 2006.

This season the road from the airport lounge to the fashion runway has been particularly short. After the "36 Hour Race" through the London shows, we survived a hectic and hysterical "Fashion Weekend" in Milan, where the calendar of presentations had been collapsed into three days of overlapping shows, impossible delays and events that went way into the night without any breaks for lunch or a sit-down dinner.

American Ballet Theater says it will skip its regular two weeks of performances this coming fall and use the time to rehearse its new "Nutcracker" production, which will run at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. After 10 years of fall performances at New York City Center, Ballet Theater moved to Avery Fisher Hall in October. No fall home has been decided on for 2011, said Rachel S. Moore, the company's executive director. "We're looking at lots of different places," she said. Ms. Moore said that the one-time costs of creating sets and costumes for the "Nutcracker," which is being choreographed by Alexei Ratmansky, also precluded fall performance this year. Overall, Ballet Theater will stage an equal number of performances, Ms. Moore said. The Wall Street Journal reported the skipped fall weeks on Wednesday. The company  will continue with its spring performances at the Metropolitan Opera.

From an outsider's perspective, the aesthetics of heavy metal music can seem fairly predictable. There are usually copious amounts of black, images of things rotting and references to corpses, funerals and obscure diseases - not to mention inadvertently comical names like Hypothalamus. Religious symbols will almost certainly be defaced. And when a book comes out on a legendary logo designer like Christophe Szpajdel, it will have the appearance of a hymnal, with its flexible, pebbled cover embossed with gold type in some vaguely Gothic font. Well, naturally. The funny thing is what happens once you crack it open - turns out Szpajdel, a 38-year-old Belgian whose day job is in forestry engineering, isn't all that inspired by death after all.

Sade's "Soldier of Love" (Epic) is No. 1 on Billboard's album chart for the third week in a row. "Soldier of Love" sold 127,000 copies last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan, bringing its three-week total to 820,000. Lady Antebellum's "Need You Now" (Capitol Nashville) holds at No. 2 with 118,000 sales, and Johnny Cash's "American VI: Ain't No Grave" (American/Lost Highway), said to be the last of Cash's prolific late sessions with Rick Rubin, opens at No. 3 with 54,000. More than 100 institutions of higher learning in this country are classified as historically black colleges and universities. That formal designation originated in 1980, when President Jimmy Carter signed an executive order to establish a federal program "to overcome the effects of discriminatory treatment and to strengthen and expand the capacity of historically black colleges and universities to provide quality education.'' Last month, President Obama signed an executive order of his own that would add nearly $100 million to the program.

A clutch is one of those things that will be around for a while. They're just so classic, really - I've got clutches from the '30s, in that envelope style that's really simple and not too overdone. This one is part of the collection that I just designed for Longchamp, and you can actually stuff a load of things in it and bash it around. The leather is textured to look like shagreen, which I love. Most bags are too heavy to carry things in, and so many of them are stiff, and you know it's going to take years to mess them up. I like things that are already worn in, something tactile that's going to be comfortable on your skin. When I was working on the collection, I showed it to my daughter, but she's a bit - you know. She just said, "Yeah, it's all right." She prefers bling and Hello Kitty. She says she doesn't like Hello Kitty anymore, but I know she really does. I mean, I love it, too. The American Medical Association last week released its annual study examining competition in the health insurance market. The verdict: competition is dwindling. In 24 of the 43 states studied, the two biggest insurers together covered at least 70 percent of the market. Last year, that was true in 18 of 42 states studied.

As The Times reported back in December, galleries all over the city are moving from the storefront to the home front. The latest addition to this mini-movement? Paul Johnson of Johnson Trading, a design gallery on Greenwich Street, just opened a show called "Home" in the Chrystie Street loft he calls, well, his home. The subject of the show is the self-taught 60-something outsider artist Robert Loughlin. Loughlin spent most of his life being a picker (or chineur), one of those people scouring flea markets looking for rare resalable gems among the rummage - always in the hopes of "selling Andy Warhol a cookie jar," as the writer Irwin Warren put it in his foreword for the show's program. Johnson started out as a picker himself, and about 10 years ago he began buying pieces from the back of Loughlin's pickup truck at the old Chelsea flea market. His collection now comprises more than 500 pieces, from chairs, canvases, record covers, advertising posters and other bizarre objects - ivory teeth and baby seats - all scribbled on with Loughlin's Tom of Finland-esque signature smoking head, obsessively filling every single one of the loft's 4,500 square feet. To this day, Loughlin still peddles his pieces (for $300 and up) at the Chelsea flea market, but it is unlikely anybody will ever be able to accumulate a collection of similar size or quality as Johnson's (not to mention as elegantly hung by the decorator to the stars Ricky Clifton). "I definitely have enough now, and I don't have any more space in my house," says Johnson when asked whether he'll continue collecting Loughlin. He pauses, before adding "Unless it's really good."

Sonoma County to Check Immigration Status | Starting Friday, the fingerprints of those arrested in Sonoma County will be sent electronically to the Department of Homeland Security and checked for immigration violations. Sonoma will be the first county in the Bay Area to participate in the department's "Secure Communities" program. Critics say the program gives local law enforcement officials a bigger role in immigration enforcement, which is conducted by the federal government. The program, which began in late 2008, is now used in 10 California counties, including Sacramento, Los Angeles and San Diego. "This is a common-sense approach: Everyone who gets arrested gets checked for immigration status," said Matt McCaffrey, a sheriff's captain. "In this case, they're already in the system for entering into the country illegally or for having a record." Separately, a United States district court judge will hold a hearing on Wednesday in Oakland on a lawsuit filed by the American Civil Liberties Union, accusing the Sonoma County Sheriff's Office of routinely holding Latinos longer than the maximum 72 hours for immigration detention. [The Santa Rosa Press Democrat]

The Armory Show 2010, which opens on Thursday, promises to be one of the biggest art events of the year, literally. Last year's fine art fair at Piers 92 and 94 drew 56,000 visitors and over 200 dealers. Tonight MoMA is hosting a kick-off event at the museum to celebrate this year's exhibition. The party, which begins at 8:30 p.m., features a live performance by The Walkmen. The New York indie band, which, Ben Sisario writes, plays "exquisitely articulated songs of exhaustion and disaffection," will perform music off its most recent album in the Agnes Gund Garden Lobby. Adding to the mix will be the D.J. Justin Miller and the experimental band Human Rights, featuring members of Beirut, Psychic Ills, No Regular Play, and Volcano the Bear. Tickets for the party, which is also a benefit, start at $100. A shuttle bus will be available to transport guests from the Armory show at Piers 92 and 94 to MoMA.

How do you pay tribute to one of the greatest composers of all time on the occasion of his 200th birthday? A weeklong series of performances featuring 200 hours of the composer's work performed on five pianos sounds just about right. This week the Winter Garden at the World Financial Center is presenting just such a tribute to Frederic Chopin, who would have celebrated the big 2-0-0 on March 1. The festival, which runs daily beginning at 9 a.m., through Friday, includes an eclectic mix of performers, with Eduardus Halim, Kimball Gallagher, Vassily Primakov, Jeffrey Swann and tonight's featured artist, Christopher O'Riley. The performance by Mr. O'Riley, the host of "From the Top" on NPR, will begin at 7 p.m.

"Midpriced Italian restaurants can be as predictable as cupcake places," writes Julia Moskin, "the same five flavors show up all over town. When one breaks the mold, like Testaccio, which opened in December with a Roman menu, we go." Testaccio, in Long Island City, is run by chef Ivan Beacco. The Roman inspiration is evident in the "braised oxtail, flower-like fried artichokes, and soft gnocchi with roasted exteriors, just glazed with tomato and gilded with cheese." Skip the "over-topped pizza" and instead go for the dishes that "get everything right — the smokiness of guanciale in bucatini all'amatriciana, a dressing's vinegary contrast to creamy-firm white beans and chunks of roast pork, an overlay of bottarga on spaghetti with garlic and clams." The location in Queens may seem like a far cry from Italy, but, Ms. Moskin adds, this stretch of Vernon Boulevard is "dark at night, but dotted with bright restaurants — like the original Testaccio, an unfancy neighborhood on the edge of Rome."

FONTEIN--Pieter Dirk Matak, from Kennbunk, Maine, a former shipping executive for many years in New York City passed away on February 22, 2010 in Kennebunk. Mr. Fontein was 91. Pieter was born in Sneek, Holland on April 27, 1918 to Fredrik and Alida Fontein. He served in World War II from 1940 to 1945 with the Royal Dutch Navy. He was married to Elfrieda van der Zee in London on February 8, 1945. Pieter worked for Holland America Lines, Northern Pan American Lines, where he rose to President, and West Wind Africa Line. Before moving to Kennebunk in 2007, he and his family lived in Oradell, NJ for 54 years. Pieter leaves behind his wife, Elfrieda; his four children, Edward, Madeleine, Frederik and Christine; 11 grandchildren and two great- grandchildren. The family will have a memorial service for their beloved patriarch in July in Biddeford Pool, Maine.

STEERS--Patricia Katherine, known to her friends as PK, died peacefully at her home in New York City on February 12 attended by close friends. She had led a long and enriching life in the arts both as a performer and an educator, initially as a ballerina with the New York City Ballet, which she joined in the early 50's. Within a few years, she was assigned soloist roles and appeared in many Balanchine and Robbins works. With the blessing of Balanchine, she joined the Paris Opera Ballet as a guest artist for a season. After leaving the New York City Ballet, she danced with Bill Carter as his partner in his Dance Ensemble company, touring in the United States and Italy. She also appeared in dancing roles in the Hollywood films Oklahoma, Seven Brides for Seven Brothers and The Joker's Wild. In a departure from her performing career, she attended Yale University where in 1987 she earned a graduate degree in architecture. Her experience as a dancer in space relationships, lighting, and set and costume design served her well. Later, she designed spaces for private clients. In 1990, she joined the Regis High School faculty as a teacher in the fine arts department conducting classes in Studio Art and Architectural Design. She also served on design juries and as a guest lecturer at Yale University and the New York School of Interior Design. Her husband J. Rich Steers predeceased her in 2000. She is survived by her brother Sean McGrath and stepsons James, George, Philip and Robert Steers. Her friends have been deeply impressed by her many accomplishments, generosity, and enviable, unflagging drive despite very compromising health problems in her later years. A memorial Mass and service will be held at Regis High School on March 5 at 9am.

STARK--Stephen, passed away on March 1, 2010, New York City. He will be missed by his domestic partner of 19 years Philip Ong, his sister Cynthia Kadish, brother Mel Stark, sister-in-law Carole Stark, four nephews, one niece, six great-nieces and three great-nephews. Mr. Stark was born and raised in Brooklyn was a proud Brooklynite. He retired from New York City Hall as The Chief Legislative Unit in 2000 after thirty-one years of service to New York City. He loved to travel and did extensively after his retirement. Services will be held on Wednesday, March 3rd, 2010 at 1pm in The Weinstein Chapel, located at 1153 Coney Island Avenue in Brooklyn NY, 718-377-4848. The family will observe Shiva at his home Brooklyn Heights on Wednesday after the services, Thursday and Friday. Also, Shiva at Mel Stark's home. Call for directions. He was a kind and generous person, who was loved by all those fortunate enough to have known him. May his soul rest in peace.

SCHERMAN--David, 58, of Topsfield, Massachusetts died on Monday, March 1, after a long illness. He was born in New York City on November 9, 195l, the son of William H. Scherman and Alice Elizabeth Wall, and was educated at Pelham, NY schools, Holderness in NH, and Berklee College of Music in Boston. A true Thoreauvian, he went to the woods to live, and in spite of a chronic illness, explored facets of his life to the fullest, becoming a wonderfully talented musician as well as an expert on sound technology, politics, bird watching, geology, American literature, the Buddhist dharma, and until recently, hiking in the White Mountains. His blog, The Natural World, has been much praised. David was a devoted Red Sox fan. He was an incomparable and beloved friend to his sister, Betsy Smith, his brothers Rowland, Thomas (deceased), Daniel and Timothy Scherman, his stepmother, Germaine Gantaume Day, and many friends who loved him and whom he loved.

SUDER--Frances. After suffering a stroke on February 26, Frances Suder passed peacefully on March 1st. Frances was a talented artist and exhibited her oils and watercolors in many art shows, earning a number of prizes. Her shows included two one-person exhibits in New York City, Soho and W. 57th St., to critical acclaim. Born in Patterson, NJ on March 14, 1927, Frances graduated from Parsons School of Design in 1947 and worked for a textile designer until she married her life partner in 1951. She and her loving husband of 58 years are the parents of three devoted and adoring children Michael of Englewood, NJ, Jonathan of Ft. Worth, Texas and Nicolle of New York City. Frances was also blessed with six grandchildren, Morgan, Jason, Roxanne, Margo, Ryan and Natalie, who lovingly referred to her as "Mimi." She is survived by her husband and all of her children and grandchildren. Another of Frances' passions was her philanthropic work. She was chairman of the State of Israel Bonds in Bergen County, Director in Women's Division of UJA of Northern New Jersey, and a life member of Hadassah. She was an excellent speaker and travelled across the country to lecture for these causes. Recently, Frances, and Isaac funded an art gallery at Boys Town Jerusalem, which also trained young students. Contributions in her memory can be sent to the Boys Town Jerusalem Foundation at: 1 Penn Plaza, Suite 6250, New York, NY 10019, Attn: Ronald Gray. Services will be on Wednesday, March 3 at 11am at Gutterman and Musicant Jewish Funeral Directors 402 Park St. Hackensack, NJ

The country's highest court ruled Tuesday that a security law requiring the mass storage of telephone, e-mail and Internet data violated a constitutional provision on privacy and must be revised. The 2008 law required telecommunication companies to retain customer usage data for six months so authorities could use it to track criminal networks. Although the Federal Constitutional Court did not rule out some form of data retention, it ordered records stored under the law to be deleted ''without delay.'' The court said that the data storage was not secure enough and that it was clear how the data would be used. Nearly 35,000 people had joined a class-action suit opposing the law.

GARNETT--James Mercer. Died on March 2nd, 2010 at age 84 in Jamestown, RI. Was born in Chestnut Hill, PA and received an undergraduate degree from Yale University in 1950. There he was a member of the Beta Theta Pi fraternity and the Scroll and Key Society. He was a proud veteran of World War ll, serving in the famed Marine 5th Division, engaged in the Battle of Iwo Jima, and with the occupational forces in Japan. He was with Marsh McLennan Insurance brokers in New York and in London where he served as Vice President and Manager of the office. He completed his career as Vice President of FJ Wilkes & Co. in New York, retiring in 1992 to his summer community of Jamestown, RI. He was a member of the Yale Club of New York; the Newport Reading Room, Newport, RI; the Conanicut Yacht Club, Jamestown, RI; and a former member of the Clambake Club of Newport, RI; as well as the Field Club and Stanwich Club in Greenwich, CT. He is survived by his wife, Sally Begg Garnett; his sister Anne Wister Garnett Boenning; his brother Stephen Hunter Garnett; and his half brother, Muscoe Russell Hunter Garnett, Jr. He is also survived by his four children, Jane Marvel Garnett, James Mercer Garnett, Jr., Sidney Scott Garnett and William Barclay Garnett, and eight grandchildren. He also leaves many loved in-laws, cousins, nephews and nieces. He was pre-deceased by his parents, Muscoe Russell Hunter Garnett and Caroline Barclay Strong, as well as his half sister, Agnes Wallace Garnett Leary. A private graveside service, officiated by the Rev. Kevin Lloyd of St. Mathew's Episcopal Church, will be held at Cedar Hill Cemetery in Jamestown, RI. In lieu of flowers, please donate to the charity of your choice.

FAIL--James M.,was a true southern gentleman who never met a challenge that did not excite him or an adventure that did not inspire him. He was a successful businessman and a generous philanthropist. Most recently, he served as the chairman of Stone Holdings, his Dallas-based financial holding company. A native of Mobile, Alabama, he attended Murphy High School and served three years in the U.S. Navy before graduating from the University of Alabama in 1949. His lifelong respect for education manifested itself in his numerous gifts to both educational facilities and individuals, including his establishing a scholarship at Birmingham Southern College for "any worthy and deserving student." This reiterated his belief that education was the greatest gift he could offer. In 2009, he was honored by the University of the South at Sewanee with a Doctorate of Civil Law honoris causa. James' love for music began at a young age with the violin, viola, and trombone. He played in the Murphy High School band and continued to enjoy performing with the Woody Herman Big Band and the Swingles in the 1940s. Later, he was a generous supporter of the Phoenix Symphony, serving as director, and the Mobile Symphony; making a sizable donation endowing its principal cello chair in memory of his wife. His great enthusiasm for sports lead him to repeatedly give to the Crimson Tide Foundation. His first donation enabled the University to build the department's media suite, named for his father- in-law, Naylor Stone, whom he greatly admired. In 2008, much to his delight and befitting his wonderful sense of humor, the University of Alabama found a way to thank him for his ongoing support by naming the visitor's room at Bryant-Denny Stadium "The Fail Room." He gained a great deal of joy from making the long journey to Pasadena this January to see the Crimson Tide win the National Championship. James' adventurous and always curious nature led him to make many great trips around the world. He took great joy in bringing his family and friends with him to share the experiences of faraway lands and new cultures; stories of these trips always entertained and inspired those around him. Mr. Fail was a member of Kappa Sigma fraternity, the Economic Club of New York and a founder of its Centennial Society, the Metropolitan Club of New York, Phoenix Country Club, the Summit Club, The Inverness Country Club, The Club of Birmingham, and The Noah Society. He attended St. Mary's-on-the-Highlands Episcopal Church. James was preceded in death by his wife, Emily Stone Fail; his son, James Naylor Fail; and his parents, Joe and Rosalie Fail. He is survived by his daughters Kathryn Luttrull and Marcia Boykin, both of Phoenix, Arizona; his grandchildren Lindsay, Hayley, Bobby, Marbury, Liza, Grey, Coulter, and Malcolm; his great-grandchildren Stone, Jonas, and Dahlia; brothers Alton and Charles Fail, and a large extended family. Throughout his successes, James Fail never lost his humility and maintained his generosity to a fault. With his beloved wife Emily, he was a shining example of how to live a rich and joyful life. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the University of Alabama general scholarship fund or St. Mary's-on-the-Highlands.Visitation will be held Wednesday, March 3, 2010 from 6pm until 8pm at Johns-Ridout's Southside. A funeral service will be held on Thursday, March 4, 2010 at 11am at St. Mary's-on-the-Highlands, with burial to follow at Elmwood Cemetery. A celebration of his life will follow at the Veranda Restaurant.

One of the darkest days in the illustrious 141-year history of Goldman Sachs was September 19, 2008, when investor confidence in Wall Street was at its nadir and Lloyd Blankfein, Goldman's chief executive, called John Mack, then the top man at Morgan Stanley. Mack was struggling to keep Morgan Stanley afloat in the wake of the collapse of Bear Stearns, Lehman Brothers, Merrill Lynch and American International Group. Goldman could have been the next to fail if Morgan Stanley did not pull through. "You have to hang on, because I'm 30 seconds behind you," Blankfein told Mack. Two days later, the Federal Reserve allowed both Goldman and Morgan Stanley to become bank holding companies, ending an era on Wall Street but likely saving our banking system.

The longstanding legal dispute between the author Clive Cussler and Crusader Entertainment took a new twist on Wednesday when a California appeals court reversed a lower court order that Mr. Cussler pay Crusader $5 million for alleged bad faith dealings over the movie "Sahara." The appeals court upheld the trial court in rejecting Mr. Cussler's claim that he was owed $8.6 million by Crusader. The ruling, which came from a three-judge panel of the second appellate district in Los Angeles, sent the long-standing dispute between Mr. Cussler and Crusader back to the lower court to determine who, if anyone, had actually prevailed in the case. That determination will affect the assignment of responsibility for legal costs.

Why is there no Jewish Narnia? That's the provocative question raised by Michael Weingrad's essay on Judaism and fantasy novels, published in the inaugural issue of the Jewish Review of Books.  Note that Weingrad is talking about fantasy as a genre, not the use of the fantastic as a literary tool. (So the existence of Kafka and Isaac Bashevis Singer does not disprove his thesis.) And note, as well, that the piece is not entitled "Why Are There No Jewish Fantasy Novelists?" To the extent that Weingrad raises that question, he's pretty easily refuted. But really he's raising a deeper issue, one that goes to the nature of the genre itself: "Why are there no works of modern fantasy that are profoundly Jewish in the way that, say, 'The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe' is Christian? Why no Jewish [C.S.] Lewises, and why no Jewish Narnias?"

The schedule of the Moscow State Radio Symphony Orchestra, on a marathon United States tour, calls for a two-hour drive from St. Louis, then a concert Thursday evening at the Jesse Auditorium at the University of Missouri. The program, as usual for this tour, is all Russian: Rimsky-Korsakov's "Tsar's Bride" Overture; Rachmaninoff's Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini, Op. 43, with Alexander Sinchuk as piano soloist; and Rimsky-Korsakov's "Scheherazade" suite. Read about this orchestra's journeys here.

The day of action was just that. People marching, whistling, chanting. Occasionally, the demonstrations became confrontational. At the University of California at Davis, police used tear gas to stop about 100 protesters from marching on to Interstate 80.  In Oakland, a group of 100 to 150 protesters approached Interstate 880 at Jackson Street. Authorities closed the freeway down in both directions. Protesters at the University of California, Santa Cruz surrounded the car while its uninjured driver was inside. Earlier, demonstrators blocked campus gate. But mostly protesters were peaceful. Several hundred people, including 80 students, parents, teachers and volunteers from Marshall Elementary school, joined a march that began at 16th and Mission streets in San Francisco and walked to city hall where a rally began at 5 p.m. At San Francisco State University, students, faculty and administrators gathered at Malcolm X plaza for political theater and poetry readings. In downtown Oakland, protesters from the University of California, Berkeley arrived singing  "Ain't no power like the power of the people cause the power of the people don't stop! ... Say what?" Younger students from Fremont gathered on the sidewalks to watch them flow down the middle of the street.   At a noon rally at Berkeley City College, students read poetry and rapped in defense of public education, singing, "We aren't under attack only in the east but here on our streets/Why do we favor ignorance with false peace?/ Education should be free, but fair/K-12 in the hoods goes nowhere."

Anne Pasternak, the director of the public arts organization Creative Time, claims she has never watched porn on pay-per-view in a hotel room. "But it is such a no-brainer for a hotel to have a good art channel!" she insists. And now, with the introduction of the Standart Video Series, the Standard Hotel will add exactly that to its list of in-room entertainment. Curated by Creative Time, this art channel will feature a seasonal menu of works by cutting-edge artists of various visual persuasions. In the first batch alone, guests will have their choice of action/adventure (the Neistat Brothers's "Yougurt vs. Gasoline"), political thriller (Bruce High Quality Foundation's faux-Marxist critique of the art world, "L'eau de Vie un Film de Jean-Luc Godard") and drama (Lee Walton's "F'Book, What My Friends Are Doing on Facebook"). Marilyn Minter's high-definition "Green Pink Caviar," with its macro views of slurping tongues, comes the closest to actual porn. The videos will be available for your viewing pleasure at all four Standard Hotel locations. Best of all, they're free. So don't be shy about watching Martha Colburn's "Triumph of the Wild" 17 times. It won't show up on your bill.

At the start of his career at Balenciaga, in the late '90s, Nicolas Ghesquiere was often fascinated by sports and science fiction, childhood hobbies. Then he explored the couture traditions of the house's founder, Cristóbal Balenciaga. In recent years, older and more mature, he has been captivated by images of the future, sometimes blending them with the past. Along the way he established separate lines, for knits, silks and limited editions, that helped to make Balenciaga profitable, but when it comes to the collections he presents in Paris, there has almost always been a sense of a designer free to create. That was again the invigorating experience this morning at the Hôtel de Crillon, on a specially installed white laboratory floor, where Mr. Ghesquiere showed a highly textured collection that looked well beyond the fall of 2010.

After three years of meetings and study, a broad array of conservation groups, government scientists and other experts on North American wildlife policy have produced a road map for restoring some large free-roaming populations of bison in the North American plains. The hurdles are many, with one of the biggest simply finding ways to acquire broad stretches of land that can accommodate the wandering species. Another is consolidating a maze of local, state and federal policies that treat the animals in different ways. Many Western states, for instance, classify bison as livestock and not wildlife, the report authors say, hampering how they can be managed in the wild. Here's the full report on restoring bison. (The video above is courtesy of the Wildlife Conservation Society.)

It's strange, the way we mourn our writers. We react to the news of their passing, typically, by rushing out to buy their books. Volumes that have sat on shelves for years, gathering dust and perhaps remainder stickers, are suddenly carried off in stacks. For many writers, especially those in midcareer or of midrange repute, death is the best (and last) great sales push they ever get. I like to think of the posthumous book purchase as an example of what Raymond Carver called "a small good thing," offered up as consolation and condolence for those yet living, part of the same chain of motive that fills homes in mourning with casseroles and pies.

Before Wallace Stevens became a great poet known for his "verbal ebullience and New England spareness," he was a journalist beating the pavement for the New York Evening Post. Those early years spent in the city informed his later work, and, beginning today, you can see how when New York University and the Poetry Society of America present "Wallace Stevens, New York, and Modernism." The conference, which runs through March 6 and is free and open to the public, includes readings, talks and presentations by literary luminaries like Mark Strand, Edward Hirsch, Elizabeth Willis and many more.

Not all of us can amass an art collection like Jeff Koons. The pop artist has works by Manet, Picasso and Poussin piled up, salon-style, on the walls of his Upper East Side home, not to mention an 1873 Courbet over his flat-screen television. But for those aspiring collectors working on a slightly smaller scale, the Guggenheim is the place to be tonight. The museum is auctioning off 200 works by artists, architects and designers from the exhibition "Contemplating the Void: Interventions in the Guggenheim Museum." The auction, a finale to the museum's 50th anniversary celebrations, will benefit the museum's exhibition programming. First preview the work and then take in a performance by Animal Collective, the artist Danny Perez and Transverse Temporal Gyrus, featuring original recorded music created specifically for this event. The late show at 9 p.m. is sold out but there are still tickets available for the early show at 4:30 p.m. The auction items will be sold online from March 4 through 18 at charitybuzz.com/guggenheim.

"It's easy to feel alive with possibility, or delusional, at the new Hermès store for men, which welcomes wealth in all its glory and repugnance," writes Jon Caramanica. This store, which opened last month across Madison Avenue from the flagship, "is a thoughtful balance of expert craftsmanship and luxury kitsch, a four-floor clubhouse that somehow manages the feel of a high-end department store." Mr. Caramanica suggests picking a desired persona, say a disheveled and raffish Julian Schnabel or Robert Redford in "Out of Africa," and making the fantasy a reality with a few choice pieces, like a rough linen-cotton blend blazer with soft suede beneath the collar. "Soon I was writing scenes of my new life in my head, most ending with a quick nuzzle from Olatz as I come in the door at Palazzo Chupi, before we sneak upstairs for an assignation on her signature crest-appliquéd Egyptian cotton sheets." The store is filled with other aspirational items. "Most dazzling is one of the store's showpieces, a chocolate leather baseball jacket perforated in an H pattern, wearable by rappers and Mediterranean tourists, but probably not you."

JAFFE--Andrew. The Board of Directors and Officers of The One Club mourn the passing of their dear friend, colleague and advisor Andrew Jaffe, who lost his long battle with cancer. Our thoughts go out to Eileen, his son Christopher, stepson Nicholas, and brothers Steve and Bruce.

A Mount Sinai professor since 1968, he taught generations of medical students and OB/GYN residents, and established Mount Sinai's first cytology laboratory. A practicing physician until his 93rd year, he is believed to have delivered more babies than anyone else at Mount Sinai. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Lucille, his children and grandchildren, and the entire Lapid family. Peter W. May, Chairman of the Boards of Trustees, The Mount Sinai Medical Center Kenneth L. Davis, M.D., President and CEO, The Mount Sinai Medical Center

In the beginning, before fish, before man, there was a garden. And the earth brought forth vegetation, beautiful to behold, sustenance for the body. And it was good. Or at least that was my vision -- a vegetable garden right outside the dining room of the restaurant I am preparing to open. A large window was custom-made for patrons to look upon it, and an emergency exit was moved and a ramp was reconfigured to avoid visual interference and unwanted traipsing through the garden.

Our condolences to Gloria, Edward and Jodi, Steven and Rena and the grandchildren.

LAPID--Louis S. The Association of the Attending Staff of the Mount Sinai Hospital mourns the passing of our long-standing colleague, mentor and friend. Dr. Lapid came to Mount Sinai as a resident in 1941 where he completed his residency, fellowship, and a research fellowship in Gynecology. He was a superb clinician in the field of Obstetrics and a compassionate practitioner of medicine. A highly respected surgeon and teacher, Dr. Lapid was adored by his patients and considered the "consummate physician" by his colleagues. He was vigorously involved in the total care of his patients and helped train generations of Mount Sinai students and residents. In 1993, he received the Jacobi Medallion award for distinguished achievement in his field and outstanding service to the institution. He will be remembered as an extraordinary diagnostician whose special smile lives on in the many lives he touched. We extend our sincere condolences to his entire family. Steven B. Weinfeld, MD, President Gila Leiter, MD, Vice President Amy J. Weinstein, Administrator

SIMONS--Victoria Alda, 65, former editor/co-owner of the Independent Newspapers of Hillsdale, recent executive director of Columbia County Bounty, died March 1 at home in Ghent. Daughter of Henry and Harriette Simons, of Manhattan, who survives, as does husband Tony Jones of Ghent; daughters Eleanor Jones Rossi (Robert) of Brooklyn and Mara Simons-Jones of Austin; sons Christopher Jones (Gwenda Marchione) of Ghent, Jayson Simons-Jones of Crested Butte, Hamilton Simons-Jones (Annette) of New Orleans; brother Adam Simons of Los Angeles.

SABBAGH--Hasib Jirries. Acceptance of condolences, "Those who live and believe in me will never die." (John 11:26).
