GROSS--Sylvia, died February 24, four days short of her 81st birthday. A loyal daughter, niece, cousin, and friend, Sylvia was beloved coast to coast. After her long career in the wholesale jewelry business of New York and Los Angeles, Sylvia lived vivaciously in Las Vegas, where she made very dear friends. As a breast cancer survivor, she devoted herself passionately to advocacy for its cure. She was a proud member of Obama's "Kitchen Cabinet". Sylvia loved her diverse friends and enjoyed jazz, tai chi, and Lakers games with them. She will be remembered fondly. Donations on her behalf may be made to the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

HEINEMAN--Natalie G. A pioneering champion for children's welfare who died at the age of 96 on February 28, 2010, in her native city of Chicago, Illinois. She will be remembered by all who knew her as a persistent advocate for social services for children and youth, an expert on adoption and foster care issues, an independent woman of intellect who always followed her heart, and as a beautiful person, inside and out, devoted to family and friends. She was a kind and selfless person, beloved by all she met. Her remarkable marriage to Chicago business and civic leader Ben W. Heineman Sr. lasted nearly 75 years. She is survived by her beloved husband Ben, her daughter Dr. Martha Heineman Pieper (Dr. William Pieper) of Chicago and her son Ben W. Heineman Jr. (Cristine Russell) of New Canaan, CT; grandchildren Thalia Field (Jamie Jewett and son Benjamin), Dr. Jessica Heineman-Pieper (Dr. Param Srikantia), Johanna Heineman-Pieper, Victoria Stein (Jotham and son Gershon), Zachary Heineman and Matthew Heineman; and many nieces, nephews and other relatives. Natalie Goldstein was born on March 16, 1913, on the south side of Chicago and lived in the city throughout her life. She graduated from the University of Chicago and did graduate work there before becoming a medical social worker. Ben and Natalie married on April 17, 1935, and she went on to lead many local and national civic and charitable organizations. She became the first woman president of the Chicago Child Care Society in 1966 and later the president of the Child Welfare League of America, which named a national award for outstanding service to children in her honor. She was one of the first women on the United Way of America national board. Other local service included the Citizens' Committee of the Juvenile Court of Cook County; the visiting committee of the University of Chicago School of Social Service Administration, and the board of the Erikson Institute for Early Childhood Education. Natalie was an intrepid family photographer, a lover of opera and symphony, and an avid studio glass collector with her husband Ben. In 2006, they donated their renowned collection to the Corning Museum of Glass, Corning, NY. The family would like to thank Dr. Neil Stone for his devotion and care. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to the Chicago Child Care Society, 5467 S. University Ave. Chicago, IL 60615. (773) 643-0452 or www.cccsociety.org. Interment will be at the Heineman family mausoleum in Wausau, WI. A private memorial service is being planned.

While I certainly don't enjoy writing checks to the I.R.S., I seem to learn something new with each passing tax season. Our firm, a business brokerage, is structured as an L.L.C., and my husband and I are the only two members. As such, owners' health insurance and medical expenses are not deductible business expenses. I swore at the beginning of 2009 that I was going to switch our high-deductible health insurance plan to one that qualified for a Health Savings Account. Like so many other administrative tasks, that one sat on the back burner and never got done.

ESTES--Richard M. The Trustees and staff of the NYC Police Foundation note with sorrow the passing of our founding trustee and staunch supporter. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife, Pamela, his children Ken, Bill and Jessica and to the entire Estes family. Mr. Estes' dedicated service of over 30 years had a significant impact on our work, and we will indeed miss him. We are deeply grieved by his death, and feel fortunate to have known him. Valerie Salembier, Chair Gregg Roberts, Acting Executive Director

Dying to be the first on your block (or the first in America) to get a new 3-D TV? Sears and Amazon.com are taking orders for two Samsung 3-D-ready LCD TVs: the $2,600 46-inch UN46C7000, and the $3,300 55-inch UN55C7000 models. For those who had predicted that 3-D TVs would cost loads more than regular models, the prices may be a surprise. The new 55-inch model costs the same as Samsung's least-expensive LED-backlit LCD of the same size, the UN55B6000. And its new 46-inch set is priced exactly between its least-expensive and middle-rung LED-backlit TVs of the same size.

Engineering and structural-repair professionals say it is relatively easy to spot foundation problems in structures that are more than 10 years old. If you are considering buying a house, look for patched-over cracks in brick or drywall and doors that have been planed. Also notice if there are cracks in sidewalks and streets in the neighborhood. In newer developments, it's harder to know if the homes will withstand a shift in soil. Therefore, it might be a good idea to have a geotechnical engineer do an inspection -- in addition to having a normal home inspection -- before you buy. Home inspectors may not have the expertise to assess soil conditions. (Licensed professionals can be found at the Web site of the Associated Soil and Foundation Engineers, asfe.org)

I am a business owner with about 95 employees. I am trying to find the logic in the Senate jobs bill. You either need to hire someone or you don't. I can't imagine a company hiring someone because it is going to save on FICA, but for the sake of argument, let's say that lots of companies do just that. The proposed legislation also stipulates that the companies will get the tax break only if they hire workers who have been unemployed for at least 60 days. This stipulation encourages companies to violate the most basic tenet of good business, which is to hire the most qualified people. If in an effort to get the FICA break, companies pass over more qualified candidates who are guilty of being employed or of not being unemployed long enough, the government will have invented a whole new category of hiring discrimination.

ELIAS--Dr. Kurt. Died at 91 on March 1, 2010 in New York City. Kurt was the beloved husband of Dr. Gloria Clare and the devoted father of three children Peter, Joan and Margaret with his first wife, Nina Dutcher. Dr. Elias was the caring brother of Dr. Hannah Kapit and was much loved by his step-children, Catherine and Kenneth. Born in Vienna in 1918, he emigrated to the United States in 1938 where he completed his education and then practiced internal medicine and oncology with special dedication to the personal care of his patients. He was respected and loved by his family and friends, and will be deeply missed.

Two Olympians, defensemen Ryan Whitney of the United States and Lubomir Visnovsky of Slovakia, were dealt for each other Wednesday at the N.H.L. trade deadline. It was the busiest trading day in league history, but few significant players were involved as teams struggled to maneuver under the salary cap. In all, 31 deals were made on deadline day, topping the previous high of 25. The 55 players moved was also a record.
GROSS--Joan Twenty-seven years. Seems like yesterday. We never stop loving you. All of us.

STEARNS--James Pierce, 78, of Kent, CT, died of cancer March 2, 2010. He was born to James and Esther Stearns on January 15, 1932 in Boston. He is survived by his wife, Margaret Byard Stearns; two daughters, Sarah Stearns Fey of Greenwich, and Katherine Stearns Symonds (Kate) of New York City; two sisters, Elizabeth Malo and Janet May; and six grandchildren -- Jack, Jimmy and Charlie Symonds, and Daisy, Annie and Mercy Fey. An alumnus of Andover, Harvard and the University of Michigan Business School, he began a long career in education teaching mathematics at Noble and Greenough and Lawrenceville Schools. He was headmaster of Mary Institute in St. Louis (1969-1976) and Fairfield (CT) Country Day School (1976-1993). He loved music, and was an enthusiastic choral singer; he was a Krokodilo at Harvard and anchored the bass section wherever he was. He delighted in games, poetry, golf, Madaquecham, hors d'oeuvres, and beautiful dovetail joints. He knew every song lyric ever written and could make anybody laugh. Memorial service at 11am on Saturday, March 13, 2010 at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Kent, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to the Choir Fund, St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, 1 North Main St., Kent, CT 06757.

SHAPIRO--Alfred, 83, died on March 3 at the end of a life well lived, filled with purpose and joy. He lifted himself out of working class Brownsville, spending hours reading at the Brooklyn Library and attending Townsend Harris High School. Service in World War II took him all over Europe and to the University of Michigan for an economics degree. He went on to receive a Masters Degree in City Planning from Columbia University. His long public service career included The Federal Reserve Bank of New York, senior planning positions in Madison, WI, Newark, NJ and New York City, the position of Executive Director of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, and service on the board of the Metropolitan Center for Mental Health. He inspired his wife Jaclyn, children Matthew, Alexander and Annie, daughter-in-law Ellen Dubin, son-in-law Robert Tirschwell, grandchildren Harry, Sam, Theodore and Sebastian, family, friends and colleagues with a charming whirlwind of ideas, words, humor, song, food and drink. Memorial contributions may be made to The National Yiddish Book Center, 1021 West Street, Amherst, MA 01002. His family will observe shiva at 194 Riverside Dr. on Saturday and Sunday from 2-7pm.

My three-week absence from the office (for my wedding and honeymoon) helped me realize that I want to focus on three major goals this year: moving to a new and bigger office, sharpening our identity in a crowded market, and increasing sales. In two months, we will be relocating our company, which provides online backup services, to an office three times our current size and twice the cost of our current space. I want to make sure the new space is comfortable, efficient, inspiring and growth-oriented. After all, it will be in this space that we will be pursuing our goals. For the first time, we will be able to bring clients and prospective clients to our office for, among other things, training sessions.

Although he is known for his high-rises, resorts and golf courses, Donald J. Trump helped create a little-known state park in northern Westchester County, donating the land for public use in 2006. It also happens to be on a list of 58 parks and historic sites the state plans to close because of budget cuts.

9:30 P.M. (SNY) GOING HOME WITH JOHAN SANTANA Mr. Santana, the ace pitcher of the New York Mets, wasn't always living the high life. In this premiere episode of ''Going Home,'' which follows several of the team's players back to their roots, Mr. Santana travels to his native Venezuela, where he reminisces about Little League games, breaking an aluminum bat on his first home run and the mountain he used to climb before each game. He also visits his mother, his childhood home and his first-grade classroom, where he sits, above, and where he met his future wife. He also hands out more than 10,000 toys and pieces of sports equipment at a pre-Christmas festival. 7 A.M. (ABC) GOOD MORNING AMERICA Tom Hanks, in the role of executive producer, continues on the talk-show circuit on behalf of ''The Pacific,'' the HBO mini-series, starting March 14, about the Pacific Theater during World War II. He moves to ''Live With Regis and Kelly'' at 9 on ABC and the ''Late Show With David Letterman'' at 11:35 p.m. on CBS.

Once again, Pentax demonstrates a new focus on design with an update to its line of rugged cameras. The new $330 Optio W90 looks like it belongs on a mountainside (thanks to its included carabiner) and feels more solidly built than its predecessor, the Optio W80. The new Optio can snap photos in water down to 20 feet (the W80 could take photos at 16 feet). The company says it can withstand falls up to four feet (versus 3.3 feet for the W80), and can operate in temperatures as cold as 14 degrees Fahrenheit (this is the rated low temperature for most rugged cameras). Like the W80, the W90 has a resolution of 12.1 megapixels and a 28-to-140mm (equivalent) lens with 5X optical zoom. It can capture 720p high-definition video at 30 frames per second.

SKIERS and snowboarders have one thing in common: falling is often part of their alpine experience. Although most crashes injure only the ego, some high-profile accidents -- like the death of the actress Natasha Richardson last year on a beginner ski trail -- have brought safety to the forefront. This winter, Vail Resorts began requiring all employees at its five ski areas to wear helmets while skiing and snowboarding on the job. And a California state senator recently introduced a bill that would require helmet use in the state for skiers and snowboarders who are 18 or younger.

GLICK--Phyllis. The Trustees of Usdan Center for the Creative and Performing Arts mourn the loss of Phyllis Glick, a founding member of the Center's staff. A woman of gentle elegance, Phyllis's selfless concern for others was her life's hallmark. Trained as an opera singer, she became an administrator, one who set an enduring standard of excellence that touched the lives of thousands of Usdan students. Friends and colleagues will treasure their memories of Phyllis forever. A memorial service will be held at 5pm on Monday, March 8th at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street, Manhattan. John Usdan, President Dale Lewis, Executive Director

Upper Deck will pay Major League Baseball Properties a substantial but undisclosed amount of money for issuing three card sets since last year without a license, according to the settlement of a federal lawsuit. The company will also pay baseball $2.4 million to settle previous debts. In a lawsuit filed in January in federal court in Manhattan, MLB Properties accused Upper Deck of trademark infringement and asked that it be restrained from using the teams' uniform, helmet and cap logos. Upper Deck produced the cards with a license from the players union. In a statement, Upper Deck said that while it could continue to sell the card sets that were the focus of the lawsuit, it was not releasing other baseball card sets that were ''already in the pipeline.''

In the summer, Tuscany is full of Americans. But as Danielle Pergament recently discovered, the best time to visit may be wintertime, when the landscape is surprisingly green, locals fill the cafes, and the cuisine is at its best.

Traditionally the province of Fifth Avenue, Times Square or, lately, the Port Authority bus terminal, the pop-up shop has been slowly migrating to a more unorthodox setting: the art world. To wit, the perennially veiled A Shaded View on Fashion blogger Diane Pernet has curated Markt, a fashion-centric installation now in its second incarnation at New York's Scope Art Fair. The exhibition spotlights (and sells) the work of burgeoning designers, including Sandra Backlund, Lamija Suljevic and Six Scents Parfums. In addition to Backlund's horsehair vest and Suljevic's brocade dresses, fairgoers can purchase a video work from electroclashers Chicks on Speed and digitally generated photographic illustrations from Hormazd Narielwalla now through Sunday.

Using one another as pillows, like a family huddled together for warmth in a house without heat, most of the Marines were catching a little sleep before their mission was to begin. But one sat wide awake at the edge of their huddle.

Representative Eric Massa, Democrat from upstate New York, abruptly announced this afternoon that he would resign effective Monday -- rather than simply not seek re-election as he had said earlier this week -- because of an ethics inquiry.

Before the Super Bowl, advertising, marketing and media companies typically release the results of polls, surveys and analyses about the commercials during the big game. With signs pointing to a possible large upturn in viewership for the Academy Awards, to be broadcast by ABC on Sunday, there is a similar outpouring of data related to Oscar and movie ads.

In the Bay Area on Thursday, it was hard to go anywhere without running into people marching or a teacher handing out flyers, all part of the national protest over education cuts, as we wrote in a continually updated blog post.

Last month, the mayor's office unveiled new guidelines for assigning public defenders to represent indigent criminal defendants. Now, some defense organizations are voicing their displeasure, fearing that the new rules will take work from experienced lawyers and overburden less experienced ones.

If you want to understand the frantic, costly and bizarre campaign to win an Oscar, read Mark Harris's brilliant feature in New York Magazine from early last month. But if you're foolish enough to be interested in handicapping this year's results, read Hendrik Hertzberg on the new voting scheme that accompanied the expansion of the Best Picture nominees to 10. Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Skye Parrott.
Blimey! Perhaps the network known as ESPN (which began life as the Entertainment and Sports Programming Network) should change its name to the ENGLISH Sports Programming Network.

Is it for alliterative purposes ("Balenciaga Beats Balmain") that the fashion week schedule once again placed Paris's two resurgent couture giants of the New Look era head to head, Scorecard wonders? In any event, in this season of pared-down minimalist dressing, Christophe Decarnin's gilded-to-the-max showing looked new and innovative -- almost. That is, until critics thought back to Nicolas Ghesquière's neoprene-newsprint-packing material-puffa fest from the morning, which fast-forwarded us all into fashion's future.
John Galliano presents the fall 2010 collection.

In Athens, strikes hit schools, hospitals and public transportation. Police used tear gas on rioters as Parliament adopted its latest austerity package. Seven police officers were injured in the protests, among the most violent since Greece's financial crisis hit, and at least five demonstrators were arrested.
On the Lens Blog, our colleagues Patrick Witty and Tyler Hicks offer an intimate account of a Marine company as it prepared for and helped launch the Marja offensive, "Operation Moshtak."
Representative Eric J. Massa, a freshman Democrat from upstate New York who is under investigation for harassing a male aide, said on Friday that he would resign from the House.
There's talk once again - this time much more hopeful - of a return to M.&A. I am still skeptical for the reasons I noted in my year-end review.

Congress has invariably refused to take any serious measure against genocide while it is underway. So is it progress that the House Foreign Affairs Committee voted yesterday to condemn the 1915 genocide of Armenians? Is it worthwhile for Congress to deal with genocide at some level, even if it's 95 years late?

LOS ANGELES - As a warm-up to the big show on Sunday, indie filmmakers (and the actors that love them) have Film Independent's Spirit Awards, which celebrate their 25th anniversary on Friday with a splashier party on a rooftop in downtown Los Angeles, in lieu of the usual beach-side digs in Santa Monica. By all accounts it is one of the most fun nights of awards season - IFC will televise it live -- and the Bagger is excited to be there, tweeting away. To get a sense of what to expect, we recently spoke with another newbie, the show's host, the comedian and actor Eddie Izzard.

How will this year's Geneva auto show be remembered? Most likely as the show in which Porsche and Ferrari brought out their exotic hybrids. But those cars weren't the only stars in an unexpectedly vibrant show.
I can't get that sappy, sing-song ditty out of my head: "Make new friends, but keep the old, one is silver and the other gold."
Wisdom, insights and random observations from this weekend's Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)
Masked youths attacked the leader of Greece's biggest union and stoned police officers Friday in an outbreak of violence over cutbacks proposed by the prime minister.

The Choice received 100 comments on a report by the research organization Public Agenda that described widespread dissatisfaction with high school guidance counselors. Many of the comments were from counselors themselves, who took issue with the report and who, like the researchers who compiled it, sought to put the predicament of the modern-day counselor in perspective. To continue this dialogue, I asked one of those counselors to write a short rebuttal essay for The Choice. He is Robert Bardwell, director of guidance at Monson High School, a public school in Massachusetts. -- Jacques Steinberg
Next week, Michelle Obama will preside at a ceremony where she'll donate to the Smithsonian the flowing winter white gown she wore to the inaugural balls in 2009.

The producers of the Broadway revival of "The Miracle Worker" have tried almost every avenue available to them to sell tickets to that play, which opened Wednesday at Circle in the Square Theater. They cast high-profile stars, including Alison Pill as Annie Sullivan and the "Little Miss Sunshine" star Abigail Breslin as Helen Keller; they hired an up-and-coming director, Kate Whoriskey, to direct the project. Then they waited for opening night, and hoped that universally glowing reviews would materialize by morning.

The British possess many traits enviable to New Yorkers: the capacity to brew a better cup of tea, the decorum not to brag loudly about their bonuses in Midtown restaurants and a history rich with kings and queens who inspire trashy novels and Hollywood movies. But they fall short in one area: brash self-promotion, especially when it comes to real estate.
Only a short time ago, if you typed "iPad accessories" into the Google search engine, you'd be asked, "Did you mean iPod accessories?"

This is a big week for gallery openings, but three shows in particular caught my eye. At Julie Saul, "Further Illuminations" includes recent gouache paintings by Maira Kalman, a longtime contributor to T, whose quirky, lyrical and observant paintings have been the basis of a wildly popular nytimes.com blog. At Demisch Danant, they're partying like it's 1989. "Wild Animals" offers a selection of postmodern designs -- mostly from the 1980s, by people like Ron Arad, Philippe Starck, Tom Dixon and Christian Germanaz -- that are by turns decorative and startling. And at the Heller Gallery, "de Rigeur," an exhibition of new work by the artist Beth Lipman, features two large installations. "Bride" consists of a 10-foot-tall dessert stand filled with glass objects in various states of order and chaos, while the autobiographical work "The Whatnots" refers to the Victorian furniture used to display collectibles; Lipman's bear pieces of black glass refer to the mourning jewelry of the period.
Here's one idea for saving on gym costs: use free gym passes to continuously test different gyms.

At the Economix blog, Princeton economist Uwe E. Reinhardt ponders a proposal by Senator Tom Coburn, Republican of Oklahoma, to deploy undercover agents posing as patients in an effort to ferret out fraud by doctors and hospitals.

When an N.B.A. team is regularly in playoff contention it can, unsurprisingly, expect to draw large numbers of fans. But it's highly unusual when a team is perennially bad, perhaps even historically bad, and can still draw a healthy crowd.

LOS ANGELES - "What better way to spend an evening than with a bunch of Irishmen," a dressed-down Tom Cruise, in blue jeans and a navy sweatshirt, said when he presented J. J. Abrams, the producer of his next film, "Mission: Impossible IV," with an award at the Oscar Wilde: Honoring the Irish in Film party last night in Los Angeles. (Yes, you read that right.) Mr. Cruise introduced the decidedly non-Irish Jeffrey Jacobs Abrams as James Jacob O'Abrams.

Henrik Lundqvist stole a point last night for the Rangers and if they make the playoffs, it would be worth remembering this 5-4 overtime loss to the Penguins (Jeff Z. Klein's Times story here). Lundqvist's 50 saves, and especially his third period and overtime in which the Penguins outshot the Rangers, 23-1, were the story of the game.
More than a quarter of New York's wage and salary workers belonged to a union last year, according to a recent Labor Department report. That's the highest rate of any state in the nation.
At our Prescriptions blog, colleague David M. Herszenhorn find that not only Republicans and Democrats are talking about reconciliation.

The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Paris Fashion Week. Here, the model Jac Jagaciak from IMG Model Management before (top, bottom) and after makeup by Aaron de May and hair by Luigi Murenu. (Drag the orange bar up to reveal the full transformation.)
With airlines preemptively canceling more flights in anticipation of bad weather, another bottleneck has formed: airline call centers.
Representative Charles B. Rangel's Washington woes are not hampering his re-election plans in New York -- at least not yet.

MONTVALE, N.J. -- Just before heading back home to Germany following a short tour of the United States, Mercedes-Benz's ESF 2009 experimental safety vehicle made one last pitstop before a gaggle of American reporters in northern New Jersey. It offered a tantalizing glimpse of more than a dozen different systems designed to make driving (and crashing) safer.
Women of the United Nations police and peacekeeping forces that entered Liberia after the civil war have inspired a new generation of Liberian women to don uniforms.
The Art Show, the annual exhibition of the Art Dealers Association of America, now coincides with the Armory Show.

LOS ANGELES- There is plenty of well-known trivia about this year's crop of historic Oscar contenders: Kathryn Bigelow ("The Hurt Locker") is only the fourth woman to be nominated for best director, for example, and would be the first to win. Lee Daniels, the director of "Precious: Based on the Novel 'Push' by Sapphire," is the first black man to direct a best picture nominee (and would be the first to win). "Avatar" would be the first sci-fi movie to win best picture (ditto "District 9," although it won't). But with the extra-long season, there's been time to dig up bits of information about Oscar newbies:

Monologue | Thursday night on "The Jay Leno Show" on NBC: More problems for the auto industry. General Motors announced this week they're recalling 1.3 million compact cars here in North America to address a power steering problem. Apparently, since President Obama took over the company, all the cars are veering to the left.

Arguably, the most divisive issue on Capitol Hill these days is the parliamentary maneuver called budget reconciliation, which Democrats are planning to use to finalize their major health care legislation over the furious objection of Republicans.

Monologue | Thursday night on "The Late Show With David Letterman" on CBS: Former governor George W. Bush is writing a book, writing a book. How about that, about his eight years in the White House. It's all part of his war on literacy.

Monologue | Thursday night on "Late Night With Jimmy Fallon" on NBC: More crazy news from the car industry. An executive at G.M. is blaming his company's 1.3 million car recall on a parts supplier owned by Toyota. I'm just waiting for people to start blaming everything on Toyota. It's like the unemployment rate, the Kennedy assassination, global warming.

Monologue | Thursday night on "Jimmy Kimmel Live" on ABC: There's a story today in the entertainment trade papers that Sarah Palin is shopping a reality show with the producer of "Survivor", Mark Burnett. That's why she quit being the governor of Alaska. I find it strange that Sarah Palin would be shopping a reality show considering the fact that she hasn't shown much interest in reality.

Lately, all I do is daydream about a warm, sunny respite from the wet, gray weather we've been having in New York. Luckily, I'm heading to Palm Springs, Calif., in a few weeks for some poolside lounging and vintage shopping. This Rachel Pally bathing suit from Anthropologie will be the perfect addition to my trip. It has a conservative cut so you don't reveal too much, and its vintage style conjures up an image of a soignée Babe Paley sitting by the pool with sunglasses on her head. Not bad for under $100.

"Haiti's Enduring Creativity" (05:06)In Haiti, artwork has been ruined or lost. Artists have been killed and injured. Yet the creative spirit still flows. Sean Patrick Farrell and Erik Olsen visited with artists and musicians as they assessed the damage to their country's cultural legacy. Songs are already being sung about "douze Janvier," as the proliferation of music underscores the importance of expression and creativity during this time: as a conduit of hope, a means to forget or a form of political protest. Amid images of an artist's mangled hand and an art school's crumbled paintings, an educator movingly declares, "Much more today, we need art to survive." (K.B.)
A lot of New Yorkers chase off the winter blues with cleverly tied scarves or variations on the scarf.

PHOENIX - Lewis Wolff, the owner of the Oakland Athletics, stood beside his team's dugout Friday morning at Phoenix Municipal Stadium. He was dressed in an A's golf shirt, green-and-gold mesh shorts, white socks and sneakers, drinking coffee from a Styrofoam cup. A genial, white-haired grandfather of three, his name will not be confused with Steinbrenner.
Local government may be shedding workers, but the federal government is growing.

While it may be the least of Taiwan's worries, it's worth noting that that island's earthquake on Thursday has significantly cut into the production of LCD panels. Two of the largest panel manufacturing plants, owned by Chi Mei Optoelectronics and  HannStar Display, had to close their lines until it becomes clear that the plants can safely reopen.

At the Mobile Premier Awards -- an international competition for mobile start-ups held last month at the Mobile World Congress -- the message was clear: Web sites are old school, and mobile is a growing requirement for every industry and business.
CF Industries Holdings took its renewed fight for control of Terra Industries directly to its rival's shareholders on Friday with a $4.7 billion tender offer.

From an apparent record number of new model introductions at this year's Geneva auto show (how many? I lost track at 100) which ones stand out? Ten best? That's about as tough a choice as winnowing down the "American Idol" cast of thousands. At least I didn't have to hear any of them sing. To wit, here's the list:

Much has been made about LeBron James's filing paperwork with the National Basketball Association on Tuesday to change his jersey number from 23 to 6. James said the change would be made out of respect for Michael Jordan, who wore No. 23 for most of his career. (For a brief time after his return to basketball after a stint in the minor leagues Jordan wore No. 45.)

The latest organization calling for the resignation of Gov. David A. Paterson is Common Cause/New York, the government watchdog group. Common Cause said Friday that the governor should "put the welfare of New York State ahead of his own personal concerns and resign." The group said that the turmoil surrounding the governor was distracting attention from the state's urgent fiscal woes.

One of the great challenges in assessing the meaning of changes in Arctic climate and other environmental conditions is putting today's observations in long-term context. This is as true for the bubbling emissions of methane from the frozen, but warming, sea bed as for sea ice around the North Pole. Two recent studies of methane emissions from frozen sea-bed sediments, including one published in Science and described in The Times today, found substantial bubbling flows of methane, a potent greenhouse gas, were reaching the atmosphere.

There's a spirit of bricolage running through this season, as if designers wanted their clothes to convey as many possibilities as possible. Why not, for example, give a sweater a fur sleeve, or a tailored jacket a knit shoulder? It's a trick we saw over and over both in Milan and New York, but it takes a remix master like Dries Van Noten to make such combinations seem purposeful rather than whimsical. Van Noten's men's-wear-inspired jackets came not just with contrasting sleeves, but with a '50s hourglass nipped waist; pastoral florals on ladylike dresses and skirts were treated with punky splashes of paint, which the designer described as "rebel realist" prints; neo-grunge sweatshirts happily coexisted with leopard print furs, rich brocades and military parkas reminiscent of the '70s.

Lorin Stein, an editor at Farrar, Straus & Giroux whose youth belies his influence in the publishing industry, was named the editor of The Paris Review, the prestigious literary magazine, its board of directors said on Friday.

RCN, the cable operator, said on Friday that it had agreed to sell itself to the private equity firm ABRY Partners for $1.2 billion, including debt, as the leveraged buyout industry continues to get back to business.

Transparency is a political value more easily praised than practiced. The Internet provides politicians with a seemingly direct line to voters and a way to bypass the filter of the media, yet online, transparency is always a potential liability. Because while you can control the message, you can't control how people will respond to it.
Big news in Local Land: It seems that the support of a Maplewood gun dealer is not what a local youth baseball league had in mind.
A look at the New Museum’s exhibit of works in the collection of Dakis Joannou.

Word of Barry Hannah's death hit a lot of people hard this week, nowhere more so than in Oxford, Miss., where Mr. Hannah lived, wrote and taught for nearly three decades. He was an institution there, a living embodiment of that city's reputation as a cerebral but rowdy literary nerve center.

The Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art in Kansas City, Mo., which completed a critically praised expansion in 2007 and has been adding aggressively to its collections as part of an extended 75th anniversary celebration, has looked to New York for its next leader, choosing Julián Zugazagoitia, the director of El Museo del Barrio in East Harlem.

Here are some final answers to readers' questions about rabbits and backyard farming from Novella Carpenter, who is featured in Kim Severson's article about eating rabbit. Diner's Journal would like to thank Ms. Carpenter and all the readers who participated in this exchange.

GENEVA -- Porsche will give its new 911 GT3 R Hybrid racecar, which was unveiled here on Tuesday, a trial by fire in the 24 Hours on the Nordschleife of Nürburgring race in Germany in May. The intent, Porsche says, is to develop the car's potentially breakthrough technologies that could give drivers race-winning bursts of power and equally valuable gains in fuel economy.
The fall 2010 collection from Balmain at Paris Fashion Week.

Starting this Sunday, the Accor hotel group is offering 50 percent off rooms in 16 countries throughout Asia. The Three-Day Super Sale covers about 300 Accor hotels, which includes brands like Sofitel, Etap Hotel, Novotel and ibis.

Jimmy Ruck, a Stanford University junior, wakes up at 5:20 a.m. so he can make the 15-mile journey to Santa Clara University, where he attends training as part of the Reserve Officer Training Corps, or R.O.T.C. It begins at 6:15. Promptly.

Television loves spinoffs, as any fan who followed, say, the creation of "The Jeffersons" and "Maude" from "All in the Family" could attest. Now a television company is planning a spinoff of sorts for a presentation to advertisers of coming programming.

François Payard will open a bakery-cafe this summer in Greenwich Village, a change in neighborhood and style from the Upper East Side patisserie and restaurant he closed last summer after a rent dispute.

It was comedy when Pam Halpert mistakenly nursed another new mother's baby in a dark hospital room on The Office last night.

At the opening of the Armory Show last night, sellers (gallery owners) and buyers (collectors) alike agreed that this season's fair was both safe and straightforward. And with the prices just right, it was quickly becoming successful. One harried collector breathlessly arrived at Emmanuel Perrotin Gallery's booth asking for the price of Peter Coffin's Napoleonic sculpture. ($350,000 - and two of the three were already sold.) David Schnell's imposing landscape paintings were drawing a crowd of buyers at Berlin's Eigen Art. "They're not crazy expensive and his work has progressed," explained a young collector, who pointed to a large 8 x 10 canvas that was apparently going in the low six figures. There was more solid work by artists like Sean Landers, Mickalene Thomas and Josephine Meckseper.

The day after Josh Levine told me I could not grow a decent vegetable garden because of the towering Norway maple blocking the southern sun, I received an e-mail message from him with a list of plants that grow in dense shade. He had downloaded the list from a Web site called Plants for a Future. I excerpt the list below, truncated and condensed.

The Columbus Symphony Orchestra has taken drastic action to stay in business. It said on Friday that it had lopped off 13 weeks of its season, translating into a 23-percent pay cut for its musicians and $1.5 million reduction of its $9 million budget next year. Its season will now run for 25 weeks instead of 38. The orchestra said that its reduction, which was negotiated with the musicians, will eliminate three paid weeks of vacation for the players, five weeks of playing for BalletMet and Opera Columbus performances; and five weeks of special one-off concerts. Subscription concerts will be preserved, the orchestra said. The Columbus Symphony, a high-quality regional orchestra in Ohio's capital, has been struggling financially for several years. The cutbacks are a particularly draconian example of trimming going on around the orchestra world amid the recession.

This week at the Geneva auto show, where the new Mini Countryman crossover made its auto-show debut, Mini also introduced a new electronic infotainment system, called Mini Connected -- as if there weren't enough going on inside the pie-plate speedometer of a Mini.

Gov. David A. Paterson's public support continues to plummet with each fresh revelation, but according to a poll conducted on Wednesday and Thursday, more voters in the state wanted him to finish his term than resign.

This week: Jon Pareles on Peter Gabriel's album of orchestral cover songs; Jon Caramanica reviews the new release from the "American Idol" alum Danny Gokey; and Ben Sisario on what's happening on the pop charts. Sia Michel is the host.

They've only been pouring the most confidential cuppa in Paris for two weeks, but a reservation is already a good idea if you want to snag a table at the city's ultimate la vie en rose Saturday-afternoon hideaway: high tea at the Ritz Hotel from 3 p.m. to 6 p.m. The real surprise? It's already just as popular with the local Prada posse as it is with the hotel's home-team Chanel ladies. (Oh, and there are a lot of men in the room, too.)

Earlier this week I gave a talk about the state of the crisis at Princeton's Plasma Physics Lab, and one audience member asked a really good question: if the problem is that interest rates are at the zero lower bound, why should we worry about government borrowing? After all, doesn't that mean that the government can borrow at a zero rate?

If Britain can countenance a meeting between Queen Elizabeth II and Lady Gaga, and permit Miley Cyrus to dance in leather hot pants for Her Majesty, then surely it can allow Snoop Dogg back into the country. That rapper's long-running battle to be allowed within British borders took a turn in his favor this week when a tribunal there said it was wrong for him to have been denied entry into Britain three years ago, Reuters reported.
The fall 2010 collection from Rick Owens at Paris Fashion Week.

Last week we discussed the papaya battery, an utterly simple device whose geometry apparently creates a temperature difference where there was none before, thus violating the Second Law of Thermodynamics and creating potentially unlimited energy. In the field of thermodynamics, which abounds in apparent paradoxes, this is one of the most delicious paradoxes ever. Devices like the papaya battery, based on ellipsoids and parts of spheres, have been known to science since at least 1959 (J.C. Fallows in "New Scientist") and have been discussed in the scientific literature in cutting-edge journals like the "Journal of Statistical Physics" and "Physics Bulletin" under the names "Ellipsoid Paradox" and "Chinese furnace" which interested readers can google.

The university that Charles Pellegrino, the embattled author of "The Last Train From Hiroshima," claimed had awarded and then stripped him of a Ph.D. issued a statement late Thursday saying that it "utterly rejects" his claims as "baseless and defamatory."

For a few days of Restaurant Week in Maplewood Village, Rod Hernandez, the chef and owner of Luke's Kitchen, decided to push all the tables that are usually lined along the walls of this alley-shaped dining room into the center to create one long communal table.

Clarence Goodson of the United States switched from frontline target man to backline general in college, and that move might be the genesis of his World Cup career.

The rapper talks about the origins of his animated project, which is about an aspiring hip-hop group trying to make its way to a resurrected Freaknik party.

History has proved that you can make a hit musical out of just about anything, from the plight of French peasants in early-19th-century France to a bunch of mewling, moonlight-contemplating cats. But can you make one about Freaknik, the popular but controversial Atlanta party of the 1980s and '90s that was eventually shut down amid concerns about overcrowding, violence and the degradation of women? T-Pain is about to find out.

Updated | 2:01 p.m. As my colleagues Thom Shaker and Ian Urbina report, police and F.B.I. investigators are examining writing, audio and video thought to have been posted on the Web in recent years by the gunman who opened fire outside the Pentagon on Thursday night.

The Denny's restaurant chain had been enjoying a wave of positive publicity after its most recent offer of free breakfasts, made in commercials that ran during the Super Bowl on Feb. 7. But a subsequent spot has earned the wrath of many consumers.
Eggs are great for breakfast, but they can be even better for a quick and easy dinner. In this week's Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman extols the virtues of the oven-baked frittata.
Pollen and dust mites may make you sniffle and sneeze. But it's the medical bills that really leave parents teary-eyed during allergy season.

We see them everywhere. And if we're being honest, we have all had the same frightening and ignoble urge to smash their heads in with a brick. I am speaking about those smug and uber-informative moms and dads who do their parenting in public places -- aggressively and at the top of their highly educated lungs. They are easy to recognize, decked out in natural fabrics and larded up with the self-importance that comes from foisting "teachable moments" on an unsuspecting public.
Our sister blog, Bits, reports that the Wi-Fi versions of Apple's iPad tablet computer will go on sale April 3, with the 3G versions available later that month.

Writing the White House memoir is a time-honored way of setting the record straight - or even spinning history a little bit. It also has the side benefit of allowing the aide-turned-author to finally unload.

Our hardcover list sees plenty of action this week. The new collected editions include a story based on a video game (No. 2, "Halo"), the latest chapter in a superhero's long-running saga (No. 3, "Starman") and more high jinks for a mercenary (No. 10, "Deadpool"). In "X Marks the Spot," Deadpool heads to San Francisco for a visit with the X-Men, who are less than thrilled with his arrival.

The economy lost 36,000 jobs in February, not quite as bad as most forecasters had expected. The consensus forecast on Thursday had been for a net loss of 68,000 jobs, largely because of the snowstorms that battered the East Coast in February.

Apple announced on Friday that the Wi-Fi versions of its long-awaited iPad will arrive April 3 in stores in the United States. The models that can tap into AT&T's 3G wireless data network will be available in late April.

When the Arch Hotel opened for business in London in late January, on the heels of reports that Britain had finally nudged out of recession, it suggested that perhaps the crash would soon be a distant memory. Indeed, the new 82-room hotel in the Marble Arch neighborhood feels like a museum dedicated to precrisis town house living: Occupying nearly a block of remodeled Georgian manses close to Hyde Park, the hotel's discreet front doors give way to interiors so perfectly appointed - white orchids blooming in green glass bowls, plump sofas by the designer Tom Dixon set around a fireplace - that the effect is almost clinical.
The jobs report today is encouraging in a number of ways, and should make the double-dip recession crowd at least pause.
How you view today's jobs report depends on snow.

Despite fears that the nation's unemployment rate could climb back into double digits because of the heavy snowstorms in February, the latest figures show that it remained nearly steady at 9.7 percent last month.

A Day of Mostly Peaceful Protests | Thousands of students, parents and faculty members, angered by cuts in state financing for education and increases in college fees, protested across the state Thursday. Although some demonstrations were confrontational, and 150 people were arrested after they stopped traffic on Interstate 880 in Oakland, most of the protests were peaceful. "How are we going to save the future if we can't even get into our classes?" Reid E. Milburn, the president of the Student Senate for California Community Colleges, said at a protest in Sacramento. Vino di Tavolo, the Wine for Our Times | The appeal of wines of the European countryside, their freshness, their blended verve and low prices, are on the minds of California wine makers right now. High-end wine sales dropped significantly in 2009. Jason Haas, who runs his family's Tablas Creek Vineyard in Paso Robles, says he is trying to find a way to make appealing table wines with approachable price tags, even though the price of land in the Bay Area tends to get in the way. He sells his own fine version of a red Côtes du Rhone, called Côtes de Tablas, for around $20. Good table wines may remain rare, but new ones are on the way, often made from less-than-fashionable varieties in less-than-fashionable places.

One Oscar category to keep an eye on this year is animation. Though Pixar's "Up" is the obvious front-runner, there will be a lot of people rooting for "The Secret of Kells." The movie, an independent film by Tomm Moore, is a hand-drawn labor of love made for only about $8 million. Mr. Moore grew up and still lives in Kilkenny, Ireland, a one-cathedral town of a few thousand people about an hour and a half south of Dublin. "If," writes Melena Ryzik, "artistically, 'The Secret of Kells' is a throwback to the era of animation before computer-generated imagery, its promotion is pure digital age, forgoing the pricey ads and flashy parties that Academy Award campaigns are traditionally built on in favor of cheaper social media and savvy targeted marketing. It was a lark, and it worked." The movie, which opens today in New York, follows the adventures of a boy — a young monk in training — as he works with an illuminator to finish the Book of Kells, the Latin manuscript transcribed by Celtic monks around A.D. 800 and considered an Irish national treasure. "Rich with pagan myth and Jungian symbolism, the movie is lavishly illustrated to mimic the perspectiveless style of pre-Renaissance art: it's not exactly lightweight fare." It is also Mr. Moore's first feature.

Titus Andronicus clearly has a few nerds in its ranks. The "fuzz-loving indie-rock" band, writes Amanda Petrusich, stole its moniker from the title of one of Shakespeare's earliest tragedies, and then named its full-length debut ("The Airing of Grievances") after a fictional holiday featured on an episode of "Seinfeld." "But, while it's prone to (friendly) borrowing, Titus Andronicus also has ideas of its own: the band's new album, 'The Monitor,' is packed with gleeful rock songs. Go listen on Saturday night at the Bowery Ballroom where the band will be performing with Parts and Labor, the Babies and Cloud Nothings, beginning at 8 p.m.

Will a rogue producer ruin "The Hurt Locker" in its bid for Best Picture? Will dark horse "Inglourious Basterds" take home a surprise win? Will Alec Baldwin sing? This Sunday all our questions will be answered when the hype and hoopla comes to an end at the 82nd Annual Academy Awards. Thankfully there are plenty of opportunities in the city to watch the results. NYC & Co. is co-hosting the city's first-ever viewing party with the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. Starting at 7 p.m. at Lincoln Center's Alice Tully Hall, cocktails and hors d'oeuvres will be served followed by a live broadcast. The Juilliard Jazz Ensemble will perform music from Oscar-winning films. Tickets are available at lincolncenter.org. For a less fancy, more campy showing head to Joe's Pub where the annual Murray Hill party will take place with comedians spoofing this year's films. (Murray will be playing Mo'nique from "Precious" and Julia Child from "Julie and Julia.") For foodies, the chef Donatella Arpaia is throwing a shindig for the little gold man at her restaurant Mia Dona. For $25, guests can sip on a blue Avatar cocktail and munch on a tasting menu featuring meatballs, white-bean bruschetta and more. And in Brooklyn, mixologist Julie Reiner is hosting a party with an actual red carpet at her establishment, Clover Club. Entry is free, and you're encouraged to dress up.

NAIROBI, Kenya -- The United Nations will begin withdrawing peacekeeping troops from Congo by June to hand control of the country's security back to the Congolese, officials with the United Nations mission to Congo said Thursday. The officials said they would still keep thousands of troops in Congo's troubled east, where a toxic mix of armed groups continue to brutalize the population. But the peacekeepers will soon pull out of the more stable areas in the central part of the country.

SANTIAGO, Chile -- Chilean emergency management officials announced Thursday that they had significantly overestimated the death toll from last weekend's earthquake, lowering the figure from about 805 people to about 279. Carmen Fernández, director of the emergency management agency, known as Onemi, said in an interview that in several badly damaged municipalities, officials had erroneously included names of people who were missing on lists of those who had been killed.

DYE--Dr. Robert E.,81, of Hershey, PA passed away at his home on March 3, 2010. He was the loving and devoted husband of Dr. Elaine Eyster for 45 years, and the caring father of their sons Robert Jr. of Menlo Park, CA and Charles of Hershey. Born in Eckman, WV, he received his undergraduate degree from Duke University in 1950. He served in the US Army Medical Corp before graduating from the University of Virginia School of Medicine in 1958. He completed a residency in Medicine at the University of Virginia and a fellowship in Gastroenterology at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical College. From 1964 to 1970, he practiced Internal Medicine and Gastroenterology in Manhattan. In 1970 he was recruited during the formative phase of the Department of Medicine at Penn State Hershey where he maintained a solo practice in Internal Medicine and Gastroenterology for 18 years. In 1994, he joined the staff at the VA Medical Center in Lebanon PA, where he assisted part-time until his 80th birthday. In 1999, he was awarded emeritus status by the president of The Pennsylvania State University. In recognition of his endeavors, the Robert E. Dye M.D. Professorship in Medicine was established in his honor in 2006. He is survived by his wife, sons, and six grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held Saturday, March 7, 2010 at Holy Trinity Lutheran Church in Hershey. Visit www.hooverfuneralhome.comfor information on memorial contributions.

Mr. Cross is survived by his wife Mary Cross, an author and photojournalist, his daughters Amanda Cross of Sanibel, Florida, Lisa Pownall- Gray of Weston, Connecticut, and three stepdaughters, Stuart Warner of Woodbridge, Connecticut, Ann Anderson of Narragansett, Rhode Island, and Polly Warner of Denver, Colorado. He is also survived by three grandchildren and eight step-grandchildren. A memorial service is scheduled for April 9 at 2pm at Princeton University Chapel, Princeton, NJ. Memorial contributions may be made to the Theodore Lamont Cross Scholarship Fund at Amherst College, Amherst, MA 01002-5000, or Doctors Without Borders, P.O. Box 5030, Hagerstown, MD 21741.

UBS and Ernst & Young won a court ruling Thursday in Luxembourg, potentially blocking hundreds of claims by investors who had lost money in funds tied to Bernard L. Madoff's fraud. Luxembourg's commercial court said that investors could not bring individual lawsuits for damages. The court said it was up to the liquidators of the funds that invested with Mr. Madoff to seek the ''recovery of the capital assets.''

It is a rare day when an N.F.L. starting quarterback is released, but the Carolina Panthers are expected to send Jake Delhomme packing Friday, taking advantage of the lack of a salary cap to dump a player they gave an ill-advised contract extension to just a year ago. The Panthers still owe Delhomme almost $13 million. The decision was first reported by Fox Sports. Delhomme led the Panthers to a Super Bowl berth and two N.F.C. championship games. But the decision to give him a contract extension after he had six turnovers in a playoff game against the Cardinals at the end of the 2008 season was heavily criticized. He continued to decline last season, when he threw 18 interceptions and just 8 touchdowns. He broke a finger in December and missed the final five games of the season, which opened the door for the Panthers to replace him with Matt Moore. The Panthers gave Moore the highest tender, an early sign that the Panthers were prepared to move on. JUDY BATTISTA

NAMER--Dr. Izak, 57, passed away on Wednesday, March 3, 2010 after a valiant and difficult fight with multiple myeloma cancer. Loved by his family, friends, colleagues and golf partners, he will be missed. Izak was the managing partner of Alfa Development/Management LLC for 22 years. One of the only companies committed to green building in Manhattan. Izak received his Bachelor of Mechanical Engineering at City College SUNY '75 and his Masters '76 and Ph.D. of Mechanical Engineering at University of California at Berkley '79. Izak was a professor of engineering and head of the mechanical engineering department at Drexel University from 1980-1988. He conducted cutting edge research on combustion and the first measurements of lanier flames with lasers for Nasa and the U.S. Air Force. Izak was born in Istanbul, Turkey. His family moved to Havana, Cuba in 1956, the country of his mothers birth. He and his brother Michael were airlifted out of Cuba to the United States in 1961 at the onset of the Castro regime under the Peter Pan Program. He was the loving husband to Susan. Devoted father of David and Jake. Cherished son of his late mother Linda, father Sam and his stepmother Paula. Adored son-in-law of Ruth and Charles Berger. Loving brother to Michael and sister-in-law Dr. Christine Namer, and stepsister Denise Faye, Leslie Fram and brother-in-law Jonathan Fram. Respected brother-in-law to Victoria and David Reeser. Mentoring uncle to Matthew, Luke and Justine. Services will be held at Eden Memorial Chapel, 327 Main St., Fort Lee, NJ 07024 on March 5, 2010, 11:30am. Followed by interment at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ, 12:30pm. Shiva will be held at 31 West 11th St., NY 10011, apt 3A.

The American International Group moved closer to the $15 billion sale of a second major life insurance unit on Thursday after the Internal Revenue Service indicated that it would rule favorably on a tax issue that had stymied the deal, people briefed on the matter said. With the resolution of the tax issue, A.I.G. would be able to wrap up the sale of the unit, the American Life Insurance Company, known as Alico, to MetLife within days, these people said. One of them said a deal could be reached by Sunday evening.

SUDER--Frances. Boys Town Jerusalem mourns the passing of a cherished member of its extended family. Fran, together with Ike, her partner in life and philanthropy, have provided their generous support and valued leadership for over three decades enabling BTJ to fulfill its mission of turning young boys from limited backgrounds into young men with limitless futures for over three decades. Fran's most recent expression of the love she had for the students of BTJ, who she regarded as 'her' boys, was the family's endowment of the Frances and Isaac Suder Jerusalem Art Gallery at the school. This project was especially meaningful to Fran as it combined her passion for art and her commitment to Israel and these deserving youngsters, the future builders and leaders of the Jewish State. We extend heartfelt condolences to Ike and the entire Suder family. May G-d comfort you among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Moshe Linchner, Dean Michael J. Scharf, President Raphael Benaroya, Chairman Josh S. Weston, Hon Chairman Rabbi Ronald Gray, Exec. VP

Thousands of villagers who came to a popular ashram in northern India for a free meal on Thursday were caught in a stampede that left more than 60 dead. The ashram's religious leader, Kripalu Maharaj, has a huge following in India and abroad for his tales of religious devotion and speeches on subjects like ''The Secret of Attachment and Detachment'' and ''Who Is a True Spiritual Master?'' Thousands of people visited his ashram in Mangarh, a village in the state of Uttar Pradesh, for a community lunch, and the stampede occurred at the ashram gate, said R. N. Singh, an official in the local district information office of Pratapgarh. Officials said the stampede started when the gate collapsed, The Press Trust of India reported.

The Jets confirmed late Thursday that they had agreed in principle with the San Diego Chargers to acquire cornerback Antonio Cromartie for a conditional 2011 draft pick. Cornerback depth was among the most pressing needs for the Jets. Although they ranked first in the N.F.L. in pass defense last season, the Jets needed a starting cornerback opposite Darrelle Revis, especially after Lito Sheppard was released.

Perhaps the most overlooked section of President Obama's speech on health care Wednesday was his insistence that the Democratic bill would take sufficient steps to control the rise in health care costs for individuals, families and the federal government. ''We have now incorporated most of the serious ideas from across the political spectrum about how to contain the rising cost of health care -- ideas that go after the waste and abuse in our system, especially in programs like Medicare,'' he said.

11 P.M. (IFC) THE 25th FILM INDEPENDENT SPIRIT AWARDSEddie Izzard is host of what the IFC people are promising will be a boisterous celebration of movies by filmmakers who embody independence and originality, broadcast in real time from Los Angeles. (The ceremony is also popular with long-winded winners because they aren't booted from the stage by music cues.) Nominees include ''Precious: Based on the Novel 'Push' by Sapphire,'' ''(500) Days of Summer'' (with Zooey Deschanel and Joseph Gordon-Levitt, above), ''Amreeka,'' ''Sin Nombre'' and ''The Last Station,'' for best feature; ''A Single Man,'' ''Crazy Heart,'' ''Easier With Practice,'' ''The Messenger'' and ''Paranormal Activity'' for best first feature; Maria Bello, Nisreen Faour, Helen Mirren, Gwyneth Paltrow and Gabourey Sidibe for best female lead; and Jeff Bridges, Colin Firth, Mr. Gordon-Levitt, Souleymane Sy Savane and Adam Scott for best male lead. 8 P.M. (CBS) GHOST WHISPERERJennifer Love Hewitt directed and stars in the series's 100th episode, in which a ghost who knows the whereabouts of a hidden munitions dump with unexploded bombs confides in Melinda that someone will die. In ''Medium,'' at 9, Allison (Patricia Arquette) enrolls in self-defense classes after being mugged.

WASHINGTON -- Two police officers at the Pentagon were wounded Thursday evening when a man walked up to the entrance of the complex's subway station and, without a word, opened fire on them, Pentagon officials said. Police officers quickly returned fire, critically injuring the gunman after hitting him once in the head and once in the shoulder. The gunman was identified as John Patrick Bedell, 36, according to a police official here assisting with the investigation.

The American Medical Association last week released its annual study examining competition in the health insurance market. The verdict: Competition is dwindling. In 24 of the 43 states studied, the two biggest insurers together covered at least 70 percent of the market. Paul B. Ginsburg, president of the Center for Studying Health System Change in Washington, spoke with Michelle Andrews about the availability of insurance. Here is an edited excerpt.

Perhaps concerned that his repeated suggestions that the Holocaust might not have happened have become less shocking over time, Iran’s president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, upped the ante on Saturday, telling intelligence officials in Tehran that the destruction of the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, 2001, was staged.
Children in Haiti are languishing in camps or working in menial jobs because thousands of schools in and around the devastated capital of the country could remain closed for months or never reopen.

Craig Silverman, the editor of Regret the Error, a Web site that reports on accuracy and honesty in the press, says most plagiarism by journalists is caught only when someone complains.  That's what happened last month at The Times, which had to endure the mortifying experience of having a bitter cross-town rival, The Wall Street Journal, point out the theft of half a dozen passages from one of its news articles.

My Sunday column is about the diminishing effectiveness of antibiotics, and the concern that our agricultural policies (stuffing livestock with antibiotics) will entail huge public health costs. The rise of antibiotic-resistance is well-known (it's a great example of evolution), and was recently documented by my Times colleague Andrew Pollack in the case of gram-negative bacteria.
In the final hours before the first Parliamentary elections in four years, the race in Iraq is still too close to call.

To bolster the case for a far-reaching overhaul of the health care system, the Obama administration is seizing on a new analysis by Goldman Sachs, the New York investment bank, recommending that investors buy shares in two big insurance companies, the UnitedHealth Group and Cigna, because insurance rates are up sharply and competition is down.

Funny that I should mention "lumps and bumps," the Comme des Garçons collection from the late '90s, in the last post: Rei Kawakubo's fall 2010 show seemed to transplant that concept to a new view of human anatomy and inner strength. "Inside decoration," Ms. Kawakubo said backstage of coats and sheer black tops clustered with shapes that brought to mind muscles, kidneys and brain matter. Or maybe those channeled and bunched skirts were meant to evoke intestines. Either way, the show was fascinating and well done.

LOS ANGELES- In a bit of Oscar presaging, "Precious: Based on the Novel 'Push' by Sapphire" and "Crazy Heart" were the big winners at Film Independent's Spirit Awards on Friday. "Precious" took best feature, best director for Lee Daniels, best first screenplay (Geoffrey Fletcher), best actress (Gabourey Sidibe) and best supporting actress (Muh-nique, as the presenter, Pierce Brosnan, called Mo'Nique). "Crazy Heart" won best first feature and best actor for Jeff Bridges, who did double-duty by performing a song from it. Mr. Bridges and Muh-nique are Oscar locks; Ms. Sidibe has been much-nominated this season but has rarely made a trip to the podium, so it was especially sweet for her.

You know you've scaled the ranks of the sleepless elite when your editor notices the berserker late night time-stamps on your Facebook posts and asks you to contribute to a forum on insomnia. How flattering! How alarming! Isn't it remarkable that, despite how isolated and alone we feel in our wakefulness, our numbers are so great we warrant our own special exploration? Fellow night owls, we have arrived. Three hoots for the weary.

BAGHDAD -- I didn't vote in the 2009 provincial elections. I think I was busy, or I didn't really care. This time is different. The vote will decide who rules the country for the next four years - the first to lead, in theory, without American soldiers. "Your vote is golden," Iraqis are being told. I really believe that, despite my disappointment with Iraqi leaders and all the chaos of the political process here.

LOS ANGELES- There's not much that can be reprinted from our dinner with the cast and writers of "In the Loop," mainly because we were laughing too much to write stuff down. A British satire about a certain war in the Middle East, nominated for a screenplay Oscar, "In the Loop" is known for its bawdiness. The dinner, on Saturday night, was more tame - just a few jokes about Hitler as a motivational speaker and Jeff Bridges's mustache being the best part of "Crazy Heart" - you know, the usual. And Armando Iannucci, a screenwriter and the director, did note that when Miramax executives wanted to buy "In the Loop" after its Sundance premiere last year on the condition that the filmmakers re-edit it, he told them to go expletive themselves.

GARNETT--James Mercer. Died on March 2nd, 2010 at age 84 in Jamestown, RI. Was born in Chestnut Hill, PA and received an undergraduate degree from Yale University in 1950. There he was a member of the Beta Theta Pi fraternity and the Scroll and Key Society. He was a proud veteran of World War ll, serving in the famed Marine 5th Division, engaged in the Battle of Iwo Jima, and with the occupational forces in Japan. He was with Marsh McLennan Insurance brokers in New York and in London where he served as Vice President and Manager of the office. He completed his career as Vice President of FJ Wilkes & Co. in New York, retiring in 1992 to his summer community of Jamestown, RI. He was a member of the Yale Club of New York; the Newport Reading Room, Newport, RI; the Conanicut Yacht Club, Jamestown, RI; and a former member of the Clambake Club of Newport, RI; as well as the Field Club and Stanwich Club in Greenwich, CT. He is survived by his wife, Sally Begg Garnett; his sister Anne Wister Garnett Boenning; his brother Stephen Hunter Garnett; and his half brother, Muscoe Russell Hunter Garnett, Jr. He is also survived by his four children, Jane Marvel Garnett, James Mercer Garnett, Jr., Sidney Scott Garnett and William Barclay Garnett, and eight grandchildren. He also leaves many loved in-laws, cousins, nephews and nieces. He was pre-deceased by his parents, Muscoe Russell Hunter Garnett and Caroline Barclay Strong, as well as his half sister, Agnes Wallace Garnett Leary. A private graveside service, officiated by the Rev. Kevin Lloyd of St. Mathew's Episcopal Church, will be held at Cedar Hill Cemetery in Jamestown, RI. In lieu of flowers, please donate to the charity of your choice.

KRAMER--Viktoria Holm. December 24, 1950 - February 17, 2010. Vikki Holm Kramer, beloved partner, mother and friend, made a peaceful transition out of this life on February 17 surrounded by her devoted loved ones. She was 59 years old and had waged an inspirational fight against lung cancer for four years. Vikki was born in Iceland on December 24, 1950 and moved with her family to New Jersey when she was six years old. Vikki followed her dream of moving to California and spent a successful decade serving as a children's commercial agent. She later moved to northern California at the request of George Lucas to work with him at Lucas Films. When she married Jeffrey Kramer she devoted herself to her true mission in life, that of being a full-time mother to her three sons. During the 1990s Vikki helped launch The Tourette Syndrome Association Annual Champion of Children Dinner, which provides one of the largest sources of income for the TSA and has educated and brought support to thousands in need. She also served on the National Board of Directors of the TSA. Vikki's proudest success were her three sons, Jordan, Jaxon and Jeremy. Her greatest joy in life was being a mother. She is survived by them, her devoted friends and her loyal and beloved partner, Dennis Jones. She was beloved and she will be greatly missed by the Tourette Syndrome Association. A celebration of her life was held on Saturday, February 27 at The North Hollywood Church of Religious Science in North Hollywood, CA. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in Vikki's name to Against the Stream Meditation Society (againstthestream.org) or Vineyard House (vineyardhouse.org).

NAMER--Dr. Izak, 57, passed away on Wednesday, March 3, 2010 after a valiant and difficult fight with multiple myeloma cancer. Loved by his family, friends, colleagues and golf partners, he will be missed. Izak was the managing partner of Alfa Development/Management LLC for 22 years. One of the only companies committed to green building in Manhattan. Izak received his Bachelor of Mechanical Engineering at City College SUNY '75 and his Masters '76 and Ph.D. of Mechanical Engineering at University of California at Berkley '79. Izak was a professor of engineering and head of the mechanical engineering department at Drexel University from 1980-1988. He conducted cutting edge research on combustion and the first measurements of lanier flames with lasers for Nasa and the U.S. Air Force. Izak was born in Istanbul, Turkey. His family moved to Havana, Cuba in 1956, the country of his mothers birth. He and his brother Michael were airlifted out of Cuba to the United States in 1961 at the onset of the Castro regime under the Peter Pan Program. He was the loving husband to Susan. Devoted father of David and Jake. Cherished son of his late mother Linda, father Sam and his stepmother Paula. Adored son-in-law of Ruth and Charles Berger. Loving brother to Michael and sister-in-law Dr. Christine Namer, and stepsister Denise Faye, Leslie Fram and brother-in-law Jonathan Fram. Respected brother-in-law to Victoria and David Reeser. Mentoring uncle to Matthew, Luke and Justine. Services will be held at Eden Memorial Chapel, 327 Main St., Fort Lee, NJ 07024 on March 5, 2010, 11:30am. Followed by interment at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ, 12:30pm. Shiva will be held at 31 West 11th St., NY 10011, apt 3A.

IN the depths of a New York City winter, it's easy to forget what tropical warmth really feels like -- that close, comforting pressure on your bare skin, the humid aroma of vegetal growth and decay, the way vistas both urban and pastoral seem to shimmer, sigh and relax in the heat. You can remember these things, sure, but they seem abstract -- faded dreams from another life. Until, that is, you find a cheap flight down south and plan a one-day escape from the frigid slush. Even with airfares edging back up, deals are still plentiful for those with a little flexibility. So, a couple of weeks ago, when I spotted a Delta Airlines flight for $189 (taxes and fees included) that would take me to Miami in the morning and return that very evening, I snatched it. In between, I would have about nine hours to soak up as much of that city's sockless, pastel culture as I could afford on a budget of, as usual, close to nothing.

No more excuses. The Hotel Networks, a television programming company based in New York that delivers on-demand channels to hotels, has teamed up with ExerciseTV to provide free workout videos in more than 1.1 million hotel rooms across the United States. The workout shows will be available at Hyatt, Marriott, Fairmont, InterContinental, Hilton, Loews, Omni, Radisson, Crowne Plaza, Doubletree and other hotels. The videos, which include titles like Incredible Abs, 6 Round Slimdown and Hollywood Celebrity Circuit from trainers like Cindy Whitmarsh and Stephanie Vitorino, are expected to reach about 18 million hotel guests each month -- unless those guests flip the channel and order room service instead.

Gathering Moss? JANN S. WENNER, a founder of Rolling Stone, has been separated from his wife, Jane Wenner, for many years, but recent real estate transactions suggest that the couple may finally be headed toward a more formal parting of the ways.

GIVEN all of the overly complicated, wildly imaginative clothing sent down the runway in the last couple of seasons, it follows that some designers would start thinking in simpler terms -- creating easy palette-cleansing looks that may not move fashion forward, but sure will keep it selling. Phoebe Philo -- of course -- initiated the shift with a resort collection for Céline made up of, as she described it, clothing women need in their wardrobe. Turns out, they were ravenous for it. At Chloé, Hannah MacGibbon has given the pared-down aesthetic her own spin with long skirts and oversize blazers. Stella McCartney sent out relaxed silk blouses and trousers to teach her customers, she told Style.com, not to be afraid of the simpler stuff. And at Jil Sander, Raf Simons took the notion a step further by returning to nature with frayed linen jackets and torn gauzy tops.

JOAN RIVERS was not impressed with the flouncy tea-length Zac Posen dress that Tina Fey sported at the Golden Globes earlier this year. ''I hope she was going for laughs, because she got them,'' Ms. Rivers pronounced. ''She looked like a decorative toilet seat cover.'' Nor did she admire the purple Bottega Veneta gown that Sandra Bullock wore to the same event: ''It looked like Prince's old prom dress.'' And Adam Lambert, all glammed up in Dolce & Gabbana at the Grammys? She got right to the point: ''If Elvis and Elvira had a kid, this would be it. He looks like a gay Col. Sanders.'' Yes, the sage of the red carpet is back. Sunday, as Hollywood stars stroll into the Academy Awards ceremony, they won't have to worry about Joan Rivers sticking a microphone in their freshly Botoxed faces and demanding, ''Who are you wearing?'' Those days are behind her.

BADIGIAN--Alice, 100, a survivor of the Armenian Genocide in Manisa, Turkey, died at home in New Vernon, NJ on February 27, where she lived with her daughter Marion. Throughout her life, she was affronted by the denial of events she witnessed first-hand, yet her belief in the triumph of truth and justice never wavered. Quietly magnificent in thought and deed, she loved her family unreservedly and is mourned by grandchildren Joyce and Billy, seven great-grandchildren, and all who knew her. Sleep well darling Nana. Donations to The Armenian Eyecare Project, at www.eyecareproject.com

Art imitates nature, but few artists observe like scientists. Especially in the United States, art is dominated by political correctness, which turns a blind eye to realities that aren't supposed to exist. Both men and women are Homo sapiens, dangerous animals indeed. Paul Dorell of Evanston, Ill., responding to Sam Tanenhaus's essay on the depiction of violent women in the arts.

PINKHAM--Lawrence Dana, a professor of journalism at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism and later at the University of Massachusetts/Amherst, died on February 28 at Cooley Dickinson Hospital in Northampton, Mass., following a heart attack. He was 83 and lived in Amherst. During his long career Pinkham also spent eight years in China, where he helped establish English-language journalism programs at several major academic institutions in Beijing, and two years in India as distinguished visiting professor and dean of the newly founded Asian College of Journalism in Chennai. Many of Pinkham's former students remember him affectionately as a person of warmth and humor, an exciting and inspiring teacher, and a man whose progressive politics and commitment to social justice informed both his life and his teaching. Some have identified him as the person who had the most important influence on their professional lives. Pinkham is survived by his wife Joan in Massachusetts, his son Christopher in New Hampshire, his daughter Claire in California, and two grandchildren, Robert and Anthony Marsella. The family suggest that anyone wishing to make a gift in Larry's name consider a donation to the independent socialist magazine Monthly Review, in New York.

A lot of New Yorkers chase off the winter blues with cleverly tied scarves or variations on the doughnut scarf (top row). Even the dachshunds get in on the act. Some scarves are so long that they keep two people warm or take the place of a coat. Others resemble nothing so much as a deflated tire tube. One of the most popular variations, lower left, is the flange that ripples down the front in a rainbow of colors.
