Older chess players are not an endangered species, but there is no doubt that chess is increasingly dominated by young men (and women). The world's top-ranked player is 19, and more prodigies are emerging everywhere. The latest is Richard Rapport, a 13-year-old from Hungary. In the Gotth'Art Cup, which ended Wednesday in Hungary, Richard earned the final norm toward a grandmaster title. He has not yet qualified for the title, because his rating is below 2,500, the level needed to become a grandmaster, but there seems little doubt that he soon will satisfy that last requirement.

SAFIAN--Leroy S.,M.D. Born December 15, 1916, died March 1, 2010 after a long illness. Dr. Safian was a dedicated and highly respected Radiologist whose career spanned over 40 years, the last 16 years of his career was spent at Montefiore Medical Center, Bronx, NY where he was known for his kindness and generosity to both colleagues and patients. Dr. Safian was an avid Bridge player and will be missed. Interment Ferncliff Mausoleum, Hartsdale, NY.

THE Dutch fashion photographer Viviane Sassen has made a name for herself shooting vibrant, graphic work for French Vogue, Purple and Pop. But it is her imagery of Africa, now on view at Danziger Projects in Chelsea, that is perhaps her most striking. Certainly, it is her most personal. Having lived as a child in Kenya, where her father was a doctor, Ms. Sassen says her earliest memories are filled with the rich colors and smells of the continent. Since 2001, she has taken regular trips back to photograph its people. The resulting series of deeply saturated, stylized portraits -- shot in South Africa, Kenya, Uganda, Tanzania and Ghana -- possess a mystical, magical beauty, not unlike Africa itself. ''People in the West have a quite limited idea of what the place is about,'' Ms. Sassen said. ''Hunger, war, AIDS ... It's so much more diverse and exciting.'' Viviane Sassen photos on view at Danziger Projects through April 10, 534 West 24th Street; danzigerprojects.com.

CONRAD--Robert, 90, died in Ann Arbor, MI on February 18. He was born in New York City, received undergraduate and law degrees from New York University, and was a proud veteran of World War II, serving in the deception unit known as the "Ghost Army". He practiced law in New York City for nearly 60 years, served as president of the City Club of New York, and was active in Democratic Party politics at the local, state and national levels. He is survived by Esther, his beloved wife of 60 years, his sister-in-law Mildred Nollman of Foxborough, MA, sons Dan of San Francisco and Fred of Ann Arbor, their wives Sarah Wilcox and Betsy Brooks, grandchildren Paul, Ted, Allison, and Jeffrey, and eight nieces and nephews and their families. Bob loved music, ballet, and the theater; he was an enthusiastic and generous host, and loved a party. He and Esther were world travelers, always looking forward to their next trip. He was loved and respected by the many friends he made throughout his life. His friends and family will miss him always. Memorial contributions may be sent to Peoples' Symphony Concerts; Suite 703; 121 West 27th Street; New York, NY 10001.

WHEN Transportation Secretary Ray LaHood told a Congressional committee Tuesday, ''We are looking at the possibility of recommending the brake override system in all newly manufactured automobiles,'' he was giving weight to a technical solution to sudden acceleration that is on only some cars. ''We think it is a good safety device,'' Mr. LaHood said, though he stopped short of saying that it would be mandated. His comment was about recommending the device, but many news articles interpreted that as possible regulation. Olivia Alair, a Transportation Department spokeswoman, said: ''I was playing Whac-A-Mole with that because the idea that it would be required had already gotten out in the ether. '''Recommend' is correct.''

In 1955, ''On the Waterfront,'' which ushered in a new era of film-making in the New York area, won eight Academy Awards, including Best Picture. In the decades that followed, many of the hundreds of films shot on location in the city have been recognized by the Academy, including ''West Side Story,'' ''The Godfather,'' ''Annie Hall'' and ''Raging Bull.'' This year two movies filmed in the city have been nominated for Oscars, ''Precious: Based on the Novel 'Push' by Sapphire,'' with six nominations, including Best Picture, and ''Julie & Julia,'' with one nomination. In 2009, two New York City films, ''Doubt'' and ''The Visitor,'' were nominated for Oscars. The maps below show many of the spots where these four films were shot on location.

WORNOW-TUCKER--Gertrude, 101, on March 3, 2010, in Canton, MA. For decades, during the middle of the 20th Century, she was an English teacher in a junior high school in Mount Vernon, New York. Mrs. Wornow-Tucker is survived by her beloved husband, David Tucker, who is himself in his 100th year. Together the two of them acquired a significant number of Hudson River School paintings which are now part of the collection of the Herbert F. Johnson Museum of Art at Cornell. She leaves two stepchildren and several step-grandchildren. She was the adored Matriarch of an extended family of nieces and nephews, including Cantor Bette Wishengrad Cohen (Michael); Ed Wittstein; and Philip Coltoff (Lynn), all of Manhattan; many grandnieces and grandnephews; as well as great-grandnieces and great-grandnephews. Even after her 100th birthday, with her commanding interest in the English language, she continued to correct the errors in grammar of family and friends. Donations may be made in her memory to the Herbert F. Johnson Museum at Cornell.

SHAPIRO--Alfred. It is with great sadness that we at MCMH & MITPP say goodbye to a wonderful friend and colleague. I have worked with Al on the Board of the Metropolitan Center for Mental Health since the mid-seventies and we have weathered many crises and issues together. Al always displayed warmth, sensitivity and sound judgment, along with an unfailing sense of humor when problems and/or issues arose in connection with the Center's Board or committees. Al was often at my home and at committee meetings, he always said how he was enamored of my de-cafe espresso, which I enjoyed making just for him. He will be sorely missed. STADLER--Charlotte K.,71, a long-time schoolteacher and mathematics specialist in the New Rochelle School District, died in her sleep Saturday, February 27, at her home in Larchmont, two months after being diagnosed with acute leukemia. She was 71. Mrs. Stadler graduated from Antioch College and received a Master's degree from Southern Connecticut State College. She taught in the New Rochelle school system for 45 years until her retirement in 2009. For most of that period, she taught or was based at Columbus School, focusing on special education in her early career and then on mathematics, teaching and coordinating at a district-wide level. Mrs. Stadler was deeply committed to the belief that all children can learn. Her approach reflected the belief that children make meaning through inquiry-based teaching and learning. She taught that through hands-on applications, critical thinking, and problem-based learning, children can be involved and understand at deeper levels. Towards that end she created a great many math games and puzzles. Her underlying faith nurtured the innate intelligence and curiosity of the children. Her favorite direction on math tests was "show your work". Mrs Stadler was an accomplished amateur watercolorist and a truly marvelous cook. The daughter of Elliott Maurice Kahn and Marjorie Untermeyer Kahn Sands, Mrs. Stadler was born on July 18, 1938, in New York City. Mrs. Stadler's survivors include her husband of 47 years, Dr. John B. Stadler; sister Julie Shubik (Martin) of New Haven; sons Daniel (Cynthia) of Norwich, Vermont, Alex (Andrew Baker) of Philadelphia, and David (Laura) of New York City; step-daughters Jenny Stadler Carlson (Steve) of Houston and Iyana Stadler (Ruth Fremont) of Philadelphia; stepson Eliot Stadler (Jody) of Minneapolis; grandchildren Henry and Lily Stadler, step-grandchildren Erin, Rita, Russell, and Zoe Carlson and Hannah and Jacob Stadler; niece Claire Shubik, a large extended family and many friends from her home, career and travels. A memorial service for Mrs. Stadler will be held at 4pm on March 27th at the Coveleigh Club (215 Stuyvesant Ave. Rye, NY 10580). In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions be made to the Charlotte Stadler Fund at Columbus Elementary School (275 Washington Ave. New Rochelle, NY 10801).

FOUR years ago Martin McDonagh, the celebrated playwright whose flamboyantly gruesome dark comedies have brought smashed skulls, child murder and other carefully calibrated outrages to Broadway, shocked the theater world in an entirely new way. At the height of his creative powers and popularity, he decided to quit the stage while he was on top. Explaining that he was repeating himself and needed to do some growing up, he told The New Yorker, ''I've said enough as a young dramatist.'' He was 35.
Theater Jason Zinoman

THE NEWS Cash-strapped states that have tried to reduce prison costs by releasing more convicts early have scaled back or reconsidered those plans in the face of mounting public opposition. BEHIND THE NEWS In Michigan, for instance, the parole rate is the highest in 16 years. But critics there and elsewhere say that often the wrong kinds of convicts -- violent criminals and sex offenders -- are being released, and are committing new crimes at alarming rates. Officials in some states said their prison cost-cutting efforts fell short when they found far fewer prisoners to be wise release risks.

BANDA ACEH, INDONESIA -- For decades, the vast jungle interior that blankets the northern Indonesian province of Aceh provided a haven for thousands of rebel foot soldiers fighting a war of independence. Now, still marginalized and largely unemployed despite nearly five years of peace, many former separatists have fled back into the forest, this time to chop it down.

ALL-NIGHTERS As Jorge Luis Borges observes in his poem ''Insomnia'': ''In vain do I await/ the disintegration, the symbols that come before sleep.'' My internal narrator, the one who is speaking in my head all day long, refuses to shut up. The day voice of the self-conscious thinker races along heedless of my desire to stop it and relax. Chaucer's narrator in ''The Book of the Duchess'' seems to have a similar problem: ''Suche fantasies ben in myn hede,/ So I not what is best to doo.'' And so, like many insomniacs before and after him, he picks up a book and begins to read. I was 13 when I had my first bout of insomnia. I couldn't sleep, and so I read, but the novels I was reading only stimulated me more, and I would find myself wandering around the house with rushing fragments of Dickens, Austen or the Brontës whirring in my head. It is tempting to think of this form of insomnia, the inability to fall asleep, as a disease of agency and control, the inability to relinquish high self-reflexive consciousness for the vulnerable, ignorant regions of slumber in which we know not what we do.

After World War II, she moved to the United States and joined the United Nations, where she met and later married AH Dantas de Brito, a Brazilian national who himself served in the UN Secretariat for thirty years. They settled in Rye, New York. She was a sculptor. Henny de Brito is survived by her children, Diana de Brito of Washington, DC and Lilli Schindler of Rye, NY, their husbands Jonathan Gottlieb and Mark Schindler, and her grandchildren Allie and Caroline Gottlieb and Heather, David and Isabelle Schindler.

HEINEMAN--Natalie G. A pioneering champion for children's welfare who died at the age of 96 on February 28, 2010, in her native city of Chicago, Illinois. She will be remembered by all who knew her as a persistent advocate for social services for children and youth, an expert on adoption and foster care issues, an independent woman of intellect who always followed her heart, and as a beautiful person, inside and out, devoted to family and friends. She was a kind and selfless person, beloved by all she met. Her remarkable marriage to Chicago business and civic leader Ben W. Heineman Sr. lasted nearly 75 years. She is survived by her beloved husband Ben, her daughter Dr. Martha Heineman Pieper (Dr. William Pieper) of Chicago and her son Ben W. Heineman Jr. (Cristine Russell) of New Canaan, CT; grandchildren Thalia Field (Jamie Jewett and son Benjamin), Dr. Jessica Heineman-Pieper (Dr. Param Srikantia), Johanna Heineman-Pieper, Victoria Stein (Jotham and son Gershon), Zachary Heineman and Matthew Heineman; and many nieces, nephews and other relatives. Natalie Goldstein was born on March 16, 1913, on the south side of Chicago and lived in the city throughout her life. She graduated from the University of Chicago and did graduate work there before becoming a medical social worker. Ben and Natalie married on April 17, 1935, and she went on to lead many local and national civic and charitable organizations. She became the first woman president of the Chicago Child Care Society in 1966 and later the president of the Child Welfare League of America, which named a national award for outstanding service to children in her honor. She was one of the first women on the United Way of America national board. Other local service included the Citizens' Committee of the Juvenile Court of Cook County; the visiting committee of the University of Chicago School of Social Service Administration, and the board of the Erikson Institute for Early Childhood Education. Natalie was an intrepid family photographer, a lover of opera and symphony, and an avid studio glass collector with her husband Ben. In 2006, they donated their renowned collection to the Corning Museum of Glass, Corning, NY. The family would like to thank Dr. Neil Stone for his devotion and care. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to the Chicago Child Care Society, 5467 S. University Ave. Chicago, IL 60615. (773) 643-0452 or www.cccsociety.org. Interment will be at the Heineman family mausoleum in Wausau, WI. A private memorial service is being planned.

How to Combine Paris, England and Scotland My daughter and I are planning to take two weeks to travel from Chicago to Britain and perhaps Paris in July. She will be 14 by then, and this will be her first exposure to Europe. I am hoping to balance some of the essential tourist ''must visits'' with some unique stops, too. Our priorities are to see London, the English countryside and Edinburgh, and to take the Chunnel to France. Should I fly into Paris, spend a few days, head to Britain for the bulk of our time and then return to Paris for the flight back? Or is it easier (and less expensive) to start in Britain? -- Sara, Chicago

THIS month, the Neue Galerie will present the first American museum exhibition devoted to Otto Dix, the German expressionist whose unsparing caricatures of bourgeois society and its rather wanton underclass defined the look of Weimar Berlin. Among the highlights of the show is ''Portrait of the Dancer Anita Berber,'' a 1925 painting that depicts the infamous cabaret star, known for downing a bottle of cognac a day and dancing in the nude, as a vision in red. Inspired by the unabashed hedonism of the work, the Neue Galerie Design Shop, in collaboration with Estée Lauder, is releasing two limited-edition beauty products that will be sold in conjunction with the exhibition: a fiery crimson lipstick called Berlin Red and a Bauhaus-style mirror compact. Mr. Dix would approve of the decadence. Berlin Red lipstick, $30, and Bauhaus-style compact, $55, at Neue

ROTHSCHILD--Amelie, 104, of Hartsdale, NY, died on March 3, 2010. She was born to Adolph and Ida Spiegel on August 13, 1905 in New York City. Her beloved husband, Mortimer, predeceased her. She is survived by her sons Eric and Peter and their wives Christine and Mary; her grandchildren Adam and his wife Katherine, Alan and his wife Sayada, Elisabeth and her husband Nathaniel Donat, Anne, Paul and his wife Carolyn, Sarah and her husband Ryan McClain; her great-grandchildren Ellen, William, Nicolletta, Camille, Jaan, Gemma, and Brynn. She was an educator, the first Jewish woman on the Scarsdale, NY, Board of Education, one of the two New York State representatives at President Eisenhower's White House Conference on Education, and a driving force for public education. She was President of the League of Women Voters of Scarsdale, the Associate Director of the New York Civil Liberties Union, and in 1958 was honored by inclusion in the first Who's Who of American Women. There will be a memorial service in mid-March. Memorial contributions may be made to Make-a-Wish Foundation (1-866-880-1382) or Hunter College (1-212-772-4085).

THE area around the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn is home to painters and prostitutes, auto mechanics and ornithologists. After the canal was designated a Superfund site last week, nearly 200 readers submitted their visions of it online -- in photography, paintings and other media. The images show the canal at dusk, the oil patches that glide on the water's surface, the dead and living industries that line its banks, and the characters who frequent its bridges and, bravely, its waters. Much more is at nytimes.com/cityroom.

The San Marcos de Tarrazú region of the central mountains of Costa Rica, June 25, 2009. ''This is Los Santos, prime coffee-growing country, an hour and a half south of San José. I participated in an Earthwatch expedition there, to research sustainable coffee cultivation in the Tarrazú region with four other American teachers. By 7 every morning we were counting coffee beans on sample plants from one of 2,600 farms belonging to the Tarrazú cooperative. It was the rainy season, so we had to complete huge counts by noon, because torrential downpours could roll in at a moment's notice in the afternoon. We counted coffee beans in our sleep at night. What with the heat, bats and biting bugs, by midmorning we could become oblivious to the gorgeous scenery surrounding us. That's probably what happened to my teammate from Valrico, Fla., Christina Hill, who is taking a break in this picture.'' Lucia Schneck, Cranford, N.J.

QUEST--Ilona Madis, dearly beloved wife, mother, grandmother, sister, and friend, died on March 3, 2010. Born in Tallinn, Estonia, March 21, 1943, she immigrated with her parents and brother to the United States after WWII. A graduate of Briarcliff College and Columbia University, Ilona was a successful Occupational Therapist before dedicating her life to her family - raising her children, guiding her grandchildren, and supporting her husband's professional career. The gracious and elegant Ilona is survived by her husband, Donald Oliver Quest, her three daughters and sons-in-law, Wendy and Peter Trevisani, Amy and Ted Pogorelc, and Susan and Jared Demark, and her eight beautiful grandchildren who gave her such tremendous joy: Blake, Halle, Luke, Jack, Dylan, Pierce, Hugh, and Jordan. Noted for her joie de vivre and nurturing spirit, her ability to brighten every occasion and make everyone feel special, beautiful Ilona will be missed by everyone whose life she touched. A funeral service will be held Monday, March 8 at 11am at St. Elizabeth's Episcopal Church, 169 Fairmount Road in Ridgewood. A memorial service will also be held at a later date to be announced. In lieu of flowers, donations will be gratefully accepted at the following entity dear to Ilona's heart: The Donald and Ilona Quest Endowed Professorship in Neurological Surgery, Columbia University, The Neurological Institute of NY, Dept of Neurological Surgery, 710 W. 168th St., New York, NY 10032.

JAKOB--Solomon, father of Susan, Grandfather of Julia and Zach Lipkins has passed. A warrior with an old soul and a wonderful mind was born in Poland and lived throughout the world. Much has been made about LeBron James's filing paperwork with the National Basketball Association on Tuesday to change his jersey number from 23 to 6. James said the change would be made out of respect for Michael Jordan, who wore No. 23 for most of his career. (For a brief time after his return to basketball after a stint in the minor leagues Jordan wore No. 45.) This move is expected to take place at the beginning of next season, and there are many who feel that it is an indicator that he plans to resign with the Cavaliers. If he were to go to another team he could change his number without filing paperwork and waiting for league approval.

WERNER--Mary Elizabeth, age 96, beloved wife of Charles S. Werner, deceased, died peacefully on February 21, 2010 in Charleston, South Carolina. She is survived by daughters, Elizabeth W. Warrick and Barbara W. Kratovil, five grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Her family will miss her deeply. She served on the Boards of the Spence School and the Women's Committee of the Lighthouse for the Blind and was a founding member of the Alumnae President's Council of Independent Schools. A memorial service will be held in New York. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Katherine S. Wilson Memorial Fund at the Hospital for Special Surgery, 535 East 70th Street, New York, New York 10021.

WE see them everywhere. And if we're being honest, we have all had the same frightening and ignoble urge to smash their heads in with a brick. I am speaking about those smug and über-informative moms and dads who do their parenting in public places -- aggressively and at the top of their highly educated lungs. They are easy to recognize, decked out in natural fabrics and larded up with the self-importance that comes from foisting ''teachable moments'' on an unsuspecting public. Vibrating with earnestness and a gravitas that can seem eerily out of proportion to the setting, they pollute the public airspace as they loudly instruct their artisanal children on topics like sharing, Unicef or the water table -- all the while glancing about furtively to make sure that people have noticed how very patient and loving and role model-y they are. Unable to let any educational opportunity go unexploited, they are famous for holding up checkout lines while they explain commerce and all the denominations of American currency to sleepy and uninterested toddlers.

The Supreme Court revisited the Second Amendment last week, and there were strong hints that it was leaning toward expanding gun rights by striking down Chicago's strict gun control law, just as it overturned a District of Columbia gun-control law two years ago. The case seems to hinge on how the right to bear arms applies to cities and states that regulate guns. Meanwhile, gun rights are expanding at the local level across the country, and advocates are busy testing the waters, or at least the lattes, as they saunter into spots like Starbucks, firearms in plain view, in states that allow weaponry in public.

FOR the current fifth-anniversary exhibition at his New York gallery Jonathan LeVine has filled it with works by 35 artists, most of whom he represents. The space is in Chelsea, but there's no cerebral conceptualism, cool abstraction or painterly gesture on view. Instead this work, variously labeled Lowbrow Art, Pop Surrealism and perhaps most accurately Pop Pluralism, is the skateboarding, graffiti-tagging, sometimes bratty and rebellious younger sibling of the art shown in most of the neighborhood's locations. Still, the art in the Jonathan LeVine Gallery seems at home in Chelsea in a way it did not five years ago. After years on the fringes of the art world, ''we've come to a turning point,'' Mr. LeVine said recently. ''The mainstream is embracing this work.''

LAPID--Louis S.,M.D. The Mount Sinai Alumni Association mourns the recent passing of Dr. Louis S. Lapid, a mainstay of The Mount Sinai Medical Center since 1940. Dr. Lapid completed his residency, fellowship and research fellowship at Mount Sinai in Gynecology in 1947. President of the Alumni Association from 1972-1973, he received the Association's Jacobi Medallion in 1993 for distinguished achievement in medicine and extraordinary service. Dr. Lapid's dedication to the medical students of Mount Sinai was unmatched. The Executive Board: Dr. Martin S. Goldstein, Dr. Jeffrey T. Laitman, Dr. Jonathan D. Schiff, Dr. Lyris A. Schonholz, Dr. Elliot J. Rayfield and the Alumni Association extend sincere condolences to Lucille, and to his children and grandchildren. At the families request, all donations can be made in Dr. Louis Lapid's name to the Mount Sinai Alumni Association Endowed Scholarship Fund to continue to benefit the students of Mount Sinai.

When N.H.L. general managers convene for their annual three-day meeting Monday in Boca Raton, Fla., one item on the agenda will occupy most of their time: what, if anything, to do about hits to the head.The general managers will see several presentations, one the result of two years of independent medical study, as they seek to make policy recommendations to the league on the controversial issue. All checks to the head are illegal in international and Olympic hockey and in the Ontario Hockey League, the top developmental league for the N.H.L., because of the danger of concussion. But they remain legal in the N.H.L. as long as they are delivered with the shoulder and not while charging, boarding or committing some other existing foul.

INTRODUCED in 1975 by Christian Restoin (the French Vogue editor Carine Roitfeld's longtime partner), Equipment was, for its two-decade span, the Levi's 501 of buttoned shirts: easy, cool, classic -- a wardrobe staple for a who's who of style icons. Jane Birkin was a fan. Catherine Deneuve bought them by the dozen. Yoko One made weekly trips to the Madison Avenue shop, and Lauren Bacall was so wild for the shirts, she'd head straight to the warehouse in Paris. ''She wanted to see all the colors,'' said Serge Azria, the chief executive and creative director of Current/Elliott who, with the blessing of Mr. Restoin, a close friend for 30 years, has now revived the label. Drawing from the archive of 3,500 shirts, the new collection includes original styles (a jersey military design remains the same) and updated variations (the signature silk button-up shirt now has front pockets and comes in an array of washed-out hues). Collectibles, all.
Film Mike Hale

DRAPKIN--Dustin Joseph, 23, passed on March 5, 2010 in Snowmass Village, Colorado. Dustin was born December 2, 1986 in Bayonne, New Jersey to Donald and Bernice Drapkin. Dustin was raised in Alpine, New Jersey, where he attended Dwight Englewood School. He graduated in 2009 from The Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania with a dual major in Management and Music. Dustin was set to embark on his passion to become a chef, having recently been accepted to the French Culinary Institute. Dustin had a passion for life that was contagious to all who had the fortune of knowing him. While his life was certainly too short, those who were touched by him understand that the quality of existence far exceeds the quantity of time in which one lives. His smile, humor and passion for life brought so much joy to both family and friends. Dustin is survived by his loving parents, Donald and Bernice of Alpine, New Jersey; devoted sisters and brothers Matthew, Dana, Nicole, David and Amanda; adoring nieces and nephews William, Lilly, Annabel, Emma and Charles. Funeral Services will be held at Temple Sinai of Bergen County, 1 Engle Street, Tenafly, NJ Monday March 8th at 10:30am. Funeral under the direction of Quinn Hopping Funeral Home, Toms River, NJ and Gutterman and Musicant Jewish Funeral Directors, Hackensack, NJ.

STEARNS--James Pierce, 78, of Kent, CT, died of cancer March 2, 2010. He was born to James and Esther Stearns on January 15, 1932 in Boston. He is survived by his wife, Margaret Byard Stearns; two daughters, Sarah Stearns Fey of Greenwich, and Katherine Stearns Symonds (Kate) of New York City; two sisters, Elizabeth Malo and Janet May; and six grandchildren -- Jack, Jimmy and Charlie Symonds, and Daisy, Annie and Mercy Fey. An alumnus of Andover, Harvard and the University of Michigan Business School, he began a long career in education teaching mathematics at Noble and Greenough and Lawrenceville Schools. He was headmaster of Mary Institute in St. Louis (1969-1976) and Fairfield (CT) Country Day School (1976-1993). He loved music, and was an enthusiastic choral singer; he was a Krokodilo at Harvard and anchored the bass section wherever he was. He delighted in games, poetry, golf, Madaquecham, hors d'oeuvres, and beautiful dovetail joints. He knew every song lyric ever written and could make anybody laugh. Memorial service at 11am on Saturday, March 13, 2010 at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Kent, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to the Choir Fund, St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, 1 North Main St., Kent, CT 06757.

Searching for a hotel for disabled travelers has become easier. Expedia.com and its subsidiary Hotels.com have rolled out search tools that allow travelers with disabilities to find and book lodgings that feature bathrooms for the handicapped, roll-in showers and Braille signage.

ON A WINTER DAY five years ago, Doug Lemov realized he had a problem. After a successful career as a teacher, a principal and a charter-school founder, he was working as a consultant, hired by troubled schools eager -- desperate, in some cases -- for Lemov to tell them what to do to get better. There was no shortage of prescriptions at the time for how to cure the poor performance that plagued so many American schools. Proponents of No Child Left Behind saw standardized testing as a solution. President Bush also championed a billion-dollar program to encourage schools to adopt reading curriculums with an emphasis on phonics. Others argued for smaller classes or more parental involvement or more state financing. Lemov himself pushed for data-driven programs that would diagnose individual students' strengths and weaknesses. But as he went from school to school that winter, he was getting the sinking feeling that there was something deeper he wasn't reaching. On that particular day, he made a depressing visit to a school in Syracuse, N.Y., that was like so many he'd seen before: ''a dispiriting exercise in good people failing,'' as he described it to me recently. Sometimes Lemov could diagnose problems as soon as he walked in the door. But not here. Student test scores had dipped so low that administrators worried the state might close down the school. But the teachers seemed to care about their students. They sat down with them on the floor to read and picked activities that should have engaged them. The classes were small. The school had rigorous academic standards and state-of-the-art curriculums and used a software program to analyze test results for each student, pinpointing which skills she still needed to work on.

LAPID--Louis S. The Association of the Attending Staff of the Mount Sinai Hospital mourns the passing of our long-standing colleague, mentor and friend. Dr. Lapid came to Mount Sinai as a resident in 1941 where he completed his residency, fellowship, and a research fellowship in Gynecology. He was a superb clinician in the field of Obstetrics and a compassionate practitioner of medicine. A highly respected surgeon and teacher, Dr. Lapid was adored by his patients and considered the "consummate physician" by his colleagues. He was vigorously involved in the total care of his patients and helped train generations of Mount Sinai students and residents. In 1993, he received the Jacobi Medallion award for distinguished achievement in his field and outstanding service to the institution. He will be remembered as an extraordinary diagnostician whose special smile lives on in the many lives he touched. We extend our sincere condolences to his entire family. Steven B. Weinfeld, MD, President Gila Leiter, MD, Vice President Amy J. Weinstein, Administrator

FOLLOWING a 47-year career in the car business that earned him a reputation as an innovative and outspoken maverick, Robert A. Lutz will retire from General Motors on May 1. The announcement came after a major reorganization that G.M. announced on Tuesday. If this all sounds vaguely familiar, that's because Mr. Lutz, 78, essentially retired last year. But a few months later, G.M. pulled Mr. Lutz back during the automaker's bankruptcy. Since then, he has served as vice chairman, regaining his enthusiasm for the spotlight.

TAMPA, Fla. -- Yankees catcher Francisco Cervelli was taken to a Tampa-area hospital for a precautionary CT scan Saturday afternoon after he sustained a concussion when he was hit in the head by a pitch. Cervelli was hit on the helmet by Zech Zinicola, a right-hander for the Toronto Blue Jays, during the third inning of an exhibition game at George M. Steinbrenner Field. Cervelli remained on the ground for about a minute and then walked off under his own power.

LOS ANGELES - So while the ratings were good for the Oscar telecast - the best since 2005, in the days before we could distract ourselves by Twittering through the boring parts - the reviews were not so kind. Though the hosts, Alec Baldwin and Steve Martin, got decent marks as personalities, their material, except for a parody of "Paranormal Activity," was deemed stiffer than a Botox joke. "Hosting the show is an odd experience because you're out there, but it isn't about you," Mr. Baldwin wrote on The Huffington Post.

The private papers of the writer David Foster Wallace, who committed suicide at 46 in 2008, have been acquired by the Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas, Austin. The archive contains drafts of books, stories, essays, poems, letters and research, including the handwritten notes for "Infinite Jest," the novel that first gained him attention. There is also a copy of his dictionary, in which he circled words, and heavily annotated copies of books by Don DeLillo, Cormac McCarthy, John Updike and others. Mr. Wallace's writing journal, which includes personal reflections, story ideas, names and plots, as well as articles on boredom, tax shelters and credit-card fraud are also included.  As part of the deal, Mr. Wallace's publisher, Little, Brown and Company, is donating editorial files related to the author. Material for "The Pale King," the novel that is being assembled posthumously by Mr. Wallace's editor, will be sent to the center after the book's scheduled publication in the spring of 2011.

The eyebrow moved into view as a beauty focal point during the spring 2009 shows: models at Marni had theirs filled in with mauve powder and punctuated with a bold, brown line, while at Diesel Black Gold, brows were painted blue. Next came the bleached-brow craze of fall 2009, which, while not an office-appropriate look, probably generated a spike in the sales of Jolen Crème Bleach. This spring is clearly time to put down the tweezers, thanks to the likes of Alexander Wang, whose models sported thick brows scored with pencil. And looking ahead to fall 2010, the brow is bolder than ever, whether aggressive or playful.

She's done Broadway, now it's on to the ballet. On Monday, New York City Ballet announced that Patti LuPone will make her New York City Ballet debut in a new production of "The Seven Deadly Sins" as part of the company's 2011 spring season. The Tony-nominated director and choreographer Lynne Taylor-Corbett, who has previously choreographed two works for the company, "Mercury" in 1992 and "Chiaroscuro" in 1994, will create the new production. "The Seven Deadly Sins," a sung ballet in seven scenes, was composed by Kurt Weill to a German libretto by Bertolt Brecht in 1933 and was first performed in Paris and produced, directed and choreographed by George Balanchine. The ballet features a character portrayed by both a singer and dancer. Ms. LuPone will play the singer; a dancer has yet to be announced. The original production featuring Lotte Lenya as the singer, and Tilly Losch as the dancer. Balanchine revived the work in 1958 with Allegra Kent in the role of the dancer. The schedule of performances and the rest of the 2011 spring season will be announced at a later date.

I couldn't fly to Japan for the weekend. But from LAX, it was only a 10-minute drive to Torrance, Calif., which might be the next best thing. Home to the American subsidiaries of both Honda and Toyota, Torrance has thousands of Japanese residents. And now it has a hotel - the Miyako Hybrid - designed specifically for Japanese business travelers. (The "hybrid" in the name is meant to suggest that, like a hybrid car, the hotel is energy efficient.) By staying there, I hoped to recapture some of the excitement I felt during my first trip to Japan, in 1989, when I didn't want to sleep, lest I sacrifice a minute of exploring.

One thing I do when I can't sleep is play alphabet games. I try to list various things from A to Z: countries, rock groups, prescription drugs, movies, books, celebrities whose first and last names begin with the same letter... you get the idea. I don't mind repeating categories from one night to another. Diseases might seem to be an unlikely insomnia game category, but for some reason, it's one of my favorites. I like to combine ailments that terrified me in childhood (lockjaw) with ones that I didn't know about until I was an adult (Ebola). And there are certain ailments that are never, ever on the list. Ever.

Representative Eric Massa, the Democrat from upstate New York who has said he will resign office effective this afternoon in the wake of an ethics inquiry, is also now claiming that his vote against health care legislation has contributed to his problems. One of the puzzles of the developing world is that women frequently do some of the hardest physical labor. Hauling water, for example, is "women's work" in culture after culture. And anybody who has tried to haul a couple of buckets of water four miles from the nearest well know how excruciatingly heavy water becomes after a few hundred yards.

Sally Hershberger knows a thing or two about beach hair, having worked on countless photo shoots with Herb Ritts, Steven Meisel and Annie Leibovitz. "I can't stand it when hair doesn't have any movement to it," says the celebrity stylist, who is also an avid water-skier. Of course, it helps to have an ocean breeze -- not to mention one of Hershberger's legendary $800 haircuts. But the next best thing, and a heck of a lot cheaper, might very well be her new line of Salon styling products. There's Texture Blast, which Hershberger says gives "insane volume"; Smooth Fix, for that non-greasy red-carpet-worthy shine; Luxe Layers for blowouts; and Shape Up for -- what else -- body building. Erin Bogart, a colorist in Hershberger's New York salon who specializes in "surfer hair" -- strategically streaky with sun-kissed tips -- digs the Mineral Spray for that saltwater treatment without the salt.

The Greek prime minister called on the United States and the European Union on Monday to crack down on speculative trading, saying that exotic market bets had driven up Greece's borrowing costs and threatened its effort to ease its debt crisis, The New York Times's Sewell Chan reports from Washington.

Overconfidence is a very serious problem, but you probably don't think it affects you. That's the tricky thing with overconfidence: the people who are most overconfident are the ones least likely to recognize it. We tend to think of it as someone else's problem.

One of the stickiest points in international climate change negotiations is how to account for carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gas emissions produced to make goods that are then sold for export. Should the producing country be held to account for those emissions? Or does the consuming country bear some responsibility for counting those emissions?

The owner of a company that owned a crane that collapsed and killed two construction workers in May 2008 was charged Monday with manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide. The man, James F. Lomma of New York Crane and Equipment Corporation, pleaded not guilty in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. Tibor Varganyi, a former mechanic for New York Crane, was charged with the same crimes as Mr. Lomma. New York Crane and J. F. Lomma Inc., another company owned by Mr. Lomma, were also charged. Mr. Varganyi was released without bail. Mr. Lomma was also released; he will have a week to post $100,000 bail. Prosecutors contend that New York Crane replaced a broken turntable on a crane with an inferior one that cracked and caused the crane to collapse during work on a high-rise building on East 91st Street.

Stirling Moss, the greatest driver never to have won the Formula One world drivers' title, was injured in an accident at his home. Two days ago, Junya Watanabe held a military parade of long green coats and parkas, not unlike the ones seen at Dries Van Noten a few days before. Then, all of a sudden, as if possessed by some primordial, unspoken understanding, every fashion editor and her assistant's assistant began wearing - you guessed it - olive green, military-inspired gear. Some have already sunk their manicured claws into pre-fall samples; others scoured their closets for long-forgotten fatigues; one editor drove to a vintage military store in Montparnasse immediately after the Watanabe show, and handed the second-hand loot to the driver, so that he could throw it into the washing machine to achieve that elusive degree of casual distress.

Dieters are often advised to stop drinking alcohol to avoid the extra calories lurking in a glass of wine or a favorite cocktail. But new research suggests that women who regularly consume moderate amounts of alcohol are less likely to gain weight than nondrinkers and are at lower risk for obesity.

The Kobalt Tools 500 at Atlanta Motor Speedway on Sunday might be better remembered for the ongoing feud between Carl Edwards and Brad Keslowski than the winner, Kurt Busch. According to The Associated Press, the feud can be traced to a race last year at Talladega, in which Keslowski won after colliding with Edwards. In Atlanta on Sunday, the two made contact twice. The first incident came early and sent Edwards to the garage. He emerged late in the race (and more than 150 laps down from the leaders). With three laps to go, he clipped Keslowski's car at 190 miles and hour. Keslowski's car launched into the air, flipped and crashed in front of the grandstands. Nascar ordered Edwards to stop his car. "That's not cool," Keselowski said afterward. "He could have killed someone in the grandstands." Nascar will decide on Monday whether to discipline Edwards. (The Associated Press)

In the book I discussed last week, Zoe FitzGerald Carter's "Imperfect Endings," a woman growing increasingly incapacitated from Parkinson's disease deliberately stops eating and drinking so she can die in her home with her children and grandchildren nearby. It's a controversial decision, both within her own family and in the society at large, but it's a legal one - and a personal one that doesn't require any bureaucracy's blessing.

Well, at least the weekend wasn't a total loss for James Cameron. There was something about the running repartee between Steve Martin and Alec Baldwin at Sunday's Academy Awards show that had a certain timeless quality to it -- which is to say, many of their jokes sounded as if they could have been written at any time and for any occasion since the invention of the talkie.

This would probably be what the producers consider an unintentional watercooler moment. In what probably put his film on the map more than winning the Oscar itself, the short documentary winner Roger Ross Williams got Kanye'd when accepting his award for "Music by Prudence." As Mr. Williams, the director, was making his speech, Elinor Burkett, the producer, jumped onstage with him and began talking over him, shades of Kanye West interrupting Taylor Swift at the Video Music Awards last year. Salon has the back story: the two have been fighting for a year; there was a lawsuit about the creative control of the film that was settled out of court. Ms. Burkett, who lives in Zimbabwe, where the movie was shot, claims she gave Mr. Williams the idea for the project, a charge he disputes. In any case they didn't talk in advance to determine who would be the one person to come onstage to accept the award. (The Academy allows only one person to speak.)

Some leading lights in environmental science have been pushing their colleagues, and institutions like the National Academies, to come out swinging against the ongoing barrage of assaults from organized opponents of restrictions on greenhouse gases and climate skeptics/contrarians/denialists/realists (pick your label depending on your worldview).

Placido Domingo disclosed his medical problem on Monday: a "localized malignant polyp" in his colon. A spokeswoman said surgeons used laparoscopic surgery to remove the polyp and that Mr. Domingo was released from Mount Sinai Hospital on Sunday. He is expected to fully recover, said the spokeswoman, Nancy Seltzer. On Feb. 22, she said Mr. Domingo, 69, a busy tenor, conductor and opera company manager, would undergo "preventive surgery" after suffering sharp abdominal pain. At the time, she declined to provide details on the nature of his ailment, citing Mr. Domingo's privacy. Doctors have required at least six weeks of rest, and Mr. Domingo hopes to return to the stage on April 16, depending on how fast he heals, in Verdi's "Simon Boccanegra" at Teatro La Scala in Milan, the spokeswoman said Monday.

With access to solar-powered energy products for Cambodia's rural poor extremely limited, the solar energy company Kamworks and the Cambodia Mutual Savings and Credit Network are partnering to provide low-interest loans to customers hoping to outfit their homes with solar panels, while Kamworks will provide and install the equipment.

On Sunday, voters in Switzerland overwhelmingly rejected a proposal to appoint lawyers to represent abused animals in court in every region of the country. As The Lede explained last week, only Zurich currently employs a lawyer to speak for animals.

A clean, linear silhouette was the story at Stella McCartney this morning. Minimalism must be catching, like the common cold. Ms. McCartney's showopened with a sleek, notched, above-the-knee coat in taupe wool (shown with bare legs and beige patent sling-backs) and moved to graphic camel and black striped tops with slacks. There were some interesting color mixes - a structured vest/top in burnt orange wool over a salmon turtleneck with black stirrup pants - and some see-through panels here and there. Shifts were super short, possibly as short as a sexy Balmain dress, and that worked against the clean message.

When Sasha Allen began singing "Aquarius," the opening number of "Hair: The American Tribal Love-Rock Musical," on Sunday afternoon, it was hard to tell at first whether the teardrop was just a bit of sparkly makeup under her left eye. As she got deeper into the song and the cast joined in behind her, though, it was clear that it was a welling, uncontrollable tear. Followed by many others, it glistened down her cheek. Elsewhere chins quivered. When the song was done, Ms. Allen was wiping her eyes, the audience was on its feet for the first of several standing Os, and many in the young, exuberant cast were openly sobbing.

In his Media Equation column, David Carr asks what happens when your own newspaper or magazine becomes the story. One recent example involved The New York Times, which was working on stories about New York Gov. David A. Paterson. The actual stories, when they ran, were nothing like the wave of rumors that preceded them. And that's just one recent example.

The Origins and Evolution of the Moonbean Name | Jesse McKinley explores the history of a nickname for Jerry Brown, which was given to him in 1976 by Mike Royko, the syndicated Chicago columnist who later asked that people stop using it. With Mr. Brown announcing last week that he would seek to become California's next governor, the "Governor Moonbean" sobriquet was resurrected by some as a description of someone who is unpredictable. Mr. Brown, who is the state's attorney general, said the name, to him, symbolized other qualities, like being "creative and not hidebound to the status quo." He added: "Moonbeam also stands for not being the insider, but standing apart and marching to my own drummer. And I've done that." [The New York Times]

The opening lines of the satirical novel "Max Havelaar" are so well-known in Dutch that even a relatively new arrival to the Netherlands, with scant knowledge of the country's literary tradition, can recite them by memory: "Ik ben makelaar in koffie, en woon op de Lauriergracht, no. 37." Translation: "I am a coffee broker, and live at No. 37 Lauriergracht." A simple declarative statement to open up one of the first works in any language to bring an exploitative colonial system under moral scrutiny; the novel has since become a cornerstone of the literary tradition of the Netherlands. Eduard Douwes Dekker, or Multatuli as he is known, finished writing the book 150 years ago. This year, a couple of events mark that anniversary.

A concrete corner of a demolished building juts from the earth out of what appears to be the middle of nowhere. (Slide 8.) In its sturdy solitude, perhaps - at another time or place - it could be a monument to a great war, a solemn reminder of destruction and loss. But on this day it provided cover from sniper fire. Or shade. Or both. This is Marja.

“If you happen to be walking through the World Financial Center in Lower Manhattan in the next several weeks,” writes Steven McElory, “be aware that a sword fight may erupt near you.” If so, do not panic; you are actually seeing actors from the New York Classical Theater production of “Hamlet,” starring, in the title role, Justin Blanchard, who will be rehearsing at the 3.5-acre center through March 25. The company, which has held open rehearsals in Battery Park and Central Park for years, is hoping to lure viewers by giving them a sneak peak at the process of how theater gets done. “Throughout the season, the company will use an empty storefront at 1 New York Plaza as a production office and costume shop. Passers-by can wander into the office and observe costume fittings, take part in scheduled discussions with members of the creative staff and even — if they are so inclined — learn about more mundane aspects of putting on a show, like sending out mailers and doing paperwork.”

William Kentridge, writes Anthony Tommasini, "belongs at the Met." The South African artist directed the company's production of Shostakovich's early opera "The Nose," which opened on Friday, and his sets and videos that animate the staging "received the heartiest bravos." The choice of Mr. Kentridge is another example of how Peter Gelb, the company's general manager, has made it a priority to recruit directors from theater and film. "With Mr. Kentridge, whose work can now be seen in an extensive exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, Mr. Gelb has brought in a major visual artist. Stop-action animation and theatrical design are central to Mr. Kentridge's work, and he has unleashed his imagination on Shostakovich's bitterly satirical and breathless opera." The music is intriguing, too: "you are not likely to hear a more insightful, ornery and, when appropriate, achingly poignant account of Shostakovich's still-shocking score than the performance the conductor Valery Gergiev drew from the Met orchestra and chorus and the large cast: some 30 artists, singing about 80 solo roles." Tonight a lecture about the production will be held at the Opera house beginning at 6.

Every year, Microsoft holds a show-and-tell extravaganza in which its researchers from around the globe gather in Redmond, Wash., to demonstrate their fanciest technology. Last week, Microsoft provided reporters with a glimpse of some of this wizardry and gave a hands-on session with its Project Natal gaming system. Natal is the gesture control add-on that Microsoft plans to sell for its Xbox 360 consoles later this year. It lets people ditch their traditional game controllers. A flick of your wrist translates on-screen to a flick of the wrist, and the same goes for a kick, head bob or bend.

8:30 P.M. (SNY) BEASTS OF THE BIG EAST: THE TOP 10 ALL-TIME PLAYERS Will Patrick Ewing, above, who started on the Georgetown University varsity basketball team as a freshman, make the cut? SNY celebrates the 30-year history of the Big East Conference with this countdown of its most notable players as selected by a panel of experts, crowned by an interview with the winner. STADLER--Charlotte K.,71, a long-time schoolteacher and mathematics specialist in the New Rochelle School District, died in her sleep Saturday, February 27, at her home in Larchmont, two months after being diagnosed with acute leukemia. She was 71. Mrs. Stadler graduated from Antioch College and received a Master's degree from Southern Connecticut State College. She taught in the New Rochelle school system for 45 years until her retirement in 2009. For most of that period, she taught or was based at Columbus School, focusing on special education in her early career and then on mathematics, teaching and coordinating at a district-wide level. Mrs. Stadler was deeply committed to the belief that all children can learn. Her approach reflected the belief that children make meaning through inquiry-based teaching and learning. She taught that through hands-on applications, critical thinking, and problem-based learning, children can be involved and understand at deeper levels. Towards that end she created a great many math games and puzzles. Her underlying faith nurtured the innate intelligence and curiosity of the children. Her favorite direction on math tests was "show your work". Mrs Stadler was an accomplished amateur watercolorist and a truly marvelous cook. The daughter of Elliott Maurice Kahn and Marjorie Untermeyer Kahn Sands, Mrs. Stadler was born on July 18, 1938, in New York City. Mrs. Stadler's survivors include her husband of 47 years, Dr. John B. Stadler; sister Julie Shubik (Martin) of New Haven; sons Daniel (Cynthia) of Norwich, Vermont, Alex (Andrew Baker) of Philadelphia, and David (Laura) of New York City; step-daughters Jenny Stadler Carlson (Steve) of Houston and Iyana Stadler (Ruth Fremont) of Philadelphia; stepson Eliot Stadler (Jody) of Minneapolis; grandchildren Henry and Lily Stadler, step-grandchildren Erin, Rita, Russell, and Zoe Carlson and Hannah and Jacob Stadler; niece Claire Shubik, a large extended family and many friends from her home, career and travels. A memorial service for Mrs. Stadler will be held at 4pm on March 27th at the Coveleigh Club (215 Stuyvesant Ave. Rye, NY 10580). In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions be made to the Charlotte Stadler Fund at Columbus Elementary School (275 Washington Ave. New Rochelle, NY 10801).

JAKOB--Solomon, father of Susan, Grandfather of Julia and Zach Lipkins has passed. A warrior with an old soul and a wonderful mind was born in Poland and lived throughout the world. He was a survivor and a unique, spiritual and loving man. Services Sunday 11:15am at the Riverside 76th and Amsterdam.

DRAPKIN--Dustin. We will miss you terribly. Perform your magic in paradise. Be assured we will care for "Mama", Dad, David, Nicole, Amanda, Dana, Matt and your little nieces and nephews. Forever Dust-The-Man. Melinda, Irv, Lindsey, Ali and Sam

PESIN--Edward, 85, of North Bergen, NJ died on March 6th. Son of Libby and Samuel Pesin, he received his BA from Rutgers, JD from Harvard Law, and LLM in tax law from NYU. He practiced law in New Jersey and New York for over fifty years and was regarded as a leading tax expert. He was responsible for the passage of the Professional Service Corporation Act in 1963, and was thereafter affectionately called New Jersey's "father of the professional corporation." He will be remembered for his astute mind, compassion, leadership in civic, professional and charitable groups, and his deep love for his family. Cherished husband of 57 years of Helene, father of Dr. Samuel (Donna) Pesin and the late Ella Pesin, and grandfather to Elyssa (Jeff) Kotzen, Jennifer Pesin, and Libby Bergier-Pesin, and brother of Ada (Philippe) Feyerick. Burial at Mt. Moriah Cemetery, Fairview, NJ on March 8, 2010 at 2pm.

DRAPKIN--Dustin. Who can forget Dustin's eyes crinkling up at the corners as he laughed. Or his dedication to his friends and his joy at sharing his love of life with them. DE BRITO--Henny, formerly Hendrika Trompetter Zwecher, was born in Hoogeven, Holland in 1919. She was a survivor of seven Nazi concentration camps, including Auschwitz, Terezin, Birkenau and Kratzau, but most of her family perished. After World War II, she moved to the United States and joined the United Nations, where she met and later married AH Dantas de Brito, a Brazilian national who himself served in the UN Secretariat for thirty years. They settled in Rye, New York. She was a sculptor. Henny de Brito is survived by her children, Diana de Brito of Washington, DC and Lilli Schindler of Rye, NY, their husbands Jonathan Gottlieb and Mark Schindler, and her grandchildren Allie and Caroline Gottlieb and Heather, David and Isabelle Schindler.

DRAPKIN--Dustin Joseph, 23, passed on March 5, 2010 in Snowmass Village, Colorado. Dustin was born December 2, 1986 in Bayonne, New Jersey to Donald and Bernice Drapkin. Dustin was raised in Alpine, New Jersey, where he attended Dwight Englewood School. He graduated in 2009 from The Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania with a dual major in Management and Music. Dustin was set to embark on his passion to become a chef, having recently been accepted to the French Culinary Institute. Dustin had a passion for life that was contagious to all who had the fortune of knowing him. While his life was certainly too short, those who were touched by him understand that the quality of existence far exceeds the quantity of time in which one lives. His smile, humor and passion for life brought so much joy to both family and friends. Dustin is survived by his loving parents, Donald and Bernice of Alpine, New Jersey; devoted sisters and brothers Matthew, Dana, Nicole, David and Amanda; beloved brother-in-law, Josh and sister-in-law, Annie; adoring nieces and nephews William, Lilly, Annabel, Emma and Charles. Funeral Services will be held at Temple Sinai of Bergen County, 1 Engle Street, Tenafly, NJ Monday March 8th at 10:30am. Funeral under the direction of Quinn Hopping Funeral Home, Toms River, NJ and Gutterman and Musicant Jewish Funeral Directors, Hackensack, NJ.

BADIGIAN--Alice, 100, a survivor of the Armenian Genocide in Manisa, Turkey, died at home in New Vernon, NJ on February 27, where she lived with her daughter Marion. Throughout her life, she was affronted by the denial of events she witnessed first-hand, yet her belief in the triumph of truth and justice never wavered. Quietly magnificent in thought and deed, she loved her family unreservedly and is mourned by grandchildren Joyce and Billy, seven great-grandchildren, and all who knew her. Sleep well darling Nana. Donations to The Armenian Eyecare Project, at www.eyecareproject.com

As my colleague Lydia Polgreen writes, the upper house of India's Parliament passed a bill on Tuesday that would amend the Constitution to reserve a third of the seats in India's national and state legislatures for women. Such a provision may sound extreme, but it is nothing new: According to the Quota Project, about half of the world's countries currently use some type of electoral quota for their national legislatures, in some cases enforced by political parties. (India has previously experimented with quotas for women in local elections.)

In Daniel Arsham's world, nothing is what it seems. A smooth wall suddenly looks as if it is being stretched like fabric. A solid white cube gives the impression that it's been eaten away. An Arcadian landscape populated only by a kangaroo is invaded by a rectangular slab that hovers in midair. A gouache rendering of Le Corbusier's modernist monastery La Tourette is pictured inside a cave. Arsham's work blurs the lines between art, architecture and performance, and explores issues of natural versus manufactured or intention versus happenstance. It has attracted impressive collaborators - Merce Cunningham, the choreographer Jonah Bokaer and the fashion designer Hedi Slimane - as well as the art dealer Emmanuel Perrotin. Arsham's third solo exhibition at Perrotin's Paris gallery, "Animal Architecture," opens on March 20. And to think, he's only 29.

Overview | What does the state of Haiti's school system reveal about the devastation and social problems there? How does any school system reflect its community and country? What misconceptions about a country's values and culture might an examination of its schools give rise to? In this lesson, students examine how Haiti's schools have been devastated following the earthquake. They then execute one of the following projects: comparing post-quake Haiti to post-hurricane New Orleans and writing poetry; taking photographs that tell their school's story; graphing the relationships among GDP, education spending and literacy; or researching one country's education system and how it conveys and reflects national culture.

Since medieval times, the desire to make maps of the world remains a story of both necessity and art. If the recent surge of books about maps is any indication, cartographic art is for all ages. How better to visualize human history and keep track of one's empire while contemplating opportunities for expansion? Andreas Gursky's latest body of work pushes his penchant for wide-angle photography to encompass the ever-increasing scope of his Weltanschauung, or worldview. Verging on 13 feet by 8 feet, Gursky's photographs are cinematic in scale, and their exhibition at Gagosian in Beverly Hills, Calif., is apt for a town filled with connoisseurs of cinematography (and movie moguls who can afford them).

In the play "Time Stands Still" (at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater through March 27), Laura Linney plays Sarah Goodwin, a war photographer badly injured by a bomb blast in Iraq. From the beginning, the director, Daniel Sullivan, and Linney knew that Goodwin's visible scars would be an important facet of the production, so the actress suggested calling in Mindy Hall, an accomplished (and as of this past Sunday night, Academy Award-winning) makeup artist who Linney had worked with on four films, including "Kinsey." "I knew Mindy would be able to come up with something a) the theater would be able to afford, b) that would look realistic and c) that I would be able to put on myself," Linney said. Applying the extensive shrapnel marks to her face, arm and leg has become something of a pre-performance meditation for the actress. "I love the quiet time it gives me before every show," she says. "I tend to get to the theater early anyway, but this gives me an excuse to get here even earlier. And you know, it's just me alone. It becomes a sort of starting point."

I associate stuffed vegetables with two very different milieus: southern France and the red-sauce Italian restaurants of my childhood. The first is a place of rosé wine, summer squashes, tomatoes, onions and little peppers, all filled with herb-scented vegetable stuffings, and sunshine. The second is, or was, a place of quart bottles of Hoffman soda, veal parmigiana, dim, reddish light - and stuffed mushrooms.

The veteran Broadway and film costume designer Albert Wolsky, who has two Academy Awards to his credit for "All That Jazz" and "Bugsy," will receive the T.D.F./Irene Sharaff lifetime achievement award next month at a ceremony that will honor several other designers as well. The Theater Development Fund, the not-for-profit group that runs TKTS and has an extensive collection of costumes for rent, announced the recipients of the design awards on Tuesday.The other honorees are: • Ming Cho Lee, who will receive the Robert L. B. Tobin Award for sustained excellence in theatrical design. Mr. Lee, who first worked on Broadway as a technical assistant for the musical "Happy Hunting" during the 1956-57 season, was the set designer for the original Broadway production of "Mother Courage and Her Children" in 1963 and more than 20 other Broadway shows, including the musicals "Billy" and "Two Gentleman of Verona" and the play "K2," for which he won a Tony Award for his set design of a ledge on the famous mountain.• Alejo Vietti, who will receive the young master award recognizing his work as a costume designer in New York and regionally, including the Off Broadway productions "Nightingale" and "Rooms: A Rock Romance."• John David Ridge, who will receive the artisan award. Mr. Ridge is a Hollywood and theater costume designer who was nominated for a Tony for best costume design in 1999 for the revival of "Ring Round the Moon."

'I'm Gay,' Republican Lawmaker Says | State Senator Roy Ashburn, Republican of Bakersfield, told a radio program Monday that he is gay, making him the first openly gay Republican legislator in Sacramento. "I'm gay," he said. "Those are the words that have been so difficult for me for so long." Mr. Ashburn, whose confession appeared to come out of his arrest last week in Sacramento for suspicion of drunken driving, said he had voted against gay rights measures because that is what he believed his constituents wanted. On the Senate floor on Monday, colleagues of both parties shook his hand and slapped his back. [The Sacramento Bee]

Fashion doesn't get more vividly macabre than RP/Encore's line of taxidermy accessories. The artist Reid Peppard makes ghoulish bow ties and pendants from an assortment of rodents and birds collected from the London streets by her cat, Panasonic, and other eagle-eyed friends. "I get texts saying: 'I've just found a dead pigeon on Old Street,' " says the 23 year-old Californian, whose beastly collections have names like Vermin, Park and Pet. "It takes chutzpah to wear my work, so most of my customers are men." Still, her creations have been commissioned for Lady Gaga, and the Balenciaga designer Nicolas Ghesquière has posted her work on his Facebook page. So next time you're on the checkout line, wear a bow tie with a dead mouse and watch the crowds part - it casts a whole new light on the term "killer accessory."

The biggest loser Sunday night at the Oscars wasn't "Avatar." It was "Up in the Air," which was shut out in every category after looking like a shoo-in for a statuette when it first came out. The backlash against Jason Reitman's movie seemed to build steadily across the last couple months, and it took an interesting form: It attacked what seemed like the film's greatest strengths, casting them as artistic liabilities instead.

Paris is cold enough this week but Karl Lagerfeld decided to make it a bit colder this morning at Chanel with a misting set of icebergs seeming to float in an Arctic-blue sea. The setting was the Grand Palais, and the bergs were hidden from the audience under a huge wooden box that mechanically rose when the show started. It was a lavish production, needless to say, with classic tweeds, cute knits and thick fur chaps dragged through the enormous wading pool by the models. All the fur, by the way, was fake. Any comment about climate change and melting ice caps was probably unintended. The Ice Hotel in Sweden provided inspiration. When asked backstage if he had ever visited the hotel, Mr. Lagerfeld, dressed in a Dior peacoat and bleached jeans with a vintage Cartier stickpin in his black tie, shivered and said no.

"The Nose," an opera by Dmitri Shostakovich that had its premiere in Leningrad in 1930 and is based on a short story by Nikolai Gogol written in 1836, is one of the Metropolitan Opera's new shows this season. As well as alchemy involving three different genres -- four if you include stagecraft -- the production bridges three centuries. It has the added element of direction and co-design by the contemporary South African artist William Kentridge, which involves video animations and a fair bit of 21st-century technology.

Nicolas Degennes is a rock star. He's not in a band, though he spends loads of time backstage. He does live gigs, but his only instruments are buckets of savoir-faire and a genius for innovation. Degennes is the artistic director of Givenchy's Le Makeup. He's the inventor of Phenomen'eyes, that mold-breaking mascara with the mace-like, spiked applicator. He travels in very arty circles, and I bet he brings the house down wherever he goes. Women love him. Men love him, too. It's because he talks to people, not at them. He also listens, makes eye contact, smiles. He's unaffected, un-jaded, un-snobby. For a Frenchman, this is nothing short of miraculous.

In one of his early collections for Saint Laurent, the designer Stefano Pilati worked Christian symbols into his clothes, including the outline of a cross in the back of a coat. So it wasn't surprising that people again saw religious references in his fall 2010 show: the many somber capes, yoked white blouses with full sleeves, the preponderance of black, hats that brought to mind a nun's cap, and the gold chains from which dangled a single figure (in fact, a silhouette of a woman). The press notes  referred only to the protection elements in the show, most obviously the clear plastic rain covers over some of the tailored pieces. But, of course, religion is protection, too.

" 'The Temperamentals,' Jon Marans's eminently likable docudrama about gay identity in the age of Eisenhower, begins with a classic vision of mid-20th-century uniformity: five guys in off-the-peg suits, as anonymous as the standard-issue, metal-frame chairs on which they're seated," writes Ben Brantley. "Discovering what lurks beneath gray flannel is both the theme and the story-propelling engine of 'The Temperamentals,' which chronicles the creation of the Mattachine Society, the breakthrough gay-rights organization. And in Mr. Marans's play the journey to such knowledge is hardly (you should pardon the expression) a straight line." The characters in the drama, currently at New World Stages, are based on real people and "lovingly incarnated by a cast led by Thomas Jay Ryan and Michael Urie."

When "The Cove" won the Oscar for best documentary on Sunday, the star of the film and dolphin activist Ric O'Barry held up a sign while the producer, Fisher Stevens, was giving his acceptance speech. It read "Text Dolphin to 44144," which automatically signs people up to receive information about the fight against the dolphin hunting practices in a Japanese village, on which the film is based. Tonight you can learn more about the issue at Asia Society where the documentary will be shown. A panel discussion will follow the screening with Louie Psihoyos and Mr. O'Barry, and moderated by New York Times reporter Andrew C. Revkin.

"With 'The Surrendered,' " writes Michiko Kakutani, "Chang-rae Lee has written the most ambitious and compelling novel of his already impressive career — a symphonic work that reprises the themes of identity, familial legacies and the imperatives of fate he has addressed in earlier works, but which he grapples with here on a broader, more intricate historical canvas." The backdrop is the chaos of the Korean War and Mr. Lee chronicles the "cruel, heartbreaking events of war with harrowing, cinematic immediacy, making palpable the excruciating violence and the huge footprint it leaves on people's lives." Tonight, the author will be at Barnes & Noble on Broadway and 66th Street.

LEVINE--Charlotte. For more than eight years a close and loving companionship between myself and Charlotte has given me the opportunity to observe her marvelous talents and love of people. Above all else she was adored by her friends. Other interests included her love of music and politics, especially apparent injustices. I shall forever be indebted for what she has taught me and the warmth of her love. Blessed be her memory. Forever in my thoughts, Bob Berkley

Francisco Cervelli, who sustained his second concussion in four months Saturday when he was hit in the head by a pitch, was cleared Monday by the Yankees' medical staff to resume physical activity. Cervelli was examined Monday by a neurologist, and all testing came back clean, the Yankees said. Manager Joe Girardi said Cervelli would begin some light activity Tuesday and, at the earliest, could rejoin the lineup Friday against Washington in Viera, Fla. Depending on how Cervelli feels, he may catch a bullpen session or take batting practice Tuesday. General Manager Brian Cashman said that Cervelli, who was not available Monday, had not experienced any recent symptoms but that the Yankees intended to proceed carefully.

PERRY--John, age 86, father of his beloved caretaker/health medical proxy son George Perry and his daughters Elaine, Angie and Connie, has died March 7, 2010. John was a federal government employee for 38 years. In WWII he was in the Navy on a spy submarine and then a fed with the FAA until his retirement with honors 20 years ago. The past 20 years he lived with his son in George and John's New York City Elmhurst, Queens co-op. He enjoyed retirement living with his beloved son George in their co-op. Visitation at the Thomas M. Quinn & Sons, 35-20 Broadway, Long Island City. 718-721-9200 on Wednesday and Thursday. 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral service at St. Demetrius Cathedral Friday, 10:15am. Burial with his beloved brother Uncle Charlie and his mother in the family plot in Mt. Olivet.
STEIN--Irene Rottkov. 8/29/24 - 3/9/65 45 years.... still so missed and saddened by all that you have missed. Your daughters, Gail and Mona

DISICK--Ellis. We are saddened beyond words for the loss of our dear friend, Ellis. We cannot believe he is gone. His warmth and caring were felt by all of our family. Even though he fought such a hard battle, our sadness and disbelief are hard to manage. We find solace in our memories of his relationship with his wonderful wife and dear friend, Laurie, and the outstanding family that he has left behind. With all our love, Suzanne, Jim, Amanda and Matthew

HAUPTMAN--Carol, died peacefully on March 7, 2010. Beloved wife of the late Joseph Hauptman and mother of Ellen Hauptman and Susan Seidel. Her sharp intellect, sense of humor and feisty personality will be greatly missed. Contributions may be made in her memory to North Shore-LIJ Health System Foundation, 125 Community Drive, Great Neck, NY 11021.

SAUNDERS--Alexis, age 34, of Tampa, FL. The beloved daughter and only child of Alan and Stephanie Saunders also of Tampa, FL. She died Sunday March 7, 2010 after four years battling brain cancer. A graduate of Vanderbilt University, an advocate of animal rights, and a talented poet who published three volumes of poetry. Services were held Monday, March 8. Contributions in Alexis's name will be greatly appreciated by the Tug McGraw Foundation, 1303 Jefferson St., Suite 100B, Napa, CA 94559. The family may be contacted at alstampa@live.com

FORSTER--Arnold, beloved husband, loving father and grandpa. We will always treasure your memory and honor your legacy. We love you. Contributions may be made to the Anti-Defamation League. Graveside service. ADL Memorial in June. Berman and Forster Families Janie, Howard, Jordan, Camryn, Carole, Charles & Molly

LANGRIDGE--Philip. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the untimely death of tenor Philip Langridge. He made his Met debut as Ferrando in "Cosi fan tutte" in 1985, and appeared as the Witch in "Hansel and Gretel" just two months ago. It was a role that showcased his splendid acting ability and wonderful sense of humor. In all, he sang 64 performances of eight roles, including Aron in the Met premiere of Schoenberg's Moses und Aron. We will remember his wonderful voice and superb musicianship and sorely miss him as a generous and beloved colleague. We offer our deepest sympathy to his wife, Ann, his children Stephen, Anita, Jennifer, and Jonathan, and his grandchildren. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director

For decades, advocates have fought to protect women from disfiguring breast cancer surgery, arguing that it was just as effective to remove only the cancerous tissue rather than the whole breast. But today, a growing number of women with breast cancer are pushing surgeons in a startling new direction. Not only do they want the cancerous breast removed, but they also want the healthy breast cut off.

KASSIMIR--Stanley, March 14, 1929-March 7, 2010. A superior person, intellectual heavyweight and Bronx Science wunderkind. He reminded us that every man and woman is entitled to their dignity and what really distinguishes people from one another was their desire to help. Destined to be the ultimate mentor to four children, their spouses, eleven grandchildren who lovingly called him "Papa," and infinite colleagues and physicians, both young and old at Roche/ Genentech for the past 25 years. Who, while in his 30s when asked the meaning of life told us that there was none and that you had to give it meaning by doing for others what they could not do for themselves. He leaves this world but not our hearts with unimpeachable integrity, unwavering loyalty and unquestionable decency. Services Wednesday 11:45am at Temple Emmanuel, 65th Street and 5th Avenue. Pauline, Joel, Robin, Mauri, Sharon, Jon, Rachelle, Richard, Linda, Spencer, Jason, Matthew, Evan, Remy, Alex, Brandon, Charlotte, Lauren, Shelly and, of course, Jack

NAGER--Jordan.
