We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Sue and her bereaved family. Lief Rosenblatt, President David J. Gelfand, Rabbi

RAHM--Hans, died peacefully on March 8, 2010, age 103, in West Orange, NJ. Devoted husband of the late Alicia Rahm, loving father of the late Michael of Seattle, WA and David and his wife Susan of New York City. Adored grandfather of Christopher Rahm of Nanaimo, BC, Katie Rahm Nicholson of Boston and William Rahm of New York City. A warm, gentle man who, as an engineer, managed chemical manufacturing plants in New Jersey before retiring to work with his wife making sculptures and running a crafts store in Montclair, NJ. Everyone who knew Hans loved him. Services private. Donations may be made to the Berkman Rahm Scholarship Fund at Manhattan School of Music, 120 Claremont Avenue, New York, NY 10027.
ABRAHAM--Raimund. I will always remember you as my friend and a very creative person. Gaetano Pesce

PAPPALARDO--Letizia, Sr.,RSHM, 76, a Religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary for 50 years, died in Rome, Italy, March 6, 2010. Teacher, principal, alumnae coordinator at Istituto Marymount, Rome Italy; drug rehabilitation counselor and trainer at Centro Italiano di Solidarita in Rome. Provincial superior (1997-2002) of the RSHM Eastern American Province, Tarrytown, NY. Funeral services in Rome, Italy. Memorial service at Marymount, Tarrytown, NY at a later date. In lieu of flowers, gifts in her name may be made to the Religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary, 50 Wilson Park Drive, Tarrytown, NY 10591.

ABRAHAMS--Beverly W. (Werner) Rochester, NY. Passed away March 7, 2010, at age 86. She was the daughter of Benjamin and Martha Werner. She was predeceased by her husband, Morton; and sister, Mildred Wagner. She is survived by her loving children, Rabbi David Abrahams, Deborah "Debby" (Howard Gordon) Abrahams, Alida (Lewis) White; grandchildren, Emelyne and Martin Abrahams, Marcia White; great-grandson, Ian Abrahams. Beverly was a graduate of Hunter High School and Hunter College, and received her Master's in English from the New School for Social Research in NYC. She married Morton Abrahams on June 25, 1950. He predeceased her on October 15, 1965. Beverly went on to become President of the General Preserve Company until she sold the business in 1966. After that, she worked for the New York Times from 1969-1991. She was a professional artist who displayed her work at The Gallery on Main Street in Canandaigua throughout the 1990's. Beverly always had a lifelong interest in art and classical music. Funeral Services will be held on Tuesday, March 9th at 2pm at Brighton Memorial Chapel, 3325 Winton Road South, Rochester, New York. Private interment, Mount Ararat, Farmingdale, NY. Following the funeral, a period of mourning will be observed at the home of Rabbi David Abrahams, 87 Willowick Dr., Fairport, on Tuesday and Wednesday from 6:30pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Rabbi's Discretionary Fund at Congregation Etz Chaim, Fairport, New York or Hunter College in her memory. To email a message of condolence, please visit Beverly's guest book at: www. BrightonMemorialChapel.com

FORSTER--Arnold. The Anti-Defamation League mourns the death of our dear friend and longtime colleague, Arnold Forster. Arnie joined ADL in 1940, and as Associate National Director developed its law and civil rights department to counter anti-Semitism, prejudice and extremism. He served as General Counsel from 1946 to 2003, though he retired from ADL in 1979. Arnie was deeply committed to the State of Israel and reported on the Arab-Israeli situation for his radio and TV series. His contributions to the fight against anti-Semitism and extremism, and for civil rights and dignity for all people, are enduring, and his legacy lives on. We extend our deepest sympathies to his daughter, Janie Forster Berman, his grandchildren and the entire family. An ADL memorial will be held at a future date. For information contact: adlmedia@adl.org Robert G. Sugarman, National Chair Abraham H. Foxman, National Director

NAGER--Jordan Selig, May 26, 1925 - March 7, 2010. Died at home after a year long battle with cancer. A lifelong New Yorker, he graduated from Poly Prep High School and Drexel University. A veteran of World War II, he was President of Nager Electric Company and Gallagher Switchboard Corporation. He is survived by Sue, his beloved wife of 54 years, his children Peter (Alice), Brad (Diane), James (Jodi) and Alison (Joseph) as well as his adored grandchildren Jesse, Joe, Rebekah, Chris, Cody, Emory, Alexandra, Noah, Abigail and an eagerly anticipated grandson on the way. He also leaves many loved nephews, nieces and in-laws. A prolific storyteller, quick to sing and dance or share a joke, avid reader, world traveler and enthusiastic host. Jordan made friends wherever he went. He was a unique man who embraced life and will be dearly missed. Funeral service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th on Wednesday at 11:30am. Donations may be made in memory of Jordan Nager to: the Damon Runyon Cancer Research Foundation (One Exchange Place, 55 Broadway, Suite 302, New York, NY 10006) or Caramoor Center for the Arts (P.O. Box 816, Katonah, NY 10536).

JUPITER, Fla. -- Mets closer Francisco Rodriguez returned to work Monday after being partly quarantined with conjunctivitis in both eyes. Rodriguez contracted the illness more than three weeks ago, when he was home in Venezuela, but could not completely shake it, he said, until this past weekend. ''Usually people say it takes four or five days,'' he said. ''For me it took more than two weeks, three weeks.''

SINGH--Dr. Sadanand, 76, died February 27, 2010, in La Jolla, California. A noted scholar, academic, educator author, entrepreneur and philanthropist Dr. Sadanand Singh led an amazingly fruitful life that helped to shape and influence countless numbers of people across the United States and around the world. Dr. Singh was born in 1934 in a small agricultural village without electricity or running water in the state of Bihar in northern India. Though predestined to become a farmer, Dr. Singh followed a different path shaped by his love of the written word and the desire to educate. He left his remote home to become the first member of his family to earn a college degree. He went on to receive his Master's of Literature from India's Bihar University, in 1958, followed by a Ph.D. in Aesthetics from India's Ranchi University, in 1963. His developing reputation as a scholar reached far beyond Indian borders, leading to an invitation from Ohio State University to join its faculty. He moved to America to accept the position, and in 1965 earned his second doctorate, in Speech and Hearing Science. He joined the faculty of Howard University in Washington, DC, in 1967 as a professor and department head, but he returned to Ohio to become Professor of Hearing and Speech Sciences at Ohio University, from 1969 to 1971. This was followed by a position of Professor and Director of the Speech and Hearing Laboratory at the University of Texas in Houston and remained there until 1980, when he became professor and chairman of the Department of Communication Sciences and Disorders at San Diego State University. Among his most treasured roles was that of author. His scholarly work has helped shape the field of speech and hearing, with numerous works including a notable treatise on phonetics, now in its third edition. His success as an author and editor led him into his next career -- that of publisher. In 1980, he and his wife, Kala, an audiologist herself, founded College Hill Press. College Hill became one of the most influential publishing companies in the speech and hearing sciences, with more than 250 titles in print. It was subsequently acquired in 1986 by Time Inc. through its subsidiary Little, Brown & Company of Boston. Tragedy struck the Singhs in 1986. While returning from a family visit to India, Kala Singh was killed during the attempted hijacking of Pan Am flight 73. Dr. Singh and their two young children were seriously injured. While recuperating from the traumatic and harrowing experience, Dr. Singh wrote two manuscripts that remain unpublished. Several years later, he rebounded and married Angie in 1990. Together, they created Singular Publishing Group. Eight years later, Singular had more than 350 titles and seven journals in print. Dr. Singh attempted retirement in 1999, when Singular was acquired by Thomson Delmar (now Delmar Cengage). However, instead of resting on his already notable laurels, he founded ContentScan. The Internet-based literature search program was later acquired by Cambridge Information Group. In 2004, he and his wife, Angie, founded Plural Publishing, which today has a vibrant and growing list of titles in speech, language, voice disorders, swallowing disorders, singing, otolaryngology and audiology. During his many careers, Dr. Singh received a wealth of professional awards and recognitions. A partial list includes three honorary degrees, honorary Phi Beta Kappa membership, the Wilber Gould Highest Honors award from the American Voice Foundation and the Distinguished Services Award from the Council of Graduate Programs in Communication Services and Disorders. In 2004, San Diego State University honored him with the endowed Sadanand Singh Professorship in Communication Sciences and Disorders. And in 2006, he received the Honors of the American Speech-Hearing-Language Association -- the professional association's rarely bestowed highest award -- as well as the Lybarger Award, the highest honor of the American Academy of Audiology. Dr. Sadanand Singh had not only a brilliant mind; he also had a huge heart. Family was at the forefront of his priorities. Despite the distance of miles, he and his brothers spoke daily. He spent much of his time with his twin teenage daughter and son, his adult children from previous marriages and their children. He also returned to India to visit family annually. It seems that every field this man, who had been predestined to be a farmer, touched proved fertile. In addition to seeking balance through cultivating a prolific edible garden in his sprawling backyard, Dr. Singh cultivated scores of lifelong friendships. This Ph.D. integrated his academic understanding of aesthetics with a practical pursuit in his life through his travels, entertaining engaging conversations and turning friends into family. He was a voracious reader, and relatives recall his ability to recite in an instant a bit of ancient wisdom or lines from a poem to fit any situation. He has passed that appreciation for family and his affection for and focus on education across generations of relatives. Dr. Singh is survived by his wife of two decades, Angie, two sons, five daughters, thirteen grandchildren, one great-grandchild and three brothers. He also leaves behind a long list of extended family and friends. His proud legacy lives on with them all. A public memorial service is being planned for mid April. Charitable donations in the name of Dr. Sadanand Singh are appreciated. For additional information, contact dr.singh.memorial@gmail.com

There was something about the running repartee between Steve Martin and Alec Baldwin at Sunday's Academy Awards show that had a certain timeless quality to it -- which is to say, many of their jokes sounded as if they could have been written at any time and for any occasion since the invention of the talkie. Don't believe it? Below are eight jokes, some from Mr. Baldwin and Mr. Martin's Oscars patter, and some from Paul Lynde's performance at a 1976 Dean Martin roast, with names and identifying details omitted. Can you tell which gags came from which performance? The answers may (or may not) surprise you.

STADLER--Charlotte K.,71, a long-time schoolteacher and mathematics specialist in the New Rochelle School District, died in her sleep Saturday, February 27, at her home in Larchmont, two months after being diagnosed with acute leukemia. She was 71. Mrs. Stadler graduated from Antioch College and received a Master's degree from Southern Connecticut State College. She taught in the New Rochelle school system for 45 years until her retirement in 2009. For most of that period, she taught or was based at Columbus School, focusing on special education in her early career and then on mathematics, teaching and coordinating at a district-wide level. Mrs. Stadler was deeply committed to the belief that all children can learn. Her approach reflected the belief that children make meaning through inquiry-based teaching and learning. She taught that through hands-on applications, critical thinking, and problem-based learning, children can be involved and understand at deeper levels. Towards that end she created a great many math games and puzzles. Her underlying faith nurtured the innate intelligence and curiosity of the children. Her favorite direction on math tests was "show your work". Mrs Stadler was an accomplished amateur watercolorist and a truly marvelous cook. The daughter of Elliott Maurice Kahn and Marjorie Untermeyer Kahn Sands, Mrs. Stadler was born on July 18, 1938, in New York City. Mrs. Stadler's survivors include her husband of 47 years, Dr. John B. Stadler; sister Julie Shubik (Martin) of New Haven; sons Daniel (Cynthia) of Norwich, Vermont, Alex (Andrew Baker) of Philadelphia, and David (Laura) of New York City; step-daughters Jenny Stadler Carlson (Steve) of Houston and Iyana Stadler (Ruth Fremont) of Philadelphia; stepson Eliot Stadler (Jody) of Minneapolis; grandchildren Henry and Lily Stadler, step-grandchildren Erin, Rita, Russell, and Zoe Carlson and Hannah and Jacob Stadler; niece Claire Shubik, a large extended family and many friends from her home, career and travels. A memorial service for Mrs. Stadler will be held at 4pm on March 27th at the Coveleigh Club (215 Stuyvesant Ave. Rye, NY 10580). In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions be made to the Charlotte Stadler Fund at Columbus Elementary School (275 Washington Ave. New Rochelle, NY 10801).

SONDHEIMER--Eric S. Selfhelp Community Services deeply mourns the passing of the esteemed elder statesman of our Board, Eric S. Sondheimer. For over fifty years, Mr. Sondheimer demonstrated an unwavering commitment to Selfhelp's historic mission of supporting life with dignity to survivors of the Holocaust. His passion for independent living is evidenced by Selfhelp's six residences, built under his guidance and direction, which house 1,000 seniors. Mr. Sondheimer will be lovingly remembered as a true gentleman whose exceptional kindness and wit was matched only by his insightful wisdom and vision. He left an extraordinary legacy for which he will always be remembered. We extend our deepest sympathy to the entire family. Victor A. Wyler, President Stuart C. Kaplan, CEO

Louis Vuitton seemed to provide the perfect bookend to the Milan-Paris ready-to-wear season, which ended tonight. Between Miuccia Pradain Milan and Marc Jacobs at Vuitton we saw the return of the lush, full-hipped woman, her breasts served up like ripe fruit. Do those dry, sober minimalists have a chance next to Laetitia Casta, who opened the Vuitton show in a pinstriped gray sundress? Mr. Jacobs's full-skirted silhouette, with corsets and sometimes a neat little jacket, was somewhere between Brigitte Bardot and Doris Day. The look certainly caught a sexy mood, but if you seriously thought about dragging those gathered skirts around, you'd be tuckered out by the time you reached the corner to hail a taxi.

A federal judge ruled on Wednesday that New York City, not Warner LeRoy, owns the name Tavern on the Green, and that Mr. LeRoy, former operator of the landmark restaurant in Central Park, effectively stole the name. The judge said Mr. LeRoy failed to tell the United States Patent and Trademark Office in 1978 that the city owned the name and "fraudulently" made "deliberate misstatements and omissions" to obtain the trademark in 1981. The decision is expected to devastate creditors of the bankrupt restaurant who had hoped that Mr. LeRoy's family could sell the trademark to raise some of the $10 million owed. Read the full article at Diner's Journal.

When an earthquake hit Haiti on Jan. 12, the photojournalist Lynsey Addario was in India, where she lives. A few days ago I commented on the House Foreign Affairs Committee passage of the resolution condemning the Armenian genocide. I generally sided with those who said that the resolution was a bad idea, on the ground that 1.) Congress has better things to do than arbitrate history; and, 2.) instead of helping Armenians, the resolution might get in the way of a Turkish/Armenian thaw that is the most important geopolitical game in the region at the moment.

Moody's Investors Service warned of a possible downgrade of Abbott Laboratories on Wednesday, citing the drug and medical products company's bid to buy Facet Biotech for $450 million, The Associated Press reports. The agency also affirmed its credit ratings and negative outlook for Abbott.

Zipora Fried is not afraid of repetition. As an artist, she is best known for her large, labor-intensive abstract drawings, which she covers in silvery thickets of rapid pencil strokes. One drawing may take weeks to complete. Now she has turned her manual skills to making a dizzying array of dumplings. Unusual pastime, you say? Not for this Israel-born, Vienna-raised, New York-based artist who, after a well-received solo exhibition last year, decided to do something about her longing for food from Austria. A schnitzel's throw from Schiller's, her new cafe on Rivington Street is the perfect respite from early spring crowds.Since the heart of Kinski's Czech-Austrian menu is the humble dumpling, or knödel,served up savory or sweet, it's a pleasant surprise to see that it's not about the same protagonist gussied up in various disguises. The sweet-cheese knödel, for instance, is made of soft farmer's cheese (not unlike ricotta) that has been steamed and rolled in spiced bread crumbs. The apricot and the nougat knödel, although similar on the outside, reveal their respective sweet centers with a gentle slice of a fork. Toward the savory end of the spectrum, the finger-thick strands of the schupfnudelnare in essence billowy, pan-fried gnocchi with rosemary and a touch of lemon.
If the cuisines of Spain and Asia collided over Central Europe, the results might look something like Dos Palillos, a new restaurant in Berlin.

Many of the country's biggest television providers have signed on to a petition asking the government to revamp station retransmission rules. Some 95 percent of all blogs are abandoned, and starting a successful site and building a real audience is little easier than turning primal forest to fertile pasture.

Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates took off from Afghanistan Wednesday after a joint news conference with the Afghan defense minister, Abdul Rahim Wardak, sowed confusion. Mr. Wardak said the Afghan army would resume responsibility for most security by October 2011. During a recent rehearsal on the Lower East Side, the choreographer and dancer Jody Oberfelder came tearing across a small studio like a downtown banshee. Her bright magenta hair was tucked under a striped crash helmet, and she was wearing suspenders with leggings, a huge grin on her face. She was soon joined by similarly dressed dancers, pushing and banging into one another with abandon as if in a mosh pit at a punk concert.

4:13 p.m. | Updated Shares of Psychiatric Solutions climbed as much as 25 percent on Wednesday afternoon after The Wall Street Journal reported that the company, which operates mental health hospitals and clinics, was in negotiations to be acquired by the private equity firm Bain Capital.

The Canadian Wind Energy Association is expressing disappointment with the federal government's recent decision not to expand or extend the so-called ecoEnergy program -- which delivered subsidies to renewable energy developers -- in its new budget.

At last night's meeting, the Maplewood Planning Board unanimously approved a site plan to convert a vacant house at 2091 Millburn Ave. to a medical office for Dr. Gitendra Rajiyah, a cardiologist and an internist.
AirTran and American Airlines are offering big discounts for numerous flights across the United States, with one-way fares starting at $44 and $39 respectively. Both deals end tomorrow, March 11.

Six new albums entered the Billboard Top 10 this week, but not one could best the two titles that have dominated the chart for the last five weeks. Lady Antebellum's "Need You Now" (Capitol Nashville), which was released in February and spent its first two weeks at No. 1, returns to the peak position with 126,000 copies sold, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Sade's "Soldier of Love" (Epic), the top seller for the last three weeks, falls to No. 2 with 79,000. The top new album is Blake Shelton's "Hillbilly Bone" (Warner Brothers Nashville), at No. 3 with 71,000.  "My Best Days" (RCA Nashville), the debut album by Danny Gokey, a finalist on "American Idol" last year, opens at fourth place with 65,000. "Almost Alice" (Buena Vista), a collection of new songs by Avril Lavigne, Owl City and others that were inspired by Tim Burton's new film "Alice in Wonderland," is No. 5 with 58,000 copies sold, and Lifehouse's "Smoke & Mirrors" (Geffen) opens at No. 6 with 54,000.

Somewhere in New York, the Allman Brothers Band must be having a good ol' Southern laugh: the long-gestating Cirque du Soleil show "Banana Shpeel," whose planned February start at the Beacon Theater pushed the band from its traditional annual residency there, said on Wednesday that it was once again postponing its start date, and will begin performances on April 29.

The resurrection of a long-forgotten label is one of fashion's favorite pastimes. (I am still waiting for NAF NAF and Gitano to rise from the ashes.) Now, more than 50 years after its inception, the Italian sportswear label Ellesse has been reborn. Although Ellesse was primarily tied to skiing and tennis throughout the '70s and '80s, the former sneaker designer Mauro Massaroto has reimagined the label as hyper-colored cool clothes that jibe with the current frenzy for all things '90s. I am slightly besotted with the women's half of the collection. Instead of plaids, flannels and bike shorts, Massaroto (along with the sneaker designer Patrizio Carlucci) go instead for the skater/club kid/track-suits-from-the Salvation Army vibe of the grunge decade. An abundance of velour, stripes, beanies and a baby blue-marigold-fire orange palette are straight out of an X-Girl ad campaign from my junior year of high school. (That is quite possibly my highest form of praise.) Already on my must-have-immediately list:
A look back stage at the Hermes fall 2010 show in Paris.

Overview | How does the immune system react to allergens, causing allergy symptoms in some people? How can children, parents, doctors and communities respond to allergies, both mild to severe? In this lesson, students conduct a one-question interview to gather data on how much their classmates know about and are affected by allergies. Then, they work in groups to create a play to teach one another, and others in the school community, about allergies, including how the immune system works in people with and without allergies.

Ford is betting a large part of its future on a revamped lineup of small cars, such as the 2010 Ford Figo. In colloquial Italian, the name means "cool." But apart from the cute name and low price tag, the Figo won't directly translate to boosting Ford's small car sales in North America. That task belongs to the Ford Fiesta subcompact, which arrives this spring.

Global movie box-office receipts rose 7.6 percent last year, to $29.9 billion, while the domestic box-office was up more than 10 percent, to $10.6 billion, according to an annual statistical report released on Wednesday by the Motion Picture Association of America.

In years past we've bitten our upper lips when watching Hollywood's royalty attempting their "creative" black tie options, with their tricky vests, shiny suits and odd colored neckties. This year it seems that most of the male attendees at Hollywood's biggest bash of the year looked to their elegant predecessors when getting ready for their walk down the red carpet. With very few exceptions, our leading men have finally gotten the memo that suit-y straight ties are no substitute for the classic bow tie when hitting the Academy Awards.

Just what effect does an Oscar have? For "The Hurt Locker," it should be a palpable one this weekend. The film, which has actually never left theaters since it opened in a very few in June 2009, will open in an additional 35 on Friday, in major markets like New York, Los Angeles, Chicago, San Francisco, Dallas, Houston, Washington D.C., Seattle, Denver, Detroit, Minneapolis and San Diego, as well as in 30 more in Canada. That will take its total in North America to 348 theaters; for comparison's sake, "Avatar" is playing in 2,163 theaters (although Tim Burton's "Alice in Wonderland" has scooped up most of its 3-D screens), and "Crazy Heart" in 1,274. The distributors of "The Hurt Locker" decided on the modest expansion in order not to cannibalize DVD sales and rentals, where the best picture winner has already been doing well. It has sold 780,000 copies (including digital downloads), and since its release on Jan. 12, has landed in the Top 10 rental list each week.

Despite the fact that his surname is practically synonymous with a Gallic sense of understated elegance, Pierre-Alexis Dumas, the artistic director of one of the oldest and most prestigious family-owned companies in France, doesn't have much patience for most people's idea of "luxury." "When you start to use that word, you're pretty desperate," he says. "I have seen so-called luxury products that have failed miserably after three weeks. We are a quality manufacturer. My concern in life is, What does quality mean and how do you achieve it?" It's a question that Dumas, 43, has been tackling all his life, though it was only in 2006 that he took over the creative reins of Hermès from his father, Jean-Louis. "I grew up in Hermès, so I always relate it to family and home, something that's very natural and intimate," Dumas says. "For me, Hermès is about the mystery and miracle of life." More...

A work-in-progress viewing of a documentary about Eliot Spitzer, the former New York governor, directed by Alex Gibney, an Academy Award winner for "Taxi to the Dark Side," will be shown as a special event at the Tribeca Film Festival, its organizers said on Wednesday. Three years ago, after Danish cartoons mocking the Prophet Muhammad enraged Muslims around the world, a Swedish artist named Lars Vilks had trouble finding a gallery willing to show his satirical drawing of the prophet's head on the body of a dog. Scott P. Brown, the Republican politician from Massachusetts who pulled out a surprise victory in January to win the United States Senate seat long held by the Democrat Edward M. Kennedy, will write a memoir about his life and political career, the publisher HarperCollins said on Wednesday. Mr. Brown, who served in the Massachusetts House of Representatives and State Senate before defeating Martha Coakley, the attorney general and Democratic candidate, in a special election, said he would write about his family background and ascent to office, as well as his values and policies of interest to him. "I am humbled to have the opportunity to share my personal story in hopes to inform, encourage and inspire others," Mr. Brown said in a statement.

12:53 p.m. | Updated Corey Haim, an actor whose status as a teenage heartthrob of the 1980s gave way to harsh adult realities of substance abuse and rehabilitation, has died, the Los Angeles Police Department said on Wednesday. He was 38.

The acting superintendent of the New York State Police announced his retirement Tuesday, becoming the second senior agency official to leave office in a matter of days, since it was revealed that the agency had intervened in a domestic abuse case involving a top aide to Gov. David A. Paterson.

Starting in 2011, California will regulate emissions from electric utility equipment of the gas sulfur hexafluoride -- commonly called SF6. It is typically used in high voltage transmission systems in circuit breakers, switches and insulation, according to a recent California Air Resources Board announcement.

One day, genetic researchers may be able to manipulate cow cells into growing cruelty-free in-vitro leather, or even magical disembodied hamburgers. But in the meantime, they've been teaching Joris Laarman - the science-obsessed Dutch designer whose computer-generated Bone Chair caused a frenzy among collectors in 2007 - how to put their experiments to good use. Laarman's new biomorphic furniture, on view now at the New York gallery Friedman Benda, includes a lamp coated in genetically modified hamster cells that have been engineered to light up like those inside a firefly. Housed in a glass dome "fed" liquid nutrients and an enzyme, the lamp glows without electricity. "If products can be grown in a lab, we won't have to use natural resources," Laarman says. "It's the most perfect production method there is." Granted, the lamp's cells run according to their own biorhythm, "charging" during the day and emitting light at night - so there's no on and off switch. But hey, anything's better than compact fluorescents.

San Francisco Considers Two Polling Days | A proposed ballot measure would make San Francisco an electoral test tube by adding a second day of voting - the Saturday before the Tuesday - in general elections held in November. Other states like Louisiana have similar programs but not for the biennial general elections. Alex Tourk, a political consultant who is organizing the campaign for the measure, said he wanted to increase access to the polls and make it easier for people with work and child care issues to vote. "Weekday voting creates barriers," he said. The proposal needs 7,178 signatures from registered voters to qualify for November's ballot. [The New York Times]

Hong Kong's biggest gallery crawl snakes through the city on March 17, when 62 galleries open their doors for the 10th annual ArtWalk (hongkongartwalk.com), an entertaining evening of art, food and drink that raises money for local charities. Tickets, which cost 430 Hong Kong dollars ($56.50, at 7.60 Hong Kong dollars to the U.S. dollar) and are on sale at six sites around town, listed on the event's Web site, offer access to participating galleries, the bulk of them in and around SoHo, a short walk from the Central district. And 56 area restaurants, each one teamed with a gallery, will offer finger food, wine and beer. John Batten, the organizer of ArtWalk, is expecting a similar crowd to last year's event, which drew about 2,000 visitors.

Senator Bob Corker, the Tennessee Republican who is playing a crucial role in bipartisan negotiations over financial regulation, pressed to remove a provision from draft legislation that would have empowered federal authorities to crack down on payday lenders, people involved in the talks said. The industry is politically influential in his home state and a significant contributor to his campaigns, records show.

Godless? New York? Please. The city where Mitzvah Tanks patrol the streets and subway evangelists shout "Hallelujah" over the roar of trains and supplicants eke out nooks in which to place their prayer rugs and face the Kaaba at Mecca; the city where St. Pat's is both an event and a landmark? God (or at least one man's self-proclaimed interpretation) is evident outside Trinity Church at the head of Wall Street. "It's hard to think of a better modern/contemporary triple bill than Merce Cunningham, William Forsythe and Maguy Marin," writes Claudia La Rocco, "And hard to think of a company better suited to tackling such diverse choreographers than the Lyon Opera Ballet." This week the company returns to the Joyce Theater for the first time in more than 15 years. Go especially to see "Beach Birds" (1991), which makes the program "a must-see event; any chance now to see Cunningham's choreography seems precious, as his own company is in the early stages of its farewell international tour before disbanding in 2012. Soon, it seems, repertory ensembles like Lyon will be the main way in which we see Cunningham's miraculous dances live."

In his original 1985 review of "Pee-wee's Big Adventure," Vincent Canby wrote that the film "is the most barren comedy I've seen in years, maybe ever. It introduces motion picture audiences to a popular California comic named Pee-wee Herman, who seems to have put together his public personality by ransacking the wardrobes of his betters." Mr. Canby goes on to add, "Like Marcel Marceau, he appears to be physically slight and he often wears lipstick, but, unfortunately, he won't stop talking and — worse — laughing at his own gags. Like Jacques Tati, he wears pants that are too short, and like Jerry Lewis, he behaves as if he were a child trapped inside the body of a man. Like them all, he desperately wants to be funny but, unlike them, he isn't." Well, many fans of Paul Reubens, who has recently begun to perform again in Los Angeles, may choose to disagree. Tonight the Museum of Modern Art is screening the film, Tim Burton's feature debut.

New Yorkers can finally raise their chins when discussing their city and coffee in front of their West Coast brethren. "New York used to be a second-string city when it came to coffee," writes Oliver Strand. "No longer. Over the last two years, more than 40 new cafes and coffee bars have joined a small, dedicated group of establishments where coffee making is treated like an art, or at least a high form of craft." Head to places like the Bluebird Coffee Shop in the East Village, where "the espresso is so plush and bright that it tastes sweet on its own" or Third Rail Coffee in the West Village, which features "elaborate designs in the cappuccino's foam." Or try unusual spots like Saturdays Surf in SoHo and Moomah in TriBeCa. The coffee awakening means that "New Yorkers can now drink coffee that is made from some of the best beans available in the United States and freshly roasted in town." We'll drink to that.

The International Ice Hockey Federation said it had ended its efforts to revive the Champions Hockey League, a competition for Europe's top clubs. The league played its inaugural season in 2008-9 but ceased operations for 2009-10 after two main sponsors, Reebok and the Russian state energy company Gazprom, pulled their sponsorship. KOPP--Ruth Philpotts, died on February 11th at age 85 in Salisbury, Connecticut. Beloved Mother of Bradford, Jeffrey and Alexander, Mother-in-Law of Jean, Susan and Kim and Grandmother of Duncan, Tyler and Andrew. Born in 1924 in Glasgow, Scotland and emigrated to New York in 1931. A long-time resident of New York and Norfolk, Connecticut. Graduated from Barnard College in 1945 and served as assistant to the dean of Barnard College, Millicent McIntosh, from 1947-1951. Master's degree from Teachers College. Devoted member of St. James Church in New York and the Church of Transfiguration in Norfolk, Connecticut. Memorial Service on May 8th at 11am at the Church of Transfiguration. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be sent to Noble Horizons, 17 Cobble Road, Salisbury, CT 06068 or the Church of Transfiguration, 21 Mills Way, Norfolk, CT. 06058.

For all the athleticism that Connecticut's lineup brought into Tuesday's game against St. John's, it was the unit's collective apathy that was most striking on the court. Coach Jim Calhoun became fed up on Saturday with his three seniors' effort in a loss to South Florida, so he benched them for the final 16 minutes. He promised to hold them accountable again Tuesday in the first round of the Big East tournament, but informed them shortly before the game that the same unit would go. No wake-up call ever came.

MESCIA--June Barbour, Playwright and Lyricist on March 6, 2010. Predeceased by her parents and sister. Survived by three beloved nieces and nephews. Memorial service Thursday March 11, 6-8pm at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave., NYC.

STADLER--Charlotte K.,71, a long-time schoolteacher and mathematics specialist in the New Rochelle School District, died in her sleep Saturday, February 27, at her home in Larchmont, two months after being diagnosed with acute leukemia. She was 71. Mrs. Stadler graduated from Antioch College and received a Master's degree from Southern Connecticut State College. She taught in the New Rochelle school system for 45 years until her retirement in 2009. For most of that period, she taught or was based at Columbus School, focusing on special education in her early career and then on mathematics, teaching and coordinating at a district-wide level. Mrs. Stadler was deeply committed to the belief that all children can learn. Her approach reflected the belief that children make meaning through inquiry-based teaching and learning. She taught that through hands-on applications, critical thinking, and problem-based learning, children can be involved and understand at deeper levels. Towards that end she created a great many math games and puzzles. Her underlying faith nurtured the innate intelligence and curiosity of the children. Her favorite direction on math tests was "show your work". Mrs Stadler was an accomplished amateur watercolorist and a truly marvelous cook. The daughter of Elliott Maurice Kahn and Marjorie Untermeyer Kahn Sands, Mrs. Stadler was born on July 18, 1938, in New York City. Mrs. Stadler's survivors include her husband of 47 years, Dr. John B. Stadler; sister Julie Shubik (Martin) of New Haven; sons Daniel (Cynthia) of Norwich, Vermont, Alex (Andrew Baker) of Philadelphia, and David (Laura) of New York City; step-daughters Jenny Stadler Carlson (Steve) of Houston and Iyana Stadler (Ruth Fremont) of Philadelphia; stepson Eliot Stadler (Jody) of Minneapolis; grandchildren Henry and Lily Stadler, step-grandchildren Erin, Rita, Russell, and Zoe Carlson and Hannah and Jacob Stadler; niece Claire Shubik, a large extended family and many friends from her home, career and travels. A memorial service for Mrs. Stadler will be held at 4pm on March 27th at the Coveleigh Club (215 Stuyvesant Ave. Rye, NY 10580). In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions be made to the Charlotte Stadler Fund at Columbus Elementary School (275 Washington Ave. New Rochelle, NY 10801).

PARIS -- Dutch airport officials announced new security measures on Tuesday, after a Dutch investigative journalist reported smuggling a refilled liquor bottle through the heightened security checks at the airport where a young Nigerian boarded a flight for the United States on Dec. 25 with explosives in his underwear. The journalist, Alberto Stegeman, said in a report televised Sunday that he had purchased a bottle of rum from a duty-free shop at Schiphol Airport in Amsterdam on Feb. 16, emptied it and refilled it with water before returning it to the store. Then he returned to the shop and ''bought'' the refilled bottle, which the shop sealed in a bag with a receipt, allowing him to take it through security checks and onto a plane that landed in London, where he transferred to a flight to Washington.

SONDHEIMER--Eric S. Selfhelp Community Services deeply mourns the passing of the esteemed elder statesman of our Board, Eric S. Sondheimer. For over fifty years, Mr. Sondheimer demonstrated an unwavering commitment to Selfhelp's historic mission of supporting life with dignity to survivors of the Holocaust. His passion for independent living is evidenced by Selfhelp's six residences, built under his guidance and direction, which house 1,000 seniors. Mr. Sondheimer will be lovingly remembered as a true gentleman whose exceptional kindness and wit was matched only by his insightful wisdom and vision. He left an extraordinary legacy for which he will always be remembered. We extend our deepest sympathy to the entire family. Victor A. Wyler, President Stuart C. Kaplan, CEO

SINGH--Dr. Sadanand, 76, died February 27, 2010, in La Jolla, California. A noted scholar, academic, educator author, entrepreneur and philanthropist Dr. Sadanand Singh led an amazingly fruitful life that helped to shape and influence countless numbers of people across the United States and around the world. Dr. Singh was born in 1934 in a small agricultural village without electricity or running water in the state of Bihar in northern India. Though predestined to become a farmer, Dr. Singh followed a different path shaped by his love of the written word and the desire to educate. He left his remote home to become the first member of his family to earn a college degree. He went on to receive his Master's of Literature from India's Bihar University, in 1958, followed by a Ph.D. in Aesthetics from India's Ranchi University, in 1963. His developing reputation as a scholar reached far beyond Indian borders, leading to an invitation from Ohio State University to join its faculty. He moved to America to accept the position, and in 1965 earned his second doctorate, in Speech and Hearing Science. He joined the faculty of Howard University in Washington, DC, in 1967 as a professor and department head, but he returned to Ohio to become Professor of Hearing and Speech Sciences at Ohio University, from 1969 to 1971. This was followed by a position of Professor and Director of the Speech and Hearing Laboratory at the University of Texas in Houston and remained there until 1980, when he became professor and chairman of the Department of Communication Sciences and Disorders at San Diego State University. Among his most treasured roles was that of author. His scholarly work has helped shape the field of speech and hearing, with numerous works including a notable treatise on phonetics, now in its third edition. His success as an author and editor led him into his next career -- that of publisher. In 1980, he and his wife, Kala, an audiologist herself, founded College Hill Press. College Hill became one of the most influential publishing companies in the speech and hearing sciences, with more than 250 titles in print. It was subsequently acquired in 1986 by Time Inc. through its subsidiary Little, Brown & Company of Boston. Tragedy struck the Singhs in 1986. While returning from a family visit to India, Kala Singh was killed during the attempted hijacking of Pan Am flight 73. Dr. Singh and their two young children were seriously injured. While recuperating from the traumatic and harrowing experience, Dr. Singh wrote two manuscripts that remain unpublished. Several years later, he rebounded and married Angie in 1990. Together, they created Singular Publishing Group. Eight years later, Singular had more than 350 titles and seven journals in print. Dr. Singh attempted retirement in 1999, when Singular was acquired by Thomson Delmar (now Delmar Cengage). However, instead of resting on his already notable laurels, he founded ContentScan. The Internet-based literature search program was later acquired by Cambridge Information Group. In 2004, he and his wife, Angie, founded Plural Publishing, which today has a vibrant and growing list of titles in speech, language, voice disorders, swallowing disorders, singing, otolaryngology and audiology. During his many careers, Dr. Singh received a wealth of professional awards and recognitions. A partial list includes three honorary degrees, honorary Phi Beta Kappa membership, the Wilber Gould Highest Honors award from the American Voice Foundation and the Distinguished Services Award from the Council of Graduate Programs in Communication Services and Disorders. In 2004, San Diego State University honored him with the endowed Sadanand Singh Professorship in Communication Sciences and Disorders. And in 2006, he received the Honors of the American Speech-Hearing-Language Association -- the professional association's rarely bestowed highest award -- as well as the Lybarger Award, the highest honor of the American Academy of Audiology. Dr. Sadanand Singh had not only a brilliant mind; he also had a huge heart. Family was at the forefront of his priorities. Despite the distance of miles, he and his brothers spoke daily. He spent much of his time with his twin teenage daughter and son, his adult children from previous marriages and their children. He also returned to India to visit family annually. It seems that every field this man, who had been predestined to be a farmer, touched proved fertile. In addition to seeking balance through cultivating a prolific edible garden in his sprawling backyard, Dr. Singh cultivated scores of lifelong friendships. This Ph.D. integrated his academic understanding of aesthetics with a practical pursuit in his life through his travels, entertaining engaging conversations and turning friends into family. He was a voracious reader, and relatives recall his ability to recite in an instant a bit of ancient wisdom or lines from a poem to fit any situation. He has passed that appreciation for family and his affection for and focus on education across generations of relatives. Dr. Singh is survived by his wife of two decades, Angie, two sons, five daughters, thirteen grandchildren, one great-grandchild and three brothers. He also leaves behind a long list of extended family and friends. His proud legacy lives on with them all. A public memorial service is being planned for mid April. Charitable donations in the name of Dr. Sadanand Singh are appreciated. For additional information, contact dr.singh.memorial@gmail.com

Counterterrorism forces in Jakarta have shot and killed one of Southeast Asia's most-wanted Islamic militants, Indonesia's president said Wednesday. The police said the militant, who goes by only one name, Dulmatin, was a senior operative for Jemaah Islamiyah, the Southeast Asian terrorist network with links to Al Qaeda. The authorities accused Mr. Dulmatin of setting and triggering one of the bombs used in the 2002 Bali nightclub bombings that killed 202 people. Mr. Dulmatin's death is another major victory for Indonesia's counterterrorism unit, which has severely weakened the militant branch of Jemaah Islamiyah over the last eight years, killing or capturing most of its senior leadership. The United States government had offered a $10 million reward for Mr. Dulmatin's capture.

8 P.M. (CW) AMERICA'S NEXT TOP MODEL André Leon Talley (above with Tyra Banks), the larger-than-life editor at large of Vogue, knows his way around the runway. In this Cycle 14 premiere, he'll move into the spot at the judges' desk vacated by Miss J. Alexander, who'll be assuming a mentoring role, as a new crop of women try to prove they have what it takes to break into the world of fashion. The winner will be managed by Wilhelmina Models, receive a $100,000 contract with CoverGirl and appear on the cover and in a six-page fashion spread of Seventeen magazine. The rotating panel of judges will include the hair stylist and salon owner Sally Hershberger; the designer Rachel Roy; and Patricia Cleveland, considered the first African-American supermodel. The fun begins as 32 would-be models meet in Los Angeles to compete for 12 spots. The women then travel to New York, where a 13th contestant is added before they all move into a loft, undergo makeovers and have a run-in with Perez Hilton. ''High Society,'' a new reality series at 9:30, follows Tinsley Mortimer, armed with an entourage of party girls and her status-conscious mother, as she tries to keep her social star aloft after her divorce from her more blue-blooded husband. 8 P.M. (TCM) STAR OF THE MONTH: GINGER ROGERSYou know what they say: Fred Astaire was great, but Rogers did everything he did, only backward and in high heels. Turner Classic Movies kicks off its Wednesdays-in-March tribute with 5 of the 10 films the duo, above, made together from 1933 to 1949, starting with ''The Gay Divorcée'' (1934), about a handsome hoofer who is mistaken by an unhappy wife for the co-respondent hired to end her marriage. The score includes Cole Porter's ''Night and Day'' and Irving Berlin's ''Cheek to Cheek,'' but it was ''The Continental'' by Herb Magidson and Con Conrad that won the first Oscar for best song. The high-stepping continues through ''Top Hat'' (1935) at 10; ''Swing Time'' (1936), Rogers's favorite, at midnight; ''Roberta'' (1935) at 2 a.m.; and ''Follow the Fleet'' (1936) at 4.
GLOBAL EDITION Suzy Menkes reports on the late designer Alexander McQueen's final show in Paris. nytimes.com/fashion

RAFTER--James Philbin, 91, of Bay Shore, L.I. on March 6, 2010. Beloved husband of the late Marionelise Rafter, devoted father to Anne (AJ) Schmidt (Walter), Elizabeth Rafter Cibley (Bruce), Kathryn Rafter (Francey) and Susan Rafter. Dear brother of George Rafter and the late Anne Lodewick. He leaves behind seven grandchildren and ten great-grandchildren. He graduated from Erasmus Hall and attended Georgetown University's School of Foreign Service and NYU. He spent his entire career in the shipping industry, retiring in 1990 as Executive Vice President of Sales and Marketing for United States Lines. He also chaired the Eastern Regional Maritime Council for several years. As a young man he swam and played lacrosse in High School and was on the championship Crescent Lacrosse team. He was an ocean lifeguard and an avid boater. He participated in several community associations and held directorships at the Downtown Athletic Club and the Babylon Yacht Club. He cherished his time with his family and many friends. His lightning quick wit, his mischievous ways, his kindness and generosity will be greatly missed. A memorial mass, to be celebrated Friday, March 12, 2010 at 10am at St. Patrick's R.C. Church Bay Shore, L.I. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Jim's memory to St. Patrick's Parish Social Ministry, 9 N. Clinton Avenue, Bay Shore, NY 11706. Funeral Services entrusted to The Fredrick J. Chapey & Sons Funeral Home, 1225 Montauk Hwy., West Islip, NY.

ROBBINS--Sheila (nee Ostrov), 99, of Kinnelon, formerly of Wayne and Pompton Lakes, NJ and Brooklyn, NY, on March 9, 2010 passed away at home. A child of the Lower Eastside of New York and the Great Depression. Out of those humble beginnings, she embraced life to its fullest, right up to the very end. Her exuberance for life, including her renowned playing of the piano, and opportunity to have a good conversation or joke was what she enjoyed most and recognized as the real connection to human beings. Sheila was predeceased by her husband Harry Robbins and son-in-law Stuart Bruskin. She is survived by her daughter Ina Bruskin (Stuart), son Eric Robbins and daughter Debra Till (Peter). She is also survived by seven grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren, her sister Pearl Viener and brother Leo Ostrov. Funeral Services will proceed at Congregation Beth Sholom, Pompton Lakes, NJ at 12 Noon, Wednesday, March 10, 2010.

TOKYO -- Japan ended decades of denials on Tuesday by confirming the existence of secret cold war-era agreements with Washington that, among other things, had allowed American nuclear-armed warships to sail into Japanese ports in violation of Japan's non-nuclear policies. The existence of the pacts, known in Japan as the ''secret treaties,'' has long been known from declassified documents in the United States and the testimony of former American and Japanese diplomats. But successive prime ministers denied their existence, turning the agreements into a symbol for many Japanese of how insider-driven Liberal Democratic governments had turned their country into a stunted democracy run without full consent by the public.

The United States Post Office issued 10 Abstract Expressionist stamps on Thursday. They depict paintings by 10 artists - Joan Mitchell and the usual male suspects, you might say - and look bright and energetic and very abstract. They're not the first stamps based on modern paintings, or even Abstract Expressionist ones, but the edition is the first to concentrate on these artists as a group. Seeing them made me feel protective. I was even compelled to offer a talking point to the woman who at the Post Office who sold them to me: if she got any guff about them she could mention that the paintings are all at least 50 years old. She seemed impressed. "They're not new at all," I said, somewhat defensively. "They're classics."

Ms. Zambello will succeed Michael MacLeod, who said in February he would leave this year after five seasons. Glimmerglass presents four productions a summer.

The heart of South Norwalk, Conn., rows of buildings from the late 19th and early 20th centuries on Washington and South Main Streets, packs a lot into a compact area. The upper floors of the buildings have artists' studios, and, at street level, the collection of restaurants, shops and galleries is diverse enough to please anyone who makes the ride -- only an hour or so -- from Grand Central Terminal on the Metro-North Railroad ($19.50 round-trip on weekends, $10 for children). It's all within an easy walk of the station, too -- including the Maritime Aquarium, the one relatively new building in the group and the one that enables grown-ups to enjoy browsing and shopping while still entertaining the children.

"Returning to our fundamental riddle: if this is the information age, what do our children know that our parents didn't?  The answer is "now." They know about now. ... Internet culture is a culture of nowness. The Internet tells you what your friends are doing and the world news now, the state of the shops and markets and weather now, public opinion, trends and fashions now. The Internet connects each of us to countless sites right now - to many different places at one moment in time. ... Nowness is one of the most important cultural phenomena of the modern age: the western world's attention shifted gradually from the deep but narrow domain of one family or village and its history to the (broader but shallower) domains of the larger community, the nation, the world. The cult of celebrity, the importance of opinion polls, the decline in the teaching and learning of history, the uniformity of opinions and attitudes in academia and other educated elites - they are all part of one phenomenon. Nowness ignores all other moments but this."

It only makes sense that Judi Dench, after accumulating a lifetime's worth of theater, film and television credits that could easily fill up a book, should finally write one. St. Martin's Press said it had acquired a memoir from Ms. Dench, called "And Furthermore," that will detail her professional and private lives, according to a press release from the publisher. Though she has lately come to be known for her role as M in the James Bond franchise, and as Queen Elizabeth in "Shakespeare in Love" (for which she won an Academy Award for just a few minutes of screen time), Ms. Dench will cover the breadth of her acting career in the memoir, from her start with England's Old Vic theater company in 1957, to joining the Royal Shakespeare Company in 1961 to playing Sally Bowles in "Cabaret" in the 1968 London production (not to mention her performances in "Hay Fever," "A Little Night Music," "Amy's View," "A Midsummer Night's Dream" and the television series "A Fine Romance" and As Time Goes By"). St. Martin's said it would publish "And Furthermore" (along with, we're sure, a healthy index) in October.

More Evidence Found in Santa Clara | Public defenders in Santa Clara County are waiting to see how the cases of accused sex offenders may be affected by the district attorney's office effort to gather new evidence from the Santa Clara Valley Medical Center. Some new material, known as intake forms, collected by the center's sexual assault response team were discovered this week. The discovery comes after last year's revelation that the center had 3,000 videotapes of medical exams of children who were alleged victims of assault. The videotapes have already led to the release of a man  convicted earlier and have put other convictions at risk. An appellate court ruled two years ago that hospital examiners were part of the "prosecution team" and that the district attorney's office was responsible for making sure evidence was turned over to defendants. "I'm sure they were dismayed at the discovery, and I'm glad to see they are jumping on it," said the public defender, Mary Greenwood. The artist, designer and architect Ron Arad first made a splash in 1981 when, inspired by Marcel Duchamp's found objects, he bought a couple of red leather car seats salvaged from an old Rover car, attached them to metal frames and called the result "Rover Chair." Now, through May 16, the first major show in London of the Israeli-born, London-based creative maverick is on display at the Barbican Center (Silk Street; 44-207-638-4141; barbican.org.uk).

Men's noise choir (with light guitars!); dot matrix cicadas; toy turntables with wrecked records; music in negative fidelity, with walkie-talkies and the Neg Box. All are part of "You're Playing It Wrong: Creative Musical Misuse," a program tonight presented by dorkbot at 92nd Street Y in Tribeca. Dorkbot is "people doing strange things with electricity," and tonight this electronic art group will offer a selection of historical and contemporary short videos and live performances featuring "inappropriate, inadvisable and occasionally disastrous creative musical mayhem." Sounds like fun.

More proof that they don't make 'em like they used to can be seen tonight at BAMcinématek with "That's Montgomery Clift, Honey!" This two-week film series takes its name from the refrain of the Clash song "The Right Profile," released on "London Calling" in 1979, 13 years after the brooding actor's death. ("And everybody say, 'He sure look funny'/That's Montgomery Clift, honey.") The series, Mike Hale writes, "will present 11 of Clift's 17 features, including most of the highlights: 'From Here to Eternity,' 'A Place in the Sun,' 'Red River' and 'The Heiress' (on opening night); of his best performances, only 'Indiscretion of an American Wife' is missing. Also on tap are the rarely shown, documentary-style 'Big Lift,' about the Berlin airlift, and 'The Young Lions' and 'The Misfits,' his two best efforts in the years after his devastating auto accident."

The most effective Louisville Cardinal on the court Wednesday night was once told to transfer by Coach Rick Pitino when he was a sophomore. Back then, Edgar Sosa was slapped with the label of being selfish, sloppy and simply too much too put up with. His mouth was fast and his trigger quicker. Time has passed, and Sosa still has his maddening moments. For all the 3-pointers he knocked down and his explosive dribbling through Cincinnati's press, Sosa's decision-making -- on defense and offense -- is still suspect at times. Several times, Pitino could be heard in an otherwise quiet Garden asking his point guard, ''What are you doing?''

One player's performance stood out during Marquette's 57-55 win over St. John's. Lazar Hayward, Marquette's senior guard from Buffalo, quickly set the tone for the Golden Eagles, scoring 12 points in the first half and finishing with 20 for the game. But two nonscoring plays he made down the stretch sealed the outcome. On the first play, with the Red Storm down by 2, St. John's D. J. Kennedy had Hayward isolated at the top of the key. Kennedy used a barrage of cross-over dribbles in an attempt to get a driving angle past Hayward. But it was Hayward who finished the play, stripping Kennedy of the ball and forcing a jump ball that gave Marquette possession.

A federal judge ruled on Wednesday that New York City owns the name Tavern on the Green because the former operator of the landmark restaurant in Central Park had trademarked the name ''fraudulently.'' The judge, Miriam Goldman Cedarbaum of the Southern District of Manhattan, ruled that the former operator, Warner LeRoy, had made ''deliberate misstatements and omissions'' that affected the original registration of the trademark, which ''was obtained fraudulently'' in 1981. She added that the original registration was ''a deliberate attempt to mislead'' the United States Patent and Trademark Office.

NEWARK -- As soon as he plopped on a stool at the end of the Rangers' bench, done for the night even though it was only the second period, Henrik Lundqvist had a towel draped over his shoulder by an equipment manager. Uncharacteristically, Lundqvist angrily flung it off. Lundqvist, a goaltender who needs to continue to play well if the scoring-challenged Rangers want to grind their way into the Stanley Cup playoffs, was not so stout Wednesday, giving up five goals on 17 shots in a 6-3 loss to the Devils at Prudential Center.

THE Guggenheim's 50th anniversary celebration last week was a magnet for fashion extremists. Fans stormed the doors at 9 p.m. to hear a performance by Animal Collective. In contrast to the band's incandescent white headdresses, guests wore riotous color: Summer of Love headbands, tomato-color satin frocks and vibrant war paint that suggested ''Avatar.'' There were studied resurrections of Seattle grunge, ''I'm with the band'' T-shirts and festoons of Sgt. Pepper military braid. Upstairs, a benefit auction presided over by the museum's Young Collectors Council was only slightly more sedate, with guests swanning by in sequins and Baudelairean frills. Angelo Chan (bottom left) wears sober tweeds by day, but traded in his banker's cravat that night for a Lanvin velvet butterfly tie. ''There's a very fine line between fashion and costume,'' Mr. Chan said, ''and this tie is as close to costume as I get.''

Henry Wittenberg, an Olympic gold and silver medalist who became one of America's greatest amateur wrestlers while he was a New York City police officer, died on Tuesday at his home in Somers, N.Y. He was 91. His death was announced by his family.

MARCHISOTTO--A.M. (Matt), August 12, 1918 - March 10, 2010. A Captain in the Army during World War II, he served as a liaison officer with the RAF in North Africa. Subsequently, he was recalled to the nation's service during the Korean War. In civilian life, he pursued a career as a business systems consultant whose designs were used by many of the nation's leading retailers. A beloved, devoted and loyal husband, father and friend, he was pre-deceased by his wife, Lucille Jones Marchisotto. He is survived by his son Alan (Mary Jane), daughter Linda De Gennaro (Orazio), by four grandchildren, Malin and Matthew Marchisotto and Adriano and Alessandro De Gennaro, all of New York City, and by his brother, Dr. Robert Marchisotto of Princeton, NJ.

KANSAS CITY, Mo. -- The Kansas City school board voted Wednesday night to close almost half of the city's public schools, accepting a sweeping and contentious plan to shrink the system in the face of dwindling enrollment, budget cuts and a $50 million deficit. In a 5-to-4 vote, the members endorsed the Right-Sizing plan, proposed by the schools superintendent, John Covington, to close 28 of the city's 61 schools and cut 700 of 3,000 jobs, including those of 285 teachers. The closings are expected to save $50 million, erasing the deficit from the $300 million budget.

Edgar Wayburn, a physician who joined the Sierra Club to take a burro trip and then went on to become a major figure in the conservation movement, leading campaigns that preserved more than 100 million wild acres, died Friday at his home in San Francisco. He was 103. In announcing his death, the Sierra Club called Dr. Wayburn ''the 20th-century John Muir,'' referring to its founder, who preserved the Yosemite Valley.

IN bad weather, some athletes turn to indoor bike trainers, which hold the bike in place while they pedal. The bicycle is placed upright in the trainer and attached by the rear wheel, and resistance is provided either by magnets or by chambers filled with fluid. The experience isn't the same as road riding, where wind and uneven terrain are factors. But coaches and athletes say that trainers are a decent -- though sometimes noisy -- substitute. ''You don't ever take a break while on a trainer,'' said Mike Ricci, the head coach of the University of Colorado triathlon team in Boulder. ''There are no stop signs, turns or traffic, so you are constantly pedaling.'' Caroline Gaynor, 26, an amateur triathlete, tested trainers for at least 90 minutes each in her apartment in Queens. ''All of them gave me hard workouts,'' she said, ''but 'good' versus 'comfortable' is a big difference when you're spending more than an hour on it.'' YISHANE LEE
Party crashers at a state dinner dealt the final blow to Desirée Rogers’ position as White House social secretary. But tension had been brewing well before.

My Thursday column proposing Teach for the World attracted a range of comments and criticisms. One blog noted that the beneficiaries would essentially be American kids and argued that if the aim is to build language and cultural skills, why not do more to expand the Peace Corps? Others noted that if we want to improve education in poor countries, the obvious way to do that is to build local capacity by training teachers -- or, I would argue, by deworming kids as has worked so well in Kenya or expanding the conditional cash grants that have been tremendously successful to promote education in Mexico.
Robert Wright, left, of Bloggingheads.tv and David Frum of FrumForum debate Israeli-Palestinian peace talks.

Perhaps inspired by my criticisms of Paul Ryan's proposed tax reforms, Jonathan Chait has a long post about how Ryan's roadmap "clarifies the essence of the Republican Party's approach to domestic policy issues," which involves "opposition to the downward redistribution of income." Noting that Ryan has said kind words about Ayn Rand, he writes that "the core of the Randian worldview, as absorbed by the modern GOP, is a belief that the natural market distribution of income is inherently moral, and the central struggle of politics is to free the successful from having the fruits of their superiority redistributed by looters and moochers." And he argues: "Every major element of Ryan's plan reflects this commitment ...  Ryan would retain some bare-bones subsidies for the poorest, but the overwhelming thrust in every way is to liberate the lucky and successful to enjoy their good fortune without burdening them with any responsibility for the welfare of their fellow citizens."

"No doubt I should be ashamed to confess that fear played a part in my return to religion, specifically a painting: Rogier van der Weyden's 15th Century Last Judgement, which I saw in Burgundy while on holiday. I had scoffed at its mention in the guidebook, but now I gaped, my mouth actually hanging open, at the naked figures fleeing towards the pit of Hell. These people did not appear remote or from the ancient past; they were my own generation. Because they were naked, they were not imprisoned in their own age by time-bound fashions. On the contrary, their hair and the set of their faces were entirely in the style of my own time. They were me, and people I knew. I had a sudden strong sense of religion being a thing of the present day, not imprisoned under thick layers of time. My large catalogue of misdeeds replayed themselves rapidly in my head. I had absolutely no doubt that I was among the damned, if there were any damned. Van der Weyden was still earning his fee, nearly 500 years after his death."

A coalition of labor unions, immigrant advocacy groups and nonprofit organizations in New York announced their support on Friday for newly introduced legislation that would greatly increase penalties against employers that violate minimum-wage and overtime laws.Supporters of the bill, known as the Wage Theft Prevention and Responsible Employer Protection Act, say that wage violations are all too common because penalties for such violations are small under New York law and because employers that break the law face little likelihood of getting caught.

One of the most striking characteristics of the 2007 red Burgundies is their relatively pale color. The particular conditions of this vintage compelled most winemakers to treat their grapes with a light hand. That is, they did not try to extract lots of color and tannin from the grapes. As a result, you can easily hold a glass of a 2007, even a grand cru wine, and see your fingers through the wine on the other side of the glass.

The long week of fashion shows in Paris was like a series of well-cooked dishes: some in a minimal, nouvelle style, deliciously light and ethereal on the palate; some quite heavy in the French bourgeois tradition, with a lot of foie gras and sweetbreads; others more exotic, vegetable masalas with many ethnic spices, from Morocco to India. But by the end of the week, as an international audience of sheiks, oligarchs, Thai queens and Dutch conquistadors finished their supper, it did not add up to a sumptuous meal. Let's just say there was no new taste sensation.

If you've never ever imagined porcelain figurines acting out a trenchant class struggle, that's probably because you're not the British ceramics prankster Barnaby Barford. Porcelain can be something of a dainty medium, but Barford's playful, often perverse arrangements - he cuts and remakes mass-market and antique porcelain figurines - turn Hallmark Store staples into subversive art objects. In Barford's adorable first film, "Damaged Goods" (screened above), a maidenly tchotchke takes a tumble. Will she go the way of Humpty Dumpty? Nine new works from the film are on view at the David Gill Galleries on Loughborough Street in London through March 20.

Spring has nearly sprung, and here at T we have a glide in our stride. And it's not just the prospect of good weather. In an increasingly homogenous world, it's nice to be reminded that there are creative types out there who are prepared to take the heat. This weekend's issue of T celebrates eccentric energy, wherever we can find it. Biomorphic lamps, off-the-wall rooms, rodent bow ties, lo-fi rock-band T-shirts, untailored tailoring and John Lennon's nonconformist cool all get their moment in the fashion sun. Elsewhere, we enter the artist Daniel Arsham's imaginarium, where sleight of hand is the house specialty; Jonathan Wingfield interviews the musician Matthew Herbert, who can make you dance to the sound of slaughtered chickens; and Armand Limnander meets Pierre-Alexis Dumas, Hermès's artistic director, who is making the venerable French house more relevant than ever. To cap it off, we profile two actors burning up the screen: our cover star Josh Brolin and the French actor and recently announced Chanel poster boy Gaspard Ulliel, who channels the season's Nouvelle Vague look in a shoot by Paolo Roversi. No wonder we're hot to trot.

"Securing the Peace in Liberia" (06:07)It is near midnight and a United Nations peacekeeping force is on patrol in the streets of Monrovia. Armed with Kalashnikov rifles, they are a thin line of security in a place that has been ravaged by years of civil war. Though the image of U.N. forces is not uncommon in parts of Africa, something remarkable is going on Liberia: the armed, uniformed peacekeepers are women. In this fascinating story, Shayla Harris examines the effect that women peacekeepers are having on Liberian society, and ponders how Liberia will cope once they're gone. She speaks with peacekeepers, U.N. officials, women on the street and President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, who makes the case that woman are in some ways better suited than men for leadership. Mrs. Sirleaf has put numerous women in high government positions, and the country is creating opportunities for women in the notoriously corrupt police force. Will they succeed? That's the question left unanswered here. The challenge is daunting, but the story inspires hope for a country where hope has for a long time been in short supply. (E.O.)

We left Manhattan for Brooklyn in 1997. Even then, before it was the rage, it felt like a destination. We kept track of all the things the neighborhoods of Brooklyn had over the metropolis of Manhattan: actual diversity, affordable restaurants, more parking and less pretension. But the best thing, no doubt, every time, was the sky. Brooklyn had sky. Not a sliver of something gauzy above narrow, vertical avenues, but a big sky, clear and vivid, like they brag about in Montana (or maybe New Jersey). The kind of sky with horizons and sunsets and stars. A movie-screen ceiling under which anything could happen.

Blank space is a blank canvas for Ji Lee. "I'm interested in exploring areas like the back of business cards and ceilings - why are they left empty?" says the renegade graphic designer, who is currently working as creative director of Google's branding and marketing unit, the Creative Lab. To fill the void above, Lee creates miniature upside-down interiors that he calls "parallel worlds," placing them on domestic ceilings (on commission) and corporate offices (on the sly). "Decorating ceilings was a common art form that somehow got lost through the reductionism of modernism," he says. The Lilliputian lairs are meticulously furnished with objects that tell a story about the "room" and its imaginary owner. One installation shows the apartment of a rocker, complete with a guitar, amp, microphone and Jimi Hendrix poster. Another, installed in a home with two small children, features a petit bourgeois living room with velvet sofas and tiny glass cabinets filled with strange furry objects made of cat hair. "The kids love it," Lee says. "That's the greatest compliment." Go to pleaseenjoy.com.

In the introduction to "Ripped: T-Shirts From the Underground" (Universe, $30), the no-wave diva Lydia Lunch traces the history of the T-shirt from its silver screen progenitors (Marlon Brando and James Dean) to a London clothing shop called Sex. It was there, circa 1975, that the promoter Malcolm McLaren and the fashion visionary Vivienne Westwood transformed "four juvenile delinquents who had been caught on numerous occasions pilfering overpriced T-shirts" into the Sex Pistols.Thirty-five years on, the D.I.Y. iconography of underground music endures, so much so that the 200 vintage tees in "Ripped" - from acts like Gary Numan, Dead Kennedys, Talking Heads and Plasmatics - look oddly familiar, no doubt thanks to what the book calls "the onset of ironic consumerism."

Nissan introduced a line of commercial work vans this week in high-roof and standard configurations. At first glance, the Nissan NV cargo vans, with their high-roof design, look like competition for Ford's Transit Connect. They're not. The Transit Connect, which Ford began selling in the United States last year, is an economical light-duty van with 135 cubic-feet of cargo space. The Nissan NV1500, NV2500 and NV 3500 are medium and heavy-duty commercial vehicles that can handle more than twice the payload of a Transit Connect.

Despite their 29-year age gap, Clark Gable and Steve McQueen had a few things in common - rural Midwestern upbringings, motorcycle obsessions, nicknames beginning with "King of" - but their cars weren't one of them. Gable had a rather big, lavish 1935 Duesenberg JN with a boxy nose and external side pipes, while McQueen's favored status symbol was a sleek 1957 Jaguar XK-SS Roadster, above. Blame World War II: "After the war, these little sporty European cars seemed much more appealing," says Ronald Labaco, co-curator of "The Allure of the Automobile," which opens March 21 at the High Museum of Art in Atlanta. In addition to putting visitors within spitting distance of both stars' former rides,the show traces the cultural and political influences on car design from the '30s to the mid-'60s - considered the golden age of auto craftsmanship. Among the Mercedes-Benzes and Porsches that seemed ahead of their time, there are cars from long-defunct companies like Duesenberg and Tucker, which, despite their glamour, found themselves drowning under the excesses of bygone eras. Sound familiar?

Infantilism may be a fashion perennial, but if the blogger Ari Seth Cohen had his druthers, every season would be a senior moment. As the founder and editor of Advanced Style, a Sartorialist for the superannuated set, he chronicles the stylish and often eccentric get-ups of a crowd that's largely ignored by the fashion system. "My eyes have always been drawn to older people," said Cohen, 28. "And from a style point of view, I find them more interesting because they are of an age where they don't have to impress anyone and can wear what they want." In addition to shots of stylish senior citizens on the street, the site features tributes to timeless style icons, including Iris Apfel and Fleur Cowles. The hardest part of showing that true chic does not dim with age? "Trying to explain what a blog is."

FAME and the Limits of Charter School Oversight | The Alameda County Board of Education, in a 5-to-0 vote Tuesday, extended the charter of Fremont's FAME Public Charter School for another five years, even as the county's senior district attorney said the financial practices that prompted a highly critical state audit were still under review. The situation underscores the paradox of charter-school oversight: The same freedoms that allow these schools to serve as laboratories of new educational practices also give them unusual financial and managerial latitude. The Alameda County school superintendent praised the school - its formal name is Families of Alameda for Multi-Cultural/Multi-Lingual Education - for providing a needed service for students. Nonetheless, the superintendent, Sheila Jordan, said in interviews that FAME's executive director, Maram Alaiwat, might have engaged in inappropriate activities involving school finances. In addition, three of four members of the school's board last year, including Ms. Alaiwat, had relatives who either worked there or did business with the school. Experts disagreed on whether, and when, the public school systems that authorize charters could intervene.

Winter isn't quite over, at least not according to the Kronos Quartet. On Saturday night, the Kronos presents "Tundra Songs," a program of music by composers from near the Arctic Circle. Go to Zankel Hall at 10 p.m. to listen.

There is a William Kentridge moment going on in New York right now. The South African artist has a retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art and his opera directorial debut, "The Nose," about a bureaucrat who awakens one morning to find his nose missing, with music by Dmitri Shostakovich, is a hit at the Metropolitan Opera. Today, go hear from the man himself at the New York Public Library, where Mr. Kentridge will be participating in "Learning from the Absurd: A Conversation with William Kentridge." Mr. Kentridge will discuss Gogol, Shostakovich, and his own creative process. Hosted by Paul Holdengräber.

There was more significance to Kansas' victory against Texas Tech than just advancing to the Big 12 tournament semifinals. It was the 2,000th victory in the university's history, and afterward the top-ranked Jayhawks wore blue T-shirts that read ''KANSAS 2,000 VICTORIES 1890-2010 2KU.'' Kansas is the third team to reach the milestone. Kentucky (2,017) and North Carolina (2,000) reached the 2,000-win club earlier this season.
