Reposing at Cobble Hill Chapels, 171 Court Street, Brooklyn, NY until Tuesday, 10:30am. Funeral service at S.S. Constantine and Helen Greek Orthodox Church, 64 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn, 11:30am. Visiting hours Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9pm, Monday 6-9pm only. Donations to the Anne Moore Breast Cancer Research Fund at new York Weill Cornell Medical Center welcomed.
FRUGAL TRAVELER Follow Matt Gross, the Frugal Traveler, as he seeks high style on a low budget. This week: a Q&A with Shirley Tafoya, president of Travelzoo North America.

I have always been intrigued by the work of Fernand Léger. His tubular, mechanical paintings from the early 1920s captured his fascination with Futurism yet also his fear of new machines. My feelings about the current techno revolution must be much like Léger's uneasy embrace. He faced the brutal industrial changes in his era, when artists felt threatened by photography and machines were taking over from humans. Yet a fantastic, high-speed world was also opening up.

THERE is the time of year when the swallows return to San Juan Capistrano and the mud daubers to Luckenbach, Tex. There is the season of the cherry blossom -- and the season of the pothole. That season is now, but two students from Italy have developed a plan to make potholes easier to avoid, even if they can't be prevented or fixed.

UNTITLED is an enigma wrapped in a Fabien Baron-designed bottle. Martin Margiela's first fragrance is complex. Spray it on your wrist, and the air around it smells clean, like fresh linens. Moments later, the scent of sweet mildew permeates the air. Once that dries, you're left with a combination of church incense and powdery hand soap. You can't put a finger (or, it would seem, a name) on it, but once you get to the finish, it's pleasing on (almost) all skin. It's due this month at the new Margiela boutique, 801 Greenwich Street (Jane Street); (212) 989-7612. CHARLOTTE DRUCKMAN
Looking for fashion's new frontier? Go east, young man.

FOX--Sidney, age 94, of Manhattan, husband of 68 years of Jean, father and father-in-law of Terry and Susan, Paul and Franne, grandfather to Avra, Aaron, and Sydney, died on March 11th. A long-time labor lawyer and activist, he represented Teamsters Local 812, Locals 312 and 371 of UFCW, as well as locals of the TWU and Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, among many others. For many years, he was an active member of the American Labor Party. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Sidney Fox Scholarship, Local 812 IBT Scholarship Fund, P.O. Box 222080, Great Neck, NY 11022.

If this city's fumes have left you craving a whiff of nature, take a walk through the Dadar flower market, where you can inhale the sharp scent of marigolds and glimpse the immensity of India's flower trade. Every morning, blossoms are picked from the fields of Gujarat and Maharastra and are rushed to flower-hungry Mumbai, where they are sold under the overpass by Dadar Station. On a recent visit, a vendor named P. Kumar pulled a chain of rose petals and small white jasmine blossoms from a cane basket. One meter of the chain, which women like to wear in their hair, is 15 rupees (or 33 cents, at 45 rupees to the dollar), and, if he sells the whole basket -- his complete inventory for the day -- he'll make up to 300 rupees. It's a small operation, but there are hundreds of small vendors like Mr. Kumar who sell here, or who buy from the wholesalers at the market and fan out across the city.

SIEGEL--Harvey, 73 years old. Proud Bronxite and current Roswell, GA resident, passed away March 12, 2010. Beloved father, grandfather, son, brother, husband, and friend will be missed by all. Harvey graduated from the Fordham University School of Pharmacy, following in his father's footsteps. He enjoyed a long, successful, professional career as a registered pharmacist, having been co-owner of Ar-Kay drug store in Washington Heights. He was recently a registered pharmacist for Rite-Aid in Atlanta. He was an avid reader, a lover of travel, history, politics, and all forms of the performing arts. He also enjoyed performing magic tricks and studying martial arts. Donations can be made in his memory at the Make-a-Wish Foundation or the Ronald McDonald House c/o Emory University. Funeral services will be held at Gutterman-Musicant, 402 Park St., Hackensack, NJ at 10am on Tuesday, March 16, 2010. Shiva will observed at the family's house.

HOFFMAN--Marvin. Lazard's Managing Directors and employees extend our heartfelt sympathy to our partner, colleague and friend Scott Hoffman on the passing of his father. Our thoughts are with Scott and his family.

CHARACTER STUDY Gaspard Ulliel's only American production so far is the 2007 film ''Hannibal Rising,'' but the 25-year-old won the 2005 César award for most promising newcomer; has starred alongside leading ladies like Isabelle Huppert, Audrey Tautou and Vera Farmiga; and recently filmed Bertrand Tavernier's medieval love story, ''La Princesse de Montpensier.'' He strayed from acting last year, to appear in a Longchamp campaign with Kate Moss, but don't expect to see him on the runways anytime soon. ''I'm not really a model,'' he says. ''When I'm doing a photo shoot, I'm not playing a part. I'm just trying to be myself.'' The actor found Paolo Roversi's way of shooting this story, using digital video and then selecting still images, a stimulating challenge. ''When you're posing, usually you change your attitude when you hear the shutter click,'' he says. ''Here I never really knew when the picture was taken. It was odd but fun.'' Though he professes fashion ignorance, Ulliel's mother is a stylist, and his father is a former fashion designer. ''I credit my parents with my sensitivity to art and creativity,'' he explains. A more recent influence on his style is the custom-built Mecatwin motorcycle he bought two years ago. Since then, everything he wears must pass the bike test: ''Your clothes must match your lifestyle.'' Enough said. Alexandra Marshall

KALOGERAKIS--Michael. The Board of Directors and staff of the Marion Kenworthy-Sarah Swift Foundation mourn the loss of Michael Kalogerakis, MD. In addition to being the President of the foundation and providing peerless leadership on issues of adolescent mental health, Mike was a dear friend and trusted colleague. His stewardship of the foundation, like everything he did, was done with grace, humor and intelligence. We will miss his warmth, kindness and friendship and extend our deepest sympathy to his family. The Board of Directors & staff Kenworthy-Swift Foundation

The kind of consolidation in the movie business, where productions of massive scale -- ''Avatar'' being the latest -- soak up dollars and the attention spans of audiences reminds me of the publishing business where megahits like the latest James Patterson novel soak up the same. Sad on both accounts, in my opinion. Ward Jones of Houston in response to A. O. Scott's article about the films that were nominated for the Academy Awards.

BROOKS--Shelton A. Died Monday, March 1, 2010 in Scarborough, Maine, at the age of 86. Born in Corpus Christi, TX, on October 26, 1923, Shelton was the son of Clough Shelton and Wanda Brooks. He attended Valparaiso University but left to join the US Army during World War II. After serving three years in the Infantry, he graduated in 1949 from Harvard University and went on to earn a Master's degree in Business Administration from New York University. Shelton worked as an investment advisor in New York City for over 50 years. In 1970, he formed his own investment management firm. Shelton met his wife, Mary Hope Lupfer, on a blind date and they were married in 1958. After Shelton retired in 2001, he and Hope moved to Maine. Shelton is predeceased by his wife, Hope, and is survived by a son. A memorial service will be held March 21, at 1pm at St. Nicholas Episcopal Church, Scarborough, Maine.

SEIDEN--Syril. Beloved wife of Stuart. Loving mother of Nina Kerr, Mark and Peter Seiden. Devoted grandmother to Matthew, Andrew, Joshua, Gregory, David, Daniel and Molly. Loving mother-in-law to Scott, Andrea and Nancy. Memorial Service Temple Beth Sholom, Smithtown, NY, March 21, 2pm. We will always love you and treasure your memory.

ALL-NIGHTERS When I was a teenager, my alarm clock went off at 4:25 every morning for swim practice. I developed a love-hate relationship with the hour between 4 a.m. and 5 a.m. It was an uncomfortable, dreadful hour, especially in the dead of Canadian winter, when I knew I had to get into a chilly, over-chlorinated pool and endure two hours of unrelenting muscle pain. But I loved the quiet, the bluish-blackness out the window, less menacing than midnight dark. Driving with my mother through our suburban streets, bundled into a team parka, listening to the sound of the tires squeaking over the snow, I felt thoughtful, watchful and -- though tired -- sensitive and alert.

McCRARY--Eugenia Potts Lester (Howard). Died, January 8, 2010. Cherished wife of Dennis and mother of Campbell McCrary. Daughter of Admiral and Mrs. John Campbell Lester. Her nickname while attending Roland Park Country School and studying piano at The Peabody Conservatory was "The Brain". The McCrarys circumnavigated the world many times with a keen interest in India. Eugenia was AB Cum Laude, Radcliffe-Harvard, '50: MA Johns Hopkins; post-graduate Harvard '53; studied at Drew University; studied at Institute of USSR, Munich; teacher at Brearley School 1954-57; owner of School of Languages, Summit, NJ; co-author of Frontiers Aflame; Chairperson of Van Cortlandt House; active member of National Society of Colonial Dames; CDA; Metropolitan Opera National Council; Mayflower Descendants; Directress General Daughters of Holland Dames; daughters of Cincinnati; Causerie du Lundi; Warden of St. Esprit Church; Huguenot Society; Board of The Colony Club; Hereditary Order Descendants of Colonial Governors. Indeed, she was a joiner, but of greater importance, she always contributed her time and efforts in a meaningful manner. Her wit, grace, and warmth will be greatly missed. Memorial service to be held on Tuesday, March 23, 2010 at 3pm, St. Thomas Church, 53rd and Fifth Avenue, New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Thomas Church Choir School.

Last winter, in the middle of my intern year, I became Facebook friends with a young man who was dying in the intensive-care unit. An investment banker in his mid-20s, he thought he was healthy until a fluttering in his chest and swollen ankles took him to a doctor. Now he was in the I.C.U. with a rare cardiac condition and the vague possibility of a transplant. And his laptop. That's the first thing I noticed the morning a group of us stood outside his room on rounds. He was shocked by his internal defibrillator three times the night before -- died, that is, three times before being brought back with jolts of electricity. And this young man with a steroid-swollen face was surfing the Internet.

"Pragmatic" is a compliment sometimes paid to politicians (Barack Obama's supporters describe him that way), and it is often used as an honorific indicating a person of common sense who knows how to get things done. "Pragmatic" is also related (at least etymologically) to pragmatism, the name of a distinctively American philosophy that emerged in the early decades of the 20th century in the work of William James, John Dewey and C.S. Peirce. Pragmatism may or may not be an ethical program depending on whose version you are reading, but it always emphasizes the resources of historically given institutions and practices and de-emphasizes the role played in our lives by supra-historical essentialisms (God, faith, truth, reason, brute fact, overarching theory) even to the extent sometimes of denying their existence.

Since my column today uses the release of Paul Greengrass's "Green Zone" as an occasion to complain about how Hollywood can't seem to capture the complexities and ironies of real-world politics, it seems worthwhile to mention a few recent exceptions to this rule. This will be a short list: Stephen Frears' "The Queen" is on it, so is Alexander Payne's "Election" (yes, it takes place in a high school - what's your point?), and so is the portrait of Baltimore's mayoral politics on David Simon's "The Wire." (The character of Clarence Royce, the compromised incumbent, is a particularly good example of how a storyteller can be fair to a fundamentally unsympathetic figure.) David O. Russell's great "Three Kings" doesn't feature any politicians, but it captures the tragic ironies of our involvement in Iraq with more clarity and sensitivity than any of the movies made about the second Gulf War. Neither Oliver Stone's "Nixon" nor Mike Nichols' "Primary Colors" are particularly successful movies, but both make a good-faith effort to portray polarizing figures from our recent past in shades of gray, rather than just black and white. (About the rest of Stone's forays into political subjects, the less said the better.) And one of the reasons so many people praised - and overpraised - the political themes in "The Dark Knight," I suspect, is that even an attempt at political ambiguity (and in a superhero movie, no less) seemed impressive, given how rarely Hollywood goes in for anything save caricature.

In most of this country and much of the world, buildings have numbers on them on the outside. The numbers correspond to the building's street address. For example, the building at 100 Main Street will often have the numeral "100" affixed to it. These numbers are used to identify the building and to help people find it.

We've written before about how men have borne the brunt of the job losses in this recession in the United States. A boyhood spent in Liberia seems like one of the least exotic things about the 25-year-old designer and D.J. Telfar Clemens, a minimalist who has found inspiration in the strangeness closer to home. "It was really weird - it's like a melting pot of every different culture," Telfar says of LeFrak City, Queens, where he was born. "My family still lives in the same apartment. The development was originally 100 percent Jewish, so there's a lot of black and Jewish mix." And Red Hook, Brooklyn, where he currently lives, has "kind of like an urban pirate feel," he says. Somehow those influences come out in his designs as unisex garments made from soft jersey fabric that practically snuggle with the body. "My work is utilitarian," he says. "Anyone can put it on, female or male, and everything is adjustable so you can tie it in a different way for a different body type." Clemens's signature line, as well as his diffusion range, Un.Der T, are available in downtown boutiques and will soon be sold on telfar.net. Coming up for the man who gave the world a two-piece unisex swimsuit? "I've always been into sportswear, but I really want to incorporate sportswear with formal wear this season."

The Forever War ended with a whimper. CF and Terra are now alone again as they were when this began over a year ago. The only thing left to do is to assess the winners and the losers.

Charles Komanoff is an environment, energy, transportation and traffic specialist, who for decades has focused on New York City. But last week he was in China, helping the country explore approaches -- like congestion pricing -- to prevent  vehicle overload in city centers. Mr. Komanoff helped shape and promote a pricing strategy in New York, where Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg sought to start charging drivers for access to Manhattan's busiest blocks. The effort failed when it was opposed by state officials beholden to car-owning commuters. "I had a lot of fun with child kidnapping," says the set designer, illustrator and T contributor Gary Card, speaking of his recent campaign for Comme des Garçons that involved adapting dark Victorian children's stories. "And people turning into horses and slugs and things -- that got my imagination ticking." The London-based Card, 28, covers the High Street with clients that include Liberty, Stella McCartney, Adidas, Hermès and Top Shop. "What I love about my job is I have the opportunity to make both art and commercial products, and something else that can be a little bit stranger and more off-beat," he says. In a recent foray into fine art at the London gallery Spring Projects, he exhibited "a gigantic cave made out of white Plasticine, which was then sculpted into 3,000 tiny heads so you walked through this strange vortex of little white faces staring at you." In appearance, Card suggests a cross between David Hockney and the British avant-garde pop star Patrick Wolf. But the creative chameleon, who wants to design furniture next, shrugs off the comparison. "My personal style is whatever I find on the floor, really."

RUBIN--Fred. Born July 15, 1953, Fred ended his valiant fight against cancer on March 12, 2010. Beloved father of Sam and Abe, brother and brother-in-law of Steve and Shelly, uncle of Stephanie and Gregory and cherished fiance of Jane. Fred died as he lived-with generosity and passion. He was a mentor, friend and inspiration to many. Fred's beautiful spirit and laugh will be missed endlessly by all who knew and loved him. Services 11am, Monday at "Riverside-Nassau North Chapels", 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

Plastic Logic, the 10-year-old spinout from Cambridge University, said on Friday that it was delaying its $800 professional document- and book-reading device, the Que, until the summer. At the International Consumer Electronics Show in January, the company said it would start selling the large, thin reader in April. The delay is another strike against the Que. Plastic Logic raised $200 million in venture capital to build its own factory in Dresden, Germany, and is coming out with a black-and-white device just as attention in the tablet world is shifting to multicolor LCDs, like that used in the iPad. Its first product is expensive compared to similar devices like the Kindle DX.
KURTZ--Jay, died March 12 at age 84. Father of Nathan, Jim, Josh. Loving Grandfather of Dominique and Francesca. Brother to Neil.

PARIS -- About a year ago Sebastian Kempa, a freelance photographer who lives near Dortmund, Germany, embarked on a project to show how clothes ''are our second layer of skin.'' ''They disguise, reveal, mirror our innermost being or help to hide it,'' Mr. Kempa says on his Web site. Mr. Kempa has photographed dozens of people with and without their clothing, and is showing the before and after results on the site, www.naked-people.de.

With Duke as a No. 1 seed, don't be surprised if the Blue Devils continue their six-year streak of losing to lower seeds. In fact, the last time they were a top seed was in 2006, when they lost in the Round of 16. This team has all the makings of an upset victim. Duke (29-5) fattened its record on a down Atlantic Coast Conference, and its biggest victory was arguably against No. 8 seed Gonzaga. All of the Blue Devils' defeats came on the road, including losses to No. 3 seed Georgetown, No. 4 seed Wisconsin, No. 4 seed Maryland and No. 10 seed Georgia Tech. Furthermore, they do not have much beyond their big three of Jon Scheyer, Kyle Singler and Nolan Smith. After a stretch of seven Final Four appearances in nine years from 1986 to 1994, it is hard to believe that the Blue Devils have not made it that far since 2004. They last won a national championship in 2001. Expect both droughts to remain intact. THAYER EVANS More players, teams and matchups to watch for, Page D3.

Conference on the Offensive Move over Pacific-10, the so-called midmajor Mountain West was viewed as a power conference by the N.C.A.A. tournament selection committee, with a league-record four teams making it. New Mexico and Coach Steve Alford, left, received a No. 3 seed, the highest ever for a team from the league. Seventh-seeded Brigham Young and eighth-seeded Nevada-Las Vegas received at-large bids to go along with 11th-seeded San Diego State's automatic bid as the conference tournament champion. Three times the league has sent three teams, the last time in 2004. The conference has received at least one at-large bid for nine consecutive years. Now, it just needs to win some games to back up its merit. A Mountain West team has never advanced beyond the Round of 16, but two conference coaches have been to Final Fours: U.N.L.V.'s Lon Kruger and San Diego State's Steve Fisher, below left.

KANE--John M, Jr. February 9, 1935-March 10, 2010, of Manhattan on March 10 from ALS. Mr. Kane is survived by his sons John Kane of Larkspur CA, Chris Kane of Belleville, NJ, and daughters, Jennifer Kane of Laurinburg, NC and Eileen Gebbia of Rockledge, FL, as well as his grandchildren, Jessi Ogden, Madeline and Charlotte Kane, Jackson and Jordan (JoJo) Kane. His wife Barbara passed in April of 2001. Viewings will be Monday, March 15 from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Gannon Funeral Home, 152 East 28th Street in Manhattan. A brief service will be held at the funeral home Tuesday at 9:30am, followed by Internment at Huntington Rural Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the ALS Foundation.

LARSON--Robert C.,Bloomfield Hills, MI. Our horizons were expanded and our lives enriched through his friendship. He moved mountains with his compassion, his wisdom and his smile. We will cherish his memory and miss him always. Gayle and Richard Burstein

Better learn the name of the Robert Morris coach because he may go soon. Mike Rice, a 41-year-old former Pittsburgh assistant, has guided the Colonials to the N.C.A.A. tournament for the second straight year and took them to the National Invitation Tournament in 2008. They have won at least 23 games and the Northeast Conference regular-season title in each of his three seasons. This time, the Colonials started 4-7, then won 19 of their next 23 games. A noted recruiter, Rice is being mentioned as a coaching candidate at Fordham, which fired Dereck Whittenburg in December. Rice was a three-year Fordham starter at guard and the captain of the 1991 team that made the N.I.T. But he may be in line for an even bigger jump -- if the Rutgers job opens. THAYER EVANS

Nine days ago, the job outlook for Houston Coach Tom Penders was bleak. His team had just lost at Tulane to finish the regular season at 15-15, and he was in danger of having his first losing record in his six seasons with the Cougars. Speculation about firing him and pursuing Billy Gillispie, the former Kentucky, Texas A&M and Texas-El Paso coach, was mounting. But on Saturday, Houston stunned UTEP in the Conference USA tournament final to cap its first four-game winning streak of the season and earn an automatic N.C.A.A. tournament bid. The victory probably saved Penders's job for at least another season. He also joined a rare fraternity of coaches that includes Lon Kruger, Rick Pitino and Eddie Sutton in taking four different teams to the N.C.A.A. tournament. THAYER EVANS

SIEGEL--Harvey, 73 years old. Proud Bronxite and current Roswell, GA resident, passed away March 12, 2010. Beloved father, grandfather, son, brother, husband, and friend will be missed by all. Harvey graduated from the Fordham University School of Pharmacy, following in his father's footsteps. He enjoyed a long, successful, professional career as a registered pharmacist, having been co-owner of Ar-Kay drug store in Washington Heights. He was recently a registered pharmacist for Rite-Aid in Atlanta. He was an avid reader, a lover of travel, history, politics, and all forms of the performing arts. He also enjoyed performing magic tricks and studying martial arts. Donations can be made in his memory at the Make-a-Wish Foundation or the Ronald McDonald House c/o Emory University. Funeral services will be held at Gutterman-Musicant, 402 Park St., Hackensack, NJ at 10am on Tuesday, March 16, 2010. Shiva will observed at the family's house.

When people asked Joe Torre about Derek Jeter, Torre would invariably mention that veterans looked to Jeter for leadership when Jeter was only a rookie. There was just an aura about Jeter, a sense that he naturally accepted the responsibility of being his teammates' focal point. Setting an example was never forced, and it was not a burden. Troy Tulowitzki is 25, so he was just 11 when Jeter was a rookie in 1996. Tulowitzki, the shortstop for the Colorado Rockies, was enthralled by Jeter and wears No. 2 in his honor. Rockies General Manager Dan O'Dowd regards Tulowitzki the way Yankees people do Jeter.

Andrey Ternovskiy, a polite, excited and eager Moscow high school student, scoured the Internet trying to find a Web site that allowed random video chats with strangers. When he realized a site like that didn't exist, he built it. Three months and tens of millions of users later, the 17-year-old is wandering around New York City and San Francisco talking to investors and programmers about where to take his project, Chatroulette, next.

LOPATER--Hans J.,age 82, passed away Saturday March 13, 2010, in Concord, MA. He was a longtime resident of Sudbury, MA. Beloved husband of Mavis Lopater and devoted son of the late Philip and Irma Lopater. Born in Vienna, Austria, he left for England in 1939 on the Kindertransport to escape from the Nazis. He came to the U.S. in 1940 with his mother and joined his father. He grew up in Chicago where he graduated from the University of Chicago. Upon graduation, he worked in the advertising industry and Gillette where he was Vice President in charge of marketing research. Upon retirement, he chaired the Goodnow Library building committee and was a fellow at Brandeis, as well. Graveside services at Sharon Memorial Park, 41 Dedham Street, Sharon, MA, on Tuesday, March 16 at 1:45pm. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory can be made to your favorite charity. Levine Chapels, Broookline, MA. (617)277-8300.

A long, long time ago - way back in the mid-1990s - when I was living in Southeast Asia, getting around the region was a frustrating process. If I wanted to visit Cambodia, I'd take a bus from wherever I happened to be - usually Bangkok or Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam - and though it never cost more than $6, the daylong ordeal was always so painful I swore I'd never do it again. Then, a few months later, I'd do it again.

Four months ago, Gen. Sarath Fonseka was the commander of Sri Lanka's army, hailed as a national hero by the country's Sinhalese majority for putting an end to the long, bloody rebellion by Tamil separatists. Two months ago, after retiring, General Fonseka was barnstorming the country as a presidential candidate. Today, having been arrested just days after failing to win the presidency, he sits in a small room at a military facility in the Sri Lankan capital of Colombo, under armed guard, reduced to communicating with the world through handwritten statements smuggled out for him.

Daniel Larison didn't much care for my column on Monday. Here's his retort to my complaint about Hollywood's simplistic takes on recent U.S. foreign policy:

"I think that liberals view the market as a somewhat barbaric and unfair mechanism for allocating resources. They view government as a mechanism for restoring fairness and justice. To a libertarian, the market mechanism is civilized. When people buy and sell in the market, they are making voluntary, mutually beneficial exchanges. In contrast, government is an arena where one side wins and the other side loses. When I shop for a coat, if I do not like the way a coat fits or how it looks, or how much the seller wants me to pay, I do not buy that coat. I buy a different coat, perhaps in a different store. The shopping process leads to peaceful, mutually satisfying trade. On the other hand, look at how the issue of health care reform is going to be resolved. It is like gang warfare, where the Democrats and Republicans are going to rumble, and at least one side is going to be very unhappy with the outcome. For me, it is the democratic process that is barbaric, and it is the market process that is comparatively peaceful and civilized."

A little French homage to the great Parisian bread baker, Lionel Poilâne, opened on Tuesday. Tartinery Nolita specializes in the kind of open-face sandwiches called tartines in France. The amusement park operator Cedar Fair announced on Monday night that it had postponed Tuesday morning's meeting for unit holders to vote on the company's acquisition by Apollo Management, saying it wanted to provide more time to solicit votes and proxies. For those unit holders who have already made the trip up to Sandusky, Ohio, for the meeting, they will have a relatively long wait. The meeting is postponed until April 8. Perhaps Cedar Fair will placate these unit holders with some free amusement park tickets in the interim.

A new group of yachts is catering to the boating crowd's appetite for adventure and design. The 105-foot Necker Belle catamaran (virginlimitededition.com;$88,000 a week), refurbished last year by Sir Richard Branson, has a wine cellar, an outdoor movie theater and a three-person submersible for exploring reefs and wrecks. Reflecting the new emphasis on exploring remote waters, Cape Race (right; mvcaperace.com; $2,000 to $3,000 per person per week) is a converted fishing trawler - outfitted with six generous cabins and a mahogany-paneled saloon - that can cross the Atlantic twice without refueling. And the Panthalassa (camperandnicholsons.com; $200,000 a week), a 184-foot ketch with off-white interiors by Foster & Partners, has an oval stairway that brings sunlight to the lower level, where staterooms are paneled in leather and bathrooms tiled in black marble.

If Steven P. Jobs wants relief from one of his more merciless satirists, a television set may not be the best place to turn. On Tuesday, the cable channel Epix and the studio Media Rights Capital said they had struck a development deal for a new series called "iCon," to be written by Dan Lyons, a Newsweek contributor who has sent up the Apple chief executive on his popular blog, The Secret Diary of Steve Jobs, and in his novel "Options: The Secret Life of Steve Jobs - A Parody." The project, which Epix described in a news release as "a savage satire centering on a fictional Silicon Valley CEO whose ego is a study in power and greed," is being overseen by Larry Charles, the director of "Borat," "Religulous" and "Brüno" and a veteran writer and producer of "Seinfeld" and "Curb Your Enthusiasm"; the half-hour, single camera series will be produced by Media Rights Capital.

This past weekend, Carnegie Mellon University's Tepper School of Business and the Donald H. Jones Center for Entrepreneurship held its McGinnis Venture Competition for start-ups that bring new technologies to market. Three entrants each won $20,000 seed finance offers and $20,000 worth of legal and business consulting services in their respective competition tracks: life sciences, clean tech and general technology.

Sherin, said Tuesday, according to Bloomberg News.

Tourette's syndrome, marked by uncontrollable urges to move the body or vocalize, can be a lifelong sruggle for some. Dr. Robert A. King and Dr. James F. For whatever reason - I ran out, I had other grains to eat, maybe I was a little tired of it - I went through most of the winter without eating oatmeal for breakfast.  And when I began again, the first morning I turned to maple syrup, which seems the default. But on day two, I woke up with one of those odd cravings, one of those bizarre certainties about what I was going to have for breakfast. The most amazing thing - to me, at least - was that I'd never made this before, yet I knew it was going to be perfect.

I got a little snippy with Ryan Avent yesterday over the remminbi issue; I guess I don't like being compared to Donald Rumsfeld. In any case, however, I think it would be useful for me to explain how I think about the current China syndrome, and why I believe that most of the responses I hear are missing the point. In what follows, I'll focus on three questions: the macroeconomics of Chinese currency intervention, the fallacies of elasticity pessimism (which I'll explain when I get there), and the political economy issue of how to deal with Chinese intransigence.

The city's Board of Health voted Tuesday morning to rate cleanliness in the city's 25,648 food-service establishments with publicly posted letter grades, adopting a controversial plan proposed 14 months ago by the city's Department of Health and Mental Hygiene. Ratings were previously available only at the department or online. Starting in July, restaurants will have to display color-coded 8-by-10-inch placards showing their most recent grade. See the full article on Diner's Journal.

Three years ago, Reggie Cunningham, a young rogue in my employ who balladeers about town under the nom de rap of the Mr. Move, asked me to check out the bar where he worked in outer Williamsburg, Brooklyn. The Bushwick Country Club had all the amenities: a trash-strewn backyard featuring a derelict miniature-golf course, Christmas bulbs strung up for lighting, stout in a Styrofoam cup and a staff comprised of what one Yelper described as "an odd assortment of pirates and misfits." I kinda liked it. It had a gritty, improvisational feel; if you were there, it was probably not by accident.

Boehner of Ohio.

For several years, Rhett Herman, a physics professor at Radford University, has been leading students on an expedition each spring break to study the condition of the sea ice off the coast near Barrow, Alaska. I'll be adding some of the students' post-trip thoughts in the comments section. Should you find yourself wandering the streets of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, these days,you might be reminded of another Williamsburg, the restored historic village in Virginia. With shops like the Brooklyn Kitchen, where you can learn how to pickle vegetablesand butcher your own pig, and Rye, where you can sip an old-fashioned at the 100-year-old oak bar, the neighborhood hasn't quite returned to colonial times - but chances are your server will have facial hair and woolens that would do an 18th-century blacksmith proud. There are glass blowers (Michael Anchin Glass Company), perfume makers (CBI Hate Perfume) and illegal urban beekeepers who've set up shop in East Williamsburgwith that same can-do spirit that got us to the New World in the first place. While you might not hear the resounding fife and drums of our founding fathers, the bars on Bedford Avenue are jammed with Bunyan-bearded hipsters who look as if they moonlight in a fiddle band. And the spirit of Patrick Henry lives on in these Brooklynites, whose call to arms is ''Give me bike lanes or give me death!''

This week, nearly 30 visual and performing artists are moving onto Governors Island, the beginning of a year-round artist studio program organized by the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council. In the newly renovated Building 110, artists will have the use of 20 studios, two rehearsal areas and a large exhibition space with views of Lower Manhattan and New York Harbor. The residencies run from March to July and from August to December; the public can have access to the studios from June to mid-October. The cultural council was selected by the Governors Island Preservation and Education Corporation after a competitive request for proposals.

A few months ago, a French obstetrician suggested that if fathers really wanted to help their partners in the delivery room, they would just stay away. They may think they are helping, Dr. Michael Odent said, but they are probably only making the mothers stressed, slowing their production of the hormone oxytocin, which results in a prolonged labor and an increased risk of Caesarian section.

Hey, Betty White, how about leaving some work for the rest of Hollywood? Sure, Ms. White, the 88-year-old comedy phenomenon, could have packed it in after her run on "The Mary Tyler Moore Show," or called it a career after the success of "The Golden Girls" (and the not-quite-success of its spinoff "Golden Palace"). But no: she is now set to appear in a new series for TV Land called "Hot in Cleveland," The Associated Press reported. The show stars three other comedy veterans of a different generation -- Valerie Bertinelli (of "One Day at a Time"), Jane Leeves ("Frasier") and Wendie Malick ("Just Shoot Me") -- as Los Angeles émigrés who end up in Cleveland. Ms. White, who plays the caretaker of the house they live in, was originally set just for the pilot episode. But as she enjoys a career resurgence that includes a gig hosting on "Saturday Night Live" in May, Ms. White was bumped up to a series regular. "Hot in Cleveland" will start showing on TV Land in June, by which time we fully expect Ms. White to be president of the channel.

Applying to college has been nerve-racking enough, but I inadvertently made my own admissions process even worse. On my very first application I missed an important deadline -- to the school I considered my safety, the University of Texas at Austin. And now I worry I may not get in anywhere else. Allow me to explain.

When I am not reading Calvin and Hobbes or watching ice hockey or drinking coffee, I am nervously anticipating the results of my college applications. And let me tell you, the worst part of the pre-college experience is not the essays or the rush to meet the deadlines. It is the waiting. It is in this miserable, hellish period that I scrutinize my accomplishments and failures; quantify myself into SAT scores and G.P.A.s, and wonder with growing horror why the numbers don't add up.

Much of the anxiety of waiting by the mailbox to retrieve decision letters from the nation's most selective colleges has -- like so much of the admissions process -- gone digital in recent years. Whether an envelope is considered fat or thin is more likely measured in bytes. And yet, the day that decisions are formally released by many of the most competitive institutions, whether by e-mail or United States mail, remains as it always has: April 1.

You're going to the Marina Abramovic retrospective, "The Artist is Present," at the Museum of Modern Art and you still don't know who Ulay is? Get up to speed on the German-born performance artist who influenced and collaborated with Ms. Abramovic. Creative Time is presenting three of her films on MTV's huge outdoor screen in Times Square from March 14 to April 14. The first two films, "Light/Dark" (1977) and "Rest Energy" (1980) feature Ulay, Ms. Abramovic's former lover. In the first film, the two kneel opposite each other and then take turns slapping each other at a quickening pace; in the second, they stand opposite each other and "slowly lean apart until they are held only by the tension of a loaded bow that is held between them — its arrow pointed directly at Ms. Abramovic's heart." The final film, "Dissolution," (1997) shows Ms. Abramovic whipping her own back. Watch the films and then go see the artist herself in the flesh.

"Singers reign at Dizzy's Club Coca-Cola this month and next, appearing with first-rate backing bands," writes Nate Chinen. Tonight, Barbara Carroll kicks off Jazz at Lincoln Center's Sing Into Spring Festival, "practicing her brand of literate jazz cabaret with help from the clarinetist and tenor saxophonist Ken Peplowski, the bassist Jay Leonhart and the drummer Alvin Atkinson." Ms. Carroll performs through March 21; the festival runs through May 2.

Charles Addams, "in his mischief," writes Edward Rothstein, "makes the illicit an enchanting, almost whimsical aspect of daily life; we descend into his realm with the same half grin as that doomed office worker, our darker natures finding pleasure in allusions to misery. We enter a world so perverse even wind-up toys commit suicide, bitter matrons ask in department stores to be directed to 'blunt instruments,' and beams of light bearing divine illumination stream from the heavens only to shine on television antennas." That enchantment clearly resonates today. A musical comedy on Broadway about the Addams family's escapades is in previews, the Museum of the City of New York has a major collection of Addams drawings on display and a book "The Addams Family: An Evilution" has been released. Tonight find out more about the man behind Morticia, Gomez, Uncle Fester, Lurch and the others when Kevin Miserocchi, the executive director of the Tee and Charles Addams Foundation and the author of the book, discusses his work at the Museum of the City of New York.

We're all familiar with sentences like this one: Mr. Smith died yesterday after a long battle with cancer. We think we know what it means, but we read it and hear it so often that it carries little weight, bears no meaning. It's one of the cliches of cancer. It is easy shorthand. But it says more about the writer or speaker than it does about the deceased. We like to say that people ''fight'' cancer because we wrestle fearfully with the notion of ever having the disease. We have turned cancer into one of our modern devils.

Justice John Paul Stevens says he will decide in about a month whether he will stay on for another Supreme Court term. ''I still have my options open,'' Justice Stevens, who will turn 90 in April, said in a March 8 interview with The New Yorker. Justice Stevens, the court's longest-serving justice and the leader of its liberal wing, has hired only one law clerk for the term that starts in October. That is the number allotted to retired justices; active ones get four. But he cautioned against reading too much into that hint. ''When I decided to just hire one clerk,'' he said, ''three of my four clerks last year said they'd work for me next year if I wanted them to.'' He was willing to make one categorical statement: ''You can say I will retire within the next three years. I'm sure of that.''

WARSAW -- They loiter at the mall for hours, young teenage girls selling their bodies in return for designer jeans, Nokia cellphones, even a pair of socks. Katarzyna Roslaniec, a young filmmaker, first spotted a cluster of mall girls three years ago, decked out in thigh-high latex boots. She followed them and chatted them up over cigarettes. Over the next six months, the teens told her about their sex lives, about the men they called ''sponsors,'' about their lust for expensive labels, their absent parents, their premature pregnancies, their broken dreams.

LEBENTHAL--Jacqueline Beymer, 79, wife of James A. Lebenthal, mother of Claudia, Alexandra, and James B. Lebenthal. Jackie lost the battle against the numerous complications of Alzheimer's on Sunday, March 7, 2010. Over the last six years she was under the loving care of her nurse Maria Canosa, an Annie Sullivan to Jackie's Helen Keller. Jackie was a true girl of the Golden West -- a soft, kind, luscious, full-lipped, blonde, blue-eyed, outdoorsy beauty whose gorgeous face was usually framed in a Stetson hat. Born in Rupert, Idaho. A graduate of Twin Falls High School. First girl from the State of Idaho to attend Vassar College. Bachelor of Arts, 1951, Master of Fine Arts, Yale School of Design, 1953. Notwithstanding her gender, she was a star pupil of the great scenic designer Donald Oenslager, but never quite made it into the then all-male stage design union. Instead she became Jacqueline Beymer, ASID, member American Society of Interior Designers, met her husband decorating his bachelor apartment, and led the grande dames of interior design as President of the Decorators Club, 1978-2000, the oldest women's professional organization in America. She taught art and design at Pace University. Scholar, dreamboat, and organization lady, she designed the Look-It-Up Book, "always a place for everything and everything in its place." A memorial will be held at the Cosmopolitan Club, 122 East 66th Street, Friday, March 19 at 4pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The Decorators Club Education Fund, Inc. P.O. Box 732, NY NY 10150-0732 greatly appreciated.

WATERFORD, Ireland -- A court hearing Monday night in this quiet town gave new glimpses into the case that American and Irish prosecutors are pursuing against a group of Muslims on both sides of the Atlantic suspected of plotting to kill a Swedish cartoonist who depicted the head of the Prophet Muhammad atop the body of a dog. Five of the seven people arrested last week in Ireland have been released, the last shortly before the hearing. But the two others, an Algerian and a Libyan, were formally charged with relatively minor offenses that lawyers involved in the case said were brought so they could be kept in custody while Irish prosecutors weighed more serious charges. The lawyers said charges against the other five were also possible.

My Thursday column argues that the crucial element of health care reform is its effort to increase access to the uninsured. Of course, I think it's also crucial to hold down costs -- that helps assure access in the long run -- and I think that the Obama plan will help curb costs in the long run. I would have loved to see tort reform part of the package, but even the legislation's promotion of research into which medical interventions work will over time presumably lead to some cost savings.

Last week Defense Secretary Robert Gates visited the district of Now Zad in Afghanistan's volatile Helmand Province. To many, it probably didn't seem like significant news. Gates reportedly went no farther than a 100 meters outside the forward operating base and there were fully armed Marines posted at short intervals not far from where he was walking. They had probably been in position for at least 24 hours before Gates arrived and the area was likely swept for explosives and insurgents multiple times in the days prior to his arrival.

Overview | How can quizzes be used as learning tools and assessments? What is the educational value of not only taking a quiz, but also creating one? Are there significant differences between interactive and traditional quiz formats? In this lesson, students take an online quiz, then create their own quizzes about scientists or science-related topics. They then take one another's quizzes and consider their efficacy for introducing a new topic, reviewing material and assessing knowledge in a graded exam.

AUSTIN, Tex. - It's not garage rock, just rock in a parking garage, as Broken Bells starts its SXSW run in the concrete surroundings of the Red River Garage. (Tonight the group performs on NPR from Stubb's.) On its album, Broken Bells is the collaboration of James Mercer from the Shins and Danger Mouse from Gnarls Barkley. Onstage, it's a seven-man band, and even though they're striving to replicate the arrangements on the album, down to the oozy keyboard effects, its flesh-and-blood players and bigger crescendos help the songs escape the subdued studio production. The songs are still morose about many human failings, but not so withdrawn, a shading that makes a difference--more psychedelic, less studied. And it doesn't hurt that, strange but true, this garage has better acoustics than some SXSW clubs.

Ice Cube -- a man whose feelings on Los Angeles and its environs are already well documented in song -- will have the debut of his new movie about the L. A. Raiders football team at the Tribeca Film Festival, the festival's organizers said on Wednesday. The documentary, called "Straight Outta L.A.," chronicles the move of the Raiders from Oakland to Los Angeles in 1982, over the objection of the National Football League, and how the team inspired its new hometown and the burgeoning hip-hop scene. The film, which was produced as part of ESPN Films' "30 for 30" series, will be shown as the opening movie of the Tribeca/ESPN Sports Film Festival on April 23, and will be shown May 11 on ESPN. The full Tribeca festival runs from April 21 through May 2.

Obviously the health care endgame has become a pretty ugly business, but having dissented from the liberal anguish over our "broken government" when the threat of the filibuster was forcing supporters of health care reform to count to 60 in the Senate, allow me to dissent as well from the conservative dyspepsia over the Democratic Party's "unprecedented" use of various parliamentary maneuvers (today, reconciliation; tomorrow, "deem and pass"; the day after that, "blue steel") to get the House and Senate bills reconciled and through. I think it's a good thing that the countermajoritarian customs of the Senate, as adapted by the minority for a more ideological age, have made it very difficult to pass a sweeping overhaul of America's de facto constitution. But I also think it's appropriate that there exists, for an extremely determined but not-quite-super majority, mechanisms that allow legislators to overcome these hurdles and push a controversial piece of legislation through. "Hard but not absolutely impossible" seems like the right bar to set for a bill of this nature. I wish the Democrats had chosen a different path, but in the end, we live in a republic, not a direct democracy: If our elected representatives can really muster enough votes, within the rules, to pass health care legislation even after everything that's happened - if they believe that strongly, in other words, that this is absolutely and without question the right policy for America - then they have every right to go for it. It may be their funeral, but it's certainly their prerogative.

The unlovely term "vernacular architecture" describes some of the most unusual buildings ever created by man, from Mongolian yurts and adobe pueblos to igloos, Irish sod houses, and Iranian desert towns. Many of these structures (like a tree-house that soars 140 feet above the West Papuan rain forest) lie at the frontiers of the imagination, while others (like a shanty in Manila held together with urban waste) we'd prefer to forget. The forthcoming book "Buildings Without Architects" (Rizzoli; $23) presents them all as works of grassroots ingenuity. Written by John May, who authored the official history of Greenpeace, the book pegs modish keywords like "energy-efficient" and "sustainable" to ancient buildings, most of which were made of stuff that's been around since prehistoric times: wood, reed, earth and clay. A house built with used Heineken bottles is a curious exception.

As I've written many times in various contexts since the crisis began, being in a liquidity trap reverses many of the usual rules of economic policy. Virtue becomes vice: attempts to save more actually make us poorer, in both the short and the long run. Prudence becomes folly: a stern determination to balance budgets and avoid any risk of inflation is the road to disaster. Mercantilism works: countries that subsidize exports and restrict imports actually do gain at their trading partners' expense. For the moment -- or more likely for the next several years -- we're living in a world in which none of what you learned in Econ 101 applies.

Piero Fornasetti famously adorned his dinnerware with more than 350 variations of a single face: that of the 19th-century singer Lina Cavalieri, known as opera's greatest beauty. On the other hand, should you set your table with a new MexICON Platter from the design studio DFC Mexico City, you might discover a slightly more startling sight - the face of the telecommunications magnate Carlos Slim, say, or the eyepatch-wearing '70s soap star Catalina Creel, who resembles "an old woman turning into a fly," according to the DFC co-founder Tony Moxham. He and Mauricio Paniagua, known for trippy creations like their three-foot-tall table in the shape of a grasshopper, conceived the series as homage to Fornasetti while introducing the world to their hometown heroes. The rest of the cast includes the poet Pita Amor, the architect Luis Barragán (left) and - the lookers of the bunch - the actors Andrés García and Verónica Castro. Lehman Brothers' now notorious Repo 105 scheme depended on forum shopping, Reuters Breakingviews says. The investment bank wasn't able to persuade its lawyers in the United States that the relevant repurchase agreements constituted real sales. So it routed them through its British subsidiary. That meant they came under the British legal system, and the law firm Linklaters was able to opine that the transactions counted as sales.

Most people know Tom Colicchio as the chief justice of the "Top Chef" Supreme Court. But before he was a celebrity presiding over a hit reality show and restaurants in New York, Las Vegas and Los Angeles, he was a cook. "And at Colicchio & Sons," Sam Sifton writes, "He is running his kitchen at a level that New Yorkers have not been able to experience since his days at the helm of Gramercy Tavern, the restaurant he opened with Danny Meyer in 1994. For the moment, anyway, Mr. Colicchio's is the must-try New York menu. His restaurant isn't perfect. But it is exciting. And the food is terrifically good." Mr. Sifton suggests ordering the tasting menu, which features sophisticated composed plates. "There are elements of French technique to the cooking here, as well as an appreciable Italian devotion to ingredients. There are Indian flavors, and central European ones; there are nods also at Spain, at the Greenmarket, at North Africa. The result is a menu with an aesthetic that is entirely American. It appropriates all that has come to it, without apology."

PRITZKER--Margaret M. (nee Winsch) of New City and formerly of Larchmont, NY, passed away Thursday, March 11, 2010 at nearly 84 years of age, after a brief illness. She was born in Berlin, Germany in 1926, and survived World War II and the bombing of Berlin. She met her husband, Henry, while he was stationed in Berlin as a member of the United States Army. They were married March 24, 1956, and she came to the United States shortly thereafter. Subsequently, she worked several years in the laboratories of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, prior to raising a family. Margaret enjoyed opera and classical music, and was an avid reader and a student of history. Together with her husband she traveled the world. She was also a tireless volunteer, giving her time to Boy and Girl Scouts, Beth Emeth Synagogue in Larchmont and other organizations. She always will be remembered as a devoted wife to Henry, mother to son Daniel and daughter-in-law Kathleen, and daughter Debra. She truly loved her role as "Oma" to her grandchildren, Jonathan, Rebecca and Shannon Pritzker, and Alexis Browne. A memorial service was held on Friday, March 12, 2010 at Hellman Memorial Chapel, Spring Valley, NY. Shiva was observed at the home of Dr. Henry A. Pritzker. If desired, donations in her memory may be made to a charitable organization of your choice.

KALOGERAKIS--Michael G.,MD. The residents and staff of The San Remo mourn the sudden loss of our dear, longtime neighbor, friend and Board member, Dr. Michael G. Kalogerakis. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Kay, and his beloved children and grandchildren. San Remo Tenants' Corp.

LEBENTHAL--Jacqueline Beymer, 79, wife of James A. Lebenthal, mother of Claudia, Alexandra, and James B. Lebenthal. Jackie lost the battle against the numerous complications of Alzheimer's on Sunday, March 7, 2010. Over the last six years she was under the loving care of her nurse Maria Canosa, an Annie Sullivan to Jackie's Helen Keller. Jackie was a true girl of the Golden West -- a soft, kind, luscious, full-lipped, blonde, blue-eyed, outdoorsy beauty whose gorgeous face was usually framed in a Stetson hat. Born in Rupert, Idaho. A graduate of Twin Falls High School. First girl from the State of Idaho to attend Vassar College. Bachelor of Arts, 1951, Master of Fine Arts, Yale School of Design, 1953. Notwithstanding her gender, she was a star pupil of the great scenic designer Donald Oenslager, but never quite made it into the then all-male stage design union. Instead she became Jacqueline Beymer, ASID, member American Society of Interior Designers, met her husband decorating his bachelor apartment, and led the grande dames of interior design as President of the Decorators Club, 1978-1980, the oldest women's professional organization in America. She taught art and design at Pace University. Scholar, dreamboat, and organization lady, she designed the Look-It-Up Book, "always a place for everything and everything in its place." A memorial will be held at the Cosmopolitan Club, 122 East 66th Street, Friday, March 19 at 4pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The Decorators Club Education Fund, Inc. P.O. Box 732, NY NY 10150-0732 greatly appreciated.

Opposite mostly reruns on CBS, Fox eked out a victory on Monday as the top-rated network in prime time. According to Nielsen's estimates, the combination of ''House'' at 8 p.m., which drew 11.2 million viewers, and ''24'' at 9 (9 million), lifted Fox to No. 1, even as reruns of CBS's sitcoms in the 9 p.m. hour, ''Two and a Half Men'' (12.5 million) and ''The Big Bang Theory'' (11.5 million), earned slightly larger audiences. CBS drew lower ratings at 8 and 8:30 for a repeat of ''How I Met Your Mother'' (6.2 million) followed by a new episode of ''Rules of Engagement'' (7.8 million). CBS's rerun of ''CSI: Miami'' won the 10 p.m. hour with 9 million viewers, finishing ahead of NBC's ''Law & Order'' (6.9 million) and ABC's ''Castle'' repeat (6.6 million). ABC placed third, averaging 8 million viewers from 8 to 10 for a ''20/20'' special, ''Inside The Bachelor: Stories Behind the Rose,'' while NBC ranked fourth with ''Chuck'' at 8 (5.8 million) and ''Trauma'' at 9 (5.2 million).

PRUITT--Gregory R. Passed on March 13, 2010, at AtlantiCare Medical Center in New Jersey, surrounded by his family and friends. Pruitt is survived by his wife, Erin, and three sons, 10 year old Alexander, seven year old Nicholas, and five year old William of Ridgewood, New Jersey; his parents Richard and Roberta Pruitt of Port St. Lucie, Florida; and his sister and brother-in-law Paige and Doug Haase of Washougal, Washington. Pruitt was Managing Partner and Director for Business Development at MediaCom, one of the largest media planning and buying networks for advertising firms. Prior to joining MediaCom, Pruitt founded his own business development consulting practice, Pruitt+Partners, after successful initiatives at Cliff Freeman & Partners, Devito/Verdi and the Ogilvy Group. Calling himself a media "adventurer," Pruitt enjoyed the challenge of getting people to say, "Yes" -- as an advertising copywriter and Madison Avenue rainmaker. One of the people who said, "Yes" was Erin Murray, a TV commercial producer at Partners & Shevack. The Pruitts were married on December 12, 1998, at Old Saint Patrick's Cathedral in New York City.Pruitt was an avid golfer and a lifelong sailor who taught himself piano so he could play the blues. He was a deeply compassionate man who cared profoundly for his family and friends and will be greatly missed.

COLEMAN--Milton. We are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend Milton Coleman, who, with his soulmate of 45 years, Lucille, became a strong and loving supporter of New York-Presbyterian Hospital. The 2008 dedication of The Lucille and Milton Coleman Tower, a residential building for Hospital employees, is testament to both the Coleman's generosity and their deep commitment to the Hospital family. Raised in New York's East Harlem during the Depression, Milton was a combat veteran of the Pacific Theater in World War II. Until the end he was active in the real estate holding company he shared with Lucille. In addition to his devoted wife, Milton is survived by a beloved daughter, Penny. We offer our deepest condolences to the entire Coleman family. John Mack, Chairman Board of Trustees NY-Presbyterian Hospital Herbert Pardes, M.D. President and CEO

Water surrounds New York and undergirds its streets. Deep below the pavement, enormous water tunnels supply the city. New Yorkers may not be conscious of such things, but whether coping with a blustery November day at Fifth Avenue and 59th Street, above, or last weekend's pummeling, they know that water is a powerful force. New York City's board of health voted Tuesday to lift a ban against beekeeping, legalizing the hives of hundreds of residents who have tended bees in defiance of the law. The unanimous vote amends the health code to allow residents to keep hives of Apis mellifera, the common, nonaggressive honeybee. Beekeepers will be required to register with the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene and to adhere to appropriate practices. That means they must be able to control bee swarms and ensure that the hives do not interfere with pedestrians or neighbors.

SCUTT--Der. The Chapin School community is deeply saddened by the death of Der Scutt, a former trustee who served the school with distinction from 1984 until 1992. Mr. Scutt brought his architectural expertise to Chapin during an important time of expansion and renovation; the resulting improvements to our historic 100 East End Avenue building have enhanced the Chapin experience in countless ways. His dedication and commitment to the school, along with his ebullient spirit, earned him the respect and affection of his fellow trustees and the Chapin family. He will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Leena Scutt; to his daughter, Kirsti Scutt Edwards, a member of Chapin's Class of 1990, and to his son, Hagen Scutt. Linden Havemeyer Wise '70, Chair of the Board of Trustees Cera B. Robbins, Trustee Emerita Patricia T. Hayot, PhD, Head of School Mildred Jeanmaire Berendsen, Headmistress Emerita

AUSTIN, Tex. - The Bronx, billed as such, is a noisy post-punk band from East Los Angeles, crashing and squalling through hard-headed songs about outcasts and desperate people. But it has an alter ego: Mariachi El Bronx, which released an album last year and showed up Wednesday night at Emo's in traditional embroidered mariachi costumes with traditional instruments, from trumpet to guitarron. It performs the Bronx's repertory, but with long-lined melodies and the rhythms of Mexican rancheras and sones. It turns out that Matt Caughtran, the Bronx's lead singer, doesn't have to shout; he can carry a tune. And the Bronx taps a side of Los Angeles that many rock bands ignore.

In the dizzying run-up of watch technology of the last 10 or 15 years, the size of watch cases, the number of diamonds on them and the staggering intricacy of their complications were matched only by the astronomical sums the timepieces commanded. It was in the midst of this spinning tourbillon of activity that a few people tried something a lot simpler, a lot cheaper and a lot more colorful. With neon-bright hues, stretchy silicone bands and novel faces, the new '80s-inspired watches could have been worn by bands like the Thompson Twins or the Human League. They all but sing, "Don't you want me, baby?"

Stumptown Coffee Roasters is setting up shop in Amsterdam. Or, to be specific, a pop-up shop, which will open on May 1. Sorensen flew to Amsterdam with seven Chemex coffee brewers and some beans; he returned with the keys to a shop that's his through the end of July.

Savannah, Ga., isn't only about Girl Scouts, Paula Deen's calorie-bomb cooking or the intrigue of John Berendt's "Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil." The city is also home to a thriving design scene spawned in large part by the Savannah College of Art and Design. While SCAD, as the 30-year-old college is known, built its reputation as one of the country's leading design schools, its administration wisely snapped up a number of big, beautiful (and, let's not forget, historic) buildings that faced probable demolition. As a result, its schools, lecture halls and administrative buildings are seamlessly woven into Savannah's urban fabric, making the college an integral part of the city and revitalizing several once-derelict neighborhoods.

AUSTIN, Tex. - Minimalism had an impish side with Hauschka, a pianist and composer from Düsseldorf who performed with a string quartet at the hushed Central Presbyterian Church on Wednesday night. Hauschka, the stage name of Volker Bertelmann, builds his repeating structures with a Romantic ear -- pensive minor chords, inviting melodic lines, slow-cresting dynamics -- and, sometimes, a foundation of rock rhythm. Even with their echoes of Philip Glass, the pieces were ingenious and exquisite.

LONDON -- It's only when you come to this city and hear British actors playing Americans that you realize how funny we all talk. I'm kidding, of course, but after listening to the peculiar nasality of some of the accents in the Old Vic revival of John Guare's "Six Degrees of Separation," I found myself wondering whether the twang-free voice I'd always assumed I'd been speaking in sounded so very peculiar to the British. I've been working on something grander-sounding and mid-Atlantic ever since.Accents can cause unusual problems for actors. First-class training doesn't necessarily instill the ability to master different voices; it's a particular aptitude that comes more naturally to some than others. I adored Patti LuPone's darkly funny performance as Mrs. Lovett in the recent Broadway revival of "Sweeney Todd," but I have never before heard an Englishwoman of any class or period - fictional or otherwise -- speaking with quite the same quirky intonations. (Video of Ms. LuPone and the rest of the cast of the Broadway revival of "Sweeney Todd" is here.)

AUSTIN, Tex. -- We had no idea what Carolina Chocolate Drops were, but came to see them as a reminder of the beauty of home cooking. To call them a string band does not really do justice to the flying instruments, the role changes and the strong and sometimes dangerous singing of Rhiannon Giddens at the Galaxy Room on Wednesday. Combing elements of scat and hillbilly yodels, the Drops, as we will call them now that we are friends, were playful with the crowd but seemingly dead earnest in leading a singalong of a "Hi-ho, diddly-eye-o" nature, replete with what looked like clog dancing, although we could not see anybody's shoes through the mass of bodies. It was our first "having a moment" moment of the festival.

"The New Tenants," which won the Academy Award for live action short earlier this month, will be among the 47 movies to be shown in the Tribeca Film Festival's short film lineup, along with works directed by Kirsten Dunst, Domenica Scorsese and others, the festival's organizers said on Thursday. "The New Tenants," written by David Rakoff ("Fraud," "Don't Get Too Comfortable") and directed by Joachim Back, tells the darkly comic story of two men who meet their unusual neighbors as they move into a New York apartment; it will play on the festival's Hard Core program. Other films announced include "Bastard," written and directed by Ms. Dunst ("Spider-Man"), about a couple in a desert motel; "Roots in Water," directed by Ms. Scorsese and written by Richard Nelson, about two siblings dealing with the death of their mother; and "A .45 at 50th," a documentary directed by Joshua Bell and John Cromwell, in which the actor James Cromwell ("The Queen") recounts his experience with the Black Panther Party. This year's Tribeca Film Festival runs April 21 to May 2.

Boxer's Opponents Gain Ground, Poll Says | A new Field Poll shows that the three candidates hoping to unseat Senator Barbara Boxer have gained ground. Senator Boxer, who is in her third term, trails Tom Campbell, a former congressman, 44 to 43 percent, and leads Carly Fiorina, the former chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, 45 to 44 percent. The survey of 748 likely voters was taken this month and has a margin of error of plus-or-minus 3.7 percentage points. Senator Boxer leads Assemblyman Chuck DeVore, a Republican from Irvine, 45 to 41 percent. [The San Francisco Chronicle]

Roman generals were among the world's first art collectors. As they captured one Greek city after another, they looted its artistic treasures. Triumphantly, they returned to Rome and paraded their loot - shiploads of marble and bronze statues - through the Forum, where spectators could marvel at its elegance and beauty. These sculptured war trophies served both as visual metaphors for a vanquished enemy, as well as precious symbols of a culture the Romans aspired to surpass.

For a man who has spent two-thirds of a century actively pushing himself into the unearthly realm, the filmmaker Kenneth Anger has a pretty firm grasp of the minutiae of the earthly one. He's 82, he reckons, but when we stop to speak during a break in the schedule of his whirlwind European tour - he's in London for a show based around his films ''Inauguration of the Pleasure Dome'' and ''Invocation of My Demon Brother'' at Sprüth Magers in London, a collaboration with Valentino for its autumn-winter show in Paris, and a celebrated guest appearance at the AV festival in Newcastle - he has a recall for the details, facts and figures that make up his constant stream of historical anecdotes and gossip that would put Rain Man to shame.

If you didn't get enough of the emerald shade on St. Patrick's Day, head to Housing Works Bookstore Café for the Moth StorySlam! where the theme will be all things green tonight. For the uninitiated, The Moth is a not-for-profit storytelling organization that was founded in New York in 1997 by a poet and novelist who happens to be named George Dawes Green. At the slams, stories are scored by three teams of audience-member judges, and a winner is announced. We're hoping for at least one story devoted to Kermie.

The group Bonga and the Vodou Drums of Haiti is led by the percussionist Gaston (Bonga) Jean-Baptiste. "This Haitian ensemble," writes Amanda Petrusich, "plays mizik rasin, a beguiling mix of traditional Haitian vodou and American rock 'n' roll. Much like the hill-country blues of Mississippi, mizik rasin is built around a hypnotic rhythmic pulse; traditional chants mix with mbira, conch, didgeridoo, cello, reeds, brass, vocals and more." Go to hear the results for free at 8:30 p.m. at the David Rubenstein Atrium at Lincoln Center.

Put on your best "Moulin Rouge!"-inspired outfit and go watch the production, conducted by Emmanuel Plasson, featuring a cast that includes the tenor Jean-Paul Fouchécourt as King Ouf, "who enjoys executing his subjects, and Jennifer Zetlan as Laoula, the princess who is supposed to marry Ouf but falls in love with a poor peddler." Fewer Hispanic students earned degrees even at both competitive and less competitive colleges nationwide, the American Enterprise Institute found.

A new study by the American Enterprise Institute, a nonprofit research organization, finds that the percentage of Hispanic students who graduate from college in six years or less continues to trail that of white students. The researchers found that 51 percent of Hispanic students who start college go on to obtain a bachelor's degree within six years, compared with 59 percent of white students.

Midwest No. 1 seeds are 100-0 against No. 16 seeds since the tournament expanded to 64 teams in 1985. Could KANSAS be the first to lose? The Jayhawks play LEHIGH, the Patriot League champion, in a night session today in Oklahoma City's Ford Center after a Northern Iowa game. In 2005, Kansas was seeded third when it lost to No. 14 Bucknell, the Patriot League champion, in a night session on the same date in Oklahoma City's Ford Center after a Northern Iowa game. Jordan Eglseder, a 7-foot, 280-pound center, gives NORTHERN IOWA a big advantage against NEVADA-LAS VEGAS; the Rebels' biggest starter is 6-8 and 225, and they have been outrebounded for the season.

Samsung unwrapped its long-awaited e-book reader for the American market this week, and it's a curious combination of useful features and an important missing feature. The $299 Samsung eReader E60 will lack 3G cellular capabilities when it ships this spring, a notable omission when compared with the current market leaders, the Kindle from Amazon and the Nook from Barnes & Noble, both of which are priced lower, at $259. The Samsung eReader will have Wi-Fi onboard for downloading content (the Nook also has Wi-Fi). The company is considering adding 3G in later editions, says Reid Sullivan, senior vice president of audio-video and digital imaging marketing at Samsung.
GEORGEOU--Elias (Lee). Kind of heart and deeds, talented and dear friend. Estelle Cohen

HOENLEIN--Erna. Religious Zionists of America Mizrachi expresses condolences to our dear friend, Malcolm, on the passing of his beloved mother Erna. We pray that the entire Hoenlein family will be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Martin Oliner, Chairman Rabbi Y. Blau, President

McKENZIE--Arthur, 93, March 17, 2010 of New York, NY. Survived by devoted wife of 42 years, Evelyn; children, Craig, Leslie and Douglas; stepchildren Nina Wintringham, Karen Wintringham, Drew Wintringham and Jill Wintringham Kennedy; 15 grandchildren and 12 great-grandchildren. Arthur was a major force in the oil tanker industry during his 60 years both on the sea and in management positions championing safety and environmental responsibility. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Seamans Church Institute in New York City. Friends may call Friday, March 19, 2-5pm and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, New York with a service at Frank E. Campbell, Saturday, March 20 at 11:30am.

Sony unwrapped PlayStation Move this week at the Game Developers Conference 2010 in San Franciscio and says it will be available this year, most likely in the fall. The Move, Sony's answer to the Nintendo Wii's wand, works with its Eye video camera and software game titles designed specifically for remote, one-handed wireless control of 3-D action. While the device will control all varieties of kicks, swings and strokes (paint strokes as well as tennis strokes), there also are controller buttons for more conventional shoot-'em-ups.

LEBENTHAL--Jacqueline Beymer. Jackie, a beloved and distinguished member of The Decorators Club, Inc. for 35 years, created a scholarly series of lectures to fund The Decorators Club Education Fund, Inc., which grants scholarships to interior design students in six NY area schools. President from 1978-1980, she received its Medal of Honor in 1994. Our very deepest sympathies to her family. Ann Lind Bowers, President

WOOD--Richard Snell, architect, age 58, on March 14, 2010 at home in Brooklyn. Son of Julia Snell and John R. Wood, Jr. Survived by his sisters Cornelia Ferrara and Margaret Wood. His brothers David, Roger and John. Services private.

In January, I wrote about the YoGen, a hand-cranked power generator for portable devices. Pulling on the YoGen's miniature outboard-motor-like chain to get a few minutes' talk time was not a great experience, but another temporary power generator may be a better idea. The Solar Surge, from NovoTek, uses the sun to charge an external supplemental battery enclosed in a case that surrounds the iPhone. According to the company, this is the first solar charging solution approved by Apple, and it works with the iPhone 3G and 3GS and the iPod Touch.

BINI--Edmund J. The faculty of the Department of Medicine at NYU Langone Medical Center mourn the passing of our beloved colleague, Dr. Ed Bini. Ed was a physician-investigator par excellence whose curiosity and creative spirit captivated students and housestaff. He was devoted to his patients and to his role as a teacher; he was a great colleague to many and will be missed by all. Martin J. Blaser, M.D. Chair, Department of Medicine NYU Langone Medical Center

BINI--Edmund. The New York Society for Gastrointestinal Endoscopy mourns the untimely loss of Edmund Bini, MD, MPH. Dr. Bini was an integral member of our society, having served as Annual Post-graduate Course co-director, Executive Council member, and Vice President. He will be remembered as an outstanding physician, researcher, mentor and friend. Ed will be sorely missed. The Society extends its condolences to Dr. Bini's widow, Rosa Cipollone, MD, and to his family and friends. The Executive Council and Members of the NYSGE

BARRIS--Sasha Lynn (nee Levy), 73, of NYC died peacefully at home among friends and family on March 13, 2010 after a courageous battle with lung cancer. Sasha was preceded in death by her daughter Della. She is survived by her brother Robert P. Levy and his wife Rochelle of Bryn Mawr, PA and five nieces and nephews. Sasha attended the Stevens School in Philadelphia and Bradford College in Massachusetts. She worked extensively in the entertainment and TV industry. Along with being an accomplished artist she was a dedicated patron of the arts. Donations may be sent to Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. Interment will be private.

To the Editor: With imports of fur apparel into the United States at their lowest point in years, it is unlikely that handing out pelts to a few designers will save the industry. (''Fashion Feels Fur's Warm Embrace,'' March 11). Forward-thinking designers like Karl Lagerfeld and Stella McCartney are showcasing luxurious fur-free materials and are receiving much-deserved praise for it. On fur farms around the world, millions of raccoon dogs, rabbits, foxes, mink, chinchillas and other animals spend their lives in wire cages only to die from neck-breaking, electrocution or live-skinning.

LEBENTHAL--Jacqueline Beymer, 79, wife of James A. Lebenthal, mother of Claudia, Alexandra, and James B. Lebenthal. Jackie lost the battle against the numerous complications of Alzheimer's on Sunday, March 7, 2010. Over the last six years she was under the loving care of her nurse Maria Canosa, an Annie Sullivan to Jackie's Helen Keller. Jackie was a true girl of the Golden West -- a soft, kind, luscious, full-lipped, blonde, blue-eyed, outdoorsy beauty whose gorgeous face was usually framed in a Stetson hat. Born in Rupert, Idaho. A graduate of Twin Falls High School. First girl from the State of Idaho to attend Vassar College. Bachelor of Arts, 1951, Master of Fine Arts, Yale School of Design, 1953. Notwithstanding her gender, she was a star pupil of the great scenic designer Donald Oenslager, but never quite made it into the then all-male stage design union. Instead she became Jacqueline Beymer, ASID, member American Society of Interior Designers, met her husband decorating his bachelor apartment, and led the grande dames of interior design as President of the Decorators Club, 1978-1980, the oldest women's professional organization in America. She taught art and design at Pace University. Scholar, dreamboat, and organization lady, she designed the Look-It-Up Book, "always a place for everything and everything in its place." A memorial will be held at the Cosmopolitan Club, 122 East 66th Street, Friday, March 19 at 4pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The Decorators Club Education Fund, Inc. P.O. Box 732, NY NY 10150-0732 greatly appreciated.
