9 P.M. (HBO) AFGHAN STAR (2009) In Afghanistan music is viewed as sinful by Islamic fundamentalists, who have sometimes called for performers' deaths. Yet since 2005 millions of viewers have been tuning into ''Afghan Star,'' a talent show in the style of ''American Idol,'' on Tolo TV, a popular independent channel. In this documentary Havana Marking tells the story of four young finalists -- two men and two women, including Lima Sahar, above -- as they risk their lives to sing. She also witnesses some viewers' first encounters with democracy as they vote for their favorite singers via cellphone while the Taliban threaten to destroy the country's mobile-phone network. (The 2008 season finale drew 11 million viewers, about a third of Afghanistan's population.) Writing in The New York Times, Stephen Holden called the film engrossing, adding that it ''subverts the cliché image of Afghanistan as a nation of intractably primitive, superstitious tribespeople who have little in common with Westerners.'' Arne Duncan, the secretary of education, took another swing at the N.C.A.A. and top college basketball programs Wednesday, reiterating a call for a ban on postseason play for teams that fail to graduate at least 40 percent of their players. TOMLINSON--Alexander C.,a retired New York investment banker who spent his post retirement years in Washington heading several organizations concerned with economic policy and capital markets in developing countries and Eastern Europe died Sunday at his home in Washington of complications of Alzheimers disease. Mr. Tomlinson was born in Haddonfield, NJ. He attended Haverford College where he later served as a trustee and received an honorary Ph.D., and the Harvard Business School where he received his MBA in 1950. He served as a lieutenant in the Navy in World War II. He spent his business career at Morgan Stanley where he was a managing director and president of Morgan Stanley Canada. He later joined Credit Suisse First Boston as a director and chairman of the executive committee. He also served on the boards of a number of non profit institutions. He is survived by his wife, Margaret, three children from his first marriage W Brierley of Oakland, CA, Deborah T. Moran of Upper Montclair, NJ, Alexander III of Chevy Chase, MD, two sisters and four grandchildren. There will be a memorial service in Washington March 25.

PITTSBURGH -- Nationally, it may seem that in the seven years since Fred Rogers's death, the legacy of America's favorite neighbor has waned. After all, two years ago PBS stopped offering his show, ''Mister Rogers' Neighborhood,'' to its member stations every weekday, offering it just once a week, though it allowed stations to digitally stockpile them for daily viewing. Then, last year, PBS quietly stopped allowing stockpiling, meaning there are no stations showing it daily.

When I can't sleep, I think about what I'm missing. I glance over at my wife and watch her eyelids flutter. I listen to the steady rhythm of her breath. I wonder if she's dreaming and, if so, what story she's telling to herself to pass the time. (The mind is like a shark -- it can't ever stop swimming in thought.) And then my eyes return to the ceiling and I wonder what I would be dreaming about, if only I could fall asleep.

"The Runaways," the long-awaited biopic about the pioneering 1970s L.A. female rock band, finally makes its debut today. And 35 years later, the rampant sexism the teenage group faced is still squirm inducing. First there was Kim Fowley, the band's obnoxious manager, who insisted that rock 'n' roll was exclusively the "sport of men." Then there were the male-dominated music magazines like Creem that dismissed them out of hand and once famously gave them a three-word review: "These bitches suck." Add to that the litany of lecherous promoters, bands and hit men who looked to the girls for one thing only, and it's no wonder that the Runaways didn't just run for their lives.

As the Book Review's photography editor, I often choose pictures for the brief art feature that appears on the page with our Fiction or Nonfiction Chronicle. Usually it's a pleasurable undertaking. Eugene Smith between 1957 and 1965 - was somewhat difficult. If fin de siècle Vienna was all black and gold and decadent, Berlin in the aftermath of World War I was a town painted red: the rouge of lips, swollen scar tissue or the last moments at dusk before the horizon slipped into the darkness of night. From time to time, the Neue Galerie reveals to us that seamy alter ego. The new exhibition dedicated to Otto Dix (1891-1969), the long-overdue first retrospective of the artist in North America, makes the scandals and scars of 1920s Berlin seem entirely fresh.

We're told that there was a magical time long ago when, whatever your seat assignment, flying was first-class. But when did it all end? Last week, Marie Force, the archivist at the Delta Heritage Museum in Atlanta, published an online gallery of photographs of Delta flight attendant uniforms from 1940 to the present. "Delta was one of the more conservative airlines," Force says. "We didn't have hot pants." Still, for almost 40 straight years, the airline's female flight attendants (something called "stewardesses") turned heads. In the 1940s, they did it with military-style overseas caps and spectator shoes; in the '50s, with futurist insignias and stiletto pumps; and in the '60s, with A-line topcoats, alligator-print boots, Chanel-inspired jackets with three-quarter-length sleeves and the "Delberet," a pillbox hat designed for Delta by Mea Hanauer, a New York milliner. The '70s were all about coo-coo colors, bell-bottom pants, Slavic tunics and, weirdly, a yellow raincoat. And then in the '80s, Delta took a sartorial nosedive that it couldn't recover from until 2001. Return your seat to its upright position, and take a look.

Catherine Opie knows women. Self-possessed, gender-defying women who favor piercings and tattoos, and run in her butch-lesbian-bondage crowd in Los Angeles. The kind of women who attract stares and sometimes abuse. Their hair-raising, Hans Holbein-inspired portraits in Opie's breakout appearance at the 1995 Whitney Biennial, when "identity politics" were at their height, gave her a notoriety that sent her in pursuit of less polarizing subjects: surfers, California freeways, city skylines, grand western landscapes and even high school football players.

"Surfing's New Wave of Aerialists" (05:12)It used to be about catching the wave. Now, for a new breed of surfer, it's about flying and twisting above it. "The future of surfing is apparently in the air," said Kelly Slater, a world champion. Competition is becoming more open to radical maneuvers. New rules are rewarding difficulty over consistency. As this video by Erik Olsen and Matt Higgins reveals, the stage was set in the late 1980s. Pioneer aerialists like Christian Fletcher employed the new moves but paid a high personal price. They were barred from competition and lost sponsorships. Mr. Olsen said he recognized that viewers have become accustomed to a high level of sophistication in surfing videos, adding that he was thankful to have found sources like Jon Steele and Elliot Leboe, "two fantastic filmmakers" who provided extra footage. The result is a dazzling exploration of surfing's past, present and probably airborne future. (K.B.)

"When conservative critics of our universities nowadays lament the decline of liberal education, they usually decry its replacement by a left-leaning politicized agenda. But the deeper truth is that liberal education has been more fundamentally displaced by scientific education buttressed by the demands of global competition. While conservatives might wish to apportion blame to those increasingly irrelevant faculty whose postmodernism has become a form of stale institutional orthodoxy, the truth is that the rise of this sort of faculty was a response to conditions that were already making liberal education irrelevant, a self-destructive effort to make the humanities 'up to date.' These purported radicals - mostly bourgeois former children of the 1960s - were not agents of liberation, but rather symptoms of the neglect of the liberal arts in a dawning new age of science reinforced by global competition.

For years, hotel designers used traditional motifs mainly for contrast - by mixing Louis XIV and Le Corbusier, they seduced trend-seeking travelers with eye-catching compostions. But period promiscuity may be giving way to a new faithfulness. These days, arch has gone back to being a noun, as hoteliers go for real historicism, creating (or recreating) grande dame properties that serve their nostalgia straight up.

4:53 p.m. | Updated In the higher mathematics of Washington, it's usually not a difficult calculation: sending one president to the Capitol is easier, logistically at least, than bringing 253 House Democrats to the White House. And so the easy math has won out: President Obama will meet with House Democrats on Capitol Hill on Saturday, rather than the other way around as the White House had previously announced. The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, is still expected to join them. Presumably, he'll walk rather than drive.

Reverb and minor chords are beautiful things for Warpaint, a four-woman band from Los Angeles. The reverb makes the guitars weightless yet enveloping, and when the women use them for high, intertwining, arpeggiated lines, they hint at the gleam of Congolese pop. The minor keys keep the songs pensive and serious. And the songs unfold with architectural clarity, advancing from ethereal to earthy.

The authors of a just-published book are ready for their moment in the spotlight - a book signing on Sunday. They are so ready that, as they talk about how they plunged into the research and organized the material and labored over the writing, it becomes clear that they could hold their own on the C-Span 2 marathon "Book TV."

"I feel like I'm really starting to learn something now," says Rachel Chandler, the 22-year-old New York-based photographer and D.J., of the few months since her recent college graduation. Chandler is developing into a latter-day Kiki de Montparnasse, spending much of her time gallivanting with an international art crowd, all the while making them dance and chronicling their capers in high-demand photos that are regularly featured in Purple Magazine and on Italian Vogue's Web site. "I know how to work a party," she says. Chandler's personal style is as eclectic as the tunes she spins: a Ralph Lauren cable knit sweater that once belonged to her mother, a men's Dries Van Noten overcoat stolen from an ex, Adidas track pants, her signature blue Belgian loafers. "Well, of course I love Rei, Junya and Yohji," she says, "but without my parents footing the bill anymore, I have to be resourceful."

The author who gave us "The Giving Tree" still has a little more left to give: a new volume of poetry and illustrations by Shel Silverstein, the writer and artist of "Where the Sidewalk Ends," "A Light in the Attic" and "Falling Up," will be published by HarperCollins Children's Books in fall 2011, Publishers Weekly reported. Antonia Markiet, a senior executive editor at the imprint, said the new book "will contain between 120 and 130 poems" by Mr. Silverstein,  none of which have been previously published. Ms. Markiet is among the editors who began working with Mr. Silverstein, who died in 1999, in the 1970s (when he was still better known as a writer of songs like "A Boy Named Sue" and an illustrator of Playboy cartoons that would never find their way into a children's anthology), and previously edited the author's posthumously published 2005 children's book "Runny Babbit." She told Publishers Weekly that Mr. Silverstein had left "a wealth of material in the archives," adding, "So many fans still write to us and to Shel's family saying how important his work is to them, that the family decided it was the right time to consider another book from that material."

If you've ever been frustrated by an 11th-hour substitution at the Metropolitan Opera in which a star performer is suddenly replaced by one of seemingly lesser caliber, it may be harder to complain about this particular late change to the lineup: on Friday the Met said Angela Gheorghiu would sing the role of Mimi in Saturday afternoon's performance of "La Bohème. She is stepping in for Anna Netrebko, who is ill, the Met said. Ms. Gheorghiu, the Romanian soprano, withdrew from the Met's Richard Eyre-directed production of "Carmen" amid marital problems with her husband, the tenor Roberto Alagna, who starred in that opera; she said last month in a statement that she wanted "to be as prepared dramatically as I am musically" for the production. But there is evidently no bad blood between her and the Met; Ms. Gheorghiu is currently rehearsing for its coming production of "La Traviata," which opens on March 29, and will sing the role of Juliette in Gounod's "Roméo et Juliette" for the Met's 2010-11 season.

AUSTIN, Tex. -- On Thursday we had a little work to send back to the real world, but the music came and found us. Typing on the patio of the San Jose Hotel, a mile or more away from the heart of SXSW, we heard what sounded like a noisy, well-sung fairy tale spilling over the wall at about 2 p.m. An investigation turned up a minifestival in the parking lot, where Morning Teleportation was playing.

Fresh from her prison stint in the video for "Telephone," Lady Gaga could soon be headed to court -- not to face any number of angry grindhouse filmmakers whose works inspired that video, but a lawsuit from a songwriter and producer who says he's the one who gave her that famous stage name. The Associated Press reported that Rob Fusari, who helped write Lady Gaga songs including "Paparazzi" and "Beautiful, Dirty, Rich," filed a $30.5 million lawsuit against the singer, saying she has frozen him out of her career as she has become more successful. Mr. Fusari, who has also worked on hit songs like Will Smith's "Wild, Wild West" and Destiny's Child's "Bootylicious," said in his suit that he was first introduced to the singer Stefani Germanotta in 2006, helping to guide her from a rock musician to a dance artist and nicknaming her Lady Gaga, from the Queen song "Radio Ga Ga." He said he had received more than $600,000 from Lady Gaga but had not received his full share of song royalties, merchandising revenue and other fees. Representatives for Lady Gaga have not yet responded to the suit, which was filed in a  state court in Manhattan.

AUSTIN, Tex. -- "Should we just keep playing until the cops come?" John Dwyer, the floppy-haired frontman of Thee Oh Sees, said about halfway into the group's set atop the Lamar Boulevard Pedestrian Bridge. It was after 3 a.m., and the crowd fist-pumped its assent, so Mr. Dwyer bent over his guitar, the lights of downtown flickering behind him, Lady Bird Lake below.

Guys, we've got your playbook. All this time, we've been operating under the mistaken assumption that you were choosing to get all belligerent every time our college boyfriend called, or to tune us out as your eyes became glued to the waitress's breasts showcased in a T-shirt two sizes too small. It stood to reason, we thought, that you could simply choose otherwise, provided, of course, that you wanted to. Now, however, thanks to Louann Brizendine, M.D., author of "The Male Brain" (Broadway Books), we understand that choosing otherwise isn't an option, because evolution has outfitted you with a brain that is, biologically speaking, not the same model as the one we were issued. (Brizendine's "Female Brain" was published in 2006, should you ever get the urge to consult it.)

By then the $4.1 million allocated in the innovative state program may be exhausted, but more cash is probably on the way.

A Plan for the University of California to Handle Prison Medicine | The University of California would benefit by taking charge of an overhaul of the state's prison medical system and creating a centralized system of managed care, according to a report by NuPhysicia, a Texas consultant hired by the state. An estimated $12 billion could be saved over the next decade with the plan, which includes allowing doctors to have access to patient information anywhere and also to see patients via video, state officials said. "This is definitely a wholesale reform of the prison health-care system," said Susan Kennedy, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger's chief of staff. [The Los Angeles Times]

To make the finest suit in the world, you first need the finest wool. Hence Ermenegildo Zegna's Vellus Aureum award, an annual contest organized by the storied Italian suit-making family to find the highest-quality merino wool on the planet. (Vellus Aureum means ''Golden Fleece'' in Latin; the prize-winning wool grower receives its fleece's equivalent weight in gold.) Now celebrating its 100-year anniversary, Zegna has woven together samples of the competition's top fleeces since 2002 to create one of the lightest fabrics ever worn: the lot's fibers measure 11.1 microns on average, while a human hair averages a whopping 100 microns. Obviously limited by supply (only about 200 feet of cloth is produced) to an edition of 20 and retailing at $22,500, each made-to-order Centennial Vellus Aureum suit takes 18-plus hours to create and passes through more than 330 pairs of hands. ''Is this the ultimate in men's-wear luxury?'' Anna Zegna, the image director of the brand, asks rhetorically. ''Oh, we certainly think so.'' More...

All you Franco-cinephiles relax. It's not too late to catch one of the films in Rendez-Vous with French Cinema — the annual festival in its 15th year ends this weekend. "In a Gallic cinema renowned for its appreciation of women," writes Stephen Holden, "this year it is the men's turn in the spotlight." On Friday you can see one of the best, Vincent Lindon, in "Mlle. Chambon." In the film, "Mr. Lindon's character is a happily married mason who fights his attraction to his son's refined, violin-playing teacher (a fluttery Sandrine Kiberlain) whom he meets when he fixes a window in her home. This mild-mannered class study suggests a discreetly buttoned up 'Lady Chatterley's Lover.' "

STEINBERG--Lawrence R.,67, died March 16, 2010, of a heart attack. A member of IATSE Local 52, Larry was a grip for 30 years. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother and uncle, he was a fine musician, a great cook and gardener. Larry graduated HS of Music and Art (1960) and Queens College (1964). He is survived by his wife, Miriam, his sons and step-sons, his grandchildren, his brothers, and his father. His sudden death saddens us all. Visitation at Jarema Funeral Home, 129 East 7th Street, New York, NY on Friday, March 19, 2-9pm with a service at 7:30pm.

BROPHY--Ira N.,88, died peacefully on March 17, 2010, surrounded by his wife of 64 years, Betty (Cohen); his daughters Susan, Melissa, and Nancy; his sons-in-law Jesse Spilka and Matthew Cooper, and his grandchildren Molly and Sam. Ira lived a rich, full life that included work, family, travel, photography, good food, music, politics, and public service. A graduate of Queens College and WWII veteran, Ira spent his early years as a marketing/sales executive before transitioning to a career in public service in 1971. His efforts for the NYC Office of Economic Development and Public Development Corporation to assist the printing industry and small businesses and develop a manufacturing center at the Brooklyn Army Terminal gave shape to the idealism that fueled his lifelong dedication to progressive politics. He also served as Congressman Jerrold Nadler's Campaign Treasurer; was the 1976 Democratic candidate for the NYS Senate in Nassau County's 8th District; and served as Board President of the South Shore Child Guidance Ctr in Freeport, NY. Funeral on March 21, at 10am, at Boulevard Riverside Chapel in Hewlett, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be directed to the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee; Museum of Jewish Heritage in NYC; or South Shore Child Guidance.

HAHN--Lorraine, born July 18, 1918 in Chicago, wife of John George Hahn, daughter of Patrick and Kathryn Ganey, passed away on March 16th, 2010. A graduate of Northwestern University and former president of La Charite, she is survived by her loving children, Susan Schwarz and John Patrick Hahn.

WARREN--William. We were so proud to be your friend. We look back fondly on so many years of laughter, family events, travel, adventure and fun that we shared with you. You were part of our respective families, there with us in good times and in bad. Our heartfelt condolences to your beloved Bobbi and your children, stepchildren and grandchildren. Our memories will never die. Nina and Alfred Mattikow Gilda Zalaznick

HOENLEIN--Erna. The Board of the American Friends of the Open University of Israel expresses its heartfelt condolences to our dear friend and supporter Malcolm Hoenlein and the members of the Hoenlein family on the loss of an Em b'Yisrael. Erna Hoenlein, Zionist pioneer, fled Nazi Germany on the eve of the Holocaust. She became a loved and respected educator in America. The neshamah of this tzadeket has ascended. May the family find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Ingeborg Rennert, President Robert de Rothschild, Honorary Chairman Malcolm Thomson, Chairman

Spokane, Wash., will feature a matchup of scorers when MARYLAND's Greivis Vasquez (19.5) faces Aubrey Coleman of HOUSTON (25.6, best in the nation).

CHARLOP--Megan, MPH. The President, Board of Trustees and entire Montefiore family are deeply saddened by the untimely passing of our great friend and colleague, Megan Charlop, MPH. Megan who was Director of Community Health in the School Health Program and a former director of the Lead Poisoning Prevention Program, was a long-time Montefiore employee and a strong public health champion for the families of the Bronx. Megan's work for Montefiore and the community has touched thousands of people. She was a tireless advocate to improve the environments within which children lived, learned and played. She inspired everyone around her with her passion, her energy and her ideas. Our heartfelt condolences go out to her husband, Richard Powers, their children and her entire family. Steven M. Safyer, MD President and CEO David A. Tanner, Chairman Board of Trustees Montefiore Medical Center

ROSENTHAL--Albert J.,91, of Scarsdale, on March 17, 2010. Beloved and devoted husband of Barbara; father of Ned (Susan Fabrick), Tom (Felicia Kang), and Bill (Mary Cappelli); and grandfather of ten. Professor and Dean Emeritus at Columbia Law School. Service Sunday, 11:15am at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions to the Alzheimer's Association.

ROSENTHAL--Al. The Columbia Law School community mourns the death of Al Rosenthal, Maurice T. Moore Professor Emeritus of Law, and Dean Emeritus. Al was a beloved teacher and friend, and served brilliantly as dean from 1979 to 1984. He left an indelible mark on our intellectual community, both as a distinguished scholar and as a compassionate and kind man. He will be sorely missed. We extend heartfelt sympathies to his loving wife, Barbara, to his three sons, Bill, Ned, and Tom, and to his adoring grandchildren.
REIFF--Ellie. My beloved pal of 63 years. How I will miss your sharp wit, intelligence and our love-hate relationship with the New York Times. I cherish the memories. Lillian Libertoff

LAPITSKY--Gary S.,of NYC died peacefully on March 15, 2010. Cherished son of Rita and John. Loving brother of John, Peter and Victoria. Dear brother-in-law, uncle and great-uncle. Beloved cousin and devoted and thoughtful friend. We will miss his kindness, wit and warm and generous heart. Heaven welcomes its newest star. Private cremation. Memorial service to be announced.

FEIN--Harry N.,on March 17, 2010. Former Recording Engineer with CBS Records and Sony Entertainment. Beloved husband of Rita (Ricky), also survived by loving nieces, nephews, family and friends. Services Sunday, 9:30am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

GRANNUM--Monica. Our beloved mother passed away on March 13, 2010 after a seven year battle with cancer at the young age of 68. She is survived by her three children: Sandra, Clive and Gairy Grannum and her four grandchildren: Robert (Christian) and Monique Paul and Madison and Hunter Grannum. A wake will be held for our mother on Friday March 19, 2010 from 4-8pm at J. Foster Phillips Funeral Home in Jamaica, NY. Our mother's funeral service will be held on 10am Saturday, March 20, 2010 at Sacred Heart Church in Cambria Heights, NY.

McKENZIE--Arthur, 93, March 17, 2010 of New York, NY. Survived by devoted wife of 42 years, Evelyn; children, Craig, Leslie and Douglas; stepchildren Nina Wintringham, Karen Wintringham, Drew Wintringham and Jill Wintringham Kennedy; 15 grandchildren and 12 great-grandchildren. Arthur was a major force in the oil tanker industry during his 60 years both on the sea and in management positions championing safety and environmental responsibility. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Seamans Church Institute in New York City. Friends may call Friday, March 19, 2-5pm and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, New York with a service at Frank E. Campbell, Saturday, March 20 at 11:30am.

DONOHUE--Connor. The staff and board of Single Stop USA mourn the passing of our beloved colleague and friend, Connor Donohue. A dedicated member of our team, Connor was wholly devoted to Single Stop's mission of eliminating poverty. His kindness, curiosity, and generosity of spirit inspired his co-workers and captivated those in the community with whom he worked. Connor's deep intelligence and his passion for helping students and families in need made him a great colleague to many. He will be missed by all. Elisabeth Mason, CEO, Single Stop USA
HOLTON--Dr. Samuel M.,87, of Chapel Hill, NC died on March 17, 2010. He was a professor of Education at UNC Chapel Hill. For full obituary see www.hallwynne.com

WILENTZ--Warren. The Board of Directors and the Officers of Hess Corporation express deep sorrow over the passing of our dear friend and trusted adviser Warren Wilentz. His brilliant legal mind and extraordinary advice were invaluable in guiding our company over the years. We will miss him dearly and send our deepest condolences to his wife Rhoda, Wayne Wilentz and Stephen Baime.
GEORGEOU--Elias (Lee). Kind of heart and deeds, talented and dear friend. Estelle Cohen

WILENTZ--Warren. Beloved son of the late Lena and David Wilentz. Adored brother of Norma Hess and the late Robert Wilentz. Devoted husband to Rhoda and father to the late Gay Wilentz, son Wayne Wilentz and stepsons Stephen Baime and the late Mark Baime. The family of Norma Hess mourns the passing of Warren. He had a tremendous joy for life and love for people. We will forever remember his sense of humor and the twinkle in his eye. Most of all, we will always cherish the memory of Warren at our family celebrations and his unparalleled singing renditions of "Yea Boo" and "Heart of My Hearts." Our deepest heartfelt sympathy and love go to his beautiful wife Rhoda; to Wayne, his wife Lisa and daughter Dana; to Stephen and his daughter Samantha; and to Mark's sons Jacob, Ilan and Isaac. Norma W. Hess Constance and Dr. Sankey Williams; Elizabeth Williams; Jennifer, Thomas and Lilly Weymouth Marlene Hess and James Zirin; Peter Hess Friedland; Margaret, Michael and Gus Chi John, Susan, Michael, David and William Hess
FUDIM--Murray. 3/19/07. I still do remember the twinkle in your eyes and feel your zest for life. I will honor and cherish all the memories we shared. Love, Marilyn

JAFFE--David, M.D. The patients of Dr. Jaffe wish to express their deep sorrow at the loss of a great man who inspired and guided us with his humanity, understanding, keen intellect, love of life, and devotion to his work, seeing patients until the end. We can never thank you enough for all that you have given, and you will live on in each of us.

TSIGRIKES--Mary, 87, on March 18th. Beloved wife of late Gus, devoted mother of Peter, George (Jude), Paul, and Helene Tsigrikes Bapis (late George), and grandmother of Maria and Michaela. Her selfless concern and devotion to others will be greatly missed. Visiting Friday 5-8pm at Westchester Funeral Home, 190 Main Street, Eastchester, NY. Cutting down the nets may be troublesome for Murray State, whose guard B. J. Jenkins gashed his hand with scissors after his team won the Ohio Valley Conference tournament. But the Racers showed they could execute a postgame dogpile to perfection Thursday, after Danero Thomas's fadeaway 15-footer at the buzzer lifted 13th-seeded Murray State to a 66-65 victory over fourth-seeded Vanderbilt in a first-round game in the West Region in San Jose, Calif.

8 P.M. (ABC) THIN ICE Sure, they can skate to form at the Olympics. But can they actually entertain us? That's the premise of this two-part competition in which professional figure skaters perform live from the MGM Grand at Foxwoods in Connecticut for prizes that total $220,000. Ten competitors from the women's, men's, pairs and dance disciplines will compete as couples, with judging split 50/50 between viewers, who can vote at abc.com, and a panel that includes Katarina Witt, Kristi Yamaguchi and Dick Button. The five couples are Shae-Lynn Bourne and John Zimmerman; Marie-France Dubreuil and Michael Weiss; Jamie Salé and Patrice Lauzon; Elena Berezhnaya and David Pelletier; and Shizuka Arakawa, above, and Stephane Lambiel. Programs will be limited to two minutes, with the winners sharing $60,000. Elisabeth Hasselbeck and Kurt Browning host. The competition concludes Sunday at 7. NOON (CBS) N.C.A.A. BASKETBALL CHAMPIONSHIP Live coverage of the first round of the men's Division 1 championship is broadcast from noon to 5 p.m. and from 7 p.m. to midnight. In the South Region, top-seeded Duke faces No. 16, Arkansas-Pine Bluff, in Jacksonville, Fla., at 7. Syracuse, the West Region's top seed, goes up against No. 16, Vermont, in Buffalo at 9.

HOUSTON -- When Tom Penders was approached to become the University of Houston men's basketball coach six years ago, he bolted to the nearest elevator. The athletic director emphatically told him that the Cougars' once mighty powerhouse, which was nicknamed Phi Slama Jama in the early 1980s because of the dunking of Hakeem Olajuwon, Larry Micheaux and Clyde Drexler, did not have the facilities or the money to be competitive in Conference USA. Nonetheless, he wanted to know whether Penders would be interested in the job.

Boycott Raises Concerns | Since January, more than 100 cases originally assigned to Judge Andrea Bryan have been transferred to other judges in the San Jose courthouse at the request of the district attorney's office. A California law, mirrored in 18 states, gives parties to a case a one-time right to insist that a judge recuse herself. The legal term is "peremptory challenge." Colloquially, it is called "papering." But the challenges have stirred up judges in all corners of this courthouse, where personal histories and professional relationships have been intertwined for decades.

AUSTIN, Tex. --Eating at South by Southwest requires major multitasking: you're on the run from show to show, scanning text messages, e-mail and Web sites for surprise guests and info on line lengths as you go, dodging bikini-ed Hula-hooping girls and stepping over street singers, trying not to bump into anyone else doing the same. If you're starving, you grab a snack from a pizza or barbecue truck and hope it gets in your mouth and not all over your clothes. All of which may account for the popularity of dinner-hour movie screenings at the Alamo Drafthouse at the Ritz on Sixth Street, where discreet waiters, whispering and ducking down so as not to interfere with movie-watching pleasure, bring you beer and fat Texas burgers (some regulars recommend a side of fried pickles), which you eat from a wooden shelf in front of your comfortable seat. If you're really serious about getting the most out of your badge or wristband, it may be the only sit-down meal you get all week.

In his fourteenth season in the N.B.A., Steve Nash of the Phoenix Suns entered the weekend tied for the league lead in assists at 11.2 a game, his highest total since the 2006-7 season. Nash did not become a starter until his third season and did not make his first All-Star team until he was 27, but he had piled up 8,255 assists, good for eighth on the career list. If he is able to keep playing at close to his current rate for three more seasons, he has a chance to become the fifth player to record 10,000 assists.

MERRILL--Marion. The Richard Tucker Music Foundation and the Tucker family mourn the loss of Marion Merrill, devoted friend and widow of the great Robert Merrill. Our deepest condolences to the Merrill family. We will miss her. Barry Tucker, President

KENNER--Peter I. March 18, 2010. Beloved husband of Barbara. Adoring father of Nicholas and Kate. Devoted nephew of Clara Halperin. He was a renowned professional photographer, past president and owner of Kenner Printing and Managing Partner of Tivoli Partners. Dedicated member of the Bard College and Hudson Valley Community. His outgoing and charming personality will be deeply missed by family, friends and fellow dog lovers of Central Park. Memorial service Monday, March 22, 5pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Peter's memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center for Pancreatic Endocrine Research, attention: Dr. Saltz, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10065.

DONOHUE--Connor. The staff and board of Single Stop USA mourn the passing of our beloved colleague and friend, Connor Donohue. A dedicated member of our team, Connor was wholly devoted to Single Stop's mission of eliminating poverty. His kindness, curiosity, and generosity of spirit inspired his co-workers and captivated those in the community with whom he worked. Connor's deep intelligence and his passion for helping students and families in need made him a great colleague to many. He will be missed by all. Elisabeth Mason, CEO, Single Stop USA

THOMAS Brooks B. A Memorial Service for Brooks Thomas, who died on February 5 due to injuries from a fall, will be held at 3pm, Saturday, March 20 at St. Bartholomew's Church, 325 Park Ave. at 51st St. A reception will follow the service.

SILVERMAN--Helen, on March 18, 2010. Beloved wife of the late Nathan. Loving mother of Alice and Fredric. Cherished grandmother of Geoffrey, Jonathan, and Benjamin. Great-grandmother of of Nathaniel and Ryan.

REIFF--Ellie (nee Eleanor Kahn), 86, died March 18. Predeceased by her husband Walter; survived by her son Andrew and his life partner Donna, her sister Edith, and a large extended family of friends and relatives who will sorely miss her warmth, wit, and zest for life.

SCHAFFER--Monroe. Dearest husband of Gladys (nee Anderson) of 68 years. Beloved son of the late Samuel and Fanny, and Max and Sadie Anderson, adored brother of the late Stanley J. and Horace. Founder of S. Schaffer Wholesale Grocery Corporation 1936. Father of Barbara and Steven Frankel, Roberta and Richard Brudner, Gail and the late Charles Heller. Cherished grandfather of Lauren, Adam Shack, Jonathan and Kari Brudner, Matthew Brudner, Zoe, Alixandra, Ross Heller and many Frankel kin. Great-grandfather of ten great-grandchildren, unbelievable uncle and dear friend to cousins and all his family circle. A major contributor to United Way, Past President of Ridgeway Country Club, leader of ADL and AIPAC and other organizations too numerous to mention. The reconciliation package unveiled by Democrats would impose $28 billion in fees on the makers of brand-name drugs over 10 years, $5 billion more than the companies had agreed to in the Senate package. But the nation's drug makers are happy with the health care package over all, and for good reason: the government also would spend an estimated $37.6 billion over 10 years filling a Medicare drug coverage gap known as the doughnut hole.

BROPHY--Ira N.,88, died peacefully on March 17, 2010, surrounded by his wife of 64 years, Betty (Cohen); his daughters Susan, Melissa, and Nancy; his sons-in-law Jesse Spilka and Matthew Cooper, and his grandchildren Molly and Sam. Ira lived a rich, full life that included work, family, travel, photography, good food, music, politics, and public service. A graduate of Queens College and WWII veteran, Ira spent his early years as a marketing/sales executive before transitioning to a career in public service in 1971. His efforts for the NYC Office of Economic Development and Public Development Corporation to assist the printing industry and small businesses and develop a manufacturing center at the Brooklyn Army Terminal gave shape to the idealism that fueled his lifelong dedication to progressive politics. He also served as Congressman Jerrold Nadler's Campaign Treasurer; was the 1976 Democratic candidate for the NYS Senate in Nassau County's 8th District; and served as Board President of the South Shore Child Guidance Ctr in Freeport, NY. Funeral on March 21, at 10am, at Boulevard Riverside Chapel in Hewlett, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be directed to the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee; Museum of Jewish Heritage in NYC; or South Shore Child Guidance.

CAIGAN--Linda, was born in Albany, NY in 1933 to Kate and Joe Mandelbaum. Cohen, and by her nephews Jay and Lee Buck. Her husband, Robert A. Caigan, died in 1978, and her sister, Joan Buck, died in 1966. Linda earned her BA from Cornell and her MSW from Columbia. She was a social worker at WJCC and Phoenix in the 60s. In the early 70s she co-founded and worked at the Hallen School for children with learning disabilities. In the 80s, as head of Family Life Education for WJCS, she lead workshops and groups. For the past 15 years she was practicing as a mental imagery therapist and helped to develop the alternative care programs at White Plains Hospital. GORDON--Irving S. 81, died peacefully at home after a valiant 17 year struggle with Lymphoma then Myelodysplasia. An early leader in the development of dry cargo grain shipment, he was widely respected in the international shipping world for the duration of his 50 year career. He was always involved in Zionist then Israeli affairs, was an amateur biblical archaeologist and Egyptologist, and an award-winning master craftsman. Ever a man of extraordinary generosity of spirit and great personal strength, he is survived by his loving wife, of 61 years, Adina, his children Mark and Miriam, his grandchildren Josh, Jena, Adam, and David, his daughter-in-law Nancy, son-in-law Bruce (Medoff), grand daughter-in-law Laura and many loving nieces, nephews, and other cherished relatives. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Lymphoma Research Foundation and the Gordon-Gindi Fund at the JCC, Tenafly, NJ. At a rally on Friday at George Mason University in Fairfax, Va., President Obama got some of his loudest applause when he talked about a provision in the House reconciliation bill that would allow adult children to remain on their parents' health insurance policies until the age of 27. The provision cited by the president is one of the more significant changes for consumers in the Democrats' health care legislation. Currently, states determine the maximum age until which policies must offer dependent coverage, and the limits vary.

GRAHAMSTOWN, South Africa --Performance wasn't the focus of Evidence Dance Company's recent State Department-sponsored trip to Africa, even though the company performed on several occasions in Senegal. Rather, the focus - both in Senegal, its first stop, and in South Africa - has been on workshops, classes and discussions, in an attempt to reach people on a one-to-one level. In Dakar, the company gave one free performance, attended by around 1,000 people. In Grahamstown there was also just one show: at the pristine Guy Butler Theater at Settler's Monument, high on a hill on the Rhodes University campus.

Eleven games on Saturday, and although most were important, none was more incredible than the one involving the continuing saga of the Phoenix Coyotes, who staged a second straight third-peroid fightback and shootout win -- this time against the West-leading Blackhawks. That result left Phoenix within a scant 2 points of the conference lead, with another head-to-head coming up Tuesday in Chicago after a game in Dallas on Sunday. And all this with prospects dimming of the Coyotes being taken off the league's hands -- and their maybe even moving to Canada after all.

The remarkable run of the Phoenix Coyotes, who entered the season under bankruptcy protection and are now operated by the league, continued last week. Going into Saturday night's home date against Chicago, the Coyotes had won seven in a row and were within striking distance of first place in the Western Conference.
Much credit for the Phoenix Coyotes' amazing on-ice performance must go to General Manager Don Maloney, who was the Rangers' assistant G.M. from 1996 to 2007.

Rumor has it that during World War II, a Frenchwoman who was married to a member of the Resistance was also the daytime companion of a Nazi SS officer. On a cold winter's night in Paris, she was meant to meet her husband at midnight on the Pont Marie, a bridge connecting Île St.-Louis to the Right Bank. He never showed up and the woman supposedly froze to death. Now her ghost is said to haunt the bridge, eternally waiting for her husband to arrive. This is one of the stories that tourists and locals can discover on the Mysteries of Paris ghost tours (33-1-97-72-18-210; mysteriesofparis.com), which began their regular season earlier this month.

Davey Johnson, a former Mets manager, is a senior adviser to the Washington Nationals. He returned to Manhattan last week to promote a new MSG Network series, "The Lineup: New York's All-Time Best Baseball Players."The shows will discuss the city's best major league players at each position as well as the top managers. The first of 10 weekly half-hour episodes, to be shown at 10:30 p.m. Eastern on Tuesday, will focus on catchers.Johnson, 67, led the Mets to the 1986 World Series title. His New York winning percentage is .588, putting Johnson among the city's greatest managers: Joe McCarthy (.627), Miller Huggins (.597), John McGraw and Billy Martin (.591), Leo Durocher (.558), Joe Torre (.551) and Casey Stengel (.531).
